рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреБ рдХрд╛рдХрд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рд╡рджреН рдЙрднрдпрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдердмреЗрджреЗрди рдордиреНрддреНрд░рдЬреНрдЮрдкрджрдВ рдордиреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдпрджрд╛ рдордиреНрддреНрд░рд┐рдгреЛ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ рддрддреНрддрджреНрдзрд╛рддреБрддрддреНрдкрд░рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирдВ7 рдордиреНрддреНрд░рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирдореН ред рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрдкрдХреНрд╖реЗ рддреБ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдерд╕рдорднрд╛рд╡рд╢реН рдЪ ред рдордиреНрддреНрд░рд┐рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рди рдкреНрд░рд╡реЗрд╢рдорд╛рддреНрд░рдореН рдПрд╡, рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐ рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрдВ “рдкрд╢реНрдпреЗрддреН” (рдореНрдзреН рео.реи) рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрддреНрддрд░рддреНрд░рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рджреН8 рдпрдерд╛рдпреЛрдЧреНрдпрдореН,9 рдЗрддрд░рдерд╛ рдЕрджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдп рдкреНрд░рд╡реЗрд╢рдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдЕрддреЛ рдиреИрдХрд╛рдХреА рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрдВ рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рддреН, рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐ рддреИрдГ рд╕рд╣ рдирд┐рд░реВрдкреНрдпреЗрддрд┐ ред
рд╡рд┐рдиреАрддрдГ рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдкрд╛рдгрд┐рдкрд╛рджрдЪрд╛рдкрд▓рд░рд╣рд┐рддрдГ ред рд╡реЗрдкрддреЛ рд╣реНрдпреН рдЕрдирд░реНрдердГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдкрд╛рд░реНрдерд┐рд╡рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╛рдиреН рди рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡рд╛рдпрдореН рдЙрдкрджреЗрд╢рдГ, рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣реНрдпреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд┐ рдкреГрдерд┐рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдореН рдЕрдзрд┐рдкрддреЗрд░реН рджреЗрд╢реЗрд╢реНрд╡рд░рд╕реНрдп, рди рд╣реНрдпреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛10 рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдпрдореН рдЕрд╡рд┐рдЪрд▓рд┐рддрдВ рднрд╡рддреАрддрд┐ рее рео.рез рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

It has been laid down that the protection of the people is a duty of the king; and this duty has been described in the following text: (a) тАШAs a means of livelihood, to carry arms and weapons for the Kс╣гatriya, and to trade, to rear cattle and agriculture for the Vai┼Ыya, and the serving of the twice-born for the ┼Ъ┼лdraтАЩтАФ(10.79). The king who acts up to this attains unexcelled regions; and in this manner virtue prospers among the people.

Other castes also, who may be living the life of the Eс╣гattriya, are entitled to kingship:тАФтАШWhoever happens to be the protector of the people is regarded as the king, Lord-Protector; and their duty has been ordained to consist in the good of the common people.тАЩ By тАШprotectionтАЩ here is meant the removal of troubles.

Troubles are of two kinds тАФseen and unseen. It is a case of тАШseen troubleтАЩ when the weaker man is oppressed by the stronger, who takes away by force his belongings; and it is a case of тАШunseen troubleтАЩ when the latter person suffers pain in the other world, through the sin accruing to him on account of his having transgressed the law (by taking what did not belong to himself). People very often act towards pne another in hatred, jealousy and so forth, and hence going by the wrong path, they become subject to тАШunseenтАЩ evils; and thence follows the disruption of the kingdom; since it is only the prosperity of the people that is called тАШkingdomтАЩ; so that when the people are in trouble, where would the тАШkingdomтАЩ lie?

It is for this reason that when cases are investigated and decided in strict accordance with the ordinances of scriptures, people, through fear, do not deviate from the right path; and hence they become protected against both kinds of trouble. Then again, in as much as for the king there is no other lawful moans of livelihood except the fines imposed upon criminals, and the taxes and duties, any obstacles in the proper administration and collection of those leads the kingdom into trouble.

From all this it follows that for the sake of preserving the kingdom, the investigation of cases is necessary, and it is this that is now described.

The term тАШvyavah─Бra,тАЩ тАШcase,тАЩ is the name given to that action of the plaintiff and the defendant which they have recourse to for the purpose of reclaiming their rights. Or, it may stand for the non-payment of debts and such other matters themselves, which often become the subjects of dispute and as such fit for investigation, which thus becomes the duty of the king.

The term тАШdesirous of investigatingтАЩ is to be construed with тАШshall investigate the suitsтАЩ (of the next verse) and the said тАШpoints of disputeтАЩ are referred to in detail again (in verse 4)тАФтАШOf these, the first is non-payment of debts, etc.тАЩ; the construction being that тАШhe shall investigate all these matters.тАЩ

The тАШcourtтАЩ is that place which is presided over by the officer going to be described below;тАФтАШenteringтАЩ means going into the place.

The question arising as to whether or not the king shall enter the Court, alone, unattended, the text addsтАФтАШalong with Br─Бhmaс╣Зas.тАЩ

Question.тАФтАЬWhat does the adjective тАШversed in counselтАЩ qualify? It cannot qualify the тАШcouncillorsтАЩ; as the said qualification is implied by the very name тАШcouncillor,тАЩ for one who does not know the art of counselling can never be called a тАШcouncillor.тАЩ Nor can it qualify the тАШBr─Бhmaс╣ЗasтАЩ; because since they are entrusted with the work of investigating cases, the knowledge of counsel (if prescribed) could be prescribed only for some transcendental purpose.тАЭ

To the above we offer the following reply: The qualification is of the тАШBr─Бhmaс╣ЗasтАЩ; if they were ignorant of counsel, they would arrive at random and wrong conclusions, and thereby bring trouble to the King, for instance, if a certain ordinary person were to file a suit against some one connected with the Chief Minister,тАФand the latter happens to lose the case,тАФthen, if he were not fined, or if he were not forced to pay up the fine, the administration of justice would not be impartial; and the people would come to the conclusion that the King is cither partial or too weak-minded;тАФon the other hand, if the man were fined, this would displease the Chief Minister, and that also would lead to trouble among the people. In such cases, if the investigating officers happen to be тАШversed in counsel,тАЩ then, whenever they are in any such suspense, they postpone the proceedings of the case, under some pretext, and advise the King in private, to the following effectтАФтАШYou please do something yourself, whereby the man may be made to compromise between these two parties,тАФthis party loses and that party wins the case,тАФbut the case has not been disposed of by us; the decision now rests with your Majesty.тАЩ Thereupon, the King, having come to know the facts of the case, orders the Chief Minister to the following effectтАФтАШYour man is going to lose his case,тАФbut for the present the decision has been postponed, in order that your prestige may not suffer; it is for you to do something whereby the other party may be appeased and his grievance removed.тАЩ Upon this the Minister, whose advice is accepted by all men, takes steps to stop the evil propensities of all men.

Others hold that, just as the single eye of the crow operates in both sockets, so the epithet тАШversed in counselтАЩ is applicable to both, тАШBr─Бhmaс╣ЗasтАЩ and тАШcouncillors,тАЩ but in different senses: when qualifying the тАШcouncillors,тАЩ being тАШversed in counselтАЩ connotes the knowledge of the details of the cases; and when qualifying the тАШBr─Бhmaс╣Зas,тАЩ it connotes impartiality.

The Br─Бhmaс╣Зas and the Councillors are not to enter only; but they are to help, in the best manner they can, in the тАШinvestigating of suitsтАЩ (spoken of below). If this were not meant, then their тАШenteringтАЩ could only be intended to serve some transcendental purpose. Thus the sense is that the King shall not decide cases by himself alone, but in consultation with the councillors and Br─Бhmaс╣Зas.

тАШWith a dignified demeanourтАЩ;тАФi.e., free from fickleness of speech, hand and feet. If he were fickle, there would be trouble.

The use of the term тАШp─Бrthiva,тАЩ тАШking,тАЩ implies that the teaching here addressed is meant not only for one who is Kс╣гatriya by caste, but for others also, who may happen to be owners of land and a kingdom. Because unless he dues what is here laid down his sovereignty does not become duly established.тАФ(1)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 600), which explains тАШmantraj├▒aс╕етАЩ as тАШartha┼Ы─Бstraj├▒aс╕етАЩ, тАШlearned in the Science of PolityтАЩ, and deduces the sense that the person who tries cases should act up to the principles of the Science of Polity, in so far as they are not incompatible with the Dharma┼Ы─Бstra, the Ethical Science.

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 18), to the effect that having entered the court, the king shall carry on the work, in association with learned men and with councillors;тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (page 2) in Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 1b):тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (3a), which has. the following notesтАФтАШVyavah─Бr─БnтАЩ, points of dispute between the plaintiff and the defendant,тАФтАШdidс╣Ыkс╣гuс╕етАЩ, with a view to determine,тАФтАШpс╣Ыthiv─лpatiс╕е,тАЩ includes non-Kс╣гatriyas also,тАФтАШmantraj├▒aiс╕етАЩ, persons conversant with the method of doing business in due accordance with the exigencies of time and place,тАФthis qualifies тАШbr─Бhmaс╣Зaiс╕етАЩ, ignorant Br─Бhmaс╣Зas being prone to give hasty advice and thereby create trouble,тАФтАШmantribhiс╕етАЩ stands for experienced councillors;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 4a).

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.7, 9-13).тАФтАШVyavah─Бra i s that which, by discriminating the good from the evil, ministers to the virtues of both the people and the king, and furthers their interests. The king should attentively look after law-suits, freeing himself from anger and greed, according to the dictates of the legal scriptures,тАФin the company of the Judge, the Minister, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and the Priest. He should never singly try cases of two parties, or hear their statement. Neither the wise king nor the Councillors are to hold a trial in secret.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.85).тАФтАШThe King should enter the court modestly, together with the Br─Бhmaс╣Зas and the Ministers versed in state-craft,тАФwith the object of investigating cases.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б-Vyavah─Бra).тАФтАШThe King shall be accompanied by those permanent members who are experienced, having hereditary connections, the best of the twice-born, expert in the sacred law and in the science of polity.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyaс╣Зa (Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava–Vyavah─Бra, p. 17).тАФтАШThat place is called Dharm─Бdhikaraс╣Зa, Court, where the truth regarding suits is investigated in pursuance of the legal scriptures.тАФThe king shall enter the court after having finished all his daily duties, and after having duly honoured, with flowers and ornaments, his preceptor, astrologers, physicians, deities, Br─Бhmaс╣Зas and Priests.тАЩ

Do. (V─лramitrodaya-Vyavah─Бra, p. 14).тАФтАШIf the King looks into lawsuits, with the assistance of the Judge, the Minister, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and the Priest, he attains heaven.тАЩ

Do. (Vyavah─Бratattva, p. 2).тАФтАШAccompanied by the Judge, the Minister, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and Priest, the King himself shall determine their victory or defeat.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (1.4-5).тАФтАШThe king, his chosen representative Judge, other Judges, the Law, the Accountant and the Scribe, Gold, Fire, Water, and the Bailiff are the ten components of the Court; in which the King examines causes with due attention.тАЩ

Do. (1.20 et. seq.).тАФтАШLet the King try causes, attended by these Judges, after having entered the Court, in a sitting or standing posture. Having risen early in the morning and performed ablutions according to rule, and having honoured the elders, astrologers, physicians, deities, Br─Бhmaс╣Зas and domestic priests.тАЩ

рдЕрддрд╢реН рдЪ рдпрддреН рдХреИрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреН рдкрд╢реНрдпреЗрджреН рдЗрддрд┐ рдкрд░рд┐рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрд╡рдореН рдЖрд░реЛрдкреНрдп рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░ рдЖрд╢рдЩреНрдХрд┐рддрдГ рдкреБрдирд╢реН рдЪ рдХреНрд▓реЗрд╢реЗрди рд╕рдорд░реНрдерд┐рддрдГ, рддрджреН рдЕрдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН, рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрднреЗрджрд╛рджреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рднреЗрджрд╛рддреН ред рд╕реНрд╡рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпреЛ рд╣рд┐ рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮреЛ рджрдгреНрдбрд╛рд╡рдзрд┐рдХрдГ, рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрд╛рд╡рдзрд┐рдГ ред рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░реЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рднрд┐рдиреНрдирдГ ред рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮреЛ рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдпрд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд┐рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирдореН, рдЗрддрд░реЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рд╕рдВрд╕рдпрдЪреНрдЫреЗрджрд╛рджреЗрд░реН рдЕрдкрд░реЛрдкрдХрд╛рд░рдХрддреНрд╡рдореН ред рдЕрддреЛ рдиреЛ рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рд╕рдВрдХрд░рд╛рд╢рдЩреНрдХреИрд╡37 рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ ред рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпреЛ рд╡рд┐рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрддреНрддрд┐рдирд┐рд░рд╛рд╕рдГ ред рдЕрд░реНрдерд┐рдирд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрдиреНрдирдпреЛрд░реН рд╣рд┐ рд╕рд╛рдореНрдпрдВ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рджрд░реНрд╢рдиреЗ рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрд╛ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рдиреЛ рдЪреЗрддреН рд╕рдВрд╡рд┐рджрд╛рдиреЗ рдХреЛ рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдзрд┐рдЧрдореЗ рдирд┐рд░реЛрдзрдГ ред рдХрд╛рдпрдХрд╢реБрджреНрдзреМ рд╣рд┐ рд╢реНрд╡рд╛рдирд┐рд░реЛрдзрд╡рд╛рдиреН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрд╛рдордГ 38 рее рео.реи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШSealedтАЩтАФsitting on the judgment-seat.

тАШStandingтАЩтАФnot moving, nor seated.

тАШSittingтАЩ and тАШstandingтАЩ constitute the only two possible alternatives, to be adopted in accordance with the gravity of the business. If the suit is an important one, and there is much to be said (by the parties), he shall he seated; whereas if the suit is a light one, and there is not much to be said, he shall remain standing. in either case, moving about is absolutely precluded. While moving, his attention would be fixed upon the path he is treading, so that he could not rightly grasp what is being said by the two parties.

Others have explained that the rule here laid down is with a view to some transcendental results; and that what is meant is that when the parties consist of ascetics or Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, and these remain standing, the King also shall remain standing, but on their being seated, he also shall be sealed.

тАШRaising his handтАЩтАФi.e., holding the hand high. This (if taken literally) would militate against what the S┼лtra-k─Бras have said regarding the upper garment being always under the right arm. Hence all that the text means is that the hand shall he lifted up, and not allowed to be in contact with any other person near at hand. In fact, this is to be done only when the King is disallowing a certain question. This shows that he is alert and carefully watching the proceedings of the case. For as a rule, whenever a man is devoting great attention to any work, he holds his arms high. If, on the other hand, he sits at ease, the defeated party is likely to sayтАФтАШThe King does not pay attention to the case, hence the members of the court, not fearing him, have decided the case against us.тАЩ

тАШHandтАЩ here stands for the arm; otherwise if one were to keep the hand only lifted up throughout the proceedings, this would be extremely painful. Nor is the advice offered with a view to any transcendental purpose.

тАШSubdued in dress and ornamentsтАЩтАФWhat was meant by тАШdignified demeanourтАЩ in the preceding verse was that he should keep control over his external and internal organs in relation to their respective objects; and this was with a view to being easily accessible to even the most modest suitors. If he were too gaudy in his appearance, it would be difficult for the more modest suitors to retain their presence of mind.

It is for this reason that gaudy dress and ornaments should be avoided. тАШDressтАЩ stands for the making up of the hair and clothes; тАШornamentsтАЩ for тАШKarс╣Зik─БтАЩ (the lotus-shaped Ear-ornament) and the rest. So тАШgaudy dressingтАЩ would consist in the wearing of richly-coloured clothes and so forth. If the King is gaudily dressed and wearing brightly be-jewelled ornaments, it could be as difficult to look at him as at the sun, for ordinary people, specially for the accused (who would thus lose their presence of mind during the trial).

тАШLook into.тАЩтАФThis declares the purpose for which the King; is to enter the Court-room.

This teaching regarding the King himself тАШlooking intoтАЩ the suits is with special reference to the inflicting of punishments; and applies to the entire investigation, ending with the full setting forth of the statements of both parties. And the intention is that by doing this he would be fulfilling his duty of тАШprotectingтАЩ the people. Such тАШlooking intoтАЩ cases not being possible for other persons, no one else could be entitled to it. As for helping in the settling of doubtful points, this result of the investigation interests all persons; and as such like the rules relating to expiations, this also falls within the province of the learned Br─Бhmaс╣Зa; specially as in connection with the latter it has been declared that тАШhe shall speak out on difficult points of law.тАЩ Similarly when a case is being investigated where the parties belong to the same profession,тАФsuch for instance as traders, cultivators, cattle-breeders, etc.,тАФif other persons belonging to the same profession And that the points in dispute are such as would affect them all, then they are all entitled to take part in the investigation.

In this connection they declare as follows (N─Бrada, 1.8)тАФтАШ(a) Families, (b) Guilds, (c) Tribes, (d) Authorised person, and (e) the King constitute the very foundation of case-proceedings; and among these the following is superior to the preceding.тАЩ

Of these,

(a) the term тАШfamiliesтАЩ stands for the body of relations; the parties shall not deviate from the decision arrived at by these,

(b) If however one party should have no confidence in these, and should sayтАФтАШthese persons are more nearly related to you,тАЩтАФthen the case shall he referred to the guilds,тАФthis term тАШguildтАЩ standing for a body of trailers and others who may he following the same profession; these persons are weightier than relatives; because the latter, through fear of relations, do not always exercise a check upon the person who deviates from the right path; while the members of a guild fight shy of any matter relating to themselves going before the King, as that would lend the KingтАЩs officers ah opportunity for interfering in the work of their guild; and hence they always take from the parties concerned sufficient security against their deviating from the decision arrived at, before they proceed to investigate a dispute; the understanding with the person standing security being that if the party deviate from the decision arrived at by the guild, he shall pay a stipulated line, or he should not let him deviate from it.

(c) тАШTribesтАЩтАФconsist of persons who always move about in groups; e.g., masons, temple0priests, and so forth. They would investigate the cases of disputes arising among themselves; and for the enforcing of decisions they shall appoint committees. The difference between these two (тАШGuildsтАЩ and тАШTribesтАЩ) is that the former consists of persons following the same profession and they can act singly also, whereas Tribes always act collectively. And it is because the Tribes act collectively that the disputants are afraid of them. According to others however, the term тАШFamiliesтАЩ stands for neutrals; and such persons, even though not members of the same guild, are conversant with all the ins and outs of the case, and as such capable of coming to a decision,

(d) The term тАШauthorised personтАЩ stands for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa learned in the Vedas; it has been laid down that such Br─Бhmaс╣Зas are entitled to speak on all disputed points of law. Such a person is superior to the foregoing, because of his learning.

(e) The KingтАЩs superiority rests upon his great power. It is for this reason that when a case has been decided by the learned King, there is no occasion for what is laid down in the following wordsтАФтАШIf a party, even though legally defeated, thinks that he has not been justly defeated, he shall be fined twice the amount of the suit, and the case re-openedтАЩ (Y─Бj├▒avalkya, Vyavah─Бra, 306); this is what applies to other cases (decided by others), For in the case of these latter there may he some ground for asserting that тАШthe judges have not decided rightlyтАЩ; but when the King himself has decided it, what can he said against it?

Another explanation of the term тАШauthorised personтАЩ is that it stands for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa who has been appointed by the King to act as his substitute. Similarly the ordinary householder also would be an тАШauthorised person,тАЩ so far as his own household-affairs are concerned,тАФthis being in accordance with the declaration that тАШthe householder is master in his own house,тАЩ which means that ho is free to deal with all disputes within his own household, up to the infliction of punishment,тАФspecially with a view to proper discipline among his children and pupils; but he may deal with all cases, except the inflicting of bodily punishment, or the doing of acts conducive to depravity. What is meant is that in the case of minor offences the householder himself acts like the King, while in that of serious offences, it is necessary to report to the King.

From all this it follows that there is no basis for the doubt raised by some people regarding the right of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and others to pronounce judgments,тАФon the ground that the injunction contained in the present verse that the King тАШshall look into the suitsтАЩ precludes all other persons,тАФor, for the great trouble that they have taken to establish that right. Because the right of the several persons pertains to different kinds of cases. The KingтАЩs right exteс╣Зс╕Нs up to the infliction of punishments, while that of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and others extends only up to the pronouncing of judgments,тАФthis latter right is distinct from the former. Then again, the motive of the King in looking into cases consists in the proper administration of his kingdom, while that of the others lies only in settling doubtful points for the benefit of other people. So that there is no possibility of cross-purposes arising.

The тАШsuits of sailorsтАЩ consist in the settling of disputes. Whenever disputes arise between two persons, settlements should be brought about by the King by means of careful investigation. Otherwise if the parties come to an agreement themselves, where would he the supremacy of the King?тАФ(2)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШRaising his right armтАЩтАФSee 4.58.

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 600);тАФthe second half in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 2);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 18) in Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (p. 2a);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 52), which says that тАШseated or standingтАЩ is meant to predude lying down and walking;тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (3a), which has the following notes:тАФтАШVin─лtaтАЩ is calm and dignifiedтАЩтАФтАШp─Бс╣ЗimudyamyaтАЩ, taking the hand out of the upper wrapper, i.e., having gathered together his clothes,тАФтАШpa┼ЫyetтАЩ determine, decide,тАФтАШk─Бry─Бс╣Зi,тАЩ non-payment of debt and so forth;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 40).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

[He shall look into the suits]тАФday after day, one by one,тАФfalling as they do under eighteen heads,тАФaccording to principles deduced from local usage and from the scriptures.тАФ(3)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЗрдгрд╛рд░реНрдзреЗрди рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрд╣реЗрддрд╡рдГ рдХрдереНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдЙрддреНрддрд░реЗрдг рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рджрдкрджрд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐рд░реНрджреЗрд╢рдГ ред “рдкрд╢реНрдпреЗрддреН” рдЗрддрд┐ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреБрд╖рдЬреНрдпрддреЗ, “рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдгрд┐” рдЗрддрд┐ рдЪ ред рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╣рдВ рдкрд╢реНрдпреЗрддреН рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдгрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рджрд┐рд╡рд╕рдЧрдордиреЗ39 рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрдГ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рд╣реЗрддреБрднрд┐рд░реН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд╣реЗрддреБрд░реН рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрд╕рд╛рдзрдирдореН ред рд╕ рдЪ рджреНрд╡рд┐рд╡рд┐рдзрдГ ред рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрд░реВрдкреЛ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛рд░реВрдкрд╢реН рдЪ ред рддрддреНрд░ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрд░реВрдкреЛ рд╜рд░реНрдердирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрд╣реЗрддреБрдГ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдГ ред рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛рд░реВрдкреЛ рдпрддреЛ рд╜рд╕рддреНрдпреЗ рд╡рд╛рд░реНрдердирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрдпреЗ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рдГ рд╕рдВрддрд┐рд╖реНрдарддреЗ ред рдпрдерд╛ рд╕рддреНрдпрд╢рдкрде рдЙрднрдпрд╛рдиреБрдордд рдПрдХрдГ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реА рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд┐рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд░реНрдерд┐рднреНрдпрд╛рдореН рдЕрднреНрдпреБрдкрдЧрддрдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрднрд╛рд╡рдГ рд╕рднреНрдпреИрд░реН рдЕрдкрд░реАрдХреНрд╖рд┐рддреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрд╣реЗрддреБрддрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рди рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдкрд░реАрдХреНрд╖рд┐рддрд╕реНрдп40 рдкреБрдВрд╕реЛ рд╡рдЪрдирд╛рджреН рдЕрд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЖрдкреНрддрддреНрд╡рд╡реЗрджрдиреЗ рд╜рд░реНрдердирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрдпрдГ41 ред рдкреНрд░рд╛рд╢реНрдирд┐рдХрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЕрднреНрдпреБрдкрдЧрдореЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛ рд╣реЗрддреБрд░реН рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред

рдЕрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рджрд╢рд╕реБ рдорд╛рд░реНрдЧреЗрд╖реБ ред рдорд╛рд░реНрдЧреЛ82 рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпреЛ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рджрд╕реНрдп ред рдПрддрд╛рдиреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреН рдЙрджреНрджрд┐рд╢реНрдп рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпреЗрдг рд╡рд┐рд╡рджрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдирд┐рдмрджреНрдзрд╛рдирд┐83 рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдгрд┐ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирд╛рдиреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдп рдЗрддрд┐ рдпрд╛рд╡рддреН ред рддрд╛рдиреНрдпреН рдЙрддреНрддрд░рддреНрд░ рджрд░реНрд╢рдпрд┐рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдордГ ред рдкреГрдердХреН рдкреГрдердХреН, рдкреНрд░рд╛рджрд╛рдиреНрдпрдореН рдПрддреЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЖрд╣ ред рдПрддрд╛рдирд┐ рдкреНрд░рдпреЗрдХрдВ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирд╛рдирд┐84 рди рдкреБрдирдГ рдкрд░рд╕реНрдкрд░рдореН рдЕрдиреНрддрд░реНрднрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ ред рдпрдерд╛рдиреНрдпрд╛рдиреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреБрд╖рдЩреНрдЧрд╛рджрд┐рд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреНрддрд░реНрднрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ ред рдиреИрд╡рдореН рдПрддрд╛рдирд┐85 ред рдЕрдиреБрд╖рдХреНрддрд╛рдирд┐ рддреБ рд╕рд╣рд╕реНрд░рд╢рдГ рд╕рдиреНрддрд┐ рее рео.рей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The first half of the verse describes the means of forming a decision, and the second mentions the number of the heads of dispute.

The verb тАШshall look intoтАЩ of the preceding verse has to be construed with the present verse,тАФas also the noun тАШthe suitsтАЩ; the full sentence being тАШday after day he shall look into the suitsтАЩ; i.e., every day he shall decide cases.

тАШAccording to principles.тАЩтАФтАШPrinciplesтАЩ are the means of coining to a decision; and they are of two kindsтАФ(l) in the shape of evidence and (2) in the shape of custom. The means leading to decisions that are in the shape of тАШevidenceтАЩ are in the form of witnesses and so forth; and those in the form of rules are such asтАФ(a) тАШthe investigation of a suit can be regarded as complete only when precise decision has been arrived at regarding its subject-matter.тАЩ A single witness, who is true to his oath, and who has been cited by both parties, who have also vouched for his veracity,тАФeven though he may not have been examined by the members of the court,тАФbecomes a reliable means of arriving at the right decision; but no decision can ho arrived at on the strength of the words of any such single person as is not known to be truthful and has not been examined, as there is in the former ease; and hence such a single witness cannot he regarded as helping the forming of a decision, even though the persons investigating the case may be agreed upon it.

Customs also are of two kindsтАФgeneral and special. These again are of two kindsтАФcongruous and incongruous, in reference to places and times. As an instance of the тАШCongruousтАЩ custom we have (a) the case where among certain people of the South, a childless woman, on the death of her hu┼Ыand, goes up to the pillar of the court of justice, and while there, if, on being examined by the officers of the court, she is found to be untainted and possessed of the necessary qualifications, she obtains her inheritance;тАФor (b) the case where among the people of the North, if food is given to a person seeking for a bride, then she becomes betrothed to him even though the actual words тАШI shall give her to youтАЩ may not he uttered. And as an instance of the тАШincongruousтАЩ rule, we have (a) the case where in some countries grains are lent out during the Spring, and double the quantity is realised during the Autumn,тАФor (b) when an article is mortgaged on the understanding that it shall be enjoyed by the mortgagee, even if the total amount of debt accruing become double of the price of that article, and the total from the very beginning is paid in gold, yet the enjoyment of it remains unmolested;тАФnow all this is тАШincongruous,тАЩ being incompatible with the law that тАШthe interest shall accumulate to only 80 per cent.тАЩ (Y─Бj├▒avalkya, Vyarah─Бra, 37), and that тАШthe accumulated interest shall not exceed the double of the principalтАЩ (Manu, 8.151).

These customs based upon the nature of the countries affected are what are mentioned in the text by the words тАШprinciples based upon local usageтАЩ; and as regards the тАШprinciples based upon scriptures,тАЩ these are declared in the scriptures themselves. Of these latter some are rules that have been propounded by the writers themselves, while others only codify the actually existing state of things. As an instance of the rule propounded by the writers we haveтАФ(a) тАШFacts are ascertained in accordance with written documents, possession and witnesses,тАЩтАФas says manu (8.41) тАШJust as the hunter infers the position of the prey by means of the drops of blood (so should the king infer the facts of a case).тАЩ Though no worldly usage can be regarded as authoritative as against the word of scripture-writers, yet in certain cases it becomes necessary to have recourse to the words of ordinary men of the world; e.g., тАШunder such and such conditions such and such an ordeal should be had recourse to,тАЩ тАШweight is to be attached to possession lasting for such a time.тАЩ Such rules, even though based upon ordinary usage, are included under тАШprinciples based upon scripturesтАЩ But among such rules, those are to be regarded as authoritative which are found to have some support in the scriptural texts; while those that are found to be without such support are not to be so accepted. For instance, there is the rule regarding the order of words in documentsтАФтАШBy me, entreated by both parties, who am the son of so and so, this has been written by so and soтАФthus exactly shall the scribe write downтАЩ (Y─Бj├▒avalkya, Vyavah─Бra, 88). In reality however, there would be no harm if the scribe were to write down his own name firstтАФтАШI so and so, the son of so and so, am writing this.тАЩ Because the only purpose for which he writes all this is with a view to show that the document has been written by such and such a person; so that so long as the name of the scribe is put down, there is nothing objectionable in it. If the scribe is known, from other sources, to be a trustworthy person, then what is written by him is regarded as reliable; so that if he were to omit the name of his family, and thus fail to indicate precisely who he is, whose reliability would the persons concerned investigate, on the basis of other sources of information? But if from his writing, or by some other means, the writer be recognised as a particular well-known scribe, then there would be no harm even if he were to omit his indicative characteristics. In this case, even if the scribe were to omit to write that тАШthis has been written by me, so and so,тАЩ there would be enough to indicate who the writer is. And it is in such cases that the examination of the scribe comes useful; and he becomes counted among тАШwitnesses,тАЩ specially when there are few other witnesses. When however there are many trustworthy witnesses ready at hand, there is not much use in investigating the trustworthiness of the scribe.

Similarly there is another ruleтАФтАШDocumentary evidence is rebutted by documentary evidence, and witnesses (oral evidence) by witnesses; documentary evidence is superior to witnesses; hence witnesses are rebutted by documentary evidence.тАЩ (N─Бrada, 1.145). For this rule also there is no foundation. For тАШdocumentary evidenceтАЩ is of two kinds: (1) written by the party himself, and (2) written by another person. The latter again is of two kindsтАФ(a) written by a scribe who volunteers to do the writing, and (b) written by an authorised scribe. The document written by another person again is, in every way, of the nature of a witness; so that there is no ground for the distinction made by the rule, in the words тАШdocumentary evidence is superior to witnesses,тАЩ specially because the тАШwitnessтАЩ has been thus defined (by Y─Бj├▒avalkya, Vyavah─Бra, 87)тАФтАШThe witnesses shall, with their own hands, write down their names, preceded by the names of their father, adding that I, so and so, am a witness.тАЩ Similarly, no reliability attaches to what has been written by a single man, just as it does not attach to a single witness. It might be argued that it is only when тАШwitnessesтАЩ set down their hands to something that they become тАШdocumentary evidence.тАЩ But this difference cannot make the one тАШsuperiorтАЩ to the other. Because trustworthiness is the only ground for тАШsuperiorityтАЩ; and this trustworthiness is equally yet to be examined in both cases. It is for this reason that in a case when there is a conflict between the two kinds of evidence, the judge should accept that which is the more numerous of the two. тАШBeing authorisedтАЩ also cannot be regarded as a ground of distinction; because even so, the тАШsuperiorityтАЩ could only consist in the fact that it is only one who has been tested that is тАШauthorisedтАЩ; but as a matter of fact, all persons тАШauthorisedтАЩ by the King are not necessarily thoroughly тАШtested.тАЩ If some one happened to be possessed, of extremely high qualifications and were absolutely free from all defects, then he, even alone, could be accepted as sufficient corroboration. As for instance, the deeds of land-grants bestowed by the King are accepted as authoritative, even though written by a single K─Бyastha scribe. In a case where there is documentary evidence written by the hand of the person who is not paying a debt, wherein he admits that тАШI have received so much from this person, and so much has to be paid to him,тАЩтАФif he should happen to deny it and say тАШI have not received anything from him,тАЩтАФthen the party producing the aforesaid document wins the case outright, and there is no occasion for the appearance of any witnesses at all.

тАЬIt is only on the strength of the manтАЩs writing that it is concluded that the debt is admitted by him,тАФand subsequently also the same man asserts, that he has not received anything; now between these two assertions, on what grounds is the latter rejects in favour of the former, and not the former in that or the latter,тАФboth of them being equally open to doubt, by reason of mutual contradiction? In fact under such circumstances it is only right that other kinds of evidence should he called in.тАЭ

This would be so, if there were equality (between the two assertions). As a matter of fact, however, the assertion тАШI have not received anythingтАЩ may he due to the manтАЩs avarice and such other causes; whereas the assertion тАШI have received such and such a thingтАЩ could never he made by any sane person without having actually received it. In the case in question, even if the man were to say that he has repaid the debt, but did not obtain the written acquittance receipt, either because a writer was not at hand, or because being engaged in some other business he was in a hurry,тАФeven so there would be no need and occasion for the calling of any further evidence, in the shape of witnesses, etc.

As regards the dictum quoted above (from N─Бrada), it cannot set aside a conviction derived from the very nature of things.

For instance, it is often found that people go on repaying debts due to rich persons, and yet do not have the payments noted on the back of the document, the idea in the manтАЩs mind being either that тАШso much I have paid to-day, and tomorrow I shall bring in more and then have the total sum entered at the same time,тАЩ or that тАШin a few days I shall repay the entire amount and then have the document torn offтАЩ;тАФbut when pressed by the rich creditor, he may be unable to clear off the entire debt, and the only amount paid remains what had been on the first day, the creditor would deny even that payment on the ground that the receipt was not given;тАФnow in this case if the court were to insist upon the dictum that тАШdocumentary evidence can be rebutted only by documentary evidence,тАЩтАФthen how could it take into consideration at all the possibility of force or fraud (on the part of the influential creditor)? for there is no possibility of any documentary evidence; and in this case, even though there is documentary evidence on one side, yet, for the purpose of coining to a right conclusion, other forms of evidence are called in; and the same could be done in other cases also. For instance, in a certain case, one of the parties (the debtor) might sayтАФтАШtrusting this man, I executed this deed for the entire sum, and the creditor told me that I may receive a part of the sum that day, as for certain reasons he was not in a position to pay the whole sum then, and that he would pay the balance the next day; but the sum paid on the first day was all that he gave me, and the balance was never paidтАЩ; and in this case there is certainly an occasion for the calling in of other kinds of evidence. And if the debtor can produce witnesses in corroboration of his statement, then the document (produced by the creditor) becomes impugned, and it becomes necessary for the creditor to prove that he did pay the balance the next day. If the conversation between the parties (regarding the part payment) were held in private (and there be no witnesses to corroborate the statements one way or the other),тАФthen there comes the occasion for having recourse to ordeals. If however there be no full confidence in ordeals,тАФon the ground of these being not always infallible,тАФthen decision should he arrived at by means of oaths.

тАЬIf such be the case, then the document written by the manтАЩs own hand becomes untrustworthy, since it stands in need of corroboration by other kinds of evidence. And this is contrary to the dictum that тАШeven without witnesses, what is written by the manтАЩs own hand should be conclusive evidence.тАЩ It is on the analogy of this same reasoning that in a case where a person has not seen the sum being actually paid by the creditor, but in his presence the debtor has admitted that тАШsuch and such an amount has been received by me from him,тАЩтАФsuch a person is accepted as a real тАШwitnessтАЩ; though in this ease it is open to the debtor to say тАШit was through my trust in the man that I admitted the payment.тАЩтАЭ

This argument we have already answered by saying that mere incompatibility with a Smс╣Ыti-text cannot set aside the real facts of the case. In certain cases the aforesaid statement (of the debtorтАФthat тАШI repaid a certain sum but did not have it entered on the back of the documentтАЩ) could be wholly out of place; and in such cases, the document would certainly be accepted as reliable evidence. For instance, in a case where the document has remained in the creditorтАЩs hands for a long time, the question naturally arises if the debtor really repaid the debt, why did he not seek out the document and receive it back; such a matter cannot be neglected or overlooked for such a long time; and from this it is inferred that what the debtor states is a lie.тАЩ It is in view of this that it has been laid down that тАШif there has been any wrongful force used in regard to any business, one should report it to the King either at once or within three days.тАЩ Again, in a case where there is mortgage, but the exact period of the mortgage is not definitely fixed, and dispute arises on that account, if there is a document written by the debtor, but without witnesses,тАФit is not open to the debtor to assertтАФтАШyou said this (made this condition) at the time through your love (for the thing), but now please give up to me the mortgaged articleтАЩ; nor would this be an occasion for his making the statement referred to aboveтАФviz., тАШI executed the deed, the man said he would give me the sum mentioned therein, but he never actually gave it to meтАЩ; because if the debt was not advanced, why did he permit the creditor to retain and make use of the mortgaged article?

тАЬIf such be the case, then the evidence in the case would consist of the said possession accompanied by the document; while what the writers on law declare is that possession by itself is sufficient evidence; as assorted in such texts asтАФ

тАШDocuments, witnesses, possession, etc., etc.тАЩ (Y─Бj├▒avalkya, Vyavah─Бra, 22).тАЭ

Why is this objection urged against us, when we have already answered it: What is accepted as evidence is possession for a definite period of time, and not mere possession. What the texts state isтАФтАШWhatever is retained for ten years, etc.тАЩ (manu, 8.147), and тАШOne loses possession of a landed property, if for twenty years he perceives and speaks of it as being actually possessed by another personтАЩ (Y─Бj├▒avalkya, Vyavah─Бra, 24).

тАЬWhat then is the exact meaning of the dictum that тАШdocumentary is rebutted only by documentary evidence?тАЩтАЭ

Others have explained this to mean (a) that when there is a doubt regarding the writer of a certain document, as to whether or not it has been written by a certain person, this can he ascertained only with the help of another writing obtained from that person;тАФ(b) that where the deed has been written before a certain witness, the doubt as to whether or not it has been written by the man can be removed only by means of witnesses; as the latter are the only evidence possible in the case; so that in this case there is no use in producing another writing of the man;тАФ(c) that in a case where the payment of the debt is being intentionally withheld, documentary evidence is superior to mere witnesses; because it is possible for witnesses to forget things, or to collude with one party or the other, or become tainted with some defect which would disqualify them as proper witnesses; as for the document on the other hand, this would he in charge of the plaintiff and as such perfectly safe; and thus it is that documentary evidence is superior to witnesses. This is what is meant by the dictum that тАШwitnesses are rebutted by documentary evidenceтАЩ; because even though the man may have forgotten a certain fact, if he sees some writing of his own bearing testimony to it, he is convinced of its being true; or when the witnesses are all dead, if their writing is recognised, it is accepted as evidence.

Other explanations have been supplied by Bhartс╣Ыyaj├▒a, and may be learnt from his own work.

Though it is true that in all cases Smс╣Ыti-texts form the source of authority, yet rules have to be laid down for meeting special cases; and it cannot be right to depend entirely on Smс╣Ыti-texts; specially because it cannot be said that the Smс╣Ыti-texts bearing upon legal proceedings are all based upon the Veda; because the winning or losing of cases deals with well-accomplished things (while the Veda bears upon things to be accomplished) and is amenable to Perception and other forms of cognition;тАФe.g., that тАШone who acts like this is defeated, while he who acts thus winsтАЩ is a well-accomplished fact. Even the few indications of these that are found in the Veda are to be regarded as being on the same footing as the assertionтАФтАШOne desiring freedom from disease should eat the Har─лtak─л (which only describes a perceptible fact). the exact significance of such Injunctive Vedic passages has been discussed by us in the section on the тАШPurification of thingsтАЩ (under Discourse 6, Verse 110 et seq.); hence we are not going to do the same thing over and again.

The objects of dispute fall within eighteen тАШheadsтАЩ; it is only with regard to these that disputes arise among men. Mutually nugatory acts are not conducive to the fulfilment of any useful purpose,тАФas we are going to show later on.

Each of these eighteen тАШheadsтАЩ is important by itself; as each by itself becomes the object of dispute, and no one of them is included in any other. The various ramifications of these are included under each head; if these ramifications were to be enumerated separately, there would be thousands of them.тАФ(3)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШVin─Бpi s─Бkс╣гibhiс╕е etc.тАЩтАФ(Medh─Бtithi, p. 793, l. 24)тАФThis is a clear reference to Y─Бj├▒avalkya (Vyavah─Бra, 89).

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 18), and again on p. 31, in support of the view that the king shall decide cases relating to all the eighteen points of dispute, on the basis of local customs and also of ordeals and other methods prescribed by the scriptures;тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 2a);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 57);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (3a), which has the following notes:тАФтАШDe┼Ыadс╣Ыс╣гс╣нa hetuтАЩ are those special means of coming to a decision which are effective in the place concerned,тАФof the custom obtaining among the people of the North and those of the Central land, of feeding the person who comes to ask for the hand of a girl, which feeding means a distinct promise to marry the girl,тАФтАШ┼Ы─Бstradс╣Ыс╣гс╣нa hetuтАЩ stands for witnesses and the rest;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 4a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Gautama (II. 19-24).тАФтАШHis administration of justice shall be regulated by the Veda, the institutes of the sacred law, the subsidiary sciences and the Pur─Бс╣Зa; the local laws, the customs of castes and familiesтАФwhich arc not opposed to the sacred lawsтАФhave also authority. Cultivators, traders, herdsmen, money-lenders and artisans have the authority to lay down rules for their respective classes. Having learnt the state of affairs from those who have authority to speak, the King shall give the decision. Reasoning is a means for getting at truth; coming to a conclusion through that, he shall decide properly.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (1.17).тАФтАШManu has declared that the peculiar laws of countries, castes and families may be followed in the absence of revealed texts.тАЩ

Do. (16.4-5).тАФтАШLet him reason properly regarding an offence; he who reasons properly regarding an offence, in accordance with the sum of the science of the first two castes is equitable towards all living beings.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava, p. 31).тАФтАШThe King shall decide suits according to the ┼Ъ─Бstras; where there are no texts to guide him, he shall decide in accordance with local custom.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (1.23).тАФтАШHaving entered the Court in the forenoon, together with elders, ministers, and attendants, he should try causes and listen to expositions of the Pur─Бс╣Зas, Law-codes and Rules of Polity.тАЩ

Do. (1.33).тАФтАШPeople who arc ignorant of the customs of the country, unbelievers, despisers of the sacred books, insane, irrate, avaricious or diseased should not he consulted in the decision of causes.тАЩ

Do. (27.24).тАФтАШSuch customs as are not opposed to the laws of the country and castes or other corporationsтАФthe King should establish in accordance with the sacred law.тАЩ

N─Бrada (3.5).тАФтАШThe members of the royal court of justice must be acquainted with the sacred law and with rules of precedence,тАФnoble, not avaricious and impartial towards friend and foe.тАЩ

Matsyapur─Бс╣Зa (R─Бjadharma, 215.50).тАФтАШHe shall attend upon Br─Бhmaс╣Зas versed in the Veda and the sciences.тАЩ

Agnipur─Бс╣Зa (234.7-9).тАФтАШHe shall then see the preceptor and having received his blessings, enter the Court; therein he shall see the Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, Ministers and Councillors; and then proceed to try the law-suits, holding consultations with the Councillors.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б-Vyavah─Бra).тАФтАШSuits shall be decided by the king or by the learned Br─Бhmaс╣Зa appointed as Judge.тАЩ

Of these the first is (1) Non-payment of Debt; (then) (2) Deposits, (3) Selling without ownership, (4) Joint concerns, (5) Non-delivery of what has been given away,тАФ[4]тАФ(6) Non-payment of wages, (7) Breach of Contract, (8) Recision of Sale and Purchase, (9) Dispute between the Owner and the Keeper,тАФ[5]тАФ(10) Disputes regarding Boundaries, (11) and (12) Assault, physical and verbal, (13) Theft, (14) Violence, (15) Adultery,тАФ[6]тАФ(16) Duties of man and wife, (17) Partition, and (18) Gambling and Betting;тАФthese are the eighteen topics that form the basis of law-suits.тАФ(4-7)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

(рдЕрдЧреНрд░реЗ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рдирдореНред)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 8.4-7)
**

тАШNon-payment of debtтАЩ is regarded as тАШfirst,тАЩ foremost, only by reason of the order in which the several heads are found mentioned in the law-books. Or тАШfirstтАЩ may mean тАШthe most important,тАЩтАФits тАШimportanceтАЩ lying in the fact that it affects even those who live in the forests.

Connected with the тАШnon-payment of debtтАЩ is also the subject of the тАШnon-granting of the acquittance-receiptтАЩ; when, for instance, the debtor says to the creditor тАШI have repaid your debt, now let me have the acquittance receipt.тАЩ This тАШnongranting of the acquittance-receiptтАЩ is not the same as the тАШnon-payment of debtтАЩ; but though not directly denoted by that term, it is implied by it.

What are included under the head of тАШnon-payment of debtтАЩ are thus enumerated (by N─Бrada, 3.17)тАФтАШWhat debt is payable and what non-payable,тАФwhen, how and to what extent?тАФas also the methods of delivery and receipt.тАЩ

Now тАШpayable debtтАЩ is that contracted by oneтАЩs self, that, contracted by his father, and by one whose property he inherits.

тАШNon-payable debtтАЩ is that contracted by oneтАЩs self, if (along with the interest) it exceeds the double of the principal, or that contracted by his father in gambling, etc.,тАЩ as declared in the textтАФтАШThat contracted by the son, or husband or father, etc.тАЩ (Says N─Бrada, 3.17)тАФтАШA woman may not pay the debt contracted by her husband, or by her son, unless she has promised to pay it, or if the debt he one contracted by her jointly with her husband.тАЩ Though all this is included under тАШpayable debt,тАЩ yet when it happens to be such as is contracted in gambling, etc., then by itself, irrespective of all other peculiar circumstances, it becomes тАШnon-payableтАЩ; but all this тАШpayabilityтАЩ or тАШnon-payabilityтАЩ is in relation to the person called upon to pay; and bonce the names тАШpayableтАЩ and тАШnon-payableтАЩ may he taken as similar to the expression тАШgobal─лbardaтАЩ (i.e., generally speaking, by itself, the debt is payable, but under special circumstances, pertaining to the person and the relationship to the original debtor, etc., it becomes non-payable).

тАШTo what extentтАЩ (in N─БradaтАЩs text) meansтАФтАШup to the limit of the double of the principalтАЩ; the distinction here also being as before. If we read тАШyatraтАЩ (in N─БradaтАЩs text), this term would refer to the place and time of payment; the idea being that the debt shall he repaid where it was taken; but if the creditor so wish it, it may he paid at another place also. The time of payment also should as nearly as possible be the same. As regards time, it has been said that there is no desire to repay debts during the Autumn, the most suitable time being either the Summer, when the harvest has been gathered in, or whenever an income is expected.

тАШHowтАЩ (in N─БradaтАЩs text);тАФi.e., so far as possible, the entire debt shall be paid; if this be not possible, then by instalments, till the whole is cleared off; and lastly, in the event of the debtor being entirely reduced to penury, he shall clear off the debt by service, as declared in verso 177 below.

тАШThe methods of delivery and receipt,тАЩтАФi.e., the signature of witnesses, the execution of deeds and so forth.

тАШAssaults, physical and verbalтАЩ (verse 6);тАФthe compound тАШdaс╣Зс╕Нav─БcikeтАЩ is formed in accordance with P─Бс╣Зini 5.4.106, the final тАШс╣нhanтАЩ affix being added according to 5.2.115.

тАШDuties of man and wifeтАЩ (verse 7);тАФthe compound тАШstr─лpum─БnтАЩ is to be expounded as тАШstriy─Б sahitaс╕е pum─Бn,тАЩтАФthe compound belonging to the same class as the compound тАШ┼Ы─Бkap─Бrthivaс╕е.тАЩ If it were formed as тАШstс╣Ы─л ca pumaс╣Г┼Ыca,тАЩ the resultant compound would be тАШstr─лpuс╣Гsadharmaс╕етАЩ (according to P─Бс╣Зini 5.4.77).тАФ(4-7)

(verse 8.4)

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2. 5);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 3 b);тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 1) which explains тАШanap─БkarmaтАЩ as тАШnon-deliveryтАЩ;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 596);тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 1);тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 325);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 3 b);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (12b);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 89b).

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p, 596);тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.5);тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 1), which explains тАШanu┼Ыayaс╕етАЩ as тАШpa┼Ыc─Бtt─Бpaс╕етАЩ, тАШrevokingтАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 1.)тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 325);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 3b);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (12b);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 896).

(verse 8.6)

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p, 596);тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 1);тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.5);тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 1);тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 325);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 3b);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (12b);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 89b).

(verse 8.7)

тАШVyavah─БrasthitauтАЩтАФтАШGiving rise to law-suitsтАЩ (Govindar─Бja);тАФтАШin deciding law-suitsтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa),

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.5);тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 1), which explains тАШdy┼лtaтАЩ as тАШgambling with inanimate objectsтАЩ and тАШsam─Бhvayaс╕етАЩ as тАШgambling with animals,тАЩ and notes that though theft, adultery, defamation and assault are all only forms of тАШcrimeтАЩ (тАШS─БhasaтАЩ) yet they have been mentioned separately, also, on the analogy of such expressions as тАШGobal─лvarda .тАЩ

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 596), which explains тАШpad─БniтАЩ as тАШsth─БnaтАЩ, тАШviс╣г─БyaтАЩ, тАШsubjects;тАЩтАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 1);тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 325);тАФin Nс╣Ыс╣гiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 3b);тАФin Kс╣Ыtya kalpataruтАЩ (12b);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 89b.)

On verses 1-7 V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 4a) has the following notes:тАФтАШVyavah─Бr─Бn,тАЩ business described above,тАФтАШp─Бrthivaс╕е,тАЩ the anointed Kс╣гatriya;тАФthe term тАШnс╣Ыpaс╕етАЩ implies that what is here enjoined applies also to those who, though not themselves kings, are appointed by the king to work for him;тАФтАШseated or standingтАЩ may be options to be determined by the kingтАЩs capacity, or by the respectability or otherwise of the parties appearing before him the raising of the right arm is for calling the attention of suitors; the dress etc. are to be humble, so that the parties may not be confounded by his gorgeous attire;тАФтАШpratyahamтАЩ shows that cases should be tried every day ;тАФтАШ de┼Ыadс╣Ыс╣гс╣нaтАЩ are those customs and arguments that may have local application, such as the customs regarding the betrothal of girls (described above) among тАШnortherners.тАЩ

**(verses 8.4-8)

N─Бrada (1.16 et. seq.).тАФтАШRecovery of Debt, Deposits, Partnership, Resumption of Gift, Breach of Contract of Service;тАФNon-payment of wages, Sales effected by a person other than the rightful owner, Non-delivery of sold chattel, Recission of Purchase, Transgression of a Compact, Boundary-disputes, Mutual Duties of Husband and Wife, Law of Inheritances, Heinous offences, Abuse, Assault, Games, and Miscellaneous;тАФthese are the eighteen topics of legal procedure.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (2.5 et. seq.).тАФтАШLaw-suits are of two kinds, according as they originate in demands regarding wealth or ininjuries. Law-suits regarding wealth are divided into fourteen kinds; and those regarding injuries into four kinds. (1) Lending money on interest, (2) Deposits (and Treasure Trove), (3) Invalid gifts, (4) Concerns of Partnership, (5) Nonpayment of wages, (6) Disobedience, (7) Disputes concerning Land, (8) Sale without ownership, (9) Revocation of sale and purchase, (10) Breach of agreements, (11) Law between wife and husband, (12) Theft, (13) Inheritance and (14) Gambling.тАФThese are the fourteen titles regarding wealth.тАФ(l) and (2) Two kinds of Insults, (3) Violence and (4) Criminal connexion with the wife of another man,тАФthese are the four titles originating in injury.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The addition of the adverb тАШmostlyтАЩ is for the purpose of indicating the importance of the said heads of dispute. As a matter of fact, there are several other points of dispute also; e.g., (a) тАШyou gave me this house to live in; why then do you give it to another person before the lapse of a year?тАЩ This cannot he regarded as included under тАШnon-delivery of what has been given awayтАЩ; because in this case there is no surrendering of ownership (which is a necessary condition in gifts); the dweller is only permitted to dwell in the house;тАФagain, (b) тАШyou have made a window in your house in front of my platform.тАЩ

тАШTaking his stand upon eternal MoralityтАЩ;тАФWealth and Pleasure are not тАШeternal.тАЩ Or, the term тАШeternal moralityтАЩ may mean that he should follow that law or custom the beginnings of which cannot be traced; while he should not pay heed to such customs as may have been adopted only by the present generation; as such custom is not eternal.тАФ(8)

рдирд┐рдпреБрдЮреНрдЬреАрдд “рд╕реНрд╡рд░рд╛рджреНрдпрдиреНрддреЛрдкрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рддреН” (рдкрддреН рдЗ- реирепреж, рдУрдиреН рдкрд╛рдгреН рез.рей.ремрек) рдЗрддрд┐ рд╣рд┐ рдХрд╛рддреАрдпрд╛ рдЖрддреНрдордиреЗрдкрджрдВ рд╕реНрдорд░рдиреНрддрд┐ рее рео.реп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The Br─Бhmaс╣Зa who is thus appointed should be тАШconversant with the eighteen points, well versed in the Science of Reasoning, fully learned in the Veda and the Smс╣Ыtis,тАФbeing called the Investigating Judge.тАЩ

If, either on account of being absorbed in some other more important business, or on account of his inherent incapacity, the king does not investigate the suits personally, then he should appoint a тАШlearnedтАЩ Br─Бhmaс╣Зa. The тАШlearningтАЩ here meant is that pertaining to legal proceedings, and the manтАЩs appointment itself is indicative of his possession of that learning; because no man deserves to be appointed to do a work which he does not know. A knowledge of the Science of Morality also comes useful, for the purpose of precluding the possibility of wrong decisions being taken under the influence of love or hate. If the man is conversant with Morality, even though love or hate may be present in his mind, yet, through fear of the said Science of Morality, he does not allow himself to be misled_(;) and it is thus that a knowledge of the Science of Morality comes in useful. As for the knowledge of legal procedure, its presence is already implied; when the man is appointed to do the work of deciding legal cases, it follows that he is possessed of that knowledge without which such cases cannot he decided. The injunction regarding the impropriety of the man knowingly perverting his judgment is contained in other texts; and with a view to avoiding this our author is going later on to lay down other Measures: e.g., тАШThree persons learned in the Veda, and the learned man appointed by the king, etc.тАЩ (verse 11). As for the knowledge of Sciences other than these, if it were made a necessary qualification for the man appointed to investigate legal cases,тАФsuch knowledge could only be regarded as meant for some unseen transcendental purpose.

тАШNiyojyo vidv─Бn sy─БtтАЩ would be the right reading (in place of tad─Б niyu├▒jy─Бd vidv─Бс╣ГsamтАЩ); because тАШniyu├▒jy─БtтАЩ is grammatically wrong, the right form being тАШniyu├▒j─лtaтАЩ; as K─Бty─БyanaтАЩs V─Бrtika on P─Бс╣Зini 1.3.66 ordains the ─Аtmanepada ending for the root тАШYujтАЩ preceded by prepositions ending in a vowel.тАФ(9)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 21), which adds that the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa so appointed is called the тАШPr─Бс╕Нviv─Бka,тАЩ тАШjudge,тАЩ who is to try the suits exactly in the same manner as has been laid down for the king; It adds a text from N─Бrada explaining the name тАШPr─Бс╕Нviv─БkaтАФтАШThe Pr─Бс╕Нviv─Бka is so called because he puts questions (pr─Бс╣н) upon the subject-matter of the suit and investigates it (Viv─Бka).тАФIt is quoted also in Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 36);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (8a);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 10b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Gautama (13.26).тАФтАШThe King or the Judge or a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa learned in the scriptures shall try the suit.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (16.2).тАФтАШLet the King or his minister transact the business on the bench.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (3.73).тАФтАШOr let him entrust a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa with the judicial business.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.3).тАФтАШThe Br─Бhmaс╣Зa knowing the entire Dharma shall be appointed by the King to try law-suits, if, under pressure of business, he is unable to look into them himself.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (1.24).тАФтАШLet the King, or a member of the twice-born caste officiating as Chief Judge, try causes acting on principles of equity, and abiding by the opinion of the judges and the doctrine of the sacred law.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.23-34).тАФтАШWhere the King cannot personally attend to the administration of justice, he should appoint a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa who is versed in the Vedas, self-controlled, highborn, impartial, unagitated and calm, who fears the next life, is religious-minded, active and devoid of anger. If the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa is not learned enough, the King should appoint a Kс╣гatriya, or a Vai┼Ыya who is versed in the sacred law; but he should never appoint the ┼Ъ┼лdra, The king should always appoint men of the caste to which he himself belongs; as most members of the royal caste are likely to be well-qualified.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava-Vyavah─Бra, p. 22).тАФтАШHe is called the Chief Judge who,тАФfully acquainted with the eighteen titles of law and with the eight thousand subdivisions thereof, skilled in Logic and other sciences, and thoroughly versed in revealed and traditional lore,тАФinvestigates the law relative to the case in hand by putting questions and passing decisions according to what was heard or understood by him.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava-Vyavah─Бra, p. 22).тАФтАШWhen no Br─Бhmaс╣Зa is available, the King shall appoint a Kс╣гatriya or a Vai┼Ыya versed in legal lore; but he shall avoid the ┼Ъ┼лdra.тАЩ

Praj─Бpati (Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б).тАФтАШThe anointed King or the learned Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, seated on the seat of judgment, shall investigate the suits quietly.тАЩ

That man, accompanied by three assessors, shall enter the excellent Court, and either seated or standing, shall investigate the suits on behalf of the king.тАФ(10)

рд╕рднреНрдпреИрд░реН рдЗрддрд┐ рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛рдиреБрдкрд╛рджрд╛рдиреЗ рд╜рдкреНрдпреН рдЙрддреНрддрд░рддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рдкреНрд░рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╛рддреН (рдореНрдзреН рео.резрез), “рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгреИрдГ рд╕рд╣” (рдореНрдзреН рео.рез) рдЗрддрд┐ рдЪ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рддреНрд░ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╛рддреН, рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛ рдПрд╡ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рддреНрд░рд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рддреНрд╡реН рдПрдХрджреНрд╡рдпреЛрдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред рддреНрд░рд┐рдкреНрд░рднреГрддрдпрд╕реН рддреНрд╡реН рдЗрд╖реНрдпрдиреНрдд рдПрд╡ ред рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгреЗ рдЪреИрддрджреН рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрд╛рдордГ ред рд╕рднрд╛рдореН рдПрд╡ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрдпрд╛рдЧреНрд░рд╛рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд░рд╛рдЬрд╕реНрдерд╛рдирд╛рдкрддреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рд╕рднрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрдп рд╕реНрдерд╛рдирд╛рд╕рдиреЗрд╖реБ89 рддрджреНрдзрд░реНрдореЗрд╖реБ рдкреБрдирд░реНрд╡рдЪрдирдВ рдкреНрд░рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рд░реНрдердВ рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердВ рд╡рд╛ ред рддреЗрди рд░рд╛рдЬрд╕реНрдерд╛рдиреЗ рдиреЛрдкрд╡рд┐рд╢рддрд┐ рее рео.резреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШAssesorsтАЩ;тАФthough the caste of these persons is not specified here, yet in view of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa being mentioned later on (in 11), and also of the phrase тАШalong with Br─Бhmaс╣ЗasтАЩ (in verse 1 above), it follows that these also should be Br─Бhmaс╣Зas.

The number is mentioned as тАШthreeтАЩ simply with a view to preclude the possibility of only one or two men being appointed: what is meant is that three or more men shall be appointed. This we shall explain in detail under the section dealing with Witnesses.

тАШShall enter the excellent Court.тАЩтАФThough entering the court as the kingтАЩs representative, he shall stand or sit on such a seat as is proper for himself. The repetition of тАШstanding or sittingтАЩ serves either to indicate the right posture for him, or to preclude other postures. The meaning of this is that he should not sit upon the kingтАЩs throne.тАФ(10)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 21);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 37);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (8a);тАФin V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 10b);тАФand in R─Бjan─лtiratn─Бkara (p. 15b).

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.77).тАФтАШThe Chief Judge is the speaker, the king is the President, the councillors are the investigators.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.85-86).тАФтАШThe King should enter the court modestly, together with the Br─Бhmaс╣Зas and Ministers versed in state-craft, with the object of investigating the cases.тАЩ

рдЙрдХреНрддрдВ рд╕рднрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрдп рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рд╛рдиреН рдкрд╢реНрдпреЗрджреН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд╕рднрд╛рд╢рдмреНрджрд╢реН рдЪ рд▓реЛрдХреЗ рдЧреГрд╣рдкреНрд░рд╛рд╕рд╛рджрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЗ рд╡рд░реНрддрддреЗ “рдордпреЗрди рдирд┐рд░реНрдорд┐рддрд╛ рджрд┐рд╡реНрдпрд╛ рд╕рднрд╛ рд╣реЗрдордкрд░рд┐рд╖реНрдХреГрддрд╛” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдХреНрд╡рдЪрд┐рддреН рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╕рдВрдШрдЯрд┐рддрд╛ рд╕рднреЗрддрд┐ рддрдиреНрдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердВ рд╕рднрд╛рдпрд╛ рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрдореН рдЖрд╣ ред рдпрддреНрд░ рддреНрд░рдпреЛ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛ рд╡реЗрджрд╡рд┐рджрдГ рд╕рдВрдирд┐рдзреАрдпрдиреНрддреЗ, рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрд╢реН рдЪ рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзреА рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддреЛ рд╜рдзрд┐рдХреГрддреЛ рд╡рд┐рджреНрд╡рд╛рдиреН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддреЛ рд╜рдирдиреНрддрд░рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЗ рд╕рдВрдирд┐рд╣рд┐рддрдГ ред рд╕реЗрд╣ рд╕рднрд╛рднрд┐рдкреНрд░реЗрддрд╛ ред рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рд╕реНрддреБрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердореН ред рдпрдерд╛ рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордгрдГ рд╕рднрд╛ рдирд┐рд░рд╡рджреНрдпреИрд╡рдореН рдЗрдпрдореН90 рдЕрдкреАрддрд┐ рее рео.резрез рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

It has been declared that тАШhaving entered the Court, he shall look into the cases.тАЩ As regards the word тАШsabh─Б,тАЩ in ordinary language it is used in the sense of a particular apartment of the house; e.g., in the Mah─Бbh─Бrata it is said that the тАШexcellent gold-burnished sabh─Б was built by MayaтАФsometimes it is also used in the sense of an assemblage of particular men. In order to preclude these two meanings of the term, the author states the definition of the тАШSabh─Б,тАЩ тАШCourt,тАЩ meant in the present context.

That place where three Br─Бhmaс╣Зas learned in the Veda are brought together, as also the learned Br─Бhmaс╣Зa appointed by the king,тАФor the person mentioned in the preceding verse,тАФthat is the тАШSabh─БтАЩ meant here.

The name of тАШBrahmanтАЩ has been mentioned for the purpose of extolling the Court; the sense being that тАШthe Court constituted as here stated is as unexceptionable as that of Brahman himself.тАЩтАФ(11)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Smс╣Ыtit─Бttva (II, p. 199), to the effect that the court becomes a true тАШCourt,тАЩ only by reason of the presence of the duly qualified Br─Бhmaс╣Зa-judge appointed by the king;тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 46), which explains тАШprakс╣Ыtaс╕етАЩ as the appointed judge;тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (8b);тАФin V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 36 and 11b), which says that no stress is meant to be laid upon the number three, as the number may be larger, up to seven; what is meant is that they shall not be less than three;тАФand in R─Бjan─лtiratn─Бkara (p. 17a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Bс╣Ыhaspati (1.11).тАФтАШThat assembly is equal in sanctity to a sacrificial session in which there sit seven, or five or three Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, who are acquainted with the world, with the Veda and with Law.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (1.5).тАФтАШA Court of Justice is composed of ten members; and an assembly of this sort, in which the King examines the cases attentively, is comparable to a religious session.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.50-52).тАФтАШThe assembly in which there are seven, five, or even three Br─Бhmaс╣Зas versed in human affairs, the Vedas and the Dharma┼Ы─Бstras is like a sacrificial session.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.72).тАФтАШThe ten requisites in the administration of justice areтАФthe king, officers, councillors, smс╣Ыti-books, accountant, clerk, gold, fire, water and oneтАЩs own men.тАЩ

N─Бrada (3.18).тАФтАШThat is not a court where there are no elders; they are not elders who do not pass a just, sentence; that is not just sentence where there is no truth; that is not truth which is vitiated by error.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.16).тАФтАШThe King who does not perform his civic duties well certainly rots in hell.тАЩ

N─Бrada (3.89),тАФтАШWhere justice is slain by injustice and truth by falsehood, the members of the court, who look on with indifference, become doomed to destruction. When justice, hit by injustice, enters a court, and the members do not extract the dart from the wound, they are hit by it themselves.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (1. 34-36).тАФтАШOf the Tree of Justice, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa is the root, the King is the stem and branches, the ministers are its loaves and blossoms, just government is its fruit;тАФrenown and wealth are the sap of its fruit; a dignified station, invincibility, esteem among men, and eternal residence in Heaven constitute the enjoyment of its fruit.тАФHaving recognised these advantages in justice, the King should be equitable towards litigants, and should pass a just sentence, discarding avarice and other evil propensities.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б, p. 47).тАФтАШWhere a decision is taken by councillors against the laws, there justice is slain by injustice. If the king happens to be inclined to act unjustly, the councillors shall not remain neutral; if they do remain neutral, they become degraded.тАЩ

M G J: ca vimocane

M G DK: yojayati

M G: ┼Ы─Бstr─Бny─Бviruddhaс╣Г; DK (1: 34): ┼Ы─Бstr─Бj├▒─Бviruddhaс╣Г

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

What is asserted here forbids two thingsтАФ(a) he who has accepted the appointment (of a Judge) should not be unjust, and (b) he should not slur over the injustice committed by others; since both these involve sin.

тАШSpeaks nothingтАЩ;тАФi.e., he who remains silent when another person is committing an injustice,тАФor he who interferes in the investigation and then says what is not compatible with the scriptures or with justiceтАФтАШbecomes tainted with sinтАЩтАФi.e., comes to partake of the sin. Hence the man should not entertain the hope thatтАФтАШit is another judge who is judging wrongly, and he may incur sin, I am only sitting silent and indifferent, why should I he affected by the sin?тАЩ

By the prohibiting of entrance into the Court what is forbidden is the accepting of the appointment of a judge to investigate cases; so that what is meant by the sentence тАШone should not enter the CourtтАЩ is that тАШhe should not accept the appointment of the investigating judge, or, if he does accept it, he should speak out what is just.тАЩ

This has been taken to imply that when even an unauthorised person happens.to be present, if he finds that the judges are acting wrongly, he should not remain silent. To this end wo have the assertionтАФтАШAuthorised or unauthorised, the man who knows what is just should always speak outтАЩ (N─Бrada 2.2). If he fear molestation at the hands of the kingтАЩs officers as to why he should speak, when he is not authorised to do so,тАФthen he should go away from that place. In support of this we have the following assertionтАФтАШWhen a wrong is being inflicted upon a weak person, if one does not save him from it, he incurs sin, only if he hag the power to gave himтАЩ (Gautama, 21.19).тАФ(13)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 604);тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.2), in support, of the view that the assessors duly appointed incur sin if they do not, check the king in the event of his taking an illegal course; but as regards other people present, these incur sin only if they either speak falsely or suppress the truth,тАФand not for not checking the king;тАФand again on 2.83;тАФand also in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 12a).

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.53, 55).тАФтАШThe man who knows Dharma can speak, whether appointed or not appointed. Either one should not come to the Court, or should speak truthfully. That man is a sinner who keeps silent or utters falsehood.тАЩ

N─Бrada (3.10).тАФтАШEither the judicial assembly must not be entered at all, or a fair opinion should be delivered. That man who stands mute or delivers an opinion contrary to justice, is a sinner.тАЩ

N─Бrada (3.14).тАФтАШHe who, having entered the Court, delivers a strange opinion, ignoring the true state of the case, resembles a blind man who, regardless, swallows fish together with the bones.тАЩ

Where justice is destroyed by injustice, or truth by falsehood, while people are looking on,тАФthere the members of the court also are destroyed.тАФ(14)

рдзрд░реНрдордГ94 рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпрджреЗрд╢рдирд┐рдпрддрд╛ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛ ред рд╕рд╛ рдЪреЗрджреН рдЕрдзрд░реНрдореЗрдг95 рддрджреНрд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдорд░реВрдкреЗрдг рд╣рдиреНрдпрддреЗ рд╡рд┐рдирд╛рд╢реНрдпрддреЗ рд╜рд░реНрдерд┐рдирд╛ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд░реНрдерд┐рдирд╛ ред рддрдерд╛ рд╕рддреНрдпрдореН рдЕрдиреГрддреЗрди рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рднрд┐рд░реН рд╣рдиреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдкреНрд░рд╛рдбреНрд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рдХрд╛рджрдпрд╢реН рдЪ рдкреНрд░реЗрдХреНрд╖рдиреНрддреЗ рди рддрддреНрддреНрд╡рдореН рдЙрджреНрдзрд░рдиреНрддрд┐, рддрддрд╕реН рддреЗ рд╣рддрд╛рдГ рд╢рд╡рддреБрд▓реНрдпрд╛ рднрд╡рдиреНрддреАрддрд┐ рдирд┐рдиреНрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рдиреН рдирд╛рд░реНрдерд┐рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд░реНрдерд┐рдиреМ рд╡рд┐рдкрд░реАрддрдореН рдЖрдЪрд░рдиреНрддреМ рд╕рднрд╛рд╕рджреНрднрд┐рд░реН рдЙрдкреЗрдХреНрд╖реНрдпреМ, рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╢реН рдЪ ред рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рдзрд░реНрдордЧреНрд░рд╣рдгреЗрди рд╕рддреНрдпрд╛рдиреГрддрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгреЗрди рд╡рд╛ рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзреМ,96 рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдкреВрд░рдгрдореН рдЙрднрдпреЛрд░реН рдЙрдкрд╛рджрд╛рдирдореН ред рдЕрддреЛ рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрднреЗрджреЗрди рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рддрдореН рее рео.резрек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШJusticeтАЩ is decision arrived at in strict accordance with the scriptures, reasoning and local customs;тАФif this is

тАШdestroyed by Injustice,тАЩтАФi.e., set aside by the reverse of justice,тАФby either the plaintiff or the defendant;тАФsimilarly where тАШtruth is destroyed by falsehoodтАЩтАФby the witnesses;тАФand all the time the judges and the other people in the Court remain looking on, and do not try to draw out the real facts,тАФthen these men also are тАШdestroyed,тАЩтАФi.e., become as good as dead corpses. This is meant to be a deprecation of the judges, etc.

For these reasons the members of the Court shall not connive at any misrepresentations being made by the parties or by the witnesses.

In as much as the mention of тАШJustice and InjusticeтАЩ only, or of тАШTruth and FalsehoodтАЩ only, would have been sufficient, the mention of both would have to be regarded as serving the purpose of tilling up the metre; hence it has been explained as referring to two distinct sets of persons (the parties and the witnesses).тАФ(14)

Where justice is slain by injustice, and truth by falsehood, the members of the Court who look on with indifference, become doomed to destruction.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Judgment should not be perverted, through fear; because justice, when violated, тАШblightsтАЩтАФ our prosperity, as also the prosperity of the sinful party and his helpers.

Similarly, when тАШpreserved,тАЩ justice removes dangers from all sources; so that even though angered, the party (defeated) cannot do any harm.

тАШHenceтАЩтАФi.e., knowing this, that happiness and unhappiness are based upon morality, one should not violate morality (or justice). If we violate justice, justice shall, like an enraged serpent, strike back at us; so lest justice blight usтАФi.e., with a view to saving ourselves,тАФwe should preserve justice.тАФ(15)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

For Justice is the revered тАШVс╣Ыс╣гa,тАЩ Bull; and he who commits the violation, тАШalam,тАЩ of it, him the gods regard as тАШvс╣Ыс╣гala,тАЩ low-born; hence one shall not violate Justice.тАФ(16)
