рд╡реГрд╖рд▓рд╢рдмреНрджрдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рдЪрдиреЗрди рдорд┐рдереНрдпрд╛рджрд░реНрд╢реА рдирд┐рдиреНрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рди рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рд╡реГрд╖рд▓реЛ рд╡реГрд╖рд▓рдГ, рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐, рдпреЛ рд╡реГрд╖рд╕реНрдп рдХрд╛рдорд╡рд░реНрд╖рд┐рдгреЛ рдзрд░реНрдорд╕реНрдп рдЕрд▓рдВрдХреБрд░реБрддреЗ ред рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рд╡рдЪрдирдГ рдЕрд▓рдВрд╢рдмреНрджрдГ ред рд╕ рд╡реГрд╖рд▓ рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдердореН рджреЗрд╡рд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрдиреНрдирд╛рдГ ред рдордиреБрд╖реНрдпрд╛рд╕реН рддреБ рдпрджрд┐ рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рд╢рдмреНрджрдореН рдПрд╡ рдордиреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ, рдХрд╛рдордВ рдордиреНрдпрдиреНрддрд╛рдореН, рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрддрд░рд╛рд╕реН рддреБ рджреЗрд╡рд╛рдГ ред рддреЗ рдЪрд╛рдиреЗрди рдкреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддреЗрди рд╡реГрд╖рд▓рд╢рдмреНрджрдкреНрд░реЛрдпреЛрдЧрдВ рдордиреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рджреЗрд╡рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрдГ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рддреН “рд╢реНрд░рд╛рджреНрдзрдХрд╛рд▓реЗ рд╡реГрд╖рд▓реИрд░реН рди рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН”, “рд╣рдиреНрддрд╡реНрдпреЛ рд╡реГрд╖рд▓рд╢реН рдЪреМрд░рдГ,” рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджреНрдпрд╛рд╕реБ рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рд╕реБ рдорд┐рдереНрдпрд╛рджрд░реНрд╢реА рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордг рдПрд╡ рд╡реГрд╖рд▓рд╢рдмреНрджреЗрди рдЧреНрд░рд╣реАрддрд╡реНрдп рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрддреЛ рд╡реГрд╖рд▓рддреНрд╡рдВ рдорд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рдзрд░реНрдордВ рди рд▓реЛрдкрдпреЗрддреН, рди рдирд╛рд╢рдпреЗрджреН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд╡реГрд╖рд▓рддреНрд╡рд╛рдзреНрдпрд╛рд░реЛрдкреЛ рдирд┐рдиреНрджрд╛ рее рео.резрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

By means of the explanation of the term тАШvс╣Ыс╣гala,тАЩ the judge who perverts justice is censured. The title of тАШvс╣Ыс╣гalaтАЩ (low-born) does not apply to one who is so by casteтАФi.e., the ┼Ы┼лdra,тАФbut he who тАШcommits the violationтАЩ (тАШalamтАЩ) of the Bull, тАШvс╣Ыс╣гa,тАЩтАФi.e., he who showers all blessings;тАФthe particle тАШalamтАЩ denoting violation, perversion.

The opinion that such a person is тАШvс╣Ыс╣гalaтАЩ is held by the gods; if it is taken as denoting a caste, it may be so taken; but the gods are more authoritative, and they accept the denotation of the term as here explained.

The mention of the тАШgodsтАЩ is only a commendatory exaggeration.

For the reason here explained, in all such texts asтАФ(a) тАШno vс╣Ыс╣гala should come in during the performance of a ┼Ыr─Бddha,тАЩ or тАШthe vс╣Ыс╣гala thief should be killed,тАЩтАФthe term тАШvс╣Ыс╣гalaтАЩ should be taken as standing for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa that perverts truth.

Consequently one should not violate Justice, lest he become tainted with the character of the тАШvс╣Ыс╣гalaтАЩ; the application of this character to the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa being a form of deprecation.тАФ(16)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 447), in support of the interpretation of тАШvс╣Ыс╣гalaтАЩ as тАШone devoid of dharmaтАЩ;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (11a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Mah─Бbh─Бrata (┼Ъ─Бnti, 90.16).тАФтАШJustice is the sacred Bull, Vс╣Ыс╣гa; he who brings about his destruction, laya, is called the Vс╣Ыс╣гala; therefore one should never renounce justice.тАЩ

Do. (Anu┼Ы─Бsana, 173.14.16).тАФтАШWhen one abandons his body, Dharma alone goes with him. Dharma is the only helper for men in the other world.тАЩ

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рднрдпрд╛рджреН рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдореЛ рди рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдп рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрддреН “рдзрд░реНрдо рдПрд╡ рд╣рддреЛ рд╣рдиреНрддрд┐” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреЗрдиреЛрдкрджрд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдореН, рд╕реНрдиреЗрд╣рддреЛ рди рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдп рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреЗрдиреЛрдкрджрд┐рд╢реНрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрдд рдПрдХрдГ рд╕реБрд╣реГрджреН рдзрд░реНрдордГ, рддрддреНрд░ рд╕реНрдиреЗрд╣реЛ рднрд╛рд╡рдиреАрдпрдГ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдордиреБрд╖реНрдпрдГ рд╕реБрд╣реГрддреН100 рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдореН рдЕрдкреЗрдХреНрд╖реНрдп рдЬрд╣рд╛рддрд┐ рдЬреАрд╡рдирдореН ред рдпреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЕрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрдорд┐рддреНрд░рдВ рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд┐ рд╕реМрд╣рд╛рд░реНрджрдореН рдЖ рдирд┐рдзрдирд╛рддреН ред рдзрд░реНрдорд╕реН рддреБ рдореГрддрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рдореН рдЕрдиреНрд╡реЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрддреЛ рди рд╕реБрд╣реГрджрдкреЗрдХреНрд╖рдпрд╛ рдорд┐рдереНрдпрд╛рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдореН рдЙрдкреЗрдХреНрд╖рд╛ рд╡рд╛101 рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛ ред

  • рднрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛ рдкреБрддреНрд░реЛ рдорд┐рддреНрд░рдореН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рд╢реН рдЪ рд░рд┐рдХреНрдердореН

  • рдзрд░реНрдорд╕реН рддреНрд╡реН рдПрдХреЛ рдиреИрдирдореН рдЙрдЬреНрдЭрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдЬрд╕реНрд░рдВ

  • рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рдЬреН рдЬрд╣реНрдпрд╛рддреН рдкреБрддреНрд░рджрд╛рд░рд╛рдиреН рди рдзрд░реНрдордореН рее

рдпрджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрджреН рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рджреН рднрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐, рддрддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рд╢рд░реАрд░реЗрдг рд╕рдордВ рд╕рд╣ рдирд╛рд╢рдВ рдЧрдЪреНрдЫрддрд┐ ред рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпреЛ рдореГрддрдВ рди рдкрд░рд┐рддреНрд░рд╛рддреБрдВ рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреН рд╕рдорд░реНрде рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрддрдГ рд╕реБрд╣реГрджреНрдмрд╛рдиреНрдзрд╡рд╛рдиреБрд░реЛрдзрд╛рджреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдзрд░реНрдореЛ рди рд╣рд╛рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ рее рео.резрен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

What has been declared in verse 15 is that Morality or Justice should not be perverted, through fear; and the present verse declares that it should not be perverted through love either.

In as much as Morality (Justice) is the тАШonly friend,тАЩ it is for this that one should cultivate it. Ordinary men often abandon their friends even during life; even in the case of those that are very great friends, the friendship lasts only till death. Morality on the other hand, follows the man even when dead. Therefore even for the sake of friendship, one should not either pervert justice or connive at its perversion.

In this sense there is the following sayingтАФтАШWife, son, friends, riches and wealthтАФall these are lost when the manтАЩs body is destroyed; it is Morality alone which never abandons him; hence one might abandon his sons and wife, but never Morality.тАЩ

Everything else, in the shape of wife, son and so forth,тАФexcept MoralityтАФperishes with the body; i.e., except Morality nothing is able to save the man on death; so that even for the sake of friends and relations, Morality should not be abandoned.тАФ(17)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Hitopade┼Ыa 1,59;тАФin Hem─Бdri (Vrata, p. 14);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Saс╣Гsk─Бra, p. 17a);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (11a).

017 The only friend who follows men even after death is justice; for everything else is lost at the same time when the body (perishes).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

One quarter of the Injustice falls on the man who commits it, one quarter on the witness, one quarter on the members of the Court and one quarter on the king.тАФ(18)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рди рдЪреИрд╖рд╛ рдордирд┐рд╖рд╛ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛- “рдЕрд░реНрдерд┐рдирд╛ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд░реНрдерд┐рдирд╛ рд╡рд╛рдиреНрдпрддрд░рд╕реНрдп рднреВрдореНрдпрд╛рджреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд╣реНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ рд╕ рдПрд╡ рднреВрдореНрдпрдкрд╣рд╛рд░рджреЛрд╖рднрд╛рдЧреН рднрд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдпрддрд┐ ред рд╡рдпрдВ рддреБ рддрджрдХрд╛рд░рд┐рдгрдГ рдХрд┐рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рджреЛрд╖рд╡рдиреНрддрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдо” рдпрддрд╕реН рддрддреН рдкрд╛рдкрдВ рдЪрддреБрд░реНрдзрд╛ рд╡рд┐рднрдЬреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдпрдореН ред рди рд╣реНрдпреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрдХреГрддрд╕реНрдпреИрдирд╕реЛ рд╜рдиреНрдпрддреНрд░ рдЧрдордирдореН рдЕрд╕реНрддрд┐ ред рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдорд┐рдереНрдпрд╛рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдирд┐рд╖реЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдорд╛рджреН рдЙрддреНрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ рдкрд╛рдкрдВ рдорд┐рдереНрдпрд╛рд▓рдореНрдмрдирдореН, рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдореН рдЕрдкрд╢реНрдпрддреЛ рд╜рдкреНрдпреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХреГрддрд░рд╛рдЬрд╕реНрдерд╛рдиреАрдпрд╛рджрд┐рджреЛрд╖рд╛рджреН рджреЛрд╖рд╡рддреНрддреНрд╡рдореН ред рдпрджрд┐ рд╡рд╛102 рд░рд╛рдЬрд╛рдзрд┐рдХреГрддреЛ рдорд┐рдереНрдпрд╛рдЪрд░рд┐рддреЗрди рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдкрд┐рддрдГ, рдкрд░рд╛рдЬрд┐рддрдВ рджреБрд╖реНрдЯрдВ рди рдирд┐рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрддреЗ рди рдЪ рдкреБрдирдГ рд╕рдореНрдпрдХреН рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрдВ рдХрд░реЛрддрд┐, рддрддрдГ рд╕реЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдкрд╛рдкрднрд╛рдЧреН рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рдЕрдзрд┐рдХреГрддреЛрдкрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердВ рд╡рд╛ рд░рд╛рдЬрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдореН ред рдпрджрд╛ рд░рд╛рдЬрд╛ рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдВ рдорд┐рдереНрдпрд╛ рдкрд╢реНрдпрддрд┐ рддрджрд╛ рджреБрд╖реНрдпрддрд┐ ред рдпрджрд╛ рд░рд╛рдЬрд╕реНрдерд╛рдиреАрдпрд╕реН рддрджрд╛ рддрд╕реНрдп рджреЛрд╖ рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ рее рео.резрео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The judges should not entertain any such idea as the followingтАФтАШBetween the plaintiff and the defendant, one or the other is taking what belongs to the other,тАФso that he will incur the sin of wrongful possession of the land,тАФwe are not committing the act,тАФwhy then should we be participators in the sin?тАЩ Because as a matter of fact, the said sin is divided into four parts.

This verse is a purely supplementary exaggeration; because in reality the sin committed by one man does not go to another. What happens then is that on the judges also falls the sin of transgressing the law that forbids unjust decisions. On the king, though he does not personally investigate the case, there does fall the sin resulting from the sinful act of the judges appointed by him and acting as his representatives. Or if, on being apprised, by the defeated party, of the unfair dealings of the authorised judges, he does not punish the dishonest officer, and does not take steps to come to a just decision, then also he becomes a participator in the sin. Or, the тАШKingтАЩ in the text may be taken as standing for the judge appointed by him; the sense being that when the king himself decides the case wrongly, the sin falls upon him, whereas when his representative does so, the sin falls upon the latter.тАФ(18)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШSabh─Бsadaс╕етАЩтАФтАШPeople assembled in CourtтАЩ (Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda)тАШJudgesтАЩ (Govindar─Бja).

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.305), to the effect that in the case of miscarriage of justice, every one of those persons should be punished;тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 15);тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 200);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 5a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Baudh─Бyana (1.19.8).тАФтАШOf injustice in decisions, one quarter falls on the party in the cause, one quarter on his witnesses, one quarter on all the judges, and one quarter on the King.тАЩ

Gautama (13.11).тАФтАШIf the sacred law or the rules are violated, the guilt falls on the witnesses, the Assessors, the King, and the offender.тАЩ

N─Бrada (3.12).тАФтАШOne quarter of the iniquity goes to the offender, one quarter goes to the witness; one quarter goes to all the members of the Court; one quarter goes to the King.тАЩ

H─Бr─лta (Vyavah─Бratattva).тАФтАШOf injustice, one quarter falls on the perpetrator, one quarter on the witness, one quarter on all the members of the Court and one quarter on the King.тАЩ

рдЖрд╣ ред рдХрд╛рдорд╢рдмреНрджрдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЧреЗ рд╣рд┐ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рддреНрд╡рдВ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рд╣рдиреНрдпрддреЗ ред

рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреБ рдмреНрд░реБрд╡рддреЗ ред рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рд╡рдХреНрддреГрддреНрд╡рд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рдирд╛рддреН рддрджрд╛ рдирд┐рдпреЛрдЬреНрдпреЛ рд╡рд┐рджреНрд╡рд╛рдиреН рд╕реНрдпрд╛рджреН рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордг рдЗрддрд┐ рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рджрдпрд╕реН рддреНрд░рдпреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╛ рдирд┐рд╖рд┐рджреНрдзрд╛рд╕реН рддрддреНрд░реЗрд╣ рдкреБрдирдГ рд╢реВрджреНрд░рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзреЛ рд╡рд┐рджреНрд╡рджреНрдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рднрд╛рд╡реЗ рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╡реИрд╢рдпреЛрд░реН рдЕрднреНрдпрдиреБрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирд╛рд░реНрде рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд╢реЗрд╖рдВ рд╕рдорд╛рдирдореН ред
рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рдорд╛рддреНрд░рдореН рдЙрдкрдЬреАрд╡рддреАрддрд┐ рдорд╛рддреНрд░рд╢рдмреНрджреЛ рд╜рд╡рдзрд╛рд░рдгреЗ ред рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрдЬрд╛рддрд┐рдореН рдПрд╡ рдХреЗрд╡рд▓рд╛рдореН рдЙрдкрд╛рд╢реНрд░рд┐рддреНрдп рдЬреАрд╡рддрд┐ рдирд╛рдзреНрдпрдпрдирд╛рджреАрдиреН рдЧреБрдгрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛рдиреН рдирд┐рд░реНрдЧреБрдгрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН ред рдмреНрд░реБрд╡рд╢рдмреНрджрдГ рдХреБрддреНрд╕рд╛рдпрд╛рдореН рее рео.реиреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

It has been said above (under verse 10) that the king shall decide cases helped by Br─Бhmaс╣Зas and by three men well versed in council. Now, in as much as the caste of these councillors has not been specified, it might so happen that ┼Ъ┼лdras might enter the Court, and being тАШcouncillors,тАЩ it would be permissible for them to decide cases, and being possessed of cultured minds, they might pronounce their opinions on matters relating to the Law; specially in all legal proceedings a knowledge of Smс╣Ыti-texts is not essential, on account of not possessing which the ┼Ъ┼лdra could be precluded from pronouncing judgments. As a matter of fact, grounds of victory and defeat (in legal proceedings),тАФsuch as witnesses and other kinds of evidenceтАФare such as are amenable to the ordinary means of knowledge. For instance, a man possessed of cultivated intelligence can easily find out that тАШsuch and such a person is a right witness, and not related, by any relationship, to the party citing him,тАЩ or that тАШsuch another person is not a right witness, having several times been found to have liedтАЩ; and such matters are not cognisable means of Smс╣Ыti-texts only.

Thus then the present verse contains the prohibition of a possible contingency.

Nor is there any definite rule regarding the caste of the тАШCouncillor,тАЩ as there is in regard to that of the тАШPriestтАЩ; e.g., having declared that тАШhe shall with them (the Councillors) consider the questions, etc., etc.тАЩ (7.56), the text does not say that тАШhe shall consider these, with the Br─Бhmaс╣Зas.тАЩ Thus the the meaning of the verse comes to be thisтАФтАШeven though a ┼Ъ┼лdra might learn up hits of Law, and be a Councillor or an officer for inflicting punishments, yet he shall not pronounce any opinion on the merits of cases being investigated in the KingтАЩs Court.тАЩ

What is said in the first half of the verse is to be explained as supplementary to the above prohibition. Because it cannot be asserted, in any case, that the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, who makes a living by his caste and is entirely devoid of learning and other qualifications, should be a propounder of the Law. Hence, when we come to examine its exact significance and form, the affirmation (contained in the first half of the verse) is found to stand on the same footing as the assertion тАШeat poison, but do not eat in his house,тАЩ where also the affirmation (тАШeat poisonтАЩ) is supplementary to the prohibition, and not a real affirmation at all.

It is for this reason that the author has added the term тАШk─Бmam,тАЩ тАШmay, at pleasure;тАЩ the very use of this term deprives the sentence of its injunctive character.

Other people offer the following explanation:тАФтАЬInasmuch as the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa has been specifically declared to be employed as the Propounder of the Law, in such texts asтАФтАШthe learned Br─Бhmaс╣Зa shall be appointed, etc.,тАЩтАФthis in itself excludes all the other three castes, the Kс╣гatriya and the rest; so that what the prohibition of the ┼Ъ┼лdra in the present verse means is that in the absence of Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, the Kс╣гatriya and the Vai┼Ыya may he appointed (hut never the ┼Ъ┼лdra).тАЭ The rest of it they explain, as above.

тАШWho makes a living by his caste only;тАЩтАФthe term тАШm─Бtra,тАЩ тАШonly,тАЩ has a restrictive force; the meaning being тАШhe who lives only on the strength of his Br─Бhmaс╣Зa-caste, and not by learning and other qualities, being absolutely devoid of all Br─Бhmaс╣Зical qualifications.

The term тАШbruva,тАЩ тАШso-called,тАЩ is deprecatory.тАФ(20)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШBr─Бhmaс╣Зabruvaс╕етАЩтАФтАШOne whose origin is doubtful, but who calls himself a Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩ (тАЩKull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШdespicable Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi and Govindar─Бja);тАФтАШan initiated Br─Бhmaс╣Зa who does not study the VedaтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 601);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 22);тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 200), which supplies the definition of тАШbr─Бhmaс╣Зabruvaс╕етАЩ as тАШthe Br─Бhmaс╣Зa who neither studies nor teaches (the Veda)тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (9a);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 11a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

(verses 8.20-21)

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.27).тАФтАШIf the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa he not learned enough, the King should appoint a Kс╣гatriya or Vai┼Ыya learned in the legal law;тАФbut he shall always avoid the ┼Ъ┼лdra.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 601).тАФ(Same as Manu.)

Vy─Бsa (Vyavah─Бratattva).тАФтАШIf the King, leaving the twice-born, tries law-suits with the assistance of ┼Ъ┼лdras, he falls.тАЩ

020 A Brahmana who subsists only by the name of his caste (gati), or one who merely calls himself a Brahmana (though his origin be uncertain), may, at the king’s pleasure, interpret the law to him, but never a Sudra.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The kingdom or that king for whom the investigation of Law is done by a ┼Ъ┼лdra, while he himself is looking on, suffers, like the cow in a morass.тАФ(21)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЛ рд╜рдпрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрдГ ред рдпрд╕реНрдп рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрдГ рд╢реВрджреНрд░реЛ рдзрд░реНрдорд╡рд┐рд╡реЗрдЪрдирдВ рдзрд░реНрдордирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрдВ рдХрд░реЛрддрд┐, рддрд╕реНрдп рд╕реАрджрддрд┐ рдирд╢реНрдпрддрд┐ рд░рд╛рд╖реНрдЯреНрд░рдВ рдкреНрд░рдЬрд╛рдГ, рдХрд░реНрджрдореЗ рдЧреМрд░реН рдЗрд╡ рее рео.реирез рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This is a supplementary declaration to the foregoing Injunction.

The construction isтАФThat king for whom the тАШinvestigation of lawтАЩтАФi.e., decision on legal casesтАФis made by a ┼Ъ┼лdra duly qualified by learning, etc.,тАФhis kingdom,тАФpeople, subjectsтАФтАШsuffersтАЩтАФis destroyedтАФтАШlike the cow in a morass;тАЩтАФтАШpa┼Ыyataс╕етАЩтАФтАШwhile he is looking on.тАЩтАФ(21)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 601);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (9b);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 11a).

021 The kingdom of that monarch, who looks on while a Sudra settles the law, will sink (low), like a cow in a morass.

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЕрджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрдореН ред рди рд╣рд┐ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐рдХрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рджрд┐рднреЗрджреЛ рдпрдерд╛рд░реНрдердГ рд╕рдВрдХреАрд░реНрдгрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН ред рддрджреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдВ рд╡реИрджреНрдпрд╡рдгрд┐рдЧреНрд╡реНрдпрдкрджреЗрд╢рд╛рджрд┐рд╡рджреН рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рджрдпрдГ ред рдпрддреНрд░ рд╡рд╛ рдзрд░реНрдорд╕рдВрдХрдЯреЗ рддреБ рди рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгреАрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрдиреНрддреЗ рддрджреН рдЕрджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрдореН рее рео.реиреи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Like the preceding verse this also is a supplementary declaration.

From the context it is clear that тАШthe majority of ┼Ъ┼лdrasтАЩ is meant with reference to the persons pronouncing judgments upon disputed cases; and the meaning is thatтАФтАШwhere among persons deciding cases there is a majority of ┼Ъ┼лdras, such a kingdom perishes quickly, through sufferings caused by famine and diseaseтАЩ; and it follows that from the destruction of the kingdom follows that of the king also.

тАШInfested with non-believers,тАЩтАФi.e., inhabited by such persons as are materialists, denying the existence of other worlds.

тАШDestitute of twice-born peopleтАЩ;тАФтАШnon-believersтАЩ cannot be regarded as a class distinct from that of Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and the rest; as that would lead to a cross-division; as has been declared thusтАФтАШBr─Бhmaс╣Зas and the rest come to hear the titles of physicians, traders and so forth.тАЩ Or, the expression тАШdestitute of twice-born peopleтАЩ may be taken to mean тАШwhere twice-born persons are not consulted and trusted in connection with difficulties relating to the Law.тАЩтАФ(22)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШ┼Ъ┼лdrabh┼лyiс╣гс╣нhamтАЩтАФтАШWhere ┼Ъ┼лdras form a majority among judgesтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШwhere ┼Ъ┼лdras, i. e., disbelievers, form the majority of inhabitantsтАЩ (Kull┼лka);тАФтАШwhere ┼Ъ┼лdras form the majority among holders of high officeтАЩ (Nandana).

Medh─Бtithi does not explain тАШ┼Ъ┼лdraтАЩ here as тАШunbelieversтАЩ; he has been misrepresented by Hopkins.

рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпреЗ рд╜рдиреБрдХреНрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рее рео.реирей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШJudgment-seat,тАЩтАФ that seat upon which the pronouncing of judgments is the principal work done. When he is seated upon his royal throne, the king regards тАШwealthтАЩ as conducive to the prosperity of the kingdom, to be the most important matter, even in preference to тАШmoralityтАЩ; but when he is engaged in deciding suits, he regards тАШmoralityтАЩ or тАШJusticeтАЩ as the most important thing;тАФthis is what is implied by the name тАШjudgement-seat,тАЩ which does not mean that тАШmoralityтАЩ or тАШJusticeтАЩ is a quality of the тАШscat.тАЩ

тАШWith his body covered,тАЩтАФi.e., having his body covered up with cloth and such other things.

тАШHe shall salute the guardian-deities,тАЩтАФhow down to the eight тАШGuardians of the People, Indra and the restтАЩ;тАФтАШhe shall proceed with the investigation of suits.тАЩ

These two actsтАФcovering up of the body and saluting the Guardian deitiesтАФare laid down with a view to some transcendental result.

тАШWith mind collected,тАЩтАФ with his mind concentrated, hot turning towards any other thing. This serves a visible purpose.

Or, the phrase тАШwith collected mindтАЩ may be taken as modifying the verb тАШsalute.тАЩ

Though what is asserted here appears to have been already said before, yet, in as much as the treatise is a metrical one, repetition cannot he very strongly objected to.

In тАШLokap─Бlebhyaс╕етАЩ тАШto the Guardian Deities,тАЩ the Dative ending denotes the recipient of a gift; since under the Sutra dealing with the Dative, it has been held (by the V─Бrtika) that that also is a тАШrecipientтАЩ for whose sake a certain act is done; e.g., тАШ┼Ыr─Бddh─Бya nigс╣Ыhс╣ЗateтАЩ (тАШHe keeps himself in check for the sake of the performance of ┼Ъr─БddhasтАЩ), тАШpatye sheteтАЩ (тАШLies down for the sake of her husbandтАЩ). Nor can the said assertion he regarded as restricted to the two roots here mentioned (in the two examples); as no such restriction is mentioned in the Bh─Бс╣гya.тАФ (23)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 41) in Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 200);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, pp. 2a and 5b);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 70);тАФand by Jim┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 4a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Bс╣Ыhaspati (1.21-23).тАФтАШThe King having risen early in the morning and performed ablutions according to rule, and having shown due honour to elders, astronomers, physicians, deities, Br─Бhmaс╣Зas and domestic priests,тАФshould enter the Court-room, decorated with flowers, ornaments and fine clothes, with a cheerful countenance. Having entered the Court in the forenoon, together with the elders, ministers and attendants, he should try cases and listen to the exposition of Pur─Бс╣Зas, Law-Codes and Rules of Policy.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.85-87).тАФтАШThe King should enter the Court modestly, together with the Br─Бhmaс╣Зas and the Ministers versed in state-craft, with the object of investigating cases. He should proceed with the work after taking the seat of justice.тАЩ

Saс╣Гvarta (Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б-Vyavah─Бra).тАФтАШBowing to the Guardians of the Regions, the King shall enter the splendid Court and carry on the work of protecting the people by looking into their suits.тАЩ

023 Having occupied the seat of justice, having covered his body, and having worshipped the guardian deities of the world, let him, with a collected mind, begin the trial of causes.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Understanding both тАШdesirableтАЩ and тАШundesirableтАЩ to be only тАШJusticeтАЩ and тАШInjustice,тАЩ he shall look into all the suits of the suitors, according to the order of the castes.тАФ(24)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рдзрд░реНрдорд╡реН рдПрд╡ рдХреЗрд╡рд▓рд╛рд╡реН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдирд░реНрдереМ- рди рдЧреЛрд╣рд┐рд░рдгреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рд▓рд╛рднреЛ рд╜рд░реНрдерд╕реН рддрджреНрд╡рд┐рдкрд░реНрдпрдпреЛ рд╡рд╛рдирд░реНрдердГ ред рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐, рдзрд░реНрдо рдПрд╡рд╛рд░реНрдереЛ рд╜рдирд░реНрдерд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдзрд░реНрдо рдЗрддрд┐ рдмреБрджреНрдзреНрд╡рд╛ рд╣реГрджрд┐ рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрдп рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдгрд┐ рдкрд╢реНрдпреЗрддреН ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛рд░реНрдерд╛рдирд░реНрдерд╛рд╡реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдмреЛрджреНрдзрд╡реНрдпреМ рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рд╡реН рдЕрдкрд┐ ред рдзрд░реНрдорд╕реНрдп рд╕рд╛рд░рддрд╛ рдмреЛрджреНрдзрд╡реНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдерд╕реНрдп рдлрд▓реНрдЧреБрддрд╛ ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рдпрддреНрд░ рдорд╣рд╛рдиреН рдЕрдирд░реНрдердГ рд╕реНрд╡рд▓реНрдкрд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдзрд░реНрдорд╕реН рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдирд░реНрдердВ рдкрд░рд┐рд╣рд░реЗрддреН ред рд╢рдХреНрдпреЛ рд╣рд┐ рдорд╣рддрд╛рд░реНрдереЗрдиреЗрд╖рджреН рдЕрдзрд░реНрдореЛ рджрд╛рдирдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рдирд┐рд░рд╛рдХрд░реНрддреБрдореН ред рд╕рдВрдирд┐рдкрд╛рддреЗ рдЪ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рд┐рдгрд╛рдВ рдмрд╣реВрдирд╛рдВ рд╡рд░реНрдгрдХреНрд░рдо рдЖрд╢реНрд░рдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рдПрд╖ рдЪ рджрд░реНрд╢рдиреЗ рдХреНрд░рдореЛ рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдпрджрд╛ рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдВ106 рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдкреАрдбрд╛ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рдпрджрд╛ рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрд╡рд░рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрдпреН рдЖрддреНрдпрдпрд┐рдХрдВ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдВ рдорд╣рджреН рд╡рд╛ рддрджрд╛ “рдпрд╕реНрдп рдЪрд╛рддреНрдпрдпрд┐рдХрд╛ рдкреАрдбрд╛” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреЗрди рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпреЗрди рддрджреН рдПрд╡ рдкреНрд░рдердордВ рдкрд╢реНрдпреЗрддреН рди рдХреНрд░рдордореН рдЖрджреНрд░рд┐рдпреЗрдд ред рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдпрд╕реНрдерд┐рддреНрдпрд░реНрдереЛ рд╣рд┐ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдп рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН рдЕрддреЛ рди рдпрдерд╛рд╢реНрд░реБрддрдореН рдЖрд╢реНрд░рдпрдгреАрдпрдореН рее рео.реирек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШJustice and InjusticeтАЩ alone are desirable and undesirable. It is not that the тАШdesirableтАЩ consists in the obtaining of cattle, gold and other things, or that the тАШundesirableтАЩ in the reverse thereof; in fact it is тАШJusticeтАЩ that is тАШdesirableтАЩ and тАШInjusticeтАЩ that is тАШundesirableтАЩ;тАФтАШunderstandingтАЩ thisтАФi.e., having come to this conclusion in his mind,тАФтАШhe shall look into the suits.тАЩ

Or, the text may mean that the king shall examine what is тАШdesirable,тАЩ and what is тАШundesirable,тАЩтАФand also what is тАШJusticeтАЩ and what is тАШInjustice.тАЩ That is, he should realise the importance of тАШJusticeтАЩ and the unimportance of what is merely тАШdesirable;тАЩ or that when the element of тАШundesirabilityтАЩ is very large, and that of тАШInjusticeтАЩ very small,тАФthere he shall avoid the former; because it is possible for a slight тАШInjusticeтАЩ to be set aside by the larger тАШdesirableтАЩ factor through gifts and expiatory rites.

In the event of several suitors coming up at the same time, he shall take them up in the order of their castes; but this order of investigation based upon castes is to be observed only when the troubles of all the suitors are of the same degree; when, on the other hand, the business of the lower caste is very urgent or very important, then this should he taken up first, in accordance with the maxim тАШhe whose trouble is urgent, etc., etc.тАЩ; and in this case the order of the castes is not to be strictly observed. It has already been said that the investigation of cases is for the purpose of maintaining order in the kingdom; so that the rules laid down need not always be followed literally.тАФ(24)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШArth─Бnarth─Бvubhau buddhv─Б dharm─Бdharmau ca kevalauтАЩтАФMedh─Бtithi has given three explanations of this (See Translation):тАФтАШFully realizing the wordly evils and advantages, but paying due heed to Dharma and Adharma as alone conducive to spiritual resultsтАЩ (Kull┼лka);тАФтАШdiscriminating the righteous and the unrighteous, and taking up the righteous firstтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Nandana);тАФтАШknowing what will please and what displease the people and understanding what is just and what is unjustтАЩ (Govindar─Бja).

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 46), as laying down the order in which the king is to take up the cases, when several come up at the same time;тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 80);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru, (16b);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 19a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.113-117).тАФтАШThe King with the Ministers after receiving the plaintiff duly should first console him and then commence the trial, he should then enquire of the plaintiff standing submissively before him тАФWhat is your business? What is your complaint? Do not be afraidтАФby what ruffian and under what circumstances hare you been molested?тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (1.24).тАФтАШLet the King, or a member of the twice-born caste officiating as Chief-Judge, try causes, acting on principles of equity, and abiding by the opinion of the judges, and by the doctrine of the sacred law.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.31, 31, 35).тАФтАШA King who acts justly must reject error when brought forward, and seek truth alone; because prosperity depends on the discharge of duty. Therefore let a King, after having seated himself on the seat of judgment, be equitable towards all beings, discarding selfish interests and acting the part of Yama Vaivasvata. Attending to the dictates of the Law, and adhering to the opinion of the Chief-Judge, he should try causes in due order, exhibiting great care.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava- Vyasa, p. 46).тАФтАШWhere two complainants arrive accusing each other and claiming the first hearing, the King shall admit them, either in the order of their castes, or in accordance with the comparative seriousness of the complaints.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Do.).тАФтАШBetween two mutual complainants, that man should be treated as the plaintiff whose hurt or complaint is more serious,тАФand not necessarily the man who appears first before the court.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Do.).тАФ(Same as K─Бty─Бyana.)

B├╝hler

024 Knowing what is expedient or inexpedient, what is pure justice or injustice, let him examine the causes of suitors according to the order of the castes (varna).

рдПрддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рдЧреВрдбреНрдГрдЖрднрд┐рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрдкреНрд░рдХрдЯрдирд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрдореН рее рео.реирел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

What the verse means is that in course of the investigations the veracity or otherwise of witnesses should he found out by means of Inference also;тАФand the mention of тАШvoice,тАЩ etc., is only by way of illustration; what the meaning therefore is, is that it shall be ascertained by means of such sure indiations as may be possible, and not necessarily only by тАШvoiceтАЩ and other things mentioned here; for the simple reason that these latter are not always infallible; e.g., in many cases persons who are not used to the presence of great men become flurried, even though they be quite truthful; while those that are pert manage to hide their real feelings.

The compound тАШsvaravarс╣Зeс╣Еgit─Бk─Бraiс╕етАЩ is to be expounded asтАФby the ─Бk─БraтАФvariations inтАФtheir тАШsvara,тАЩ тАШvoiceтАЩтАФтАШvarс╣ЗaтАЩ тАШcolourтАЩтАФand тАШiс╣Еgita,тАЩ тАШaspectтАЩ;тАФthe тАШchangeтАЩ referred to being modifications undergone by menтАЩs ordinary тАШvoiceтАЩ and the rest

By means of these he shall тАШdiscoverтАЩтАФascertainтАФthe тАШinternal dispositionтАЩтАФ intentionтАФтАШof menтАЩтАФ of suitors and witnesses.

The тАШchange of voiceтАЩ occurs in the form of faltering, being choked with tears and so forth;тАФthat of тАШcolourтАЩ in the form of sudden changes of complexion and so forth;тАФthat of тАШaspectтАЩ in the shape of perspiration, trembling, thrilling of hairs and so forth.

тАШBy means of the eyeтАЩ;тАФi.e., by suddenly casting on them an angry look.

тАШBy gestures,тАЩтАФi.e., by the movement of the hands, the eye-brows and so forth.

It is a fact of common experience that voice and the rest, if carefully watched, disclose the most hidden feelings;тАФthe fact of these being indicative of hidden feelings being well known among men, as we find in ordinary experience.тАФ(25)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШIс╣ЕgitaтАЩтАФтАШPerspiring, trembling, horripilation and so forthтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, Govindar─Бja and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШcasting down the eyes &c,тАЩ (Kull┼лka);тАФтАШaimlessly moving about the arms &c.тАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

тАШ─Аk─БraтАЩтАФтАШMannerтАЩ compounded with тАШsvara-varс╣Зa-iс╣ЕgitaтАЩ collectively, (Medh─Бtithi and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШaspect, e.g., pallor, horripilation, sweatingтАЩ (Govindar─Бja, Kull┼лka, and N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa) who take the term independentlyтАФcopulatively compounded with тАШsvaraтАЩ &c.

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 620);тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva (p. II, 218),… which adds the following notes:тАФтАШSvara,тАЩ such as choking voice,тАФтАШvarс╣Зa,тАЩ abnormal pallor and so forth,тАФтАШiс╣Еgita,тАЩ i. e., sweating, trembling and horripilationтАФтАШ─Бk─Бra,тАЩ disfigurement,тАФтАШcakс╣гuс╣г,тАЩ timid, or piteous look,тАФтАШceс╣гс╣нita,тАЩ the manner of standing and moving. It adds that all these, being uncertain indications, have to be regarded as inferior to witnesses and other kinds of direct evidence;тАФin

Kс╣Ыtykalpataru, (21b), which has the following notes:тАФтАШVibh─Бvayet,тАЩ determine, ascertain,тАФтАШbh─Бvam,тАЩ motive, intention, тАШnс╣Ыс╣З─Бm,тАЩ of the two parties and of the witnesses,тАФтАШ─Бk─БraтАЩ transformation in the natural voice and other things,тАФthat of тАШsvaraтАЩ appears in the form of trembling and so forth, that of тАШvarс╣ЗaтАЩ in the shape of paleness and so forth;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 30a), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШSvaraтАЩ stands for the choking of the voice and so forth,тАФтАШvarс╣ЗaтАЩ for the тАШdarkness of complexion,тАЩ and so forth,тАФтАШiс╣ЕgitaтАЩ for perspiration, trembling and the like,тАФтАШ─Бk─БraтАЩ for the raising of the eye-brows and so forthтАФтАШcakс╣гuтАЩ for the timid look,тАФтАШceс╣гс╣нitaтАЩ for the listless changing of position.тАФ(25)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

(verses 8.25-26)

N─Бrada (6.10-11).тАФтАШWhen the face changes colour, or the voice falters, or the features look suspicious, when they do not give evidence in public, when they make impossible statements as to place and time, when there are doubts regarding their place of residence, when they indulge in expense for bad purposes, when they have been previously convicted of larceny, when they keep bad company, or when documents speak against them,тАФthey may be convicted as thieves,тАФnot by the possession of stolen goods alone.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.13-15).тАФтАШIf he shifts his position, licks the ends of his mouth, perspires in his forehead, his face becomes pale, speech is dry and halting, talks much and inconsistently, is not pleasant in the eye or in his speech, twists his lips, the natural condition of his mind, speech and body becomes changed,тАФsuch a person, whether he be a complainant or a witness, should be regarded as at fault or wicked.тАЩ

R─Бm─Бyaс╣Зa (Vyavah─Бratattva, p. 31).тАФтАШThe man cannot hide his internal feelings entirely, without showing some slight shadow of it in his external appearance; it becomes exposed even against his will.тАЩ

025 By external signs let him discover the internal disposition of men, by their voice, their colour, their motions, their aspect, their eyes, and their gestures.

The inner mind is indicated by such variations as those of aspect, gait, gesture, speech, and by changes in the eye and the face.тАФ(26)

рддрдерд╛ рд╣рд┐, рд▓реЛрдХреЗ110 рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╢рдХреНрддрд┐рддрд╛рдиреЗрди111 рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЗрди рд╕реНрд╡рд░рд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЛрдХреНрддрд╛рд░реНрдерд╛рдзрд┐рдЧрдореЗрди рджрд░реНрд╢рдпрддреАрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкреМрдирд░реБрдХреНрддреНрдпрдореН ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрдиреНрддреЗ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпрдиреНрдд рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЖрдХрд╛рд░рд╛ рдЗрдЩреНрдЧрд┐рддрд╛рджрдпрдГ ред рдЗрдЩреНрдЧрд┐рддрдВ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рддрдореН ред рд╡реНрдпрдХреНрддрд┐рднреЗрджрд╛рджреН рдмрд╣реБрд╡рдЪрдирдореН ред рдЧрддрд┐рдГ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрд╛рджреН рдЕрддреНрд░рд╛рдзрд┐рдХрд╛ ред рд╕рд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╕реНрдЦрд▓рдиреНрддреА рд╕реНрд╡рднрд╛рд╡рддреЛ рд╜рдиреНрдпрдерд╛рднреВрддрд╛ ред рднрд╛рд╖реАрддрдВ рдкреМрд░реНрд╡рд╛рдкрд░реНрдпрд╡рд┐рд░реБрджреНрдзрдВ рд╡рдЪрдирдореН ред рд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░рд╡рд┐рдХрд╛рд░ рдЖрд╕реНрдпрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛рджрд┐рдГ ред рд╢реЗрд╖рдВ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХ рдПрд╡ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рддрдореН ред рдПрддреИрд░реН рд╡рд┐рдХреГрддреИрд░реН рдЕрдиреНрддрд░реНрдЧрддрдВ рдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдВ рд▓реМрдХрд┐рдХреИрд░реН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд░рд╛рдкрд┐ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдпрдд рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рдорд╛рд╕рд╛рд░реНрдердГ рее рео.реирем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

What this verse does is to support, by ordinary experience, what has gone in the preceding verse; hence there is no repetition.

тАШ─Аk─БraтАЩ is that which changes, variations; such as aspect and the rest.

тАШAspectтАЩ has already been explained; the plural number is used in view of there being numerous individual aspects.

тАШGait,тАЩтАФthis is in addition to what has gone in the preceding verse; it means the ordinary gait of a man being tripped or otherwise altered.

тАШSpeechтАЩтАФinconsistent and contradictory statements.

тАШChanges in the faceтАЩтАФthe mouth being parched and so forth.

The rest has all been explained under the previous verse.

By means of the variations of all these the innermost heart is indicated even in ordinary life; such in brief is the meaning of the verse.тАФ(26)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 260);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 43);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 112);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (22a), which has the following notes:тАФтАШIс╣ЕgitaтАЩ stands for perspiration, thrilling of the hair,тАФтАШvik─БraтАЩ of the eye, the look of love or anger,тАФтАШceс╣гс╣нitaтАЩ, throwing about of the hand and so forth,тАФтАШgaty─БтАЩ halting gait and so forth;тАФтАШceс╣гс╣нitaтАЩ, inconsistent and contradictory statements,тАФтАШvaktra vik─БraтАЩ, drying of the mouth &cтАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 30b).

026 The internal (working of the) mind is perceived through the aspect, the motions, the gait, the gestures, the speech, and the changes in the eye and of the face.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The king shall take care of the property owned by a minor, till such time as he may return from the teacherтАЩs house, or till he may have passed his minority.тАФ(27)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ рдирдиреБ рдЪ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдВ рд╡рдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпрддрдпрд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╕реНрддреБрддрдореН ред рддрддреНрд░ рдХрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╕рдЩреНрдЧреЛ рдмрд╛рд▓рдзрдирд░рдХреНрд╖рд╛рдпрд╛рдГ ред

рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рджрдкрджрддрд╛рдореН рдПрд╡реИрддрджреН рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрд╛рдиреН рдирд┐рд╡рд░реНрддрдпрд┐рддреБрдореН рдЗрджрдореН рдЖрд░рднреНрдпрддреЗ112 ред рдмрд╛рд▓рдзрдирдВ рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрд╛ рд╕реНрд╡рдзрдирд╡рддреН рдкрд░рд┐рдкрд╛рд▓рдиреАрдпрдореН ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛ рдкрд┐рддреГрд╡реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдмрд╛рдиреНрдзрд╡рд╛ рдордпреЗрджрдВ рд░рдХреНрд╖рдгреАрдпрдВ рдордпреЗрджрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рд╡рджреЗрд░рдиреН ред рди рдЪрд╛рдиреНрдпрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╕рдЩреНрдЧреЛ рд╜рд╕реНрддрд┐ ред рдЖрд╢рдЩреНрдХреНрдпрдорд╛рдирд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рд╡рдЪреН рдЪ ред рди рдХреЗрд╡рд▓реЗрд╖реБ рд░рд╛рдЬрдзрд░реНрдореЗрд╖реВрдкрджрд┐рд╢реНрдпрддреЗ рдЕрддреЛ рд╜рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреНрдиреН рдПрд╡рд╛рд╡рд╕рд░реЗ рд╡рдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН113 ред рдмрд╛рд▓реЛ рджрд╛рдпрд╛рджреЛ рд╜рд╕реНрдп рддрджреН рдЗрджрдВ рдмрд╛рд▓рджрд╛рдпрд╛рджрд┐рдХрдореН ред рджрд╛рдпрд╛рджрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореНрдпреН рдЕрддреНрд░реЛрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдмрд╛рд▓рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдХрдВ рдзрдирдВ рддрд╛рд╡рджреН рд░рд╛рдЬрд╛ рд░рдХреНрд╖реЗрджреН рдпрд╛рд╡рджреН рдЕрд╕реМ рд╕рдорд╛рд╡реГрддреНрддрдГ рдЧреБрд░реБрдХреБрд▓рд╛рддреН рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧрддрдГ рдпрд╛рд╡рджреН рд╡рд╛рддреАрддрд╢реИрд╢рд╡рдГ рдЕрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрдмрд╛рд▓рднрд╛рд╡рдГ ред рдЕрдпрдВ рдЪ рд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрдГ ред рдпреЛ рдЧреГрд╣рд╢реИрд╢рд╡реЛ рднрд╡рддрд┐ рддрджрд░реНрдердореН рдЕрддреАрддрд╢реИрд╢рд╡рдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрд╕реН рддреБ рд╡реНрд░рддрдХрдГ рд╕ рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╢реИрд╢рд╡реЗ114 рдЖ рд╕рдорд╛рд╡рд░реНрддрдирд╛рддреН рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрд╛рд▓реНрдпрдзрдирдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрд╛рддреАрдирд╛рдВ рд╕рдорд╛рд╡рд░реНрддрдирдореН рдЕрд╡рдзрд┐рдГ, рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рд╢реИрд╢рд╡рд╛рддреНрдпрдпрдГ рее рео.реирен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

An objection is raisedтАФтАЬThe subject that was introduced was the investigation of suits; where then was the occasion for the protecting of the property of minors?тАЭ

Answer.тАФThis subject has been introduced here, just with a view to show that the property of minors does not come within the scope of legal proceedings; it has to be protected by the king, like his own property; otherwise the minorтАЩs uncles and other relatives would quarrel among themselves, each assertingтАФтАШI shall take care of it.тАЩ There is no connection of this subject with the present context. It has had to be introduced here,тАФand not along with the exclusive тАШDuties of the King,тАЩтАФbecause in regard to this people may have the notion that even such property may form the subject of legal proceedings.

тАШB─Бlad─Бy─БdiтАЩтАФthat of which a minor is the тАШd─Бy─Бda,тАЩ i.e., owner, in which sense the term is used here. The property owned by minors shall be taken care of by the king, till such time as he may return from the teacherтАЩs house, or till he may have passed his minority. This second alternative of passing the minority is meant for those who pass their childhood in their own home (and are not handed over to an ─Аc─Бrya). In the case of one however who has entered the teacherтАЩs house as a Religious Student, even though he may have passed his minority, his property shall have to be looked after until he returns from the teacherтАЩs house. Or, the meaning may he that in the case of twice-born persons, the тАШreturnтАЩ shall be the limit, while in that of others, it shall be the тАШpassing of minority.тАЩтАФ(27)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 598), which explains тАШB─Бlad─Бy─БgatamтАЩ as тАШbelonging to a minorтАЩ and тАШ─Бnup─БlayetтАЩ as тАШshould guard it against co-parcenersтАЩ;тАФand in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 244).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Gautama (10.48).тАФтАШThe property of infants must be protected until they attain their majority or complete their studentship.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (16.8-9).тАФтАШThe King shall protect the property of persons unfit to transact business;тАФbut when a minor comes of age, his property must be made over to him.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (3.65, Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 598).тАФтАШThe King shall protect the property of infants, of people without protectors and of women.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita (Do., p. 599).тАФтАШThe King shall protect the property of infants, of persons unable to transact business, and of the wives of the Vedic Scholar and the Warrior. Ownerless properties revert to the King.тАЩ

Baudh─Бyana (Do.).тАФтАШUntil sons are able to transact, business, they shall keep their property along with the accrued profits carefully till they attain majority.тАЩ

Agnipur─Бс╣Зa (R─Бjadharma, 222.18-19).тАФ(Same as Manu, reading тАШb─Бlaputr─БsuтАЩ in place of тАШba┼Ы─Бputr─Бsu.тАЩ)

K─Бty─Бyana (Do.).тАФтАШIf a man dies leaving an infant, son, the relations shall protect his property.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рд░рд┐рдХреНрде] рдЗрддрд┐ рдирд┐рддреНрдпрдВ рдзрдирдореН, рд╕рдорд╛рд╕рд╛рд░реНрдердГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдЪ рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдорд╛рддреГрдкрд┐рддреГрдХреЛ рд╜рдпрдореН рдЕрдирд╛рдердГ рд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрд╛рджреН рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдпрддреЗ ред рдпрддрд╕реН рддрджреНрдзрдирдВ рддрд╛рд╡рджреН рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрд╛ рд░рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдорд╛рдгрдВ рддрд┐рд╖реНрдареЗрддреН рдпрд╛рд╡рджреН рдЕрдпрдВ рд╕рдорд╛рд╡реГрддреНрддрдГ ред рд╕рдорд╛рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рд╕реН рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрд╕реНрдп рд╕рдВрд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рдХреНрд╖рдорддреНрд╡реЛрдкрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдЪ рд╕рддрд┐ рд╕рдорд╛рд╡реГрддреНрддрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╢рд┐рд╢реБрдВ рд╕рдиреНрддрдВ рди рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрд╛рджрдпреЗрджреН рдЕрд╕рдорд░реНрдердореН рдЕрд╡рд╡рд┐рддреНрддрд╕рдВ[рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЗ ред рдпрд╛рд╡рджреН рд╡рд╛рддреАрддрд╢реИрд╢рд╡рдГ], рдЕрд╕рдорд╛рд╡реГрддреНрддреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ ред рд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрд╛рдкреЗрдХреНрд╖рддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрд╛рджрдпреЗрджреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН ред рдЕрдирд╛рдерд╡рд┐рддреНрддрд╕рдВрд░рдХреНрд╖рдгреЛрдкрджреЗрд╢рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрд╛рджреН рдЗрджрдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рддрджреНрд░реВрдкрдореН рее рео.реирен рее

B├╝hler

027 The king shall protect the inherited (and other) property of a minor, until he has returned (from his teacher’s house) or until he has passed his minority.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Whoever may be without a protector, that personтАЩs property shall he taken care of by the king; the тАШbarrenтАЩ women and the rest being mentioned only by way of illustration. It is only thus that the тАШprotection of the peopleтАЩ becomes accomplished. The preceding verse lays down the period of time during which the said protection of the property is necessary.

тАШVa┼Ы─БтАЩтАФbarren woman.

тАШSonless womanтАЩтАФone who has no son, or whose son is incapable, or whose son is in a bad condition.

Between va┼Ы─Б and aputr─Б we have the copulative compound.

тАЬThe barren woman also is sonless.тАЭ

True, but both have been mentioned for the purpose of showing that even though her husband he alive, the said woman may be looked after; as on account of her being superseded (by another wife taken by her husband), her husband may neglect her.

тАШWhose family is extinctтАЩ;тАФthis is added with a view to indicate those who have no protector in the shape of husbandтАЩs younger brother, or paternal or maternal uncle, and being women, are themselves incapable of looking after their own property,тАФand whose other relations are jealous of her property. Otherwise, as a rule, the character and property of women should be looked after by her relations; as has been thus declaredтАФтАШOn the husband lies the burden of supporting and protecting the woman, for which he is capable; when the husbandтАЩs family becomes extinct, and there is no man left and no standing, and there are no Sapiс╣Зс╕Нas even left, her fatherтАЩs people become her protectors; when both families are extinct, the king is the supporter and protector of the womanтАЩ (N─Бrada, 13-28 to 29).

When the woman herself is, somehow, capable of taking care of herself, then there is nothing done by the relations; it is in view of this that the text has added тАФтАШof women in distressтАЩ;тАФthis epithet indicating inability. Others have explained the term тАШwomen in distressтАЩ to mean тАШthose whose husbands are in distressтАЩ;тАФeven a woman whose husband is alive becomes a tit object for the kingтАЩs care, if her husband is incapable of taking care of her. This applies to the case of women in whose family there are no men left to take care of them. The epithet тАШwhose family is extinctтАЩ thus means тАШthose who have no family, i.e., relations.тАЩ

Others have explained the term тАШniс╣гkul─БтАЩ to mean the misbehaved woman; of those women also the property acquired by means of their beauty has to be protected by the king.

According to this explanation the term тАШniс╣гkul─БтАЩ has to be taken by itself (and not as qualifying the other terms).

тАШWidows faithful to their husbandsтАЩ;тАФтАШvidhav─Б,тАЩ тАШwidow,тАЩ is one whose husband is dead;тАФтАШdhavaтАЩ being a synonym for тАШhusbandтАЩ; and she who is deprived of the dhava is тАШvidhav─Б,тАЩ тАШwidow.тАЩ Till such time as she remains faithful to her husband, she deserves to have her property looked after by the king. In the event of her being unfaithful, she does not deserve to have any property at all, as we read in another Smс╣Ыti textтАФтАШShe who is bent upon doing injury, who is devoid of modesty, who wastes money, who is addicted to misconductтАФsuch a woman does not deserve to have property.тАЩ Such a woman is to be banished; and this тАШbanishmentтАЩ shall be only in the form of being driven away from the main apartment of the home, and not in being driven away entirely; because even in the; case of such women as have become outcasts the scriptures have laid down that they shall be; provided with a separate dwelling-house, clothing and food:тАФтАШIn the case of outcast women also, this same action should be taken; clothing, food and water should be provided for them and they should live near the house.тАЩ In view of this, wherever.we find an injunction regarding the banishment of such women,тАФe.g., in such texts as тАШthe womanтАЩs entire property, etc., etc.,тАЩтАФthe тАШbanishmentтАЩ should be understood to be of the nature just explained. And she deserves to retain what she may have saved from the fond that is granted her; this the relatives shall not take away.

So far as the present treatise (of Manu) is concerned, in regard to such women what has been proscribed is supersession, and not. the confiscation of property; as has been declared (under 9.80)тАФ^(тАШ)She who drinks wine, misbehaves, or is disobedient, or diseased, or mischievous, or wasteful, shall always he superseded.тАЩ Hence on the strength of ManuтАЩs text, the above-quoted text as to the; unfaithful wife not deserving any property has to be explained as follows:

тАЬSuch a woman shall not receive that property which she should have received on account of her super-session; that is, she shall not receive what has been enjoined as to be; given to her in the following textтАФтАШTo the superseded wife shall he given a compensation for her supersession.тАЩ But what may have been given to her before that shall not be taken away from her.тАЭ

Our opinion however is that in the case of the woman who is inimical to her husband, or addicted to misbehaviour, confiscation of property is only right, and proper; since in Manu also (9.78) it has been declared thatтАФтАШShe who disregards her husband when she is maddened, or drunk, or diseased, shall be abandoned for three months, having been deprived of her ornaments and clothesтАЩ;тАФi.e., she shall be deprived of her ornaments and clothes before being abandoned.тАФ(28)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШNiс╣гkul─БsuтАЩтАФтАШThose women who have no brother-in-law, or uncle to take care of themтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi and

R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШharlotsтАЩ (тАШothersтАЩ in Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШthose maidens whose family is extinctтАЩ (Govindar─Бja);тАФтАШthose who have no Sapiс╣Зс╕НasтАЩ (Kull┼лka).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 512), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШVa┼Ы─БтАЩ, barren woman,тАФтАШaputr─БтАЩ, one who has lost her son,тАФтАШNiс╣гkul─БтАЩ one who has lost all her paternal and maternal relations.

Viс╣гс╣Зu (3.65).тАФ(See under 27.)

Agnipur─Бс╣Зa (R─Бjadharma, 222.20).тАФ(Same as Manu.)

рд╕реНрд╡рдмрдиреНрдзреБрднреНрдпрд╢реН рдЪреИрддрджреН рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЗрдг рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрд╛ рд░рдХреНрд╖рд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рдЪреМрд░рд░рдХреНрд╖рд╛ рддреБ рд╕реНрд╡рд░рд╛рд╖реНрдЯреНрд░рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрд╛ рд╡рд┐рд╣рд┐рддрд╛ рее рео.реиреп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This тАШpunishment of thievesтАЩ has been laid down for those relatives who should appropriate the property of women. They appropriate her property in manifold wavs; giving out., for instance, thatтАФтАШshe is not mistress of herself as regards what she gives away and what she enjoys,тАФI am the real owner of the; property.тАЩ

It is in view of the possibility of people thinking that such misappropriators are not тАШthievesтАЩ that the text lays down the тАШpunishment of thievesтАЩ for them.

тАШWhile they are alive, if the relationsтАЩтАФbrother-in-law and othersтАФтАШshould appropriate their property,тАФon them the king shall inflict punishment,тАЩтАФshall punish them.

The тАШpunishment of thievesтАЩ is going to be described later on (verse 334)тАФтАШWith whatever limb a thief operates against men, each of those limbs the King shall cut off, in order to prevent the repetition of the act.тАЩ

What the verse means is that the property of helpless women should be specially guarded against her own relations; guarding against thieves being the duty that has been laid down for the King as owing to the entire kingdom.тАФ(29)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.147), in support of the view that except the husband, no co-parcener should lay hands upon the property of women during their life-time;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 752), to the effect that when the woman is dead, her relations do have a right to her Str─лdhana property;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 512); and in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 70).

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 752).тАФтАШWhile the woman is alive, her husband or sons or brother-in-law or relations have no power over her str─лdhana; if they take it from her, they should be punished.тАЩ

Agnipnr─Бс╣Зa (R─Бjadharma, 222.21).тАФ(Same as Manu.)

Property, the owner whereof has disappeared, the King shall keep for three years; up to three years the owner may receive it; but after that the King (shall take it).тАФ(30)

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреБ рдиреГрдкрддрд┐рд░реН рд╣рд░реЗрджреН рдЗрддрд┐ рднреЛрдЧрд╛рдиреБрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирдореН рдЕрдкрд╣рд╛рд░рдореН рдЖрд╣реБрдГ ред рди рд╣рд┐ рдКрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рддреНрд░рд┐рднреНрдпреЛ рд╡рд░реНрд╖реЗрднреНрдпрдГ рдкрд░рдХреАрдпрд╕реНрдп рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрд╕рд╛рдкрд╣рд╛рд░реЛ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдГ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рддреН рддреНрд░рд┐рднреНрдпреЛ рд╡рд░реНрд╖реЗрднреНрдп рдКрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рдореН рдЕрдирд╛рдЧрдЪреНрдЫрддрд┐ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдирд┐ рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрд╛124 рднреЛрдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред
  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рддреИрд░реН125 рдЕрдпрдВ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдГ рдХрдердВ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рдиреАрдпрдГ- “рдпрддреН рдХрд┐рдВрдЪрд┐рджреН рджрд╢рд╡рд░реНрд╖рд╛рдгрд┐” (рдореНрдзреН рео.резрекрен) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдпрджрд┐ рдЪ рдкрд░рдХреАрдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд╣рд╛рд░реЛ рди рдпреБрдХреНрдд рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рднреЛрдЧреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдиреИрд╡ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдГ ред рдкрд░рдХреАрдпрдВ126 рд╡рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рджрд┐рд╡рджреН рднреБрдЬреНрдпрдорд╛рдирдВ рдирд╢реНрдпрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡ ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдирдкрд╣рд╛рд░реЛрдкрдЪрд╛рд░реЛ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдГ, рднреБрдХреНрддреЗрд░реН127 рдПрд╡рд╛рдкрд╣рд╛рд░рдлрд▓рд╕реНрдп рд╕рджреНрднрд╛рд╡рд╛рддреН ред рдЧрдЬрддреБрд░рдЧрд╛рджреЗрд╕реН128 рддреБ рдХреАрджреГрд╢реЛ рднреЛрдЧ рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд╛рдЪреНрдпрдореН ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рдиреН рди рдпрдерд╛рд╢реНрд░реБрддрд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрдпрд╛рдЧреЗ рдХрд╛рд░рдгрдореН рдЕрд╕реНрддрд┐ ред рд╣рд░рддрд┐рд╢реН рдЪ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгрд╛рддреНрдпрд░реНрдереЗ рдЕрд╕рдХреГрджреН рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЧ рдЛрдХреНрдердВ рд╣рд░реЗрджреН рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджреМ ред рддрд╕реНрддреНрдорд╛рддреН рдкрд░реЗрдг рдиреГрдкрддрд┐рд░реН рд╣рд░реЗрддреН рд╕реНрд╡реАрдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдпрдореН рдПрд╡рд╛рд░реНрдердГ рее рео.рейреж рее

рдХрдердВ рдкреБрдирдГ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореА рдкреНрд░рдирд╖реНрдЯреЗ рдзрдиреЗ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рддреНрд╡рдВ рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдкрдпреЗрддреН ред рдЕрдд129 рдЖрд╣ ред

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

When some one has lost something,тАФit having dropped on the ground while he was going along the road, or in the forest,тАФand the conservator of the forests, or some other official of the King, finds it and brings it to the King,тАФthe King shall arrange for its safe keeping and have it kept exposed to view at the royal gate or on the public road, and made it known by heat of drum if any one has lost anything; or he shall have it kept in charge of keepers on the spot where it was found. For three years he shall thus keep it.

Then, before the lapse of three years, if some one reports with proofs that the property belongs to him, then it should he made over to him, after deducting the sixth part of it, which is said (in verse MM) to be the KingтАЩs share; and after the lapse of three years the King shall take the property into his own treasury.

That тАШriktha,тАЩ тАШproperty,тАЩ is said to be тАШpraс╣Зaс╣гс╣нasv─Бmika,тАЩ of which the owner has тАШdisappearedтАЩтАФi.e., cannot he traced.

тАШTryabdamтАЩ denotes the aggregate of three years; the feminine affix being absent, just as it is in the compound тАШtrivarс╣гam.тАЩ The term тАШabdaтАЩ is synonymous with тАШyear.тАЩ

тАШShall keepтАЩтАФshall have it deposited.

тАШUp to three years,тАЩтАФi.e., before the period of three years is over,тАФтАШthe owner may receive it,тАЩтАФassert, his ownership.

The term тАШarv─Бk,тАЩ тАШup toтАЩ denotes limit, and indicates priority of time or place.

Others have explained the sentence тАШthe king shall lake itтАЩ to convey the permission to him to enjoy the property. What these people mean is that even after the lapse of throe years, it would, not be right for the King to тАШtakeтАЩ or possess what belongs to another person; and hence what is meant is that after the lapse of three years, if the lightful owner does not turn up, the King shall enjoy the usufruct of the property.

But how will these people explain the verse тАШWhatever an owner sees enjoyed by others during ten years, and though present, says nothing, that he shall not recoverтАЩ (8.117)? Further, if it he asserted that the тАШtaking awayтАЩ of another manтАЩs property cannot be right,тАФthen the using also of such property cannot be right. Specially as another manтАЩs property in the shape of clothing and the like, becomes unfit by use. For these reasons it is only right that the mention of тАШtaking awayтАЩ should he taken to mean actual possession; specially as enjoyment, which is the fruit of possession, would be present (according to the other view also). Then again, what sort of тАШenjoyment of usufructтАЩ would there ho in the case of such property as the elephant, the house and the like?

Thus then, there is no reason for abandoning the direct literal meaning of the words; specially as the root тАШhс╣Ы,тАЩ тАШto take away,тАЩ has often been found to be used in the sense of possession, as in such phrase тАШriktham haret,тАЩ тАШshall take possession of the property.тАЩ Hence what the sentence means is that after three years the King shall тАШtakeтАЩтАФi.e., take possession ofтАФthe property.тАФ(30)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This rule is meant for only such property as does not belong to a Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАФsays Nandana.

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 778), which notes that the rule (relating to the keeping of the property for three years) pertains to the case of property belonging to Br─Бhmaс╣Зas with exceptional qualifications;тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б on 2.38, which notes that the meaning is that for three years, the property must be kept in safe custody; if the owner turns up before the lapse of one year, the entire property should be handed over to him; but if he turns up after one year then a portion of the property is to be taken by the king as fee for keeping it; the proportion being specified below in verse 33; it adds that the last clause, permits the king to spend the property after three years, only in the case of the owner not turning up at all.тАФIt is quoted again under 1.173, where it is noted that the period of three years is meant for the case of the owner being a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa тАШendowed with learning and character.тАЩ

It is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 226), which notes that this only permits the king to make use of the property (not to make it his own). In view of what the Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б and Apar─Бrka have said, it is interesting to note that Madnap─Бrij─Бta reads тАШabdamтАЩ and тАШabd─БtтАЩ, which clearly puts down the period as one year only.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 87), which also notes that the rules refer to the property of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa learned in the Veda.

This is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (R─Бjan─лti, p. 266), which adds the following notes:тАФReading this text along with Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2-33), we take the rule to be that, if the owner turns up before the lapse of one year, the entire property should be made over to him, but if after that, the king should take from it his own share;тАФfor three years he should keep the property in the same condition in which it was found; and after that he is permitted to spend out of it;тАФand if the owner turns up after three years, then the king should take out of it his own share, which should be equal to that of the owner,тАФgiving the fourth part of the royal share to the man who found the property.

It is quoted in Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (─Аhnika, p. 36a and Vyavah─Бra, p. 27b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Gautama (10.36-38).тАФтАШThose who find lost, property, the owner of which is not known, shall report it to the King. The King shall cause it to be proclaimed and hold it in his custody for a year. After that one-fourth of the value of the property goes to the finder and the remainder to the King.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (16.19-20).тАФтАШProperty entirely given up goes to the King. If it be otherwise, the King with his ministers and the citizens shall administer it.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.33).тАФтАШThe property lost and found, the King shall make over to him to whom it belongs; if he fails to substantiate with proofs his claim to it, he shall he punished with fine equal to the value of the property.тАЩ

Do. (2.172).тАФтАШIf a man obtains from another person the property that had been stolen or lost,тАФwithout reporting it to the KingтАФhe should he fined 96 Paс╣Зas.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.173).тАФтАШWhen a stolen or lost property is brought to the King by the customs-officers or by village-officers, the owner thereof shall get it if he turns up before one year; after that the King shall take it himself.тАЩ

Agnipur─Бс╣Зa (R─Бjadharma, 222.16-17).тАФ(Same as Manu.)

Artha┼Ы─Бstra (p. 96).тАФтАШIf the owner of the lost property proves his ownership, he obtains what had been lost and recovered. If he fails to prove his ownership, he is fined the fifth part of the value of the article: and the article becomes the lawful property of the King; if the owner takes forcible possession of the article lost and found, he is to he fined the first amercement. Property lost and found should remain deposited in the Customs Office; and after three fortnights, it is to he handed over to the rightful owner or surrendered to the royal treasury.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The author explains in what, manner the rightful owner shall establish bis ownership over the lost property.

Whenever any one comes and says тАШthis is my property,тАЩ тАШhe should be questioned in proper form.тАЩтАФтАШQuestioned,тАЩ i.e., examined.

тАЬWhat is the proper form of questioning?тАЭ

The questioning could be done in the following manner:тАФWhat is the article that has been lost? Of what colour? Of what size? What is the number of things? Was it dropped or not dropped? If it was dropped, at which place was it dropped? Whence did you obtain it?

If he gives a correct account of the colour, number and other details; тАШcolourтАЩ of animals, clothes and the like: тАШthe cow or the cloth lost was whiteтАЩ; similarly the тАШnumberтАЩ: тАШthere were ten cows or yokes.тАЩ тАШOther detailsтАЩтАФsuch as, e.g., if it was gold what was its weight, if it was in a lump or a definite shape. If he gives a correct account of all this, then he establishes his ownership, and as such тАШought to receive the property.тАЩ

An тАШaccountтАЩ is called тАШcorrect,тАЩ when it is found that what it describes is in exact agreement with what is known by other means of knowledge.

The mention of тАШcolour, number and other detailsтАЩ is only by way of illustration, and; implies also the producing of witnesses and other evidence of ownership.тАФ(31)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 347), which adds the following notesтАЩтАФтАШanuyojyaс╕етАЩ тАШshould be questionedтАЩ,тАФтАШr┼лpamтАЩ, тАШwhite and so forthтАЩ,тАФтАШsaс╣Еkhy─Б,тАЩ тАШfour, five &cтАЩ,тАФthe term тАШ─БdiтАЩ is meant to include the тАШkindтАЩ character and such other details regarding lost property.

It is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 226);тАФand in Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (─Аhnika, p. 36a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This verse lays down the penalty for preferring a false claim.

He who does not provide a тАШcorrectтАЩтАФtrueтАФaccount of the time and place of the lost articleтАФthat тАШit was lost at such a time and at such a placeтАЩ;тАФтАШcolourтАЩ white and the rest; тАШformтАЩтАФthat тАШit was a piece of cloth, or a pair of petty-coatsтАЩ and so forth; тАШsizeтАЩтАФthat^(тАШ)it was five cubits or seven cubits in lengthтАЩ;тАФif he fails to give a correct account of all this, then he deserves a fine equal to the property to which he had laid a false claim.тАФ(32)

Property that has been lost and found should remain in the charge of specially deputed (officials); and the thieves that he may detect in connection with this, the king shall cause to be killed by an elephant.тАФ(33)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЖрджрджреАрдд рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрдпрд╛рддреН рд╖рд╖реНрдардВ рднрд╛рдЧрдВ рджрд╢рдордВ рджреНрд╡рд╛рджрд╢рдВ рд╡рд╛ рдкреНрд░рдирд╖реНрдЯрд▓рдмреНрдзрд╛рджреН рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдЕрд╡рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдиреЗ рд╜рд░реНрдкрдпреЗрддреН ред рддрддреНрд░ рдкреНрд░рдердореЗ рд╡рд░реНрд╖реЗ рджреНрд╡рд╛рджрд╢реЛ рднрд╛рдЧреЛ рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпреЗ рджрд╢рдорд╕реН рддреГрддреАрдпреЗ рд╖рд╖реНрда рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рд░рдХреНрд╖рд╛рдХреНрд▓реЗрд╢рдХреНрд╖рдпрд╛рдкреЗрдХреНрд╖реЛ рднрд╛рдЧрд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрдГ ред рд╕рддрд╛рдВ рдзрд░реНрдордореН рдЕрдиреБрд╕реНрдорд░рдиреН рд╢рд┐рд╖рд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдПрд╖ рд╕рдорд╛рдЪрд╛рд░ рдЗрддрд┐ рдЬрд╛рдирд╛рдирдГ рее рео.рейрей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШPranaс╣гс╣н─БdhigatanтАЩтАФ that which has been lost and then found, i.e., at first lost and subsequently found.

тАШShould remain in charge of officials specially deputedтАЩтАФwhose chief duty is to take care of the property.

While it is thus kept, if thieves should happen to steal it,тАФthen these thieves the King shall cause to be killed by an elephant.

The specification of the тАШelephantтАЩ can only he with a view to some invisible (transcendental) result.тАФ(33)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

Which particular part of the property is to be taken by the king in any particular case shall depend upon the length of time for which it has been kept by the king (Medh─Бtithi and R─Бghav─Бnanda),тАФor on the trouble involved in keeping it (Medh─Бtithi and Govindar─Бja),тАФor on the character of the owner (Kull┼лka and N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.33), which concludes that dining the first year, the king should hand over to the owner the entire property, keeping nothing for the state,тАФduring the second year he should keep for the state the twelfth part of it,тАФduring the third year, its tenth part,тАФand during the fourth year and onwards, the sixth part; and in every case the fourth part of the royal share should be given to the man who found the property.тАФThis is again quoted in the same work under 2.173, where also the same explanation is accepted.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 778), which declares that whether the king shall take the larger or smaller share shall depend upon the trouble involved in the keeping of the property.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 87), which accepts the explanation given in the Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б, and adds that the rule that the king should take the whole property after the lapse of three years is meant for those cases where the owner of the property is not known; but in cases where it is known that such and such an article has been forgotten here by this or that man,тАФthe property has to be handed over to him, even though he may turn up after the lapse of three years.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 347), which adds the following notes;тАФтАШPraс╣Зaс╣гс╣н─Бdhigat─БtтАЩ means тАШout of the property that was lost, discovered and kept in custody;тАЩтАФthe alternatives regarding the portion to be taken by the king are based upon the amount of trouble involved in the keeping of the property;тАФthis rule is meant for the case of property other than the тАШsingle-hoofedтАЩ and the rest mentioned in Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.174).

It is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 226);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (R─Бjan─лti, p. 265), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШPraс╣Зaс╣гс╣нaтАЩ means тАШfallen away from the possession of the ownerтАФif some such property has been found by the customs-officer or other officers guarding the place, and brought over to the king,тАФthen out of that, if the owner should turn up to claim it during the first year, the king should hand over to him the whole of it,тАФif during the second year, he should keep for the state the twelfth part of it,тАФduring the third year, the tenth part, and during the fourth year and onwards, the sixth part, adding that the increased share is justified by the increased trouble involved in keeping the property for a longer period.

It is quoted in Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 27b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

(verses 8.33-34)

Artha┼Ы─Бstra (p. 96).тАФтАШIn the case of the loss of property in the shape of a biped, the owner shall pay five Paс╣Зas as the fee; in that of one-hoofed animals, 4 Paс╣Зas; in the case of cows and buffaloes, 2 Paс╣Зas; in that of small cattle, one fourth of a Paс╣Зa; in the case of gems and minor metals, five per cent, of the value.тАЩ

Gautama (10.36-38).тАФ(See under 30.)

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.174).тАФтАШThe owner should give to the Under 4 Paс╣Зas in the case of a one-hoofed animal, 5 in the ease of man, two in the ease of buffaloes, camels and cows, and a fourth Paс╣Зa in the case of sheep or goat.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara).тАФтАШIf a man recovers his own property that had been lost, he shall report it to the King; and he shall take it only after he has proved his honesty.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдКрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рдореН рдПрд╡ рддреНрд░реНрдпрдмреНрджрд╛рджреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдЧрддрд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдХрдореН, рди рддреБ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд░реНрдкрдпреЗрддреН ред рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐ рдЙрджреНрдзреГрддрд╖рдбреНрднрд╛рдЧрд╛рджрд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдВ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд░реНрдкрдпреЗрддреН ред рд╖рдбреНрднрд╛рдЧрд╛рджрд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛ рдЪ рдЧреБрдгрд╛рдкреЗрдХреНрд╖рдпрд╛ рд╕рдВрд░рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╢реНрд░рдорд╡реНрдпрдкреЗрдХреНрд╖рдпрд╛ рдЪ рдирд┐рдпрдореНрдпрддреЗ рее рео.рейрей рее

B├╝hler

033 Now the king, remembering the duty of good men, may take one-sixth part of property lost and afterwards found, or one-tenth, or at least one-twelfth.

034 рдкреНрд░рдирд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдзрд┐рдЧрддрдиреН рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдореН ...{Loading}...

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Out of the property that has been lost and found, the king, remembering the duty of good men, shall take the sixth part, or the tenth, or the twelfth.тАФ(34)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдкреНрд░рдирд╖реНрдЯрдореН рдЕрдзрд┐рдЧрддрдВ рдкреНрд░рдирд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдзрд┐рдЧрддрдВ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдВ рдкреНрд░рдирд╖реНрдЯрдВ рдкрд╢реНрдЪрд╛рджреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдЧрддрдореН ред рдЕрдзрд┐рд╖реНрдард┐рддрдВ рдпреБрдХреНрддреИрд╕реН рддрддреНрдкрд░реИрд░реН рдЖрд░рдХреНрд╖рдкреБрд░реБрд╖реИрд╕реН рддрд┐рд╖реНрдареЗрддреН ред рддрдерд╛рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдпрджрд┐ рдХреЗрдЪрди рдЪреМрд░рд╛132 рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрдпреБрд╕реН рддрд╛рдиреН рд░рд╛рдЬрд╛ рдЗрднреЗрди рд╣рд╕реНрддрд┐рдирд╛ рдШрд╛рддрдпреЗрддреН ред рд╣рд╕реНрддрд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдореН133 рдЕрджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрдердореН134 рее рео.рейрек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШShall takeтАЩтАФsiezeтАФeither the sixth or the tenth or the twelfth partтАФof the property lost and found, and make over the remainder to the owner. During the first year, he shall take the twelfth part, during the second year, the tenth part, and during the third year, the sixth part. Or, the option regarding the share may be based upon the amount of trouble entailed in taking care of the property.

тАШRemembering the duty of good men,тАЩтАФi.e., knowing that such is the practice among cultured people.тАФ(34)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 347), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШPraс╣Зaс╣гс╣н─БdhigatamтАЩ, тАШwas first lost and then recoveredтАЩ;тАФтАШyuktaiс╕етАЩ, тАШcarefully devoted to guarding the propertyтАФтАШibhenaтАЩ, тАШby means of an elephantтАЩ;тАФand in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 149). which notes that the тАШguardingтАЩ is to be done by the kingтАЩs officers, and explains тАШibhenaтАЩ as тАШby an elephantтАЩ.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

(verses 8.33-34)

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЕрд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдХрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЕрд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рдпрддреНрдиреЗрди рд░рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердореН рдЗрджрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдпреБрдХреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдЪ рд░рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рдВ рд╣рд╕реНрддрд┐рд╡рдзреЛ рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирдГ рее рео.рейрек рее

B├╝hler

034 Property lost and afterwards found (by the king’s servants) shall remain in the keeping of (special) officials; those whom the king may convict of stealing it, he shall cause to be slain by an elephant.

035 рдордорд╛рдпрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ...{Loading}...

рдордорд╛рдпрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рдпреЛ рдмреНрд░реВрдпрд╛рдиреН
