Viс╣гс╣Зu (8.2-4).тАФтАШThe King cannot be made a witness; nor an ascetic, nor a learned Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, nor a gamester, nor a thief, nor a person who is not his own master, nor a woman, nor a child, nor a perpetrator of violence, nor one overaged, nor one intoxicated or insane, nor a man of ill-repute, nor an outcast, nor one tormented by hunger or thirst, nor one oppressed by a sudden calamity, nor one wholly absorbed in evil passions;тАФnor an enemy or a friend, nor one interested in the subject-matter, nor one who does forbidden acts; nor one formerly perjured; nor an attendant; nor one who, without being appointed, comes and offers his evidence.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.70-71).тАФтАШThe following are not to be made witnesses:тАФWoman, child, aged person, gamester, one intoxicated or insane, one accused of a heinous crime, actor, heretic, forger, one with defective organs, outcast, a near relative, or one related in business, friend, enemy, thief, one addicted to violence, those beset with perceptible faults, one despised (by good men).тАЩ

Baudh─Бyana (1.19.13).тАФ(See under 62.)

N─Бrada (1.157-162).тАФтАШIncompetent witnesses have been declared by the learned to be of five sorts: (1) Actually declared by law to be incompetent, (2) incompetent on account of depravity, (3) incompetent by reason of contradiction, (4) one of uncalled for deposition, (5) one of intervening decease. (1) Learned Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, devotees, aged persons and ascetics are those who have been declared by law to be incompetent, without any reason being given for it;тАФ(2) thieves, robbers, dangerous characters, gamblers and assassins are incompetent by reason of their depravity, there is no truth to be found in them;тАФ(3) if the statements of witnesses called by the King do not agree, they are rendered incompetent by reason of contradiction,тАФ(4) he who, without being appointed to be a witness, comes of his own accord to make a deposition, is called a spy in the law-books and he is unworthy to bear testimony;тАФ(5) where can any person bear testimony, if the claimant is no longer in existence, whose claim should have been heard? Such a person is rendered incompetent by reason of intervening decease.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.177-192).тАФтАШThose must not be examined as witnesses who are interested in the suit; nor friends or associates or enemies or notorious offenders or persons stained with a heavy sin;тАФnor a slave or an impostor, or one not admitted to ┼Ъr─Бddhas; nor a child, nor an oil-presser, nor one intoxicated, nor a mad man, nor a careless man, nor one distressed, nor a gamester, nor one who sacrifices for the whole village;тАФnor one engaged in a long journey, nor a merchant who travels to transmarine countries, nor a religious ascetic, nor one sick or deformed; nor a simple man, nor a learned Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, nor one who neglects religious practices, nor a eunuch nor an actor;тАФnor an atheist, nor an apostate, nor one who has forsaken his wife or his fire, nor one who makes illicit offerings, nor an associate who eats out of the same dish as oneself, nor an adversary, nor a spy, nor a relation, nor one related by the same womb;тАФnor one who has proved an evil-doer, nor a public dancer, nor one who lives by poison, nor a snake-catcher, nor a poisoner, nor an incendiary, nor one who has committed a minor offence;тАФnor one oppressed by fatigue, nor a ferocious man, nor one who has relinquished worldly appetites, nor one penniless, nor a member of the lowest castes, nor one leading a bad life, nor one still a student, nor an oilman nor a dealer in roots;тАФnor one obsessed by a demon, nor an enemy of the King, nor a weather-prophet, nor an astrologer, nor a malicious person, nor one self-sold, nor one of deficient limbs, nor one living by prostitution;тАФnor one with bad nails or black teeth, nor one who betrays his friend, nor a rogue, nor a dealer in spirituous liquor, nor a juggler, nor an avaricious or cruel man, nor an enemy of the company of traders or of an association;тАФnor one who takes animal-life, nor a leather-manufacturer, or a cripple, or an outcast, or a forger, or a quack, or an apostate, or a robber, or one of the KingтАЩs attendants;тАФnor a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa who sells human beings, cattle meat, bones, honey, milk, water or butter; nor a member of a twice-born caste who is addicted to usury;тАФnor one who neglects his duties, nor a judge, nor a bard, nor one who serves low people, nor one who quarrels with his father, nor one who causes dissension. These are the incompetent witnesses. When a heinous crime, or a robbery or adultery or defamation has been committed, the King should not inquire too strictly into the character of the witnesses. A child also cannot be made a witness; nor a woman, nor one man alone, nor a cheat, nor a relation, nor an enemy. By the consent of both parties even one man alone may become a witness in a suit.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (7.29-30).тАФтАШThe motherтАЩs father, the fatherтАЩs brother, the wifeтАЩs brother, maternal uncle, brother, friend and son-in-law are inadmissible as witnesses in all disputes. Persons addicted to adultery or to drinking, gamblers, calumniators, insane, suitering, violent persons and unbelievers cannot act as witnesses.тАЩ

рддреНрд╡рдВ рдореЗ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реА рднрд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдпрд╕реАрддрд┐ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рдХреГрддрд╛ рдзрдирд╡рд┐рд╕рд░реНрдЧрд╛рджрд┐рдХрд╛рд▓реЗ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рддреНрд╡реЗ рдиреГрдкрддрд┐рд░реН рдирд╛рдзреНрдпреЗрд╖рд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рддрд╕реНрдп рд╣рд┐ рд╕рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдВ рджрджрддрдГ рдкрдХреНрд╖рдкрд╛рддрдореН рдЖрд╢рдЩреНрдХреЗрд░рдиреН ред рдкреНрд░рднреБрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рд╡рд╛ рджрджрддреЛ рд╜рдиреНрдпрддрд░рд╕реНрдп рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдирд╛рд╢рдГ ред рди рдЪ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдзрд░реНрдореЗрдг рдкреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯреБрдВ рдпреБрдЬреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрджреНрджреЗрд╢рд╡рд╛рд╕реА рдЪ рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд▓реЗрдЦрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд╕рдВрд╡рджрдпреЗрддреН рддрдерд╛рдкрд┐ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдзрд░реНрдордВ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рди рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЗрддрд┐ рддрджреЗрд╢рд╡рд╛рд╕рд┐рдиреЛ рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрдГ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдХрд░рдгрдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ253 ред

рдХрд╛рд░реБрдХрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рд╕реНрд╡рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпреЛрдкрд░реЛрдзрд╢рдЩреНрдХрдпрд╛ ред рд╕рдВрдЧрддреНрдпрд╛ рдЪ рддреЗ рдЬреАрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ ред рд╕реНрд╡рднрд╛рд╡рд╢реН рдЪреИрд╖ рдЬрд╛рдирдкрджрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдпрддреН рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдВ рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддрд╡рдиреНрддреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ “рдЬреАрд╡рд╛рдорд╣реЗ рд╡рдпрдореН” рдЗрддрд┐ рдЬрд┐рддрд╛рдГ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдХрд╛рджрд┐рднреНрдпреЛ рд░реБрд╖реНрдпрдиреНрддрд┐ ред рддрддрд╢реН рдЪ рд╕рд╛рд░реНрд╡рд▓реМрдХрд┐рдХреА рд╕рдВрдЧрддрд┐рдГ рдХрд╛рд░реБрдХрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдЫрд┐рджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдХрд┐рдВ рдЪ рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрд┐рдкрд░рд┐рд▓рдШреБрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рд╡реГрддреНрддреЗрд╢реН254 рдЪрд▓рдпрд┐рддреБрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╢рдХреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪ рдкрдХреНрд╖рдкрд╛рддрдВ рднрдЬреЗрд░рдиреН ред

рд╢реНрд░реЛрддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╕реНрдп рддреБ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рддреНрд╡реЗ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрддрд╛ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖рд┐рдзреНрдпрддреЗ рд░рд╛рдЬрд╡рдиреН рди рдкреБрдирд░реН рдЕрдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдпрд┐рддрддрдпрд╛255 ред рди рд╣рд┐ рд╢реНрд░реЛрддреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреНрд╡рдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдорд╛рдгреНрдпрдВ рд╡рд┐рд╣рдиреНрддрд┐, рдЬрдирдпрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рддрдГ ред рди рд╣рд┐ рд╢реНрд░реЛрддреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреНрд╡рдВ рд╡рд┐рд╕рдВрд╡рд╛рджрд╣реЗрддреБрддрдпреЛрдкрд▓рдмреНрдзрдореН ред рдПрд╡рдореН рдЙрддреНрддрд░рддреНрд░рд╛рдкрд┐ ред

рдХрд╛рд░реБрдХрд╛рдГ рд╢рд┐рд▓реНрдкреЛрдкрдЬреАрд╡рд┐рдирдГ рд╕реВрдкрдХрд╛рд░рд╛рдпрд╕реНрдХрд╛рд░рд╛рджрдпрдГ ред рдХреБрд╢реАрд▓рд╡рд╛рдГ рдирдЯрдирд░реНрддрдХрдЧрд╛рдпрдирд╛рджреНрдпрд╛рдГ ред рд╢реНрд░реЛрддреНрд░рд┐рдпреЛ рд╡реЗрджрдкрд╛рдардХрдГ ред рдпрд╕реН рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдзреНрдпрдпрдирддрддреНрдкрд░рдГ рд╕ рдЗрд╣ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рд╢реНрд░реЛрддреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреНрд╡рдВ рдХрд░реНрдорд╛рдиреБрд╖реНрдард╛рдиреЛрдкрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред рддреЗрдирд╛рдиреБрд╖реНрдард╛рдирдкрд░рд╕реНрдп рддрджреНрд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдзрддрдпрд╛ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрд╕реНрдереЛ рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордЪрд╛рд░реА ред рдкрд░рд┐рд╡реНрд░рд╛рдЬрдХрдкрд╛рдЦрдгреНрдбрд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрдзрд╛рд░рд┐рдгрд╕реН рддреБ рдХреБрд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддрд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдПрд╡рд╛рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд╛рдГ ред рд╕рдЩреНрдЧреЗрднреНрдпреЛ рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рд░реНрдЧрддрд╛ рд╡реЗрджрд╕рдВрдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕рд┐рдиреЛ рдЧреГрд╣рд╕реНрдерд╛рдГ ред рд╕рдЩреНрдЧрдГ рдЕрднреНрдпрд╛рд╕рддреЛ256 рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпреЛрдкрднреЛрдЧрдГ, рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрдердХрд░реНрдорд╛рд░рдореНрднреЛ рд╡рд╛ рее рео.ремрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

At the time that one is lending out money, the king should not he made a party to the transaction by being requested to the effect тАШyon shall he my witness.тАЩ Because if the king gave evidence, people would suspect him of partiality,тАФbeing all-powerful as he is; and tinтАЩs would lead to the detriment of the interest of one or the other;тАФnor would it be proper to question the king in the same manner as an ordinary witness. Though being an inhabitant of the same place, the king might corroborate statements by means of written notes, yet what is forbidden is his appearance as a regular witness of the ordinary class.

As for craftsmen and the rest, they should not be made witnesses for fear of injury to their business. These men live by the good-will of the people; and it is human nature that though men know (that their case is false), yet the mere consideration that they are losing it leads them to bear a grudge against the witnesses and others; and thus the universal goodwill of the artisan and the rest becomes lost, further, in as much as these men are of mean nature, they are prone to being diverted from the path of honesty, and hence becoming partial.

As regards the тАШVedic scholar,тАЩ what is denied is not his trustworthiness, but the propriety of his appearing as a witness; just as in the case of the king. Because the foot of the man being a тАШVedic scholarтАЩ does not deprive him of his trustworthiness; on the contrary, it only intensifies it to a special degree; and (his for the same reason that Vedic scholarship has never been found to be the instigator of perjury.

Similarly with those that follow.

тАШCraftsmenтАЩтАФthose that make a living by some crafts; such as cooks and the like.

тАШActorsтАЩтАФdancers, singers and so forth.

тАШVedic scholarтАЩтАФone who studies the Veda; the person meant here is one who is always engaged in Vedic study. Or, тАШVedic scholarshipтАЩ may be taken as indicating the performance of religions rites; and in that, case the prohibition would apply to one who is engaged in such performance;тАФthe work of the witness being prejudicial to such rites.

тАШOne in holy ordersтАЩтАФthe Religious student. As for those who merely wear the badge of the Wandering Mendicant, or of the heretical orders,тАФthese are inadmissible on the ground of their following the heretical scriptures.

тАШOne toko has renounced attachmentsтАЩтАФThis stands for those householders who have тАШrenounced the Veda.тАЩ тАШAttachmentтАЩ means either the repeated enjoyment of sensual objects, or the undertaking of acts for ordinary worldly purposesтАФ.(65)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШKu┼Ы─лlavaтАЩтАФтАШActors, dancers singers and so forthтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШactorsтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa);тАФтАШactors and so forthтАЩ (Govindar─Бja and Kull┼лka);тАФтАШsingersтАЩ (Nandana).

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 66);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 10a);тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 281);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б, (Vyavah─Бra, p. 177);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (80b);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 49b), which reproduces Medh─БtithiтАЩs, explanation.

рдЕрдзреНрдпрдзреАрдирд╢рдмреНрджреЛ рд╜рддреНрдпрдиреНрддрдкрд░рддрдиреНрддреНрд░рдЧрд░реНрднрджрд╛рд╕рд╛рджреМ рд░реВрдвреНрдпрд╛ рд╡рд░реНрддрддреЗ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреБ рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШOne wholly dependentтАЩ:тАФthis term is applied by usage to the horn slave and such other persons who are entirely subservient to other persons.

Others read тАШadhy─Бdh─лna,тАЩ which means a prisoner.

тАШOne under pupilageтАЩтАФthe son or the pupil (of either party), who is entirely under the sway of the Teacher. Or the term тАШvaktaryaс╕етАЩ may he taken as standing for one whose body has been deformed by leprosy or some such disease.

тАШDasyuтАЩ here stands for the servant engaged on fixed wages,тАФso called because he тАШaccomplishes workтАЩ (), as explained by the followers of the Nirukta. Since such a servant is engaged on daily wages, he is not absolutely dependent on others; that is why he has been mentioned separately. As persons belonging to this class live upon the wages earned, they would become deprived of their livelihood (if they deposed against their employer); and further, as their living is small, they are liable to corruption, hence untrustworthy also. As for the thief or robber (who also is called тАШdasyuтАЩ), as he is mentioned by a separate word (in the next verse), he cannot be taken as spoken of here by means of the term тАШdasyu.тАЩ Or, the term тАШdasyuтАЩ may stand for a hard-hearted person, one of cruel disposition.

тАШVikarmakс╣Ыс╣нтАЩ is one who adopts an occupation forbidden by the scriptures; e.g., the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa adopting the occupation of the Kс╣гatriya, or the Kс╣гatriya that of the Vai┼Ыya and so forth.

тАШToo old.тАЩтАФOne who is too old is subject to lapses of memory.

тАШMinor,тАЩтАФone who is too young and not yet entered business.

тАШA single personтАЩтАФin as much as тАШat least threeтАЩ has already been laid down,тАФwhich leaves no possibility of citing a single witnessтАФthe prohibition of тАШa single personтАЩ is to be taken as permitting under certain circumstances, the citing of only two witnesses. Otherwise, in a case where, it being laid down that a document must be attested by three persons,тАФpeople might be led to think that if the third attestor is not present, the other two persons may write, but they are not admissible as a тАШwitness.тАЩ

тАШPerson belonging to the lowest classтАЩтАФ the barbarian, the Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla and so forth. These are percluded here, because they might be regarded as admissible by reason of their having their origin in the ┼Ъ┼лdra-caste (who is permitted in verse 60).

тАЬOne with defective organsтАЩтАФ with his perceptive faculties rendered defective by bodily disease.тАФ(66)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШVaktavyaс╕етАЩтАФтАШSon or pupil or such others as can be ordered aboutтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi and R─Бmacandra);тАФтАШone whose body is disfigured by leprosy or such other diseasesтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, alternative);тАФтАШdespised by reason of misconductтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa, Kull┼лka, R─Бghav─Бnanda and Nandana).

тАШDasyu,тАЩтАФтАШServant receiving wagesтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi. Govindar─Бja and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШcruel manтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, alternative, Kulj┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda); тАШlow-caste manтАЩ (Nandana)тАШmurdererтАЩ (R─Бmacandra).

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 66)тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 10a);тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 281);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 177);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (30b), which explains тАШadhyadh─лnaс╕етАЩ as one who is held in bondage;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 49b), which reproduces Medh─БtithiтАЩs explanations.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШAfflictedтАЩтАФby the death of relatives and friends.

тАШIntoxicatedтАЩтАФsenseless through wine.

тАШDementedтАЩтАФseized by epilepsy, or obsessed by ghosts.

тАШTormented by hunger or thirstтАЩтАФSuffering from the pangs of hunger or thirst.

тАШFatigueтАЩтАФcaused by much physical labour, involved in walking long distances, engaging in battle and so forth;тАФтАШoppressedтАЩ by it.

тАШLoveтАЩтАФDesire for intercourse with women. One who is separated from his beloved, as also one who is too much with her,тАФboth of them are untrustworthy, on account of their mind being engrossed in the loved one, or in the fear of being separated from her.

тАШIn rageтАЩтАФwho is too angry with some person,тАФeven other than the parties of the suit; such a person having his mind entirely taken up with rage is unable to perceive things rightly, or to remember them correctly.

тАШThiefтАЩ;тАФeven though the thief also is тАШone who adopts a forbidden occupation,тАЩ yet since ho has been mentioned separately, it has to be explained on the analogy of the expression тАШgo-bal─лvardaтАЩ (тАШcows and hullsтАЩ).тАФ(67)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 66);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 10a);тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 281);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 177);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (30b);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 49b).

рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд╕рджреГрд╢рд╛ рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрд╛рдГ ред рдпрдГ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрддрд░реЛ рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрдГ рд╕ рд╡рд┐рд╕рджреГрд╢рдВ рд╢рдЩреНрдХреНрдпрдорд╛рдирдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрднрд╛рд╡рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рджрд┐рд╢рдиреН рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реНрдпреЗ рди рд╢реНрд░рджреНрдзреЗрдпрд╡рдЪрдиреЛ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рдпрддрд╕реН рддрдерд╛рднреВрддреЗрди рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрднреВрдд рдПрд╡ рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рд╕ рд╣рд┐ рддрд╕реНрдп рд╕рджреГрд╢рдГ ред рд╕рджреГрд╢рд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд╣рд┐ рд╕рдорд╛рдирджреЗрд╢рд╕реНрдерд╛рдирдореН262 рдЗрддрд░реЗрддрд░рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдЬреНрдЮрддреНрд╡рдВ рдЪ рд╕рдВрднрд╛рд╡реНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЗрддрд░рд╕реНрдп рддреБ рддрддреНрдкреНрд░рджреЗрд╢рд╕рдВрдирд┐рдзрд┐рд░реН рдпрддреНрдиреЗрди рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдпрдГ ред рд╕рджреГрд╢рдпреЛрд╕реН рддреНрд╡реН рдФрдЪрд┐рддреНрдпрд╛рддреН263 рд╕рд┐рджреНрдз рдПрд╡ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рд╣реАрдирд╕реНрдп рд╣реАрдирдЧреБрдгреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╕рджреГрд╢рд╛рджреН рдЧреНрд░рд╣реАрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рди рддреВрддреНрдХреГрд╖реНрдЯрдЧреБрдгреЛ рди рдЧреНрд░рд╣реАрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рд╕рд╛рджреГрд╢реНрдпрдВ рдЬрд╛рддреНрдпрд╛ рд╢рд┐рд▓реНрдкрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд╡рд╛ рдЧреБрдгреЗрди рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрдпрд╛ рд╡рд╛ рд╢реНрд░реБрддрд╛рдзреНрдпрдпрдирд╛рджрд┐рдХрдпрд╛ рд╕рдорд╛рдирд╢реАрд▓рддрдпрд╛ рдЪ ред рдПрддрдЪреН рдЪ рдирд╛рддрд┐рдорд╣рддрд┐ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпреЗ рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рди рд╣рд┐ рд╣реАрдирдЧреБрдгреЗрд╖реБ рдкреНрд░рдпрдпрд┐рддрддрд╛ рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪреАрдпрддреЗ ред

рдЕрдиреНрддреНрдпрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдЪрдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓рд╢реНрд╡рдкрдЪрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рддрд╛рджреГрд╢рд╛ рдПрд╡реНрдЖрдиреНрддреНрдпрдпреЛрдирдпрдГ ред рдЕрдиреНрддреЗ рднрд╡рд╛ рдЕрдиреНрддреНрдпрд╛рдГ ред рд╕рд╛ рдпреЛрдирд┐рд░реН рдЙрддреНрдкрддреНрддрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рдгрдВ рдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ ред рдкреНрд░рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдВ рдЪреИрддрддреН ред рдпреЗ рд╕рдорд╛рдирд╛ рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рд╢рд┐рд▓реНрдкрд╢реАрд▓рд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рд╕реН рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЗрд╣рд╛рдиреБрдХреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╡рдгрд┐рдХреНрдХрд╛рд░реБрдХреБрд╢реАрд▓рд╡рд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдореН, рд╣реЗрддреЛрдГ рд╕рдорд╛рдирддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рее рео.ремрео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In the case where both plaintiff and defendant are males, the evidence of females is not admissible; when however the suit lies between a male and a female, or between two females,тАФthere women do appear as witnesses. But there is no restriction as to women aloneтАФand no men,тАФbeing witnesses for women. In fact it is only in suits relating entirely to males that woman are admissible as witnesses only in special cases, since the only reason that is given for excluding women is their fickleness, but there are some women who are as truthful as the best propounded of the Veda and as steady.

тАШFor twice-born persons similar twite-born menтАЩ As for the twice-born person of the higher class, and hence more trustworthy,тАФhe may make certain statements whose veracity may be doubted,тАФand hence his words are not absolutely reliable. In fact the witness should be one who is accepted by the parties as reliable; and this is possible only when he belongs to the same class; as it is only men of the same class who by reason of living in the same place are expected to know all about one anotherтАЩs transactions; while for others, it would be difficult to come into sufficiently close proximity with men of the lower strata; which, on the other hand, is always available for men of the same class. Similarly for men of inferior qualities, men of the same kind are to be witnesses; though this does not mean that persons with higher qualifications are not admissible.

The тАШsimilarityтАЩ here meant may beтАФ(a) in caste, or (b) in occupation, or (c) in qualities, or (d) in action, such as the studying of the Veda and so forth, or (e) in character.

But all this restriction is not meant to be applicable to very important suits; because as a rule much reliability is not found in men with inferior qualifications.

тАШFar men of the lowest classтАЩтАФsuch as the Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla and the restтАФmen of the same low class. The compound тАШantya-yonayaс╕етАЩ is to be expounded as those who have their yoni or origin in the lowermost stratum.

This is meant to be only illustrative. The same rule holds good regarding other classes of people,тАФsuch as craftsmen, actors and so forth,тАФfor whom also the witnesses should be тАШsimilarтАЩтАФin caste, occupation, character, etc.; though these have not been mentioned in the text; because the same reason is present in their case also.тАФ(68)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШSadс╣Ы┼Ы─Бс╕етАЩтАФтАШInhabitants of the same place, of the same caste, same occupations, same qualificationsтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШof the same casteтАЩ (Kull┼лka) тАШof the same caste and equally virtuousтАЩ (Govindar─Бja).

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 665);тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.68);тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 214);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 9b);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru, 30b);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 47a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (16.30).тАФтАШLet the King admit women as witnesses regarding women; for twice-born men, twice-born men of the same caste; good ┼Ъ┼лdras for ┼Ъ┼лdras, and men of low birth for men of the low caste.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.69).тАФтАШOr all men may be witnesses for all castes.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.153).тАФтАШAmong companies of artisans, or guilds of merchants, artisans or merchants shall be witnesses; and members of an association among other members of the association; persons living outside, among those living outside; and women among women.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.156).тАФтАШIf in a company of artisans or guilds of merchants, or in any other association, anyone falls out with his associates, they should not bo made witnesses against him; for they all are his enemies.тАЩ

рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЗрд╖реБ рд╕реНрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╡реГрддреНрддрдпрдГ рдЖрддреНрдордиреЛ рдЬрд╛рддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рд╕рд╛рджреГрд╢реНрдпреЗрди рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрдГ рд╕реНрдпреБрдГ, рдЕрд░реНрдердкреНрд░рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд╛рд░реЛ рд╜рдиреНрдпреЗ рд╡рд╛рд░реНрдерд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд┐рдирдГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдЪ рдкреНрд░рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЕрд╕реНрдп рддрд╛рдкрд╕рдкреНрд░рд╡реНрд░рдЬрд┐рддрд╡рдгрд┐рдХреНрдХреБрд╢реАрд▓рд╡рдЧреЛрдкрд╛рд▓рдХрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рд╕рд╛рджреГрд╢реНрдпреЗрди рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрдГ рд╕реНрдпреБрдГ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪ рд╜рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд╡рд┐рдЯреНрд╢реВрджреНрд░рдпреЛрдирдпрдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдпрдирд┐рд░реНрджреЗрд╢реЛ рд╜рдпрдВ рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЗрднреНрдпрд╕реН рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд░ тАФ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In the case of anything done in the interior of a house, or in a forest, or in the case of injury to the body,тАФany person who may be cognisant of the facts may give evidence on behalf of the parties to the suit.тАФ(69)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШIn the interior of a house,тАЩтАФany sudden act that may be committed, in the shape of defamation or assault or incest or theft or other crimes;тАФin the forestтАФif any of the said crimes are committed;тАФor when the body is hurt by robbers or by other similar persons, and property is robbed;тАФor when some one has stood security for a debt, but there are no witnesses to it; or even though there were any, they could not wait till the time of the trial;тАФor when the debt is repaid in private;тАФin all such cases, any person тАШwho may be cognisant of the factsтАЩтАФ who may have witnessed the transaction in question,тАФthere being no restriction as to caste, or of similarity of standing and the like.

The phrase тАШin the interior of a houseтАЩ stands lor a secluded place in general; so that uninhabited temples and such places also become included. The mention of the тАШforestтАЩ also indicates the same thing.

Others have explained the clause тАШ┼Ыar─лrasy─Бpi v─БtyayeтАЩ to mean тАШwhen the entire structure of the case is going to fall through, any man can be cited as a witnessтАЩ; i.e., when a case having been instituted is going to fall through, and there is no chance Of its being re-instituted, then there should be no restriction as to the caste, or sex, or age, or rank or relationship and the like. This is what is further explained in the following verse.тАФ(69)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 671), which adds that тАШanubh─БviтАЩ means an eye-witness, one who has actually seen the occurrence;тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 214);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 181), which explainsтАЩ тАШanubh─БviтАЩ as тАШone conversant with the facts of the caseтАЩ;тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (3a), which explains тАШanubh─БviтАЩ as тАШone who has had anubh─Бva, experienceтАЩ;тАФand in тАШV─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 51a), which has the same explanation of тАШanubh─Бvi.тАЩ

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдирдиреБ рдЪрд╛рд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрд╛рджреН рдмрд╛рд▓рд╛рджрдпрдГ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рддреНрд╡реЗ рдирд┐рд░рд╕реНрддрд╛рдГ ред рди рд╣реНрдпреН рдПрддреЗ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдореН рдЕрд╡рдзрд╛рд░рдпрд┐рддреБрдВ рд╢рдХреНрдиреБрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ рдмреБрджреНрдзреЗрд░реН рдЕрд╕реНрдереИрд░реНрдпрд╛рддреН рдкрд░рд┐рдкрд╛рдХрд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рд░реН рджреЛрд╖реИрд╕реН рддрджреН рдЖрдкрджрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкреНрд░рд╕реВрдпрдорд╛рдирд╕рдордЮреНрдЬрд╕рдореН рдЗрддрд┐, рди рд╣реНрдпреН рдЖрдкрджрд┐ рд╢рдХреНрддрд┐рд░реН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╡рд┐рд░реНрднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рдпреЛ рд╣рд┐ рдмреНрд░реВрдпрд╛рддреН “рди рд╡рд╛270 рдирд╡реМрджрдирдГ рдкрдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ; рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдЧреНрдиреМ рддреБ рдкрдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ рддрд╛рджреГрдЧреН рдПрддрддреН рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред

рдиреИрд╖ рджреЛрд╖рдГ ред рдПрд╡рдореН рдЕрд░реНрдердореН рдПрд╡реЛрддреНрддрд░рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХ рдЖрд░рднреНрдпрддреЗ рее рео.ренреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The mention of тАШwomanтАЩ thus permits departure from the rule laying down the sex of the witness; that of тАШminorтАЩ and тАШaged personтАЩ that prescribing his age; and that of тАШpupilтАЩ makes an exception in favour of relations in general;тАФthis being mentioned only by way of illustration, indicating the admissibility of persons similarly circumstanced; hence the restrictions regarding caste or position also are not to be strictly observed. But dear friends, or enemies or persons of proved dishonesty.are not admissible in any case; nor any one in whom there is suspicion of the presence of motives for telling a lie, or those who have been found to be unreliable. Those however who have been found to be only slightly unreliable, but otherwise endowed with superior qualifications, may, in some cases, serve as witnesses. On this point we have the following assertionтАФтАШThere may be one man among a thousand who would not tell a lie, under the influence of friendship or enmity or some other interested motive.тАЩ

In the event of other witnesses not forthcoming, even a woman тАШmay give evidence,тАЩтАФthis clause being construed from the preceding verse.

тАШPupilтАЩтАФindicates tutorial and sacerdotal relationship in general.

тАШRelativeтАЩтАФthis term makes an exception in favour of what cannot be avoided; the sense being that even though the man may bear some relationship to the parties, if he is not very nearly related, he may be admitted. Hence the cousin, the uncle, the brother-in-law and such other near relatives should not he made witnesses, the name тАШrelativeтАЩ being, in ordinary usage, applicable to these persons.

тАШSlaveтАЩтАФindicates the relation of ownership in general; that is why the master, the teacher and the priest are not to be made witnesses in any kind of suit. The term тАШslaveтАЩ stands for the born slave and тАШservantтАЩ for one who serves on wages.

тАЬThe minor and others have been excluded on the ground of incapacity,тАФthey are incapable of realising what is evidence, because of their mind being fickle and undeveloped; so that any exception in their favour, oven in connection with emergencies, cannot he right. For certainly even in an emergency they do not acquire the right capacity. In fact, such an exception would he similar to the case where a man having said тАШfresh rice shall not he cooked,тАЩ adds тАШbut if there is no fire it shall be cooked?тАЩ

There is no force in this objection; as it is in view of these considerations that we have the next verse.тАФ(70)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This rule refers to the cases contemplated in the preceding verse (Govindar─Бja and Kull┼лka),тАФтАШto the last of these cases onlyтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 671), which adds that the women and others mentioned here to be admissible as witnesses should be understood to be only such as are free from the disqualifications of being prejudiced or wickedly inclined and so forth.

It is quoted in Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 214);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 70);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 181);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (32a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

(verses 8.70-72)

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, pp. 670-671).тАФтАШIn cases of disobedience of the royal edict, of adultery, of violent crimes, of theft and of assaults,тАФone should not be particular regarding the admissibility of witnesses. In the case of occurrences within a house, or at night, or outside the village, if a suit is brought forward, the King shall not be very particular regarding the admissibility of witnesses.тАЩ

U┼Ыanas (Apar─Бrka, pp. 670-671).тАФтАШA slave, a blind man, a deaf man, women, children, very aged persons and others,тАФif they are not connected with the partiesтАФmay he witnesses in the case of crimes of violence. All those persons who have been declared to he incompetent witnesses may he admitted as witnesses according to the gravity of the case. But even so a child, or a single person, or a woman, or forger, or a relative or an enemy should not be admitted; as they would he found to depose falsely; the child would do it through ignorance, the woman through inherent untruthfulness, the forger by reason of his being a habitual wrong-doer, the relations through their affection, and the enemy as a means of revenge.тАЩ

Gautama (13.9).тАФтАШThere can be no objection against any witness in a case of criminal hurt.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (8.6).тАФтАШIn cases of theft, of violence, abuse and assault, and of adultery, the competence of witnesses should not be examined too strictly.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.72).тАФтАШAll persons may be witnesses in cases of adultery, of theft, of assault and of violent crimes.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.189).тАФтАШIn cases of heinous crime, or robbery, or adultery, or one of the two kinds of assault, he should not enquire too strictly into the character of the witnesses.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.188).тАФтАШSlaves, impostors and other incompetent witnesses enunciated shall nevertheless be witnesses in suits of especially grave character.тАЩ

рд░рд╛рдЧрджреНрд╡реЗрд╖рдзрдирд▓реЛрднрд╛рджрд┐рд╕рд╛рдзрд╛рд░рдгрдореН рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рдирддрдГ рдкрд░реАрдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдореН ред рддрдЪреН рдЪреЛрдХреНрддрдореН рдПрд╡ ред рдЙрддреНрд╕рд┐рдХреНрддрдЪреЗрддрд╕рдГ рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддреНрдпреИрд╡реЛрдкрдкреНрд▓реБрддрд╛ рдЕрдзреАрд░рдзрд┐рдпрдГ рее рео.ренрез рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The meaning of this is as follows:тАФ

The present verse is not meant to admit such minors and others as are either in absolute bondage or with disordered minds,тАФand hence entirely inadmissible. If it did so, it would be laying down something wholly new. The persons indicated by this as admissible are, in fact, those who are capable of understanding things, but whose minds are not quite steady. And what is meant is that the words of such persons should be fully examined with the help of reasonings, and they should be admitted as reliable only if it is found that they speak coherently and are not tainted with any suspicious signs of corruption. This is what is meant by the wordsтАФIn the event of their deposing falsely the judge should make up his mind regarding the speech being irregular. That is to say, the falsity of the deposition should be deduced from its irregularity;тАФthis тАШirregularityтАЩ consisting in the incoherence of the statements and the absence of explicitness and clear utterance.

All this is meant to indicate the condition of the minor and other persons; the meaning being that those who have been reduced, either by age or by disease, to a condition in which desiring to say one thing they utter something quite different, and that also indistinctly, should not be made witnesses. This ground for inadmissibility as witness can always be ascertained by direct perception; the other grounds,тАФsuch as the presence of love or hatred or avarice and so forth,тАФcan be found out only by investigation; as has been already declared.

тАШSo also in the cate of men with disordered minds,тАЩтАФi.e., those who are inherently of unsound mind.тАФ(71)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

Nandana is misrepresented by Hopkins.

This verse is quoted in Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 196), which explains тАШUtsiktamanas─БmтАЩ as тАШimpatientтАЩ;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (32b).

In all cases of violence, of theft and adultery, and of assault, verbal and corporeal,тАФhe shall not investigate the character of the witnesses.тАФ(72)

рд╕рд╣реЛ рдмрд▓рдореН, рддрджреН рдЖрд╢реНрд░рд┐рддреНрдп рдпрддреН рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ рддрддреН рд╕рд╛рд╣рд╕рдореН ред рд░рд╛рдЬрд╡рд╛рд▓реНрд▓реНрднреНрдпреЗрди рдорд╣рд╛рдкрдХреНрд╖рддрдпрд╛ рд╕реНрд╡рд╢рд░реАрд░рдмрд▓реЗрди рдмрд▓рд╡рджрд╛рд╢реНрд░рдпреЗрдг рд╡рд╛ рдпрджреН рдЕрдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдХрд░рдгрдВ рддрддреН рд╕рд╛рд╣рд╕рдореН, рдпрдерд╛271 рд╡рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдкрд╛рдЯрдирд╛рдЧреНрдирд┐рджрд╛рд╣рдХреЗрд╢рдЫреЗрджрд╛рджрд┐ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреН рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдореН ред рдЕрддреНрд░ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгреЛ рди рдкрд░реАрдХреНрд╖реНрдпрд╛рдГ ред “рдЧреГрд╣рд┐рдгрдГ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдгрдГ” (рдореНрдзреН рео.ремреи) рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡рдорд╛рджрд┐рд░реВрдкрдкрд░реАрдХреНрд╖рд╛рддреНрд░ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖рд┐рдзреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрд╛ рддреБ рд╡реНрдпрднрд┐рдЪрд╛рд░рд╣реЗрддреБрддрдпрд╛ рд╢рдЩреНрдХреНрдпрддреЗ рд░рд╛рдЧрджреНрд╡реЗрд╖рдзрдирд▓реЛрднрд╛рджрд┐рд░реВрдкрд╛ рд╕рд╛ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпреИрд╡ ред рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрдореВрд▓рддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдГ рд╕реНрдореГрддреЗрд░реН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН рее рео.ренреи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШS─Бhasa,тАЩ тАШviolenceтАЩ;тАФтАШtahaтАЩ means тАШforceтАЩ; and what is done by force is тАШs─Бhasa,тАЩ тАШviolenceтАЩ; whenever an improper act is done by a man, either on the strength of his being the kingтАЩs favourite, or of his having a large following, or of his own bodily strength, or of the help of some powerful person,тАФit is called тАШs─Бhasa,тАЩ тАШviolence.тАЩ e.g., the tearing of cloths, the burning by fire, the cutting of the hands, and so forth.

The rest are all well known.

In such oases the character of the witnesses need not be investigated;тАФthis precludes the investigation that has been laid down above, under verse 60, et seq.; that investigation, on the other hand, which bears upon doubt regarding the manтАЩs reliability, on account of the presence of love, hatred, avarice and the like,тАФthat must be done. The placing of this limitation upon what is laid down in the text is justified by the consideration that the present treatise is known to have a visible source, in the person of a personal author; as has been explained before.тАФ(72)

On a conflict among witnesses, the king shall accept the majority; in the case of equality (of number) those possessed of superior qualifications; and in the case of conflict between equally qualified witnesses, the best among the twice-born.тАФ(73)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдпрддреНрд░ рднреВрдорд┐рднрд╛рдЧрд╛рджреМ рд╡рд┐рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрддреНрддрд┐рд░реН рджреНрд╡рд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдВ рдЪ рднреЛрдЧрд╕рд╛рдзрдирдВ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгреЛ рдирд┐рд░реНрджрд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдГ ред рддреЗ рдЕ рдХреЗрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд┐рдиреЛ рднреЛрдЧрдореН рдЖрд╣реБрд░реН рдЕрдкрд░реЗ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд░реНрдерд┐рдирдГ ред рддрддреНрд░ рдмрд╣реВрдирд╛рдВ рд╡рдЪрдирдВ рдЧреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдпрдореН ред рд╕рдорд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпреЗрд╖реБ рддреБ рдпреЗ рдЧреБрдгреИрд░реН рдЙрддреНрдХреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛ рдмрд╣реБрдЧреБрдгрд╛ рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рдПрдХреЗрди рд╡рд╛ рдЧреБрдгреЗрди рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╛рд░реНрдереЛрдкрдХрд╛рд░рд┐рдгрд╛272 рд╕рд╛рддрд┐рд╢рдпреЗрди рдпреБрдХреНрддрд╛рдГ ред рдЧреБрдгрд╡рддрд╛рдВ рд╕рдордЧреБрдгрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рднреЗрджреЗ рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рд░реН рдЖрджрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛ ред рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕рд╛рдореНрдпреЗ рд╢рдкрдердГ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрджреН рд╡рд╛ рддрддреНрд╕рдорд╛рдирдореН273 ред

рдмрд╣реБрддреНрд╡рдВ рдкрд░рд┐рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдмрд╣реВрдирд╛рдВ рд╡рдЪрдирдВ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгреАрдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рджреНрд╡реИрдзрдВ рдкрд░рд╕реНрдкрд░рд╡рд┐рд░реБрджреНрдзрд╛рд░реНрдерд╛рднрд┐рдзрд╛рдирдореН рее рео.ренрей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In a dispute over the possession of land, eg., when several witnesses have been cited in proof of possession, if some depose to possession by the plaintiff, while others to that of the defendant,тАФthen the king shall accept the statement of the majority.

When the number on both sides are equal, he shall Accept the statement of those тАШpossessed of superior qualifications,тАЩтАФi.e., of a larger number of qualities, or of a single quality, but in a very large degree, very much to the benefit of mankind.

When there is a conflict between two equally qualified witnesses, preference has to be given to the higher caste.

Lastly, when both sets are equal in all respects, then recourse should he had to ordeals, or some other similar means of discrimination.

тАШAccept the majorityтАЩтАФi.e., accept as true the statement of the majority.

тАШConflictтАЩтАФmaking contradictory statements.тАФ(73)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШDvijottam─БnтАЩтАФBr─Бhmaс╣ЗasтАЩ (Govindar─Бja and N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa;тАФтАШrighteous Br─Бhmaс╣ЗasтАЩ (Kull┼лka and Raghav─Бnanda).

This verse is quoted in Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 211);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (32a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (8.39).тАФтАШIf there is contradictory evidence, let the King decide by the majority of witnesses; if there is equality in number, by superiority in virtue; if there is parity in virtue, by the evidence of the best among the twice-born.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.78, 80).тАФтАШWhen there is contradiction, the evidence of the majority should be accepted; when the number of witnesses is equal on both sides, then the evidence of those better qualified should he accepted; when there is contradiction among witnesses equally qualified, the evidence of those should be accepted who are possessed of the best qualifications. Even after the witnesses have deposed, if other witnesses, either better qualified or in larger numbers, come forward to depose to the contrary, the former witnesses should be rejected as false.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.229).тАФтАШWhen there is conflicting evidence, the majority of witnesses decides the matter. If the number of witnesses is equal on both sides, the testimony of those should be accepted as correct whose veracity is not liable to suspicion. If the number of such witnesses is equal on both sides, the testimony of those should be accepted who are possessed of a superior memory.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (7.35).тАФтАШIn a conflict among witnesses, the testimony of the majority should be accepted; when the number is equal on both sides, the testimony of the more virtuous ones; when the virtuous witnesses are divided, the testimony of those specially eminent for the performance of righteous acts; whenever those are divided, the testimony of those endowed with superior memory.тАЩ

Evidence based upon what is directly seen and is heard is admissible; and a witness, telling the truth in such cases, does not fall off from spiritual merit or worldly prosperity.тАФ(74)

рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рд░реНрдерд╣рд╛рдиреЗрд╢реН рдЪ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рд╛рд╡рдЧрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рее рео.ренрек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАЬIt has already been said (under 69) that evidence may be given by any person who may be тАШcognisant of the facts of the caseтАЩ; why then should any inadmissibility be suspected, in view of which it is now said that evidence on the basis of what is seen and heard is admissible?тАЭ

Our answer is as follows:тАФIt has been said that the witness shall be warned by the person who he is going to file his suit, sayingтАФтАШyou shall be my witnessтАЩ; so that people might think that if a person has not been so warned, he shall be inadmissible; it is in view of this that the present declaration has been made. The meaning is that if a person happens to be close by when a certain transaction is being gone through and is cognisant of the facts, he is admissible as a witness, even though ho may not have been warned by the parties, saying тАШyou will please bear in mind this transaction between us.тАЩ

The term тАШdirectlyтАЩ has to be construed with тАШwhat, is seenтАЩ as also with тАШwhat is heardтАЩ; so that if some one bears of a fact from one person, and from the former some one else hears it, then the person who has heard of it at second hand is not admissible as a witness; as it is only on hearsay, and not on the basis of any direct source of knowledge, that the man would know that тАШthis man has committed such and such a crime,тАЩ or that тАШhe owes such and such a sum to that man.тАЩ

тАШWhat is directly seenтАЩтАФmeans direct knowledge of the facts of the case, bearing upon loan-transactions, assaults and so forth; i.e., when these occurrences are actually wen with the eye; or тАШdirectly heardтАЩ in the case of verbal assaults,тАФsuch as тАШI shall take away your wife,тАЩ and so forth,тАФand such admissions by the debtor as that тАШI have borrowed such and such a sum from that man,тАЩ and so forth.

Though the root тАШdс╣Ы┼Ыi,тАЩ тАШto see,тАЩ denotes all forms of apprehension (and as such includes auditory perception also), yet тАШwhat is heardтАЩ has been mentioned separately for the purpose of filling up the metro. All that is meant is that тАШa person who has a right knowledge of the facts is admissible as a witnessтАЩ; and the phrase тАШwhat is seenтАЩ is meant to stand for all valid kinds of knowledge; so that what is known by inference is also regarded as тАШknownтАЩ; similarly also all trustworthy Revelation, which is an authoritative means of knowledge in regard to imperceptible things also.

The second half of the verse is merely re-iterative, the telling of truth having been already enjoined before, and the fact of the liar losing both spiritual merit and worldly prosperity being already known from other sources of know ledge.тАФ(74)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Vyavah─Бratattva (p. 26);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (27a), which says that тАШsamakс╣гadar┼ЫanaтАЩ and тАШ┼Ыravaс╣ЗaтАЩ stand for all forms of valid knowledge, hence the meaning is that that man is a witness who possesses a right knowledge of the subject-matter of the enquiry;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 44b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Bodh─Бyana (1.19.7).тАФтАШIn order to gain the good opinion of men, a witness shall give evidence in accordance with what he has seen or heard.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (8.13-14).тАФтАШThe evidence of witnesses is of two kindsтАФwhat was seen and what was heard. Witnesses are free from blame if they give true evidence.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.148).тАФтАШHe should he considered as a witness who has witnessed a deed with his own ears or eyes; with his ears, if he has heard another man speaking; with his eyes, if he has seen something himself.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (7.8-13).тАФтАШThat witness is denominated a messenger who is a respectable man, esteemed and appointed by both parties, and has come near them to listen to the speeches of the plaintiff and the defendant. He is a spontaneous witness who declares that he has witnessed the transaction, after having approached the court of his own accord, while a cause is being heard. That witness who communicates to another man what he has heard, at a time when he is about to go abroad, or is lying on his death-bed, should he considered as an indirect witness. He also is called an indirect witness who repeats, from his own hearing or from hearsay, the previous statements of actual witnesses. He is called a secret witness to whom an affair has been entrusted or communicated by both parties, or who happens to witness the transaction. The King himself, having heard the statements of both the Plaintiff and the Defendant, may act as a witness.тАЩ

рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╢реНрд░рд╡рдгрд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдВ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рддреНрд╡рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрд┐рдГ, рди рддреБ рдирд┐рдмрдиреНрдзрдирддрдГ ред рдЕрддреЛ рд╜рдиреНрддрд░реЗрдгрд╛рдкрд┐ рдирд┐рдмрдиреНрдзрдирдВ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реА рд╕реНрдпрд╛рджреН рдПрд╡ ред рдПрддрд╛рд╡рд╛рдВрд╕реН рддреБ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгреЛ рдирд┐рдпрдордГ ред рдирд┐рдмрдиреНрдзреЗрдирд╛рдкрд┐ рдкреГрд╖реНрдЯреЗрди рд╕рддрд╛ рд╕рддреНрдпрдВ рд╡рдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдпреЗрди тАФ

074 Evidence in accordance with what has actually been seen or heard, is admissible; a witness who speaks truth in those (cases), neither loses spiritual merit nor wealth.

075 рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реА рджреГрд╖реНрдЯ-рд╢реНрд░реБрддрд╛рджреН ...{Loading}...

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

A witness asserting, in an assembly of noble men, anything apart from what he has seen and heard, falls downwards into hell after death and becomes shut out from heaven.тАФ(75)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЕрд╕рддреНрдпрд╛рднрд┐рдзрд╛рдиреЗ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рдВ рдлрд▓рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рд░реНрдердореН рдЗрджрдореН ред рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╢реНрд░реБрддрд╢рдмреНрдж рдЙрдкрд▓рдмреНрдзрд┐рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдп рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрджреН рдЕрдиреБрдкрд▓рдмреНрдзрдореН ред рддрдЪреН рдЪреЗрджреН рдмреНрд░рд╡реАрддрд┐ ред рдЖрд░реНрдпрд╛рдГ рд╕рднреНрдпрд╛рдГ рд╕рдореНрдпрдХреНрдХрд╛рд░рд┐рдгрдГ ред рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рд╕рдВрд╕рджрд┐ рд╕рднрд╛рдпрд╛рдореН рдЕрд╡рд╛рдЩреН рдЕрдзреЛрдореБрдЦрдГ рдирд░рдХрдВ276 рдпрд╛рдордВ рдпрд╛рддрдирд╛рд╕реНрдерд╛рдирдВ277 рдЧрдЪреНрдЫрддрд┐ ред рдкреНрд░реЗрддреНрдп рдореГрддреНрд╡рд╛ рд╕реНрд╡рд░реНрдЧрд╛рдЪреН рдЪ рд╣реАрдпрддреЗ рднреНрд░рд╢реНрдпрддрд┐ ред рдпрджреН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреЗрди рд╕реНрд╡рд░реНрдЧрд╛рд░реЛрд╣рдгрд┐рдХрдВ рдХрд░реНрдо рдХреГрддрдВ рддрджреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдХреМрдЯрд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдкрд╛рдкрд╕реНрдп рдЧреБрд░реБрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдмрдзреНрдпрддреЗ ред рди рддреБ рд╕реНрд╡рд░реНрдЧрд╕реНрдп рдХрд░реНрдордгрдГ рдкрд╛рдкреЗрдирд╛рдиреНрдпреЗрди рдирд╛рд╢рдГ ред рд╕реНрд╡рдлрд▓рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рдХрд░реНрдордгрд╛рдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд░ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддреЗрднреНрдпрдГ рее рео.ренрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The present verse describes the results accruing to the witness who deposes falsely.

The term тАШseen and heardтАЩ is synonymous with тАШapprehended,тАЩ as has been already explained; тАШapart from thisтАЩ is what is not apprehended, or known to him;тАФif he asserts any such thing, тАШin an assembly of noble men,тАЩтАФin the court consisting of honourable persons,тАФhe тАШfalls downwardsтАЩтАФheadlongтАФтАШinto hellтАЩтАФto a place where he undergoes punishments at the hands of the god Yama;тАФтАШafter deathтАЩтАФтАШand becomes shut out from heaven,тАЩтАФi.e., falls down. That is, even though he may have committed deeds entitling him to go to heaven, yet he becomes shut out from it, by virtue of the more serious nature of the sin of perjury. It is not that the тАШKarmaтАЩ calculated to carry him to heaven is destroyed by this sin; since every act is conducive to the fulfilment of its own reward (and does not interfere with that of others), with the sole exception of the Expiatory Rites (which have no results of their own, and only tend to nullify those of the corresponding sinful acts).тАФ(75)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШSaс╣ГsadiтАЩтАФтАШIn the CourtтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШin an assembly of Br─Бhmaс╣ЗasтАЩ (Govindar─Бja).

тАШSvarg─Бt h─лyateтАЩтАФтАШFalls off from heaven which he may have earned by meritorious actsтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, Govindar─Бja, Kull┼лka and Nandana);тАФтАШeven after passing through hell, he cannot get into heavenтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

This verse is quoted in Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 200);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (38a).

рдЕрдирд┐рдмрджреНрдзреЛ рд▓реЗрдХреНрдпрдореН рдЕрдирд╛рд░реВрдвреЛ рд╜рдкреАрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рдИрдХреНрд╖рдгрд╢реНрд░рд╡рдгреЗ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рддреЗ ред рд╢реЗрд╖рдВ рд╕реБрдмреЛрдзрдореН рее рео.ренрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАЬUnder verso 74 it has been already declared that even though a man may not have been originally appointed as a witness, his evidence, as bearing upon what is directly known to him, is admissible; what then is the use of saying again that тАШeven though not put down, etc., etc.тАЩ? What additional information is provided by this verse?

People might be led to think thatтАФтАШwhen a man has been put down as a witness on the original document, his evidence is admissible as a matter of course,тАФbut not so that of one who has not been so put down,тАФfor if both were admissible, then there would be no point in entering any witnesses upon the document.тАЩ It is with a view to set aside this idea that the author has added the present verse. The former verse refers to cases where no witnesses have been put down, while this refers to a case where the document is duly attested by witnesses.

тАШNot put downтАЩтАФnot entered in the document.

тАШSeeingтАЩ and тАШhearingтАЩ have been already explained.

The rest is clear.тАФ(76)

тАШAnibaddhaс╕етАЩтАФтАШNot entered as a witness in the documentтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi),тАШтАФbut accidentally present at the transactionтАЩ (Kull┼лka, N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Nandana).

This verse is quoted in Vyavah─Бratattva (p. 26);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (28a);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 46a), which explains тАШanibaddhaс╕етАЩ as тАШnot cited or entered.тАЩ

рд╢реБрдЪреНрдп рдЗрддреАрдХрд╛рд░реЛ рджреБрд░реНрд▓рднреЛ “рд╡реЛрддреЛ рдЧреБрдгрд╡рдЪрдирд╛рддреН” (рдкрд╛рдгреН рек.рез.рекрек) рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рдирд╛рддреН ред “рдХреГрджрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд╛рддреН”280 рдЗрддрд┐ рдХреЗрдЪрд┐рддреН рд╕рдорд░реНрдердпрдиреНрддреЗ рее рео.ренрен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The evidence of a single person having been declared to be inadmissible, the present verse lavs down an exception in favour of one who is free from covetousness. So that if a man is known to be truthful, he is certainly admissible as witness. But women are never admissible,тАФbe they one or many,тАФтАШeven though pureтАЩтАФpossessed of high qualifications; and the reason for this is that тАШthe understanding of women is not steadyтАЩ; fickle-mindedness is the very nature of women; while other qualifications are acquired, and as such liable to lapses through carelessness, idleness and so forth; so that their inherent fickleness remains as a constant factor. Just as in the case of a dyspeptic,тАФeven though a certain amount of appetite may have been regained by the use of butter and other things, yet even the least neglect on their part, brings on the inherent Dyspepsia again. Consequently, on account of this uncertainty, there can be no confidence in women, even though they be highly qualified.

As for the declaration (in 70) that тАШin the event of no witnesses being available, women may be made witnesses,тАЩтАФthat refers to cases where they can be immediately questioned, and there is no possibility of their mind being tampered with by any person. When however there has been an interval of time, it is quite possible that they may be won over by the party whoso case is weak and who is in fear of losing it. So that in such cases their evidence is not admissible at all.

тАШOther men tainted with defects;тАФeven persons other than women,тАФand men,тАФwho are тАШtaintedтАЩтАФbesetтАФwith such defects as love, hatred and so forth; i.e., men in whom those defects abound to a every large extent.

Though Love, Hatred and the rest, as being forbidden by the scriptures, have, already been declared by name to be sources of suspicion and dishonesty,тАФyet they are referred to here again, for the purpose of including those that have not been so mentioned by name, and all writers sanction the mentioning of the general and special aspects of the same tiling.

Some people have adopted the тАШaтАЩ before тАШlubdhaтАЩ and construed the verse to mean that тАШeven though free from covetousness, a single man cannot be a witness,тАФhow much less then one who is covetous,тАЩтАФand hence as permitting the evidence of two men.

Though the form тАШ┼Ыucyaс╕етАЩ is impossible, in view of P─Бс╣Зini 4.1.44, yet some people justify it as being in accordance with the V─Бrtika on 4.1.45тАФ(77)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 213), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШEkoтАЩ lubdhastu s─Бkс╣г─лтАЩ is the reading adopted by Kull┼лka Bhaс╣нс╣нa; the other readingтАФтАШeko lubdhastvas─Бkс╣г─лтАЩтАФadopted by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana, is not right; because as a matter of fact, even several avaricious men would be as─Бkс╣г─л, and hence there would be no point in the term тАШekaс╕е.тАЩ But admitting this reading, the verse could be taken as not admitting the evidence of one тАШavaricious manтАЩ, and thereby admitting that of one man who is free from avarice, even though he be ignorant of law. It is for this reason that Vi┼Ыvar┼лpa and others have explained the meaning to be that when accepted by both parties, even a single man may be admitted as witness, and they have not laid stress upon the condition that he should be тАШconversant with law;тАФтАШDo┼Ыaiс╕етАЩ stands for theft and so forth.

This verse is quoted in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (32a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

[Vide Texts under 64 et seq.]

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.72).тАФтАШEven a single man may ho admitted as a witness, by the consent of both parties, if he is versed in Dharma.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.188).тАФтАШSlaves, impostors and others described as inadmissible as witnesses shall he witnesses in suits of a specially grave character.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.192).тАФтАШBy the consent of both parties, a single man may become a witness in a suit. He must be examined in public as a witness,тАФthough he has been mentioned (in the Texts) as an incompetent witness.тАЩ

Do. (1.190-191).тАФтАШA woman cannot he a witness; a woman would speak falsely from want of veracity.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

What the witnesses state naturally in regard to the case should he accepted; on the other hand, what they state, not quite naturally, but тАШfrom considerations of righteousnessтАЩ тАШis uselessтАЩ,тАФi.e., should not he accepted. The describing of things exactly as they were seen is what is meant by тАШnatural statement what is otherwise than this,тАФi.e., what is stated with the motive that what is said may not cause suffering to the poor party concerned,тАФтАШis uselessтАЩ; e.g., when one party complainsтАФтАШI have been insulted by this personтАЩтАФand the other denies it, the witness may sayтАФтАШyes, ho was insulted, but in joke, not through maliceтАЩ; and in this case, the statement тАШthe man has been insultedтАЩ should he accepted; while the qualifying statement тАШin joke,тАЩтАФwhich had not been put forth by the defendantтАФand was made by the witness unasked (gratuitously)тАФneed not he accepted.

тАШIn relation to the caseтАЩтАФpertaining to the suit.

тАШUselessтАЩтАФfutile.

Others explain the verse as follows:тАФIt may so happen that through shyness, a witness deposes in a halting manner,тАФbut that alone need not be made a ground for rejecting his statement; what is to be done is that the nature of the witness should he examined by reasoning, and then it should be determined that тАШthis person speaks haltingly through shyness, what he says, however, is quite true?

But the real meaning is as explained above; so much attention need not be paid to this other explanation.тАФ(78)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШSvabh─БvenaтАЩтАФтАШQuite naturallyтАЩтАФтАШnot out of compassionтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, who says nothing regarding тАШdepending on womenтАЩ as Buhler wrongly puts it),тАФтАШnot out of fear and the likeтАЩ (Kull┼лka);тАФтАШthe reliability or otherwise of the witness is to be ascertained after due consideration of his Svabh─Бva, character, and not from the manner of bis giving evidenceтАЩ (тАШothersтАЩ in Medh─Бtithi),тАФтАШwithout hesitation, quicklyтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa);тАФтАШin accordance with truthтАЩ (Govindar─Бja and Nandana).

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 80);тАФand in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 282).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.396).тАФтАШOne should accept the evidence of witnesses given spontaneously, not through force; after the evidence has been once given by the witness, he shall not be repeatedly cross-examined.тАЩ

The investigating Judge shall question the witnesses assembled in the court, in the presence of the plaintiff and the defendant, gently exhorting them in the following manner.тАФ(79)

рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдХрд░реНрддрд░рд┐ рдШрдЮреН ред “рдЪрдЬреЛрдГ рдХреБ рдШрд┐рдгреНрдгреНрдпрддреЛрдГ” (рдкрд╛рдгреН рен.рей.релреи) рдЗрддрд┐ рдХреБрддреНрд╡рдореН ред рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЯреН рдЪрд╛рд╕реМ рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШIn the courtтАЩтАФinside the court room; the compounding being in accordance with P─Бс╣Зini 2. 1.40;тАФthose who have presented themselves at the place of the trial; should he questioned тАШin the presence of the plaintiff and the defendantтАЩтАФboth;тАФthey being тАШgently exhortedтАЩ in the manner described below,тАФnot addressed harshly; because if addressed harshly, they would become frightened of the judge, and thereby losing the normal condition of their mind, they would he unable to recall all the details of the case; because fright always deprives people of their memory.

тАШPr─Бс╕Нviv─БkaтАЩ Investigating тАШJudgeтАЩ is the name given to the officer appointed by the king to try cases. Though the name, in its literal significance of тАШquestioning and judgingтАЩ applies to the king also, yet we find the two names used separately, in such texts asтАФтАШIf the Minister or the Judge (Pr─Бс╕Нviv─Бka) should pervert the details of a suit, the king himself shall look into it, etc.тАЩ (Manu. 9.234.)

In the term тАШpr─Бс╕Нviv─Бka,тАЩ тАШpr─Бс╣нтАЩ means one who questions, тАШpс╣Ыchati;тАЩ it being derived from the root тАШprachтАЩ to тАШquestionтАЩ with the nominative affix тАШkvipтАЩ; the elongation of the vowel and the change into тАШс╣нтАЩ being analogous to the case of the roots тАШvaci,тАЩ тАШ┼Ыri,тАЩ тАШdruтАЩ тАШ┼Ыru,тАЩ тАШpru.тАЩ тАШPr─Бс╣нтАЩ is the qualifying epithet to тАШviv─Бka,тАЩ which means тАШone who judges or investigates knotty legal casesтАЩ;тАФthe nominative affix тАШgha├▒тАЩ being added in accordance with P─Бс╣Зini 3. 3. 113, and the change of тАШcaтАЩ into тАШkaтАЩ being in accordance with тАШP─Бс╣ЗiniтАЩ 7.3.52. the term pr─Бс╕Нviv─Бka thus means the questioning or Investigating Judge.тАФ(79)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 75) in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 18);тАФin

Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 198);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (33b), which explains тАШsabh─Бntaс╕етАЩ as тАШin courtтАЩ, and тАШanuyu├▒j─лtaтАЩ as тАШshould question.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 8.79-86)
**

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.398-414).тАФтАШThe witness should be interrogated, after being well-governed by oaths, teachings of Pur─Бс╣Зas, narration of great merits of virtue and the great sins of falsehood:тАФтАЬWhere, when, how, whence and what have you seen or heard,тАФwhether written by the man himself or caused to be written by somebody,тАФspeak truly all that you know.тАЭ The witness who gives true evidence attains happy life hereafter and unrivalled fame in this worldтАФthis is the remark of Brahm─Б, etc.тАЩ (the rest as in Manu 83-85).

N─Бrada (1.198 and 200).тАФтАШAfter having summoned all the witnesses and hound them down firmly by an oath, the Judge shall examine them separately. They should be men of tried integrity and conversant with the circumstances of the case. By sacred texts extolling the excellence of truth and denouncing the sinfulness of falsehood, let him inspire them with deep awe, as followsтАФ(Verses 201 to 228тАФ201, 208, 209 being the same as Manu 93, 98, 99 respectively)тАЩ.тАФ[All this is to be addressed to all witnesses; Manu reserves 89 to 101 for ┼Ъ┼лdra witnesses only.]

Gautama (13.5).тАФтАШWitnesses shall not speak singly, or without being asked.тАЩ

─Аpastamba (2.29.7).тАФтАШA person who is possessed of good qualities may be called as witness and shall answer the questions put to him, according to the truth…… after having been exhorted to be fair to both sides.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (8.24 et seq.).тАФтАШLet him exhort the witnesses with the following speechesтАФтАЬWhatever places of torture await the killer of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and other great criminals… those places of abode are ordained for a witness who gives false evidence; and the fruit of every virtuous act he has done, from the day of his birth to his dying day, shall he lost to him. Truth makes the sun spread his rays; Truth makes the moon shine; Truth makes the wind blow; Truth makes the earth bear all things; Truth makes waters flow; Truth makes the fire burn. The atmosphere exists through truth; so do the gods; and so do the offerings. If veracity and a thousand horse-sacrifices are weighed against each other, truth ranks even higher than a thousand horse-sacrifices. Those who, acquainted with the facts, and appointed to give evidence, stand mute, are equally criminal with, and deserve the same severe punishment as, false witnesses.тАЭ After having addressed him thus, let the King examine the witnesses in the order of their castes.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.73-75).тАФтАШHe shall address the following words to the witnesses standing near the plaintiff and defendantтАФтАЬHe who hears false witness goes to those regions which are reserved for people committing heinous offences, and other crimes, for incendiaries, for murderers of women and children. Whatever virtuous act you may have done during a hundred lives, understand that all that will go to the party whom, by your false evidence, you make lose the suit.тАЭтАЩ

Baudh─Бyana (1.19.9 et seq.).тАФтАШThe wise man should address an appointed witness in the following manner:тАФтАЬWhatever merit thou hast acquired, etc., etc.тАЭтАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (16.32-34).тАФтАШDepose, O witness, according to the truth; expecting thy answers, thy ancestors hang in suspense, as to whether they shall rise or fall, etc., etc.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШWhat you know in regard to the matter of this suit, any transaction, secret or open, that may have been carried on between these two persons,тАФall that declare freely; since you are witnesses in this suit.

тАШYou are the sole authority in this matter; truth and untruth are in your handsтАЩтАФthus addressed the persons cited as witnesses become encouraged.

тАШIn this matter.тАЩтАФThough the text mentions this formula in its most general form, yet, in as much as it is not possible for any person to be a witness regarding all things, it follows that the subject-matter of the suit should be stated here. Because until they are informed of the details they cannot understand the question.тАФ(80)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

From this verse onward the text lays down the manner in which the witnesses are to be exhorted.

By telling the truth, the witness attains тАШirreproachable regions,тАЩ in the shape of Heaven and the rest, which are the source of desirable results.

Or, the term тАШl okaтАЩ may be taken in the sense of тАШcasteтАЩ; the sense in that case would he that тАШhe is born in a happy future life.тАЩ

In the present life also, he obtains тАШunsurpassable fameтАЩтАФrenown, superior to which there is none; i.e., people bestow praise upon him.

SuchтАФtruthfulтАФspeech is honoured by Brahm─Б, Praj─Бpati, himself.тАФ(81)

тАШStating the untruth in his evidence, he becomes firmly bound in Varuс╣ЗaтАЩs fetters, helpless during a hundred births. One should, therefore, give true evidence.тАЩтАФ(82)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЗрдг рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╢реБрднрд╛рд╢реБрднрдкреНрд░рджрд░реНрд╢рдиреЗрди рд╕рддреНрдпрд╡рдЪрдиреЗ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрдГ рдкреНрд░реЛрддреНрд╕рд╛рд╣рд┐рддрд╛рдГ ред рдЕрдиреЗрди рд╡рд┐рдкрд░реАрддрд╛рднрд┐рдзрд╛рдиреЗ рджреБрдГрдЦреЛрддреНрдкрддреНрддрд┐рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдореН ред рд╕рддреНрдпрд╡рдЪрдирд╛рд░реНрдердореН рдПрд╡реИрддрддреН ред рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрдГ рдХрд░реНрдо рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдореН ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рд╕рддреНрдпрдВ рдмреНрд░реБрд╡рд╛рдгреЛ рд╡рд╛рд░реБрдгреИрдГ рдкрд╛рд╢реИрд░реН рдмрдзреНрдпрддреЗ рдкреАрдбреНрдпрддреЗ ред рднреГрд╢рдореН рдЕрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердореН ред рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╢рдГ рдкрд░рддрдиреНрддреНрд░реАрдХреГрддрдГ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдЪреЗрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд╕реБ рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдЪрдХреНрд╖реБрд░реНрдЧрддрд╛рд╕реНрд╡реН рдЕрдкрд┐ ред рд╢рддрдВ рдпрд╛рд╡рдЬреН рдЬрдиреНрдордирд┐ рд╡рд╛рд░реБрдгрд╛рдГ рдкрд╛рд╢рд╛ рдШреЛрд░рд╛рдГ рд╕рд░реНрдкрд░рдЬреНрдЬрд╡реЛ рдЬрд▓реЛрджрд░рд╛рдгрд┐ рд╡рд╛ ред рдПрддрджреНрджреЛрд╖рдкрд░рд┐рд╣рд╛рд░рд╛рд░реНрдердВ рд╕рддреНрдпрдВ рд╡рджреЗрджреН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдГ ред рдЖрдЬрд╛рддреАрд░реН рдЗрддрд┐ рдирд╛рдпрдВ рдорд░реНрдпрд╛рджрд╛рднрд┐рд╡рд┐рдзреНрдпреЛрд░реН рдЖрдЩреН ред рддрдерд╛ рд╕рддрд┐ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдореА рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдЙрдкрд╕рд░реНрдЧреЛ рд╜рдпрдореН рдЕрдирд░реНрдердХрдГ, рдкреНрд░рд▓рдореНрдмрдд295 рдЗрддрд┐рд╡рддреН296 ред рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпрд╛ рдЪреЗрдпрдВ рдЖрд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рд╢реН рдЪрд╛рддреНрд░ рдЧрдореНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╢рддрдВ рдЬрдиреНрдорд╛рдиреНрдпреН рдЖрд╡рд░реНрддрддреЗ рдЙрджрд░рдЧреГрд╣реАрддрдГ рее рео.реореи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The preceding verse encourages the witnesses by putting before them the spiritual and temporal results following from the telling of truth; the present verso describes how results accrue from saying what is contrary to truth; and the purpose of this also is to induce the witness to tell the truth.

тАШS─Бkс╣гya,тАЩ тАШevidence,тАЩ is the work of the witness; in that work, stating what is not true, the man becomes тАШboundтАЩтАФtormentedтАФтАШin Varuс╣ЗaтАЩs fetters,тАЩтАФтАШfirmlyтАЩтАФto a very great extent;тАФтАШhelplessтАЩтАФ rendered totally dependent on others, even in regard to the operations of speech and the eyes,тАФтАШduring a hundred births.тАЩ

тАШVaruс╣ЗaтАЩs fettersтАЩ are in the shape of terrible snakes or in the form of the disease of dropsy.

In order to guard against such calamities, the witness should state the truth;тАФsuch is the sense of the injunction implied by the text.

In the term тАШ─Бj─Бt─лс╕е,тАЩ the initial ─Б is not the indeclinable тАШ─Бс╣ЕтАЩ which denotes limit; for, if it were that or we would have the Ablative ending. Hence it is to be taken as a preposition meaning nothing; just like the preposition тАШpraтАЩ in such words as тАШpralambateтАЩ and the like. The case-ending also is the Accusative. What the term signifies is repetition; the meaning being that the man sutlers from dropsy repeatedly during one hundred births.тАФ(82)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАЬDropsy is a disease specially attributed to Varuс╣Зa (see с╣Ъgveda 7.89.1, and the story of ┼Ъunaс╕е┼Ыepha, Aitareya Br─Бhmaс╣Зa 7.15). The fetters of Varuс╣Зa are mentioned as the punishment of liars in the Atharva Veda, 4.16.6.тАЭтАФBuhler.

This verse is quoted in Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 199);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (33b), which explains тАШ┼Ыatam-─Бj─Бt─лс╕етАЩ as тАШduring a hundred livesтАЩ;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 53b).

рдирд╢рдмреНрджреЛ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд┐рддрдГ ред рдкрд╛рдкрдХреГрддрдГ рдХреВрдЯрд╛рджрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд┐рдг рдПрд╡рдВ рдЬрд╛рдирддреЗ ред рди рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрд╕реНрдорд╛рдиреН рдкрд╢реНрдпрддреАрддрд┐ ред рдЗрддрд┐рдХрд╛рд░реЗрдг рдордиреНрдпрддреЗрд░реН рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдердГ рдХрд░реНрдореЗрддрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрд╛рджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рди рдирдГ рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреН рдкрд╢реНрдпрддреАрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╖ рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдердГ ред рддрд╛рдВрд╕реН рддреБ рджреЗрд╡рд╛ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдорд╛рдгрд╛рдГ рдкрд╢реНрдпрдиреНрддрд┐ ред рд╕реНрд╡рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рд╛рддреНрдорд╛ ред рддрджреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН “рдЖрддреНрдорд╛рдЗрд╡ рд╣реНрдпреН рдЖрддреНрдордирдГ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реА” (рдореНрдзреН рео.реорек) рдЗрддрд┐ ред

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдирдиреБ рдХрдГ рдкреБрдирд░реН рдЕрдпрдВ рдкрд╛рдкрдЪрд╛рд░реА, рддрд╕реНрдп рдЪ рдХреЛ рд╜рдиреНрдпреЛ рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╛ ред рдпрд╛рд╡рддрд╛рддреНрдореИрд╡ рдХрд░реНрддрд╛ рд╢реБрднрд╛рд╢реБрднрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдЪрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдкреБрд░реБрд╖реЛ рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯреЗрддрд┐ ред

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рд╕рддреНрдпрдореН ред рддрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡ рджреЗрд╡рддрд╛рддреНрд╡рдореН рдЕрдзреНрдпрд╛рд░реЛрдкреНрдп рднреЗрджреЗрди рдХрд░реНрдордХрд░реНрддреГрд╡реНрдпрдкрджреЗрд╢реЛ рд╜рдиреГрддрдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердГ ред рджреЗрд╡рддрд╛рд░реВрдкрдВ рддреНрд╡рдВ рдЬрд╛рдиреАрд╖реЗ297 ред рддрд╛рддреНрддреНрд╡рд┐рдХрдореН рдЖрддреНрдореАрдпрдореН рдЖрдиреНрддрд░рдВ рд░реВрдкрдВ рд╢рд╛рд░реАрд░рдореН, рддрдерд╛ рдмрд╛рд╣реНрдпрдореН рдЕрдирд╛рддреНрдореАрдпрдореН рдЕрд╕рд╛рд░рдореН, рдПрддрджреБрдкрднреЛрдЧрд╛рд░реНрдердВ рдорд╛ рджреБрд╖реНрдХреГрддрдВ рдХрд╛рд░реНрд╖реАрд░реН рдЗрддрд┐ рдкреНрд░реЛрддреНрд╕рд╛рд╣реНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЕрддреЛ “рдорд╛рд╡рдордВрд╕реНрдерд╛рдГ рд╕реНрд╡рдореН рдЖрддреНрдорд╛рдирдореН” рдорд╛рд╡рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рд╕реАрд░реН “рдиреГрдгрд╛рдВ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрдореН рдЕрдиреБрддреНрддрдордореН” (рдореНрдзреН рео.реорек) ред рдЕрдиреНрдпреЛ рд╣рд┐ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реА рдЕрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреНрдиреН рдПрд╡ рд▓реЛрдХреЗ, рдЕрдпрдВ рддреБ рдореГрддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд┐ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдВ рджрджрд╛рддрд┐ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдПрддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рднреЗрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рдЕрд╕рддреНрдпрд╡рд╛рджреА298 рдХрджрд╛рдЪрд┐рдиреН рдордиреНрдпрддреЗ- “рдЖрддреНрдорд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрдиреНрдирд╕реНрдп рдХрд┐рдореН рдПрд╖ рдореЗ рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдкрд┐ рдХрд░рд┐рд╖реНрдпрддрд┐” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрдиреН рди ред “рдЧрддрд┐рд░реН рдЖрддреНрдорд╛ рддрдерд╛рддреНрдордирдГ”299 (рдореНрдзреН рео.реорек) ред рдЖрддреНрдорд╛рдирдореН рдЕрдиреНрддрд░реЗрдгрд╛рдиреНрдпрд╛ рдЧрддрд┐рд░реН рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ ред рди рд╣рд┐ рджреНрд╡рд╛рд╡реН рдЖрддреНрдорд╛рдирд╛рд╡реН рдПрдХрд╕реНрдп рднрд╡рддрдГ ред

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреБ рдордиреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ рдкрд░рдорд╛рддреНрдорд╛ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реА рд╕рдВрд╕рд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рддреНрдорд╛рдиреЛ рдирд┐рдпреЛрдЬреНрдпрд╛ рдЗрддрд┐ рднреЗрджрдГ рее рео.реорел рее

рдХреЗ рдкреБрдирд╕реН рддреЗ рджреЗрд╡рд╛ рд░рд╣рд╕реНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдкреНрд░рдЪреНрдЫрдиреНрдирдВ рдкрд╛рдкрдореН рдЖрдЪрд░рдиреНрддрдВ рдпреЗ рдкрд╢реНрдпрдиреНрддрд┐, рдЕрдд рдЖрд╣ ред

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The particle тАШnaтАЩ is misplaced.

тАШSinnersтАЩтАФperjurors and othersтАФтАШthinkтАЩтАФfeelтАФthat тАШno one sees usтАЩ;тАФthe particle тАШitiтАЩ shows that the whole clause is the object (of the verb тАШthinkтАЩ);тАФthe construction of the clause being тАШna naс╕е ka┼Ыcit pa┼Ыyati.тАЩ

тАШThe godsтАЩтАФnamed in the next verseтАФтАШsee themтАЩ; as also their own sinner soul. This is what is meant by the assertion that тАШthe soul is the soulтАЩs witness.тАЩ

тАЬBut who is it that commits the sin? And who apart from him is the one that sees? In fact it is the soul itself that does all that is good or evil, and certainly there is no other тАШinner personalityтАЩ that sees it.тАЭ

True; but the same soul has been represented as a тАШgod,тАЩ and as such spoken of as the doer of the act (of seeing); and this has been done for the purpose of preventing the man from telling a lie, the sense of the exhortation thus isтАФ

тАШYou know that the real nature of your true personality is divine, which is within the body, while your exterior body is not your soul;тАФhence, for the nourishing of this latter, do not commit a single act;тАФhence too do not disregard or despise your soul, the best witness of man. Other witnesses give evidence only in this world, while the soul hears evidence even after death; hence one should be afraid of such a witness.тАЩ

The liar may be led to thinkтАФтАШwhen I am born again with another soul, what will my present soul, which is the seer, be able to do to me?тАЩ But this is not so; since тАШthe soul is the soulтАЩs refugeтАЩ (verse 84). Apart from his soul, there is no refuge for man; and there are not two souls for a single man.

Others hold that the difference is that the soul spoken of as the тАШwitnessтАЩ is the supreme one, while the souls born in the persons of the world are those that are under his sway.тАФ(85)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШHeaven, earth, water, heart, moon, sun, fire, death-god, wind, night, the two twilights, and morality know the conduct of all corporeal beings.тАЩтАФ(86)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╣реГрджрдпрд╢рдмреНрджреЗрди рд╣реГрджрдпрд╛рдпрддрдиреЛ рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрдкреБрд░реБрд╖ рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рджрд┐рд╡рд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ300 рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯреГрддреНрд╡рдореН рдЕрдЪреЗрддрдиреЗрд╖реБ рдЪреИрддрдиреНрдпрдореН рдЖрд░реЛрдкреНрдпрддреЗ301 ред рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рдиреНрддрд░реЗ рддреБ рдорд╣рд╛рднреВрддрд╛рдирд┐ рджреЗрд╡рддрд╛рддреНрдорддрдпрд╛ рдЪреЗрддрдирд╛рдиреНрдпреН рдПрд╡ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪ302 рдкреГрдерд┐рд╡реА рднрд╛рд░рд╛рд╡рддрд░рдгрд╛рдп рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдорд╛рдгрдореН рдЙрдкрд╛рдЧрдорджреН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд░реНрдгреНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдЧрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рди рдХрд┐рдВрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдпрдореН рдЕрд╕реНрддреАрддрд┐ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╢рд░реАрд░рд┐рдгрд╛рдВ рд╡реГрддреНрддрдВ рд╢реАрд▓рдВ рдЪрд╛рддреНрдордирдГ рдХрд╛рдпрдЧрддрдВ рд╢реБрднрдореН рдЕрд╢реБрднрдВ рдЪ рдЬрд╛рдирддреЗ рее рео.реорем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The question ending as to who are the gods that see the sin committed secretly and in private, the text puts forward present verse.

The term тАШheartтАЩ stands for the subtle spirit located in the heart. The Heaven and the rest are spoken of as тАШseersтАЩ figuratively;тАФthough they are insentient, they are represented as sentient. According to other philosophical systems, all the great elemental substances are portions of gods, and as such actually sentient; e.g., it is described that the earth went to Brahm─Б, in order to seek for help in relieving her of the burden of sinners.

The gods being all-pervading, there is nothing unknown to them; hence they know the conduct and character, as also the good and bad points in the body of the soul.тАФ(86)

In the presence of gods and Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, during forenoon, the judge, pure himself, shall ask the twice-born persons, who have been purified and are facing either the north or the east, to give evidence.тАФ(87)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рджреЗрд╡рд╛ рджреБрд░реНрдЧрд╛рдорд╛рд░реНрддрдгреНрдбрд╛рджрдпрдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдорд╛рдХрд▓реНрдкрд┐рддрд╛рдГ ред рд╢реБрдЪреАрдиреН рдХреГрддрд╕реНрдирд╛рдирд╛рдЪрдордирд╛рджрд┐рд╡рд┐рдзреАрдиреН ред рд╢реБрдЪрд┐рдГ рдкреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╛ рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рддрдерд╛рд╡рд┐рдз рдПрд╡ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдЛрддрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдкреВрд░рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердореН рдПрд╡ ред рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреН рее рео.реорен рее

тАШGodsтАЩтАФDurg─Б, S┼лrya and the rest, set up in the form of images.

тАШPurified,тАЩтАФi.e., who have performed the rites of bathing, mouth-rinsing and so forth.

тАШPure,тАЩтАФthe judge himself should have purified himself in the same way.
