рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАЬOn what basis do we have the instrumental ending in gob─лjak─Б├▒canaiс╕е? If it be said to be due to these being instruments in the act of questioning, that cannot be; as it is the word (and not the kine, etc.) that are the instruments, a means of questioning.тАЭ

There is no force in this objection. We have to construe the words in such a manner as to make the тАШkine,тАЩ etc., instruments of the questioning. The word тАШp─Бtakaiс╕е,тАЩ тАШsinsтАЩ has got to be construed both ways, so that we have the phrase тАШgob─лjak─Б├▒cunaiс╕е p─Бtakaiс╕е,тАЩ which gives the meaning that тАШhe should ask them by mentioning sins pertaining to the kine, grains and gold,тАЩ i.e., the form of the question to be employed should heтАФтАШif you tell a lie, you would he incurring the same sin that follows from stealing or killing the cow.тАЩ

Similarly, by mentioning the sins going to be enumerated (in the next verse), he should question the ┼Ъ┼лdra. The term тАШsinтАЩ here should he taken as standing for words expressing sins; because the sins themselves could not be the means or instrument of the questioning, as pointed out above.тАФ(88)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШGob─лjaka├▒canaiс╕етАЩтАФтАШThreatening him with the guilt of all offences committed against kine and the restтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi) тАШwith the guilt of the theft of kine etc.тАЩ (Govindar─Бja, Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШwith the loss of his kine etc.тАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa);тАФтАШby making him touch the cow and other thingsтАЩ (Nandana).

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 674);тАФand in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 78), where however the first half is read as тАЬsasyena ┼Ы─Бpayedvi??aс╣Г kс╣гanniyaс╣Г v─Бhan─Бyudhaiс╕етАЭ;тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 215), which adds:тАФThe Vai┼Ыya is to be admonished with the words:тАФтАШthose sins would accrue to you which are involved in stealing the cow etc. if you tell a lie and the ┼Ъ┼лdra with the wordsтАФтАШall kinds of sins would fall on you etc. etc.тАЩ;тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 204);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (33b).

тАШWould go to the dogsтАЩтАФwould be futile, so far as you are concerned. Others however explain that тАШgoing to the dogsтАЩ is indicative of positive harm; the sense beingтАФтАШthe merit of the man becomes thrown away, in the same manner in which a man, having earned, with great difficulty, gold and other excellent treasures, were to throw it all into an unclean streamтАЩ: it has been pointed out more than once that the merit acquired by one person cannot go over to another.тАФ(90)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

With a view to strike terror in the heart of the man, it is next described who is the тАШsilent watcherтАЩ (mentioned in the preceding verse).

You have heard of the God, who is the destroyer of the body and property and other things belonging to all living beings, and who punishes them with torments; that God resides in your heart, and not away from you; in the event of committing a wrong, he will punish you immediately;тАФand do not think that being your own sold, ho will ignore your fault; because no one is his тАШown.тАЩ

тАШIf you have no quarrel with himтАЩтАФif he is satisfied with you and trusts you, then what would be the need for your going to bathe in the Gaс╣Еg─Б for the cleansing of your sins? What too would be the need for going to Kurukс╣гetra? For the reward of going to these places consists in the destruction of sins and acquiring of merit; and all this is obtained by the man here and now, if he is at pence with the Supreme Self (within him). As a matter of fact, the soul of a sinner is never free from fear; the unbeliever also has doubts regarding what is going to happen to him at death.

The Gaс╣Еg─Б is a river that purifies: and in тАШKurukс╣гetraтАЩ it is the land itself that purities.тАФ(92)

[See the texts under [79 et seq.]]

рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡реИрдХрд▓реНрдпрдВ рд╕рддреНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЕрдкреЗрддрдВ рднрд╛рд╖рддреЗ ред рдпрдерд╛ рдХрдгреНрдЯрдХрд╛ рдЕрд╢рд┐рддрд╛314 рднрдХреНрд╖рд┐рддрд╛ рдЬрдирдпрдиреНрддрд┐ рди рддрд╛рджреГрд╢реАрдВ рдорддреНрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░реАрддрд┐рдВ рдЬрдирдпрдиреНрддрд┐ ред рдпрджрд╛ рдзрдирд▓реЛрднреЗрди рдХрд╛рдЪрд┐рддреН рдкреНрд░реАрддрд┐рдорд╛рддреНрд░рд╛ рднрд╡рддрд┐ рддрдерд╛рдкрд┐ рдорд╣рд╛рджреБрдГрдЦрдВ315 рднрд╡рддреАрддрд┐ рд╕рдХрдгреНрдЯрдХрдорддреНрдпрд╛рд╢рдиреЛрдкрдорд╛ рее рео.репрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The pleasure produced by the eating of the fish is not equal to the pain caused by the swallowing of the bones; similarly, there is a slight pleasure produced by the little money that is received (as bribe), but the subsequent suffering is very great; it is on this basis that the analogy of fish-eating has been cited.тАФ(95)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 205), whiqс╕е says that according to some

people, this and the preceding two verses are to be addressed to witnesses of the lower order only; hence in ordinary cases, after тАШkur┼лn gamaс╕етАЩ, the exhortation should begin with тАШy─Бvato b─Бndhav─Бn &c.тАЩ (verse 97);тАФthese exhortations are to be addressed to ┼Ъ┼лdras and to poverty-stricken twice-born persons also;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (35b).

рд╕рддреНрдпрдореН рдПрддрддреН ред рдХрд╛рд▓реНрдкрдирд┐рдХреЗрди рднреЗрджреЗрдиреИрд╡рдореН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН ред рдпрдерд╛ рд╣рдиреНрддреНрдпреН рдЖрддреНрдорд╛рдирдореН рдЖрддреНрдордиреЗрддрд┐ рее рео.репрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШWhile he is speakingтАЩтАФwhile the witness is giving evidence.

тАШKnowing,тАЩтАФcognisant of what is true and what is not true.

тАШSoulтАЩтАФthe Inner Guide.

тАШDoes not distrust,тАЩтАФhas no doubt as to whether the man will tell the truth or not; is sure that ho will tell the truth.

He whose innermost soul is so confident,тАФto such a person the gods regard no one as тАШsuperiorтАЩтАФmore praiseworthy.

тАЬWho is the speaker, and who, apart from him, is the distruster? In fact, the soul is one only; when he, through his effort, utters speech, he becomes the speaker; and the same entity that comes to have тАШdistrust,тАЩ when he is faced by doubts regarding what and how tilings are going to happen; so that there cun be no difference between the two.тАЭ

This is quite true; but the statement in the text is based upon an assumed distinction; just like the statement тАШone injures his soul by his own soulтАЩ (Bhagavad-git─Б).тАФ(90)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛рдиреГрддрд╛рд╢реНрд░рдпрд╛рдГ рдкрд╛рдкрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛рдГ рдХреВрдЯрд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдг рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрддреН рдкреНрд░рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рд░реНрдердВ рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрдореН рдЖрд░рднреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдпрдВ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдГ рд╕рдВрдмреЛрдзрдирджреНрд╡рд╛рд░реЗрдгреЛрдкрджрд┐рд╢реНрдпрдорд╛рди316 рдЖрджрд░рд╛рд░реНрдердГ рд╕рдВрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрджреН рдЧреБрд╣реНрдпрдВ рдорд┐рде рдЙрдкрджрд┐рд╢реНрдпрддреЗ рддрджреН рдпрдерд╛рдХрдердВрдЪрд┐рджреН рднрд╡рддреАрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд╡рдзрд╛рд░рд┐рддрдВ рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рдирд╛рддрд┐рдЧреБрд░реБ рдЗрджрдВ рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрддрд┐рдорд╣рд╛рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирдореН рдЕрд╡рд╣рд┐рддреИрдГ рд╢реНрд░реЛрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред

рд╕реМрдореНрдпреЗрддрд┐ рдЪреИрдХрд╡рдЪрдирдореН рдЕрдиреЗрдХрд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдпрд╕рдВрдирд┐рдзрд╛рдиреЗ рднреГрдЧрд╛рд╡реН рдПрд╡ рд╡рд┐рд╡рдХреНрд╖рд┐рддрдореН ред рдпрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реНрдп рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡реНрдпрдзрд┐рдХрд░рдгрд╕рдкреНрддрдореА ред рдпрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрднреЗрджрднрд┐рдиреНрдиреЗ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЗ рдпрддреН рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдВ рддрддреНрд░ рддрдиреНрдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддрдВ рдпрджреН рдЕрдиреГрддрдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╖рд╛ рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрд╕рдкреНрддрдореА ред рдЕрдкрд░рд╛ “рдпрд╕реНрдп рдЪ рднрд╛рд╡реЗрди” (рдкрд╛рдгреН реи.рей.рейрен) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрднреЗрджрд╛рддреН рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрднреЗрджрдГ, рддрддреНрд░ рд╕рдорд╛рдирд╛рдзрд┐рдХрд░рдг рдПрд╡ ред рддрд╛рд╡рдд рдЗрддрд┐ рдкрд░рд┐рдорд╛рдгреЗ рд╡реНрдпреБрддреНрдкрд╛рджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрддреНрд░ рдпрддреН рдкреНрд░рднреВрддрдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдкрд░рд┐рдорд╛рдгрдВ рд╕рдВрднрд╛рд╡реНрдпрддреЗ, рд╢рд┐рд╢реВрдиреН рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рдпреЛ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд╛рдиреН317 рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрддреЛ318 рд╡рд┐рд╢рд┐рдирд╖реНрдЯрд┐- рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрдпреЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрдиреБрдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╢ рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕реБрдЦрдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрддреНрддрдпреЗ рд╜рдиреБрдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЗрдг рд╣реНрдпреН рдЕрднрд┐рдзреАрдпрдорд╛рдирдВ рд╕реБрдЦреЗрди рдкреНрд░рддреАрдпрддреЗ ред рдЖрдиреБрдкреВрд░реНрд╡реА рдЪ рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛рдЧрддрд╛рддреНрд░рд╛рднрд┐рдкреНрд░реЗрддрд╛ ред рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛ рдПрд╡ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдорд╛рдгрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН “рдкрдЮреНрдЪ рдкрд╢реБ” рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐” рее рео.репрен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The present text introduces a section where it is pointed out that the degree of sin committed by the perjurer varies with the nature of the matter of the suit.

When this fact is asserted in the form of an address, it serves the purpose of indicating its importance, when something is said in secret, it is regarded as some slight matter, not of any importance; but what is said now is important, and hence should be listened to with attention,тАФsuch being the implication of the hortatory form adopted.

The term тАШgentle friend,тАЩ in the singular form, is intended for Bhс╣Ыgu alone from among the several whom Manu is instructing.

тАШYaс╣гmin s─Бkс╣гyeтАЩ;тАФthe two locatives are not in apposition; the meaning isтАФтАШthe false evidence that is given in regard to a certain subject-matterтАЩ;тАФso that the locative denotes тАШmatter,тАЩ while the locative absolute means something quite different. Or the diversity in the evidence being in accordance with the diversity in the matter, the two locatives may be in apposition also.

The term тАШt─БvatтАЩ is generally used to denote extent; and as extent is of various kinds, the author specifies it as being тАШby number.тАЩ

тАШIn due order,тАЩтАФfor the purpose of easier understanding; when a subject is stated in due order, it becomes easily understood. The тАШorderтАЩ meant here is with reference to the number; as it is number that is going to be described in the following verses.тАФ(97)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШHantiтАЩтАФтАШDestroysтАФi.e., leads to hellтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi on 98, and N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Kull┼лka);тАФтАШmakes to fall from heaven, or makes to be born among lower animalsтАЩ (R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШincurs the guilt of killing themтАЩ (Kull┼лka, alternative).

тАШSaumyaтАЩтАФAddressed to Bhс╣Ыgu (Medh─Бtithi), but later on under 99, he rejects the view and says that it must be taken as addressed to the witness giving evidence.

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 674);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 205);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru, (35b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

(verses 8.89-97)

  • рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдпрдВ рди рддрддреНрдХрд╛рд░реНрдпреЛрдкрджреЗрд╢рдГ ред рддрддреНрдХрд╛рд░реНрдпреЛрдкрджреЗрд╢реЗ рд╣рд┐ рд╣рд┐рдВрд╕рд╛рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддреА рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдХреМрдЯрд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдореН рдПрддрджреН рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рдЙрддреНрддрд░реЛрддреНрддрд░рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рдГ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдЧреМрд░рд╡рд╛рд░реНрдерд╛ рди рдкреБрдирд░реН рд╡рд┐рд╡рдХреНрд╖рд┐рддреИрд╡ ред рддреЗрдиреЛрддреНрддрд░реЛрддреНрддрд░рд╕реНрдп рдЧрд░реАрдпрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред

рдЕрдпрдВ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рдГ рдХрд╕реНрдп рджрд╛рд╕ рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡рдВ рд╕рдВрд╢рдпреЗ рдпрджреН рдЕрдиреГрддрдВ рддрддреН рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╛рдиреГрддрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рее рео.репрео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The compound тАШpa┼Ыvanс╣ЫtamтАЩ is to be expounded as тАШpa┼Ыunimittam-anс╣Ыtam,тАЩ тАШfalse evidence regarding animals,тАЩтАФon the analogy of the compound тАШ┼Ы─Бkaparthivaс╕е.тАЩ

False evidence destroys five relatives;тАФthis тАШdestroyingтАЩ consists in making them fall into hell;тАФthe five relatives beingтАФ(1) the father, (2) the mother, (3) the wife and (4-5) a couple of children (son and daughter).

тАЬHow can the result of sin committed by one accrue to another?тАЭ

Our answer is that it is on account of association that one person goes to heaven or to hell, by virtue of the virtuous or vicious acts committed by another.

What is really meant is that the perjurer is abandoned by the said relatives;тАФor, that ho incurs the sin that would accrue from the killing of the relations; and hence even though not actually killing them, he is described as тАШdestroyingтАЩ them, on the ground that the spiritual effect of the two acts is the same.

This however is a purely hortatory exaggeration; and it is not meant that the man actually commits the act; if this latter were meant, then the man would be subject to the expiatory rites prescribed in connection with the actual killing of the said relatives; while as a matter of fact, the perjurer is subjected to only those sites that have been prescribed in connection with the sin of perjury.

The gradual increase in the number (of relatives destroyed) is meant to indicate the increasingly heavier character of the expiation necessary; and the statements are not meant to be taken as literally true. Hence all that is meant is that each succeeding act of perjury (mentioned) makes the man liable to a heavier expiation than the preceding one.

On being questioned as to the person to whom a certain slave belongs, if the witness deposes falsely,тАФit is a case of тАШfalse evidence regarding men.тАЩтАФ (98)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 674);тАФin Smс╣Ыtisaroddh─Бra (p. 336);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Saс╣Гsk─Бra, p. 220), which says that тАШpa├▒caтАЩ, тАШfiveтАЩ, qualifies тАШbandhav─БnтАЩ тАШrelations,тАЩ who have been mentioned in the preceding verse;тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 205);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (35b).

Baudh─Бyana (1.19.12-13).тАФтАШBy false testimony regarding gold, he ruins three ancestors; by false testimony regarding small cattle, he ruins five; by false testimony regarding kine, he kills ten; he ruins a hundred by false evidence regarding horses, and a thousand by false evidence regarding man; a witness who speaks falsely about land ruins the whole world.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (16.34).тАФтАШHe kills five by false testimony regarding a maiden; ten by false testimony regarding kine, a hundred by false testimony regarding a horse, and a thousand by false testimony regarding a man.тАЩ

Gautama (13.14-15).тАФтАШBy false evidence concerning small cattle, a witness kills ten; by that regarding cows, horses, men, or land,тАФin each succeeding case, ten times as many as in the one preceding; or, by false evidence regarding land, the whole human race.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

QuestionтАФтАЬHow can association with the sinful person affect those not yet born,тАФthat it is said that the man kills the born as well as the unborn?тАЭ

It has been already pointed out that all this is merely a hortatory exaggeration.

тАШHe kills all by deposing falsely in regard to land; never tell a lie regarding landтАЩ;тАФthis direct form of address has been adopted for the purpose of indicating the gravity of the offence.

QuestionтАФтАЬWhat is it that is called Land?тАЭ

AnswerтАФIt is what is known as globe, the earth with hilly protuberances, extending to the ocean.

ObjectionтАФтАЬBut who can be the owner of all this extensive earth? Who too can take it away by force? For there is no king over the whole earth. To this effect there is the earthтАЩs song addressed to Vi┼Ыvakarman Bhauvana,тАФthe latter term being his name derived from his fatherтАЩsтАФтАШno mortal can give me awayтАЩ;тАФwhich means that there is no one who owns the entire earth,тАФтАШI shall sink into the midst of the water, having heard that he is desirous of haring intercourse with me,тАЩтАФthis sinking within water implying the futility of the gift,тАФтАШvain is thy promise to give me awayтАЩтАФтАШjust as what Is thrown into the water becomes useless, so also is your promise to give the Earth to Ka┼Ыyapa useless.тАЩ (┼Ъatapatha Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, 13. 7. 1. 15). The meaning of all this is that the earth is the common property of all men, to be equally enjoyed by all; and kings are appointed only for taking care of it. Thus then, cither the giving away or the taking away of the whole extent of this earth being impossible, how can there be any disputes regarding its possession?тАЭ

AnswerтАФTrue; but, just as the entire earth is spoken of as тАШbh┼лmi,тАЩ тАШland,тАЩ so also are Holds, villages and platforms and over these latter, ownership is certainly possible; and the making over or the taking away also of such ownership is directly perceptible; the тАШtaking awayтАЩ of this consists in asserting ownership in an improper manner; and the mere dismantling of a house or the cutting of a tree does not constitute the act of тАШtaking away.тАЩ Hence if a man walks over another manтАЩs land, or takes clay out of it, ho is not said to тАШtake away the land.тАЩ

тАЬBut the M─лm─Бс╣Гsakas have declared that тАШIt cannot be the land, because it is common to allтАЩ (Jaimini, 6. 3. 3) [where the word тАШlandтАЩ stands for the whole earth].тАЭ

But the term is found to be used in the sense also of parts of the earth, by the revered Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зadvaip─Бyana, who has declared as follows, in course of the description of the duty of charityтАФтАШOn the earth the king should permit the duty of charity by others also; this is a sacred treasure laid down for kingsтАЩ [which refers to the gift of land]. As for the assertion of the M─лm─Бс╣Гsakas regarding тАШlandтАЩ being тАШcommon to all,тАЩтАФthis refers to the entire globe, to roam about over which all men are equally entitled, and which therefore, cannot he owned by any one; how then could it be given away? In accordance with this view, villages and towns can be given away at the Vi┼Ыvajit sacrifice. Others however quote the words тАШthey present as sacrificial fee, the bh┼лmi with the exception of the platform and the wifeтАЩs room,тАЩтАФand explain, that, since any such exception would not be applicable to the entire earth, the giving must refer to fields and such other parts of it only.

In view of the term тАШvad─лс╕етАЩ (singular) in this verse, the words тАШlisten, gentle sirтАЩ (of verse 97) should he taken as addressed to the witness, and not to the pupil.

All the words in the second person contained in verse 88 onwards (up to 92) are meant to be addressed to the ┼Ы┼лdra witness, as is clear from the gravity of the offence indicated, and also from the similarity in the verbal forms used;тАФwhile from verse 93 onwards are to be addressed to all witnesses. That such a break in the construction is intended is shown by the adopting of a different verbal form;тАФthe Second Person is used in the former set of verses while in the latter we have the Third Person, which clearly indicates dissociation from the previous context.тАФ(99).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШSarvam hantiтАЩтАФтАШDestroys everythingтАФi. e., incurs the guilt of killing all animate beingsтАЩ (Kull┼лka and Govindar─Бja);тАФтАШdestroys even more than a thousand beingsтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa);тАФтАШdestroys the entire universeтАЩ (Nandana).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Baudh─Бyana (1.19.12).тАФ(See under 98.)

Gautama (13.6).тАФтАШBy false evidence regarding land, one destroys the whole human race.тАЩ

The sin accruing from false evidence relating to the waterтАФmuch or littleтАФcontained in wells, tanks and other reservoirsтАФis similar to that in the ease of land.

тАШSexual enjoyment of womenтАЩ;тАФi.e., in answer to the questionтАФтАШby whom has this woman been ravished sexually.тАЩ

тАШWater-born gems,тАЩтАФsuch as the pearl;тАФтАШgranitic gemsтАЩтАФthe emerald and the like;тАФthe term тАШgemsтАЩ being construed both ways. There are various kinds of gems, waterborn and granitic; hence all that was necessary was to mention the тАШgemsтАЩ only; and the mention of the qualifying epithet must he taken only as serving the purpose of filling up the metre.

тАШWater-bornтАЩтАФproduced in water.

тАШGraniticтАЩтАФformed from stones.тАФ(100)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШCraftsmenтАЩтАФartisans; carpenters, blacksmiths, cooks and so forth.

тАШActorsтАЩтАФdancers and singers.

тАШMenial servants,тАЩтАФthose who serve others for a living; known as тАШd─Бsa.тАЩ

тАШMoney-lenders,тАЩтАФwho live upon interest on money lent.

These persons, even though they he Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, should, in the matter of taking evidence and administering ordeals,тАФthat this is meant is dear from тАШthe contextтАФhe тАШtreatedтАЩтАФi.e., questionedтАФтАШlike ┼Ъ┼лdrasтАЩ; but not so in other matters. That is to say, in taking evidence, the ┼Ъ┼лdra is not questioned with reference to charity, virtue and the like, and in ordeals, he is subjected to the ordeal by fire; and the same treatment should be meted out to the persons mentioned here.

Though ordeal has not yet been spoken of in the present context, yet what is said here is taken as applying to the case of ordeals also, because they are dealt with immediately after the present section, and immediate sequence also is a basis of relationship; the two subjects therefore are closely interrelated.тАФ(102)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 674), and again on p. 681, as indicating that in certain eventualities even a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa may be condemned to death;тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 19);тАФin V─лramitrodaya (Raj─Бn─лti, p. 268), which refers to Apar─Бrka and adds that the term тАШvipr─БmтАЩ here stands for the illiterate Brh─Бmaс╣Зa who does cattle-tending &c., as also for such Kс╣гatriyas and Vai┼Ыyas as are addicted to degraded vocations;тАФin Hem─Бdri (D─Бna, p. 35 and ┼Ъr─Бddha, p. 359);тАФin Pr─Бyascittaviveka (p. 384);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 205).

рддрджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛рдкрд┐ рдЬрд╛рдирдиреНрдиреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛ рд╡рджрдиреН рди рд╕реНрд╡рд░реНрдЧрд╛рджреН рднреНрд░рд╢реНрдпрддрд┐ ред рдХреВрдЯрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╡рджрдиреН рди рджреБрд╖реНрдпрддреАрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рдХрд┐рдВ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рджреИрд╡ ред рдиреЗрддреНрдпреН рдЖрд╣ ред рдзрд░реНрдорддреЛ рд╜рд░реНрдереЗрд╖реБ ред рдзрд░реНрдореЗрдг рджрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддреЗрдирд╛рд░реНрдереЗрд╖реБ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЗрд╖реБ ред рдзрд░реНрдорд╕реНрдп рдЪ рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддрддреНрд╡рдореН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН рдЙрддреНрддрд░рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЗ рджрд░реНрд╢рдпрд┐рд╖реНрдпрддрд┐ ред рдПрддрдЪреН рдЪ рди рд╕реНрд╡рдордиреАрд╖рд┐рдХрдпреЛрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣реНрдпреН рдПрддрд╛рдВ рд╡рд╛рдЪрдореН рд╡рджрдиреНрддрд┐ рдЕрд╕реНрдорд╛рддреН рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╕реНрдорд░реНрддрд╛рд░рдГ3 ред рдХрд╛ рдкреБрдирд░реН рджреИрд╡реА рд╡рд╛рдХреН ред рдпрдпрд╛рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддреЗ рд╜рдиреГрддрдВ рд╡рджрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╖рд╛ рджреЗрд╡рд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд┐рдиреА рд╡рд╛рдХреН рддрд╛рдВ рдордиреНрд╡рд╛рджрдпрдГ рд╢реНрд░реБрддреНрд╡рд╛ рд╡рджрдиреНрддреАрддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЗ рд╜рдиреГрддрдкреНрд░рд╢рдВрд╕рд╛ ред

рдЕрдиреНрдпреИрд╕реН рддреБ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рддрдпрд╛рдпрдВ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЛ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рддрдГ ред рддрджреН рдПрддрджреН рдЧреЛрд░рдХреНрд╖рдХрд╛рджрд┐рд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреБрдпреЛрдЧрд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпреЗрд╖реБ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгреЗрд╖реБ рднрд╡рд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛ рдмреНрд░рд╛рдГрдордгреЗрд╖реБ “рд╕рддреНрдпрдВ рдмреНрд░реВрд╣рд┐” (рдореНрдзреН рео.реорео) рдЗрддрд┐ рдпрдерд╛ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛ рдПрддреЗ рдХрдердВ рд╢реВрджреНрд░рд╡рджреН рдЕрдиреБрдпреЛрдЬреНрдпрд╛ рдЗрддрд┐ рддрджреНрд╡рд┐рджрд╛рдиреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рди рджреБрд╖реНрдпрддреАрддрд┐ рдпрддреЛ рдордиреНрд╡рд╛рджрдпрдГ рдПрд╡рдВрд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рдВ рд╡рд╛рдЪрдВ рд╡рджрдиреНрддрд┐ рдпрдереИрддреЗ рд╢реВрджреНрд░рд╡рджреН рдЖрдЪрд░рдгреАрдпрд╛4 рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддреЗ рдЪ рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рдзрд░реНрдордпреЛрдГ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрдореН ред рддреИрд╢реН рдЪ рд╕рддреНрдпрдВ рд╡рджрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рддрдЪреН рдЪ рдпрдерд╛рд╡рд┐рд╣рд┐рддрдВ рддрддреНрд░ рд╕ рдПрд╡ рдзрд░реНрдореЛ рдпрддреНрд░ рд╡рд╛рдиреГрддрдВ рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдиреГрддрд╛рднрд┐рдзрд╛рдирдореН рдПрд╡ рдзрд░реНрдо рдЗрддрд┐ рее рео.резрежрей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Though deposing otherwise than the truth, the man does not fall off from heaven; i.e., even though he has given false evidence, he does not incur sin.

тАЬIs this so at all times?тАЭ

The text proceeds to say that it is not so always; but only in cases where it is done тАШthrough piety,тАЩтАФi.e., through such pious motives as pity and the like; тАШcasesтАЩ means suits. How piety forms the motive is going to be shown in the next verse.

What is said here by the author is not out of his own mind; even previous writers on Smс╣Ыti have reproduced this тАШdivine assertion.тАЩ тАЬWhat divine assertion?тАЭтАФThe assertion that тАШone should give false evidence from considerations of pietyтАЩ has emanated from the gods; and having heard that, Manu and other writers have reproduced it.

This is only a praising of false evidence under special circumstances.

Others however have explained this verse as supplementing the previous injunction; and under this explanation what is said here should apply to what has been said regarding the cattleтАФtenders and other Br─Бhmaс╣Зas being exhorted like ┼Ъ┼лdras, when asked to give evidence. People might ask how a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa should be exhorted like a ┼Ъ┼лdra; and the text explains that there can be nothing wrong in this, since Manu and other writers have made the declaration that they are to be treated as ┼Ъ┼лdras, and they are the sole authority in matters relating to right and wrong.

Witnesses should tell the truth; and that in the manner in which it is enjoined; so that in a case where lying is righteous, that should he regarded as right.тАФ103

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

Buhler wrongly says that Nandana omits this verse; Hopkins is equally inaccurate in saying that Nandana places this verse after 104.

This verse is quoted in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (38a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Bс╣Ыhaspati (7.34).тАФтАШLet him preserve, even by telling a lie, a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa who has sinned once through error and is in peril of his life, and is oppressed by rogues and others.тАЩ

рдирдиреБ рдЪ рдкреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддрд╛рд╡реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдиреИрд╡ рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдореН рдЕрд╕реНрддрд┐ рдирд┐рдпреЛрдЧрд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рд╡реН рдЗрд╡ рд╡реНрдпрднрд┐рдЪрд╛рд░рд╛рдиреБрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирд╕реНрдореГрддреНрдпрднрд╛рд╡рд╛рддреН49 ред рдЕрдерд╛рдкреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддреМ рдХрд╛рдордпреЗрдд рдорд╛рд░рдгрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрднрдпрд╛рддреН рдкреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддрддреЗ рд╕реЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзреЛ рд░рд╛рдЧрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рдореН рдПрд╡ рд╣рд┐рдВрд╕рд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдпрддрд┐ ред рди рдЪрд╛рд╕реМ рд░рд╛рдЧрддреЛ рди рдкреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддрддреЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рддреБ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрднрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдпрд╛ рддреБ рдкрд░реЛрдкрдХрд╛рд░рддрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рдГ рд╕рд╛рдкрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрдкрд░рд┐рд╣рд╛рд░реЗрдг ред рдпреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдХрд┐рдВрдЪрд┐рджреН рдпрд╛рдЪреЗрджреН50 рдЕрдпрдореН рдЕрд╣рдореН рдЖрддреНрдорд╛рдирдВ рд╣рдиреНрдореАрддрд┐ рд╣рдиреНрдпрд╛рдиреН рди рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрд░рдпрдЪреНрдЫрддреЛ рдШрд╛рддрдХрддреНрд╡рдВ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЛрдЪреНрдЫреЗрджрдкреНрд░рд╕рдЩреНрдЧрд╛рддреН рее рео.резрежрек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

There is the general prohibition.тАФтАШone shall not speak a falsehoodтАЩ; and the present verse declares that this prohibition applies to cases other than that entailing the death of the ┼Ъ┼лdra and others; and it does not actually enjoin the telling of falsehood. For if it meant the latter, then any coordination between this and the said general prohibition would he impossible.

тАЬWhat is the condition meant to refer to what is asserted here? the phrase in that case cannot be taken as indicating that condition; as this phrase qualifies death; and as death is not existent at the time, it could not be the required condition; for if it were, the meaning would come to be that тАШwhen the death has been brought about, falsehood should be spokenтАЩ; and this is not what is meant.тАЭ

The term тАШwhereтАЩ referring to the case, the phrase тАШin that caseтАЩ also would refer to the same. Hence the meaning comes to be thatтАФтАШin a case where the party defeated becomes liable to deathтАЩ; and this certainly can serve as the required condition.

As for the kingтАЩs wrath, this cannot he regarded as the required condition; as it is an uncertain factor, and also because any penalty inflicted entirely through wrath would be illegal.

For all these reasons the only right course is to take the text as supplementary to the prohibition of lying.

In connection with GautamaтАЩs test, there is no chance of its being taken as an injunction of lying; for all that it says isтАФтАШthere is nothing wrong in lying, if a manтАЩs life is dependent upon itтАЩ (13.24).

In the face of such prohibitions and sanctions, it depends on the will of the man whether he shall tell the truth or untruth; so that arguing in his mind that by telling the truth, he becomes the cause of the death of the accused, and hence the transgressor of the law that тАШone shall not kill any living being,тАЩтАФthe man decides to tell the untruth; and in this he does what is quite reasonable.

Question. тАЬAll that the man does is to answer the question that is put to him; he does not kill; and without killing, how can he be tainted with the sin of killing?тАЭ

Answer. The man being free to say what he chooses, if, on account of his deposition, the accused comes to be killed by the king, he does become a means of thaс╣н killing, and hence its perpetrator or agent.

Question. тАЬEvery kind of means does not become an agent, e.g., when nobility is acquired by wealth, or тАЬfame by learning,тАЭ wealth and learning are the means but not the agents. What makes a certain thing the means is its capacity to bring about a special kind of effect in the form of substance or quality. Even when an action is spoken of as such an effectтАФe.g., in the assertion тАШcooking is done by fireтАЩтАФthe action that is spoken of by the verbal noun (тАШcookingтАЩ) is in its accomplished form (and hence as good as a substance or a quality; since an action is that which is still in course of being accomplished). But the effect spoken of in the present context is of a totally different kindтАФscriptural or spiritual, and not temporal,тАФbeing brought about by what is declared in the scriptural texts; and the Agent of such an act is not of the same character as that of the former. If the character of the Agent were to consist in command and prayerтАФwhich mean ordering and requesting,тАФthen, in the case of such assertions as тАШmake the corns become hot,тАЩ the use of the causal form would he impossible, as it refers to the corns, which are not sentient (and hence cannot have any command or prayer addressed to them).тАЭ

All this has already been answered by the commentators, who have explained that in such cases the action of the principal agent is imposed upon (represented as belonging to) the subordinate (insentient) agent. Such imposition upon insentient objects we find in such expressions asтАФтАШalms-begging affords shelter,тАЩ тАШthe dry cow-dung teaches,тАЩ and so forth. In such cases, the help accorded (in the shape of lodging and teaching) is not by the insentient things (begging and cow-dung), but by a different agent, who is the real instigator of the acts. the act of teaching, for instance, is prompted by the Injunction of having recourse to a Teacher; and when the teacher is doing this act of teaching, he is hampered by cold and such other hindrances; and this cold is removed by the dry cow-dung (being burnt as fuel); thus it is that the action of тАШteachingтАЩ itself comes to be imposed upon the cow-dung. An тАШagentтАЩ or an тАШinstigatorтАЩ is so called because of the impelling or urging done by it; and we do find such impelling being done also by such insentient things as wind and water, in reference to the burning of fire and floating of wood (respectively). And in all such cases as there can be no directing, etc., done by the Fire, the words would have to be regarded as used in a figurative sense.

If again the character of the тАШagentтАЩ be hold to consist in doing something conducive to the act in question,тАФthen this could only he in accordance with the actual action of the Agent concerned, which action would be in the form of preparing for the main act; for one who arranges for an act is said to hate it done; when for instance, for a person who is going to dine, one man brings up the dish and another serves the rice and so forth; similarly when a man is going to do the act of killing, one man offers him the weapon, while another, by recounting the misdeeds of the man going to ho killed, kindles the rage of the person going to kill him. In all such cases, though each of these other abettors does not do any directing or urging, yet, in as much as he helps to bring about conditions favourable for the fulfilment of the act concerned, becomes a sort of an тАШagentтАЩ in it, in the sense that what he actually does is conducive to the said act.

According to this view, the cow-dung and the Teacher would stand on the same footing (as agents in the act of teaching).

But in this connection also that principal instigator is the тАШAgentтАЩ without whom the act cannot be accomplished and who does not fall within the category of any other particular case-relation. Without the readier, the cow-dung itself cannot become a prompter of the teaching; while the teacher can do the teaching, even without the cow-dung, and hence the cow-dung becomes the subordinate factor. As for those things that are definitely recognised as the тАШinstrument,тАЩ or such other factor conducive to the accomplishment of an act,тАФthese also would he clearly subordinate. For instance, when one sees a man going to a remote village again, even on slight business, he says тАШthe horse makes Devadutta go.тАЩ

Question.тАФтАЬAs a matter of fact, in connection with the nomenclature of the case-relations, there is no reference made to the greater or less intimacy of the determining relation; what difference then is there between the cow-dung and the Teacher (so far as the character of the nominative agent of the act of teaching is concerned)? The. distinction that you have drawn between the two is a mere gratuitous assumption of yours, and there is no reality behind it; while all Injunctions and Prohibitions refer to realities. Further, it has also been declared that тАШthe exact nature of case-relations is determined by the wish of the speaker.тАЩ Under the circumstances, if a certain speaker wishes to speak of a nonagent as the agent, the Injunctions and Prohibitions relating to the Agent could become applicable to him. For instance, when enunciating the Sins, manu himself mentions тАШthe buyer, the seller, the cooker and the serverтАЩ (ns the killer of the animal whose flesh is eaten). From this it is clear that the maxim that you have propounded is meant for the purpose of lending support to the position taken up by yourself, and it does not touch the reality of things.тАЭ

It is for this very reason that the commentators have agreed that if the mere doing of something conducive to an act were the condition of being the тАШagent,тАЩ then every kind of cause (of the act) would have to be regarded as тАШagent.тАЩ So that when one gives food to a man, and this man, being a glutton, happens to die by over-eating,тАФthe man who gave the food would become the agent in the act of killing. As a matter of fact, however, the action of the feeder has not been prompted by the idea of killing the man; it was prompted by the idea of a totally different act, in the form of feeding, and not in that of killing; nor was it prompted by hatred or jealousy or any such feeling. So that oven though the man may have helped to bring about the death, yet he does not become the тАШagentтАЩ of that act. That is all that we have to say. In a case where one takes away lands or gold, etc., belonging to another person, and the latter dies through grief caused by the robbery,тАФit has to be considered whether the robber becomes the тАШagentтАЩ in the act of robbing only, or in that of killing also.

тАЬWhat is then to be тАШconsideredтАЩ in this connection? The relation of Cause and Effect can he ascertained by infallibility; and the robbing of land or gold is not an infallible cause of death, to the same extent as striking with the, sword or starving is.тАЭ

What sort of тАШinfallibilityтАЩ is meant here? It may he held that if by a certain thing, some one dies, while others do not,тАФthen the agency or causal efficiency of that thing (towards bringing about death) would be regarded as тАШfallible.тАЩ But any such principle would be defective, on account of the divergence in the constitution of men. One and the same medicine is found to be beneficial to a man of phlegmatic constitution, but harmful to another. In fact in the case of all men, the appearance of now forces is dependent upon such contingencies as those of disposition, place, time, nature and accessories. In fact in the eases cited also, the death is dependent upon the wealth and progeny of the man concerned, as also upon thirst and other living organisms (?). For instance, if the man robbed is of a very passionate disposition, or liable to give way to grief, the trouble caused by the robbery becomes conducive to death. And in such a case can the agency (of the robber in the net of killing) he denied? On the other hand, if the man is easy-natured, ho ignores the robbery. This same reasoning applies also to the case of the man who, being obsessed by grief, commits suicide by having recourse to starvation, falling from a precipice, taking poison,тАФlaying the blame of it upon other persons.

тАЬBut in such cases, in as much the taking of poison and other well-known causes of death would be present, the wrong done in the shape of robbing the land, etc., could not be regarded.os the cause of the death.тАЭ

But since the man has recourse to the means of death, by reason of being stricken with grief, caused by the robbery,тАФthe robbery becomes the indirect cause of the death.

If such be the case, then if some one happens to be aggrieved by wholesome advice given by a well-wisher and commit suicide, the person offering the advice would be a тАШmurderer.тАЩ Similarly, jealous persons, withering under the pangs of jealousy, would place the blame of their suffering upon the wealthy person of whom they are jealous. Likewise, when a man with unhinged mind dies upon the death of his son or his loved person,тАФthese latter would have to be regarded as тАШmurderers.тАЩ In the same manner some light-hearted people, on seeing a beautiful woman, become so affected that, becoming brokenhearted, they lose all consciousness; and in this case chaste women would have to be censured. And lastly (in the event of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa dying of grief caused by the death of a loved person) the dead person would incur the sin of having killed a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa.

All this would be quite true, if there were no specific injunctions and prohibitions covering special oases. As a matter of fact however, the offering of wholesome advice is enjoined, while the robbing of what belongs to another is forbidden. It has been thus declaredтАФтАШIn the case of people engaged in doing good to others, if there happen something untoward, no blame attaches to those people; as for example, in the case of physicians administering medicine.тАЩ This does not mean that it is only in the case of medicines administered by physicians producing untoward results that there is no blame attaching to the physicians,тАФbut in all similar cases; e.g., when a cow has become stuck in the mire, if a man exerts himself to the utmost in pulling her out with his hand, and the cow happens to die, the man, who tried to pull her out, is not open to blame. Similarly in all analogous cases.

If a man happens to carry on bis business carefully and acquires much prosperity in the shape of riches,тАФif some people happen to burn with jealousy, that man does not transgress any scriptural prohibition. Further, an act becomes an object of prohibition only when its causal efficiency (towards harm) is certain and unfailing; and no definite deduction can be drawn regarding the momentarily changing mental aberrations of. living beings; so that it cannot be definitely ascertained that such and such a person has died on account of the beauty of such and such a woman. And so long as we can get at well-ascertained objects of prohibition, it cannot be right to make it pertain to doubtful cases.

тАЬBut in a case where the fact of the man becoming pale and withered in body, it is definitely ascertained that the cause of his suffering lies in the beauty of a certain woman,тАФthis woman should either renounce her chastity and meet him, or else she should be regarded as a murderess.тАЭ

Certainly not; even though the causal efficiency (of the womanтАЩs chastity towards her loverтАЩs sufferings) be duly ascertained, yet chastity cannot become an object of prohibition; because such a prohibition would be contrary to a definite Injunction; there is such an Injunction regarding the avoidance of unchastity; and so long as an Injunction has room for application in an objection not touched by any other Injunction, it cannot encroach upon the objective of a contrary Injunction (so that so long as the prohibition of killing has room for application in the shape of ordinary murder, etc., it cannot encroach upon the objective of the Injunction of chastity.)

Some people argue as follows:тАФтАЬWhat the injunction of chastity prohibits is that act which is done under the impulse of sexual passion, and not that which is done under a righteous impulse sanctioned by the scriptures. Hence, if the woman has intercourse with her dying lover, solely for saving his life, being moved entirely by the consideration that the poor man may lose his life,тАФshe does not, by the act, transgress the injunction of chastity as regards the dictum that one injunction cannot encroach upon the objective of another; as the act in question does not form the objective of any other injunction, being due entirely to passion. It might he argued that there is no scriptural injunction sanctioning the act (of the woman meeting the dying lover), because there is no Smс╣Ыti text permitting adultery in such cases, as there is one sanctioning the begetting of a child from the dead husbandтАЩs younger brother. It is true that if she did not act so, she would be encompassing the death of the man,тАФand it is on account of the prohibition of the act of killing that she acts in that manner. But that prohibition applies only to the killing that is done through the passion of hatred; while when the woman desists from meeting the man, it is not through hatred of him, but on account of the prohibition of adultery. The act too that one may do for benefiting another person, must be one that avoids the transgressing of all prohibitions.тАЭ

In a case where some one asks a man for a certain thing, and threatens that he would kill himself if the thing is not given to him,тАФand does actually kill himself,тАФthe man who refused the request cannot be regarded as a murderer. For if men were to be so regarded, there would be an end to all worldly business.тАФ(104)

This verse is quoted in Pr─Бya┼Ыcittaviveka (p. 432), which says that this is to be regarded as mere arthav─Бda, as expiatory rites are prescribed for this lying also;тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 207), as an exception to the general rule regarding deposing truthfully;тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (38a);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, p. 58a), which explains that this verse makes silence, or even lying, better than telling the truth, under the circumstances.

Gautama (13.24-25).тАФтАШNo guilt is incurred in giving false evidence in case the life of a man depends thereon;тАФbut not if the man involved be a wicked one.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (16.35).тАФтАШMen may speak an untruth in marriage, during dalliance, when their lives are in danger, or the loss of their entire property is imminent; and for the sake of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa; they declare that an untruth spoken in these five cases does not make the speaker an outcast.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.83).тАФтАШWhen the death of a member of any caste is involved the witness may speak an untruth.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (7.34).тАФтАШLet him preserve, even by telling a lie, a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa who has sinned once through error, and is in peril of life, and oppressed by rogues and others.тАЩ

B├╝hler

104 Whenever the death of a Sudra, of a Vaisya, of a Kshatriya, or of a Brahmana would be (caused) by a declaration of the truth, a falsehood may be spoken; for such (falsehood) is preferable to the truth.

рдПрддрдЪреН рдЪ рди рдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН ред рдЕрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рд╣рд┐ рдкрдХреНрд╖реЗ рджреЗрд╡рддрд╛рддреНрд╡рдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреЛ рдореГрдЧреНрдпрдореН ред рддрддреНрд░64 рдпрд╛рдЧрд╕рдВрдкреНрд░рджрд╛рдирдВ рджреЗрд╡рддреЗрддрд┐ рд╕реНрдорд░рдгрд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдзрдГ ред рдПрд╖рд╛ рдЪ рд╕реНрдореГрддрд┐рд░реН рдмрд▓реАрдпрд╕реА, рдирд┐рд░рдкреЗрдХреНрд╖рддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН ред рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╛ рджреЗрд╡рддрд╛ рдЙрджреНрджреЗрд╢реНрдпрд╛65 рдзреНрдпреЗрдпрд╛ рдЪ ред рдпрд╕реНрдпреИ рджреЗрд╡рддрд╛рдпреИ рд╣рд╡рд┐рд░реН рдЧреГрд╣реАрддрдВ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН рддрд╛рдВ рдордирд╕рд╛ рдзреНрдпрд╛рдпреЗрджреН рдЗрддрд┐ рддрддреНрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдХрд░реНрдорддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рдХрд░реНрдордгреНрдпреН рдПрд╖рд╛ рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпрд╛ рее рео.резрежрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШSpeech-goddessтАЩтАФgoddess in the form of speech; the rice boiled for her is said to be тАШdedicated to the speech-goddessтАЩ;тАФRice not over-boiled is called тАШchantтАЩ;тАФwith these they should offer sacrifices.

We have тАШcarubhiс╕е,тАЩ тАШwith half-boiled rice,тАЩ in the plural number, on account of the plural number in the verb тАШyajerauтАЩ, тАШthey should sacrificeтАЩ; and it does not mean that each man shall offer several kinds of rice. Nor is this offering to be made by several persons collectively, as is done in the case of the Vr─Бtyastoma offering. The plural number in the present case is exactly analogous to the plural number in such passages asтАФтАШIf it rains, many Br─Бhmaс╣Зas should offer sacrificesтАЩ; and it is not like that in the case of the тАШkapi├▒jala birdsтАЩ (where at least three are meant).

In the case in question the lie is told for the sake of helping the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa or some such person; and this lying itself is a тАШsinтАЩ;тАФthe action of lying itself being a sin. The genitive ending in the phrase тАШanс╣Ыtasyainaс╕етАЩ тАШsin of lyingтАЩ denotes apposition; just as in the phrase тАШDharmakriy─БтАЩ (where тАШdharmaтАЩ and тАШkriy─БтАЩ are in apposition). Some people however hold that тАШvirtueтАЩ and тАШviceтАЩ or тАШmeritтАЩ and тАШsinтАЩ are produced by actions (and do not consist in the actions themselves); and according to this view in the phrase тАШanс╣Ыtasya enaс╕е,тАЩ тАШsin of lying,тАЩ the terms тАШsinтАЩ of тАШlyingтАЩ would not be in apposition; the тАШsinтАЩ being the effect of the lying, and hence figuratively spoken of as being in apposition with it.

The тАШniс╣гkс╣ЫtiтАЩ of this sin is тАШpurifying,тАЩ тАШcleaning,тАЩтАФi.e., expiation.

тАШBestтАЩтАФmost excellent.

тАЬWhy should there be any sin in this caseтАФwhen it has been declared that there is nothing wrong in lying under the circumstances mentioned.тАЭ

Some people answer this objection by pointing out that the avoiding of untruth leads to excellent results (even when the telling of untruth may be permissible): a man may, on the basis of the scriptures, have taken the vow that throughout his life he would not tell a lie; and if such a man were to tell a lie for saving the life of a man, he would incur the sin of having boon false to his vow; and it is in view of this sin that the present text prescribes the expiation. Even though such acts as the burning of a house and killing are prohibited, yet they have been sanctioned under special conditions. Similarly we have (in the preceding verse) the sanction for lying under special circumstances; hence the mention of its тАШexpiationтАЩ must be regarded as a mere reference (to the prohibition of lying in general).

Question.тАФтАЬHow can a sacrifice be offered to Sarasvat─л with what has been dedicated to the goddess of speech?тАЭ If the rice has been тАШdedicatedтАЩ to the Speech-goddess, how can the sacrifice be regarded as offered to Sarasvat─л? Or, if the two Sarasvat─лs (one spoken of by the name тАШSarasvati, тАШwhile the other is referred to by the name тАШspeech-goddessтАЩ) combined be regarded as the deity to whom the sacrifice is offered,тАФthen there arises this difficulty that, as a matter of fact, the exact nature of the deity of a sacrifice can be learnt entirely from words, and the two names here used are two distinct words (so that both could not refer to the same deity); for instance, if the injunction of an offering is in the formтАФтАШthe offering should be made to Agni,тАЩтАФpeople do not use the other names of Agni,тАФsuch as тАШJvalanaтАЩ тАШKс╣Ы┼Ы─БnuтАЩ and the likeтАФwhen actually making the sacrifice. Similarly when the injunction is in the form тАШone should offer to V─Бyu,тАЩтАФeven though it is distinctly laid down that тАШVaya is Pr─Бс╣ЗaтАЩтАФthe name тАШPr─Бс╣ЗaтАЩтАФis not used when the offering is actually made.тАЭ

All this is quite true; тАШspeech-goddessтАЩ is the deity of the sacrifice,тАФthe nominal affix in the term тАШv─БgdaivatyaтАЩ being denotative of the deific character; and the deity is not denoted by the term тАШSarasvat─лm,тАЩ which appears with the accusative ending. Because the Accusative ending denotes the objective, while the deity is the recipient, and not the objective.

тАЬHow then is the term тАШSarasvat─лmтАЩ to be construed?тАЭ

The present passage is only a hortatory exaggeration, just like the assertion тАШone should make au offering to Agni, Agni is all deities;тАЩ and what the present statement means is that тАШspeech-goddess is Sarasvat─л herself, and hence when the offering is made to the former she is pleased, and it reaches the other also.тАЩ

The character of the тАШdeityтАЩ is ascertained only through sacrifices; as in the case of sacrifices offered to Agni, to Praj─Бpati and so forth (where the fact of Agni or Praj─Бpati being the deity is ascertained only by the sacrifice being offered to them).

Some people explain that what is meant is that the deities are to be worshipped, the root тАШyajiтАЩ (in тАШyajeranтАЩ) signifying the act of worshipping; and the deity worshipped forms the objective of the тАШworshipтАЩ; so that the use of the Accusative in тАШSarasvat─лmтАЩ is only right and proper. There are several such assertions as тАШhe worships the deityтАЩ (where the deity is the object of the verb to worship).тАЭ

This however is not right. As under this view the deific character of Sarasvat─л will have to be deduced from somewhere else; and such an interpretation would be contrary to the dictum that тАШthe deific character consists in being the recipient of a sacrificial offering.тАЩ This dictum however, being self-sufficient, is highly authoritative.

The real explanation is that the deity to whom a sacrifice is offered is to be made the recipient of the offering, and also to be meditated upon,тАФaccording to the injunction, тАШOne shall think in his mind of the deity for whom the offering is held upтАЩ; so that the deity is also the object of the act of meditating; and the accusative ending (in тАШSarasvat─лmтАЩ) actually denotes the objective itself.тАФ(105)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШKapi├▒jalaiс╕етАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, p. 937, l. 11)тАФThis refers to a case dealt with in M─лm─Бс╣Гs─Б-s┼лtra, where it is said that whenever the plural number is used, we should understand it to mean three; for instance, when тАШKapi├▒jala birdsтАЩ are spoken of as to be sacrificed. Medh─Бtithi says that this principle should not be applied to the present case of the plural in тАШCharrubhiс╕етАЩ.

Nandana does not read the verse differently as asserted by Hopkins.

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 682), which adds that the plural number in тАШCarubhiс╕етАЩ is due to the plurality of the persons referred to hereтАФтАШteтАЩ, тАШtheyтАЩ;тАФin Pr─Бya┼Ыcittaviveka (p. 432), which says that this refers to the three higher castes only.

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Pr─Бya┼Ыcitta, p. 390);тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 355), which adds that тАШV─Бgdevat─БтАЩ here must be taken as standing for Sarasvat─л, the terms тАШV─БkтАЩ and тАШSarasvat─лтАЩ being synonymous, specially as it is only thus that the offering shall be consistent with its name тАШSacrifice to Sarasvat─лтАЩ; it proceeds to add that the pronoun тАШteтАЩ here stands for those witnesses who tell a lie for saving a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa or a Kс╣гatriya from death;тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 207); and in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (38b).

рдШреГрддрдореН рдЕрдЧреНрдирд╛рд╡реН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рддреНрд░рд╛рдиреБрд╖рдЩреНрдЧрдГ ред рдпрдерд╛рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐ ред рдпрд╛рджреГрд╢рдГ рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╕рдорд╛рдЪрд╛рд░ рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рддреЗрди рдЪ рд╣рд╡рд┐рд╖рдГ рд╕рддреНрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН77 рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд╛рдпрд╛рдореН рдЗрддрд┐рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрддрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдкрд░рд┐рд╕рдореВрд╣рдирдкрд░реНрдпреБрдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рд╡реЗрдХреНрд╖рдгрд╕реНрд░реБрд╡рд╣реЛрдорд╛рджреНрдпреЗрддрд╛рд╡рдиреНрдорд╛рддреНрд░рдореН рдЕрдиреБрдЬрд╛рдирд╛рддрд┐ ред рд╡рд╛рд╢рдмреНрджрд╛рджреН рд╡реИрдХрд▓реНрдкрд┐рдХрд╛рдГ рд╕рд░реНрд╡ рдПрд╡ рее рео.резрежрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The mantras called тАШk┼лс╣гm─Бс╣Зс╕Н─БтАЩ are found in the Yajurveda; with these he shall offer clarified butter into the fire. The root тАШhuтАЩ (in тАШjuhuy─БtтАЩ) signifies the act of giving away to a certain deity; and as the term тАШagnauтАЩ mentions Agni only as the receptacle into which the offering is to be poured, the deity of the offering should be deduced from the words of these Mantras themselves. In those cases where the words of the mantras are not found to be indicative of any deity,тАФe.g., in the mantra тАШdevakс╣Ыtasyainasovayanamasi, etc.тАЩ (Y─Бjurved─Б, 8.13) Praj─Бpati is to be accepted as the required deity,тАФso say the people learned in sacrificial lore. The other alternative view is that the offering in such cases is to be associated with those that have already been found to be the тАШdeityтАЩ of other offerings. The author of the Nirukta also has declaredтАФтАШwhat others could be the deity?тАЩ Though there is no deity common to all offerings in general, each sacrifice has its own materials as well as deity clearly indicated, sometimes directly, sometimes indirectly through mantras.

What we say however is that the mantra тАШdevakс╣Ыtasyainasovayajanamasi,тАЩ itself contains the term тАШyajanaтАЩ; and as тАШyajanaтАЩ is the same as тАШy─Бjana,тАЩ it is the latter that is the required deity; and as in the case of every mantra, there is hound to be something that is denoted by it, there will always be some words of the mantra that would indicate the required deity.

The verse тАШut, etc.,тАЩ refers to the verse тАШUduttamam varuс╣Зa p─Б┼Ыamasmat, etc.тАЩ (с╣Ъgveda, 1.24.15); and the epithet тАШsacred to Varuс╣ЗaтАЩ has been added in order to exclude the other verse beginning with тАШutтАЩ,тАФvis., тАЬUt-tv─Б madantu stom─Б,тАЩ etc. (с╣Ъgveda, 8.64.1).

тАШWith the three verses sacred to the waters.тАЩтАФThe term тАШdaivataтАЩ is synonymous with тАШdevat─БтАЩ; and the three verses of which the Waters are the deity are тАШ─Аpohiс╣гс╣нh─Б mayobhuvaс╕е, etcтАЩ (с╣Ъgveda, 10.9.1). In this case there is one oblation with each of these three verses and one with all the three collectively.

The terms тАШclarified butterтАЩ and тАШinto the fireтАЩ have to be construed with every clause.

тАШAccording to rule,тАЩтАФi.e., in accordance with the practice of cultured people. Hence, in as much as the offering being that of butter, all the details of the primary sacrifices could not be transferred to it,тАФthis phrase sanctions the adopting of only such details as the brushing of the place, sprinkling it with water, examining of the butter, pouring the oblations with the sruva and so forth.

The particle тАШv─БтАЩ shows that all the offerings mentioned are to be regarded as optional alternatives.тАФ(106)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

K┼лс╣гmaс╣Зс╕Нaiс╕етАЩтАФi.e ., V─Бjasaneya Saс╣Гhit─Б, 20.14-16, or Taittir─лya ─Аraс╣Зyaka, 10.3-5.

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 682), which adds that тАШuditiтАЩ refers to the opening word of the mantra тАШUduttamamvaruс╣Зa p─Б┼Ыamasmat &c.тАЩ (с╣Ъgveda, 1.24.15);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Pr─Бya┼Ыcitta, p. 390);тАФin Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Vyavah─Бra, p. 207);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (38b).

рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреНрд╡реН рдЖрд╣реБрд╕реН рддрджреН рдЛрдгрдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрдиреБрдпрд╛рджреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдпрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рдЛрдгрд╛рдкрд╣рд░рдгрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгреЗрди83 рдкрд╛рдкреЗрди рдпреБрдЬреНрдпреЗрдд ред рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮреЗ рд╡рд╛ рдЬреАрдпрдорд╛рдирд╕реНрдп рдпреЛ рджрдгреНрдбрд╕реН рддрддреЛ рджрд╢рдордореН рдЕрдВрд╢рдВ рджрджреНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЗрддрд┐ рджрдгреНрдбрд┐рддрдГ рдкреБрдирдГ рджрдгреНрдбреНрдпрддреЗ84 рее рео.резрежрен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Fifteen days and nights make a тАШfortnightтАЩ; the aggregate of three fortnights is called тАШtripakс╣гamтАЩ; according to P─Бс╣Зini 2.4.17, the compound should have a feminine ending, but this is precluded by the exception that follows, regarding тАШp─БtraтАЩ and other words (which include the word тАШpakс╣гaтАЩ also).

тАЬIn that case the feminine form тАШtripakс╣г─лтАЩ should be impossible.тАЭ

The wrong gender in that case is to be regarded as a тАШVedic anomaly.тАЩ

The Ablative ending in тАШtripakс╣г─БtтАЩ has the force of the participial affix тАШlyap.тАЩ

The meaning of the verse thus is thatтАФтАШHe who after having waited for three fortnights, dees not give evidence, without being ill, should hear the burden of that debtтАЩ;тАФтАШas also the tenth part out of it, as a penalty.тАЩ

тАШDebts and other mailersтАЩ;тАФthe addition of the phrase тАШand other mattersтАЩ indicates that what is said here applies to all kinds of suits; and the repetition of the term тАШdebtтАЩ is only by way of illustration. The meaning is thatтАФтАШin a suit where for the said time no evidence is given, the burden of the defeated party is to be borne by the witnesses.тАЩ

тАШGada,тАЩ тАШillness,тАЩ is meant to indicate other kinds of disability also; so that due cognizance should be taken of such conditions also as family troubles, fear of creditor and so forth.

The term тАШbandhaтАЩ following a numeral word, denotes penalty, and stands for the тАШtenth part.тАЩ

The terms тАШnaraс╕етАЩ and тАШsarvataс╕етАЩ are added only for filling up the metre.

Others explain that the assertion тАШshould hear that debtтАЩ means that тАШhe incurs the sin of stealing the amount of the debt.тАЩ

The meaning is that the man shall pay the tenth part of the fine that would be payable to the king by the defeated party.тАФ(107)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

Hopkins again misrepresents Nandana as reading тАШgatonaraс╕етАЩ for тАШNarogadaс╕е.тАЩ It is clear that Hopkins had a very defective manuscript of NandanaтАЩs commentary.

тАШSapt─Бh─Бt,тАЩ тАШwithin a week,тАЩтАФthe use of the Ablative implies that the proposition тАШbeforeтАЩ is understood. That is, on anyone of the seven days, after he has given evidence, if the witness is found to suffer from sickness, it implies that he has been adjudged by destiny to be a perjuror, and hence he should be punished in accordance with the aforesaid rule.

тАШIllnessтАЩ stands for any kind of acute suffering;тАФтАШfireтАЩ for the burning of cattle and conveyances;тАФand тАШdeath of a relativeтАЩ for the death of the son or the wife or some other near relative;тАФall these being indicative of his having given false evidence.тАФ(108)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШWitnessless cases,тАЩтАФthose cases in which there are no witnesses;тАФin regard to these, when the king fails to find out the truth,тАФby any means,тАФi.e, by any ordinary methods,тАФтАШhe shall discoverтАЩтАФlearnтАФit тАШby means of oathтАЩтАФi.e, by transcendental methods of inference. The root тАШlabhтАЩ тАШto get atтАЩ (in тАШlambhayetтАЩ), though literally meaning the attaining of a thing, indirectly implies knowing.

All that the advice conveyed by the injunction means is that тАШin cases where there are no witnesses, he shall discover the truth by means of oathтАЩ; all the rest merely fills up the metre.

тАШMithaс╕етАЩтАФbetween themselves.тАФ(109)

тАШ┼ЪapathenaтАЩтАФтАШSupernatural proofтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШoathтАЩтАФтАШtouching of the head and so forthтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa),тАФor declaring тАШmay heinous sins accrue to me if what I have said turns out to be untrueтАЩ (Nandana).

Gautama (13.12-13).тАФтАШSome declare that the witnesses shall be charged with oath to speak the truth. In the case of others than Br─Бhmaс╣Зas that oath shall be sworn in the presence of Gods, of Br─Бhmaс╣Зas and of the King.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.235, 236, 239).тАФтАШWhen owing to the negligence of the creditor, both documentary evidence and witnesses are missing,тАФand the defendant denies his obligation, three different methods may be adopted:тАФTimely reminder, Argument, and thirdly, Oath; these are the measures that the plaintiff should adopt against his adversary. N─Бrada (1.247-249).тАФтАШIf no witness is forthcoming, for either of the two litigant parties, he must test them through ordeals and oaths of every sort. Bс╣Ыhaspati (10.1-3).тАФтАШA forger of gems, pearl or coral, one withholding a deposit, a ruffian and an adulterer shall, in every case, be tested by oaths and ordeals. ┼Ъukran─лti (4.5, 529).тАФтАШThe six kinds of decision areтАФthrough evidence, argument, custom, oaths, kingтАЩs edict and confession by the defendant.тАЩ

рдкреИрдЬрд╡рдиреЛ рд░рд╛рдЬрд╛ рдмрднреВрд╡ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдХрд╛рд▓реЗ рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рддреНрд░реЗрдгрд╛рдХреНрд░реБрд╖реНрдЯреЛ рдордгреНрдбрд▓рдореН рдЕрдзреНрдпрдЧрддрдГ рдХрд╛рдордХреНрд░реЛрдзрд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдВ рд╕рдВрдХреНрд╖реБрдмреНрдзрд╛рдЪрд░рдгреЛ88 рд╜рдШрд╛рд╕реБрд░реЛ рдпрд╛рддреБрдзрд╛рдиреЛ рд╜рд╕реНрдореАрддрд┐ рд╢рдкрдердВ рдЧреГрд╣реАрддрд╡рд╛рдиреН ред рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рддреНрд░реЗрдгреЛрдХреНрддрд╕реН рддрд╕реНрдп рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрдГ рд╕рдордХреНрд╖рдореН рдЕрдиреЗрдиреИрд╡ рддрддреНрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╢рддрдореН рдЕрд╢рд┐рддрдореН рдПрд╖ рд╣рд┐ рд░рдХреНрд╖ рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрддрдГ рд╕ рдЙрд╡рд╛рдЪ ред рдЕрджреНрдпреИрд╡ рдореНрд░рд┐рдпреЗ рдпрджрд┐ рд░рдХреНрд╖рдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЖрддреНрдордиреНрдпреН рдЕрдирд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд╢рдВрд╕рдирдореН рдЕрддреНрд░ рд╢рдкрдердГ ред рдкреБрддреНрд░рджрд╛рд░рд╛рджрд┐рд╢рд┐рд░рдГрд╕реНрдкрд░реНрд╢рдиреЗ рдПрддрджреН рдЕрдирд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд╕рдВрд╢рдирдВ рд╢рдкрдереЛ рдордиреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ рее рео.резрезреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This is a commendatory supplement to the foregoing injunction of having recourse to oaths.

тАШBy the great sagesтАЩтАФi.e., by the seven sages, called тАШSaptarс╣гi,тАЩ and the rest;тАФтАШoaths have been taken, for the purposes of a case,тАЩтАФi.e., for the purpose of arriving at a decision regarding doubtful cases.

In this connection the story recounted by the revered Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зadvaip─Бyana may be cited as an example. On one occasion when their lotuses had been stolen, the seven sages swore among themselvesтАФтАШhe who has stolen your lotus shall go the way of sinners,тАЩ and so forth.

тАШBy the GodsтАЩтАФIndra and the rest, also; e.g., when Indra was accused in relation to Ahaly─Б, he swore many oaths, being afraid of being cursed.

тАШVashisthaтАЩ has been mentioned separately, for the purpose of indicating his special importance;тАФhe also swore; the term тАШoathтАЩ itself conveying the sense of swearing, the verb тАШsworeтАЩ should be taken in the sense of тАШtookтАЩ; just as we have such expressions as тАШsacrifices a sacrifice,тАЩ тАШnourished with self-nourishment,тАЩтАФso have we also the expression тАШswore an oath.тАЩ тАШShepeтАЩ is the third person singular form in the Past Perfect tense of the root тАШshapтАЩ to swear.

Before the king Paijavanu;тАФSud─Бs, the son of Pijavana was a king; and, during his reign, on being accused by Vi┼Ыv─Бmitra in the midst of an assembly, Vashistha was beset with anger and desire and took the oath with regard to his being a^(тАШ)demonтАЩ; in the presence of that same king he had been accused of having тАШdevoured his hundred sonsтАЩ and hence being a тАШdemonтАЩ; whereupon he sworeтАФ^(тАШ)may I die to-day, if I am a demon!тАЩтАФthis invoking of an undesirable contingency upon himself being what is called an тАШoath.тАЩ In a case where people swear by laying their hands upon the head of their wife or children, the тАШoathтАЩ consists in invoking evil upon these latter.тАФ(110)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШPaijavanaтАЩ is another name for king Sud─Бs, say N─Бr─Бy─Бс╣Зa and Kull┼лka.

For the story of the seven sages, see the Mah─Бbh─Бrata 13.93; 13. тАЬSee S─Бyana on с╣Ъgveda 7.104.15, which is considered to contain the oath sworn.тАЭтАФBuhler.

This verse is quoted in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 406);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (62a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

N─Бrada (1.243, 244).тАФтАШOf gods and sages even, the taking of oaths is recorded. Vasiс╣гс╣нha took an oath when he was accused of having assumed the shape of an evil spirit. The seven с╣Ъс╣гis resolutely took an oath together with Indra, in order to clean themselves mutually of suspicion, when each was suspected of having stolen lotus-fibres.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.461).тАФтАШOrdeals are known as divya, divine, because they were used by the devas, gods, in the discrimination of difficult cases.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The wise man shall not take an oath improperly; taking an improper oath, one becomes ruined here as well as after death.тАФ(111)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдорд┐рдереНрдпрд╛рд╢рдкрдереЗ рдлрд▓рд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рдирдореН рдПрддрддреН ред рд╡реГрдерд╛ рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛ рдЕрд╕рддреНрдпрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рдпрд╛рд╡рддреН ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдкрд╣реНрд░рд┐рдпрдорд╛рдгрд╕реБрд╡рд░реНрдгрд╛рджрд┐рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдЬрд╛рддреНрдпрдкреЗрдХреНрд╖реЛ рд╜рдиреГрддрд╢рдкрдерджреЛрд╖реЛ рд╜рдиреНрдпрдерд╛рд╢рдкрдереЗ рд╕реНрд╡рд▓реНрдкреЗ, рдЧрд░реАрдпрд╕рд┐ рддреБ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпреЗ рдЧреМрд░рд╡рд╛рджреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрддрд░реЛ рджреЛрд╖реЛ рд╜рд╕реНрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡ ред рдкреНрд░реЗрддреНрдп рдирд╛рд╢реЛ рдирд░рдХрдореН, рдЗрд╣ рдорд╣рджреН рдЕрдпрд╢рдГ ред рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрд░реЗ рддреБ рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рддреЗ89 рд░рд╛рдЬрджрдгреНрдбрдГ рее рео.резрезрез рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This verse describes the effect of improper swearing, тАШimproperтАЩ meaning contrary to truth, false.

The gravity of the sin of тАШfalse swearingтАЩ is dependent upon the nature of the property stolenтАФbe it goods or something else,тАФand also upon that of the caste of the person involved and so forth. But even in minor matters one should not swear falsely; in more serious matters of course, the sin is more heinous.

тАШRuin after deathтАЩ consists in falling into hell; and тАШruin hereтАЩ is in the form of public obloquy, and also punishment at the hands of the king, in the event of the true facts being discovered by other means.тАФ(111)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШVс╣Ыth─БтАЩтАФтАШFalseтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Nandana);тАФтАШneedlessly, in small mattersтАЩ (R─Бghav─Бnanda).

This verse is quoted in Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 229),тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p.406);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyav─Бhara, 89a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

N─Бrada (1.257, 258).тАФтАШWhere no one declares himself ready to undergo punishment, an ordeal cannot take place. An ordeal shall be administered to litigants when there is reason for it, not otherwise. Therefore an intelligent, virtuous, righteous and wise king (or judge) should abstain from administering any one of the five ordeals, unless both parties consent to it.тАЩ

рдЗрдпрдВ рдЪ рдорд┐рдереНрдпрд╛рд╢рдкрдердирд┐рдиреНрджрд╛ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╡рд╛рдпрджрд░реНрд╢рдиреЗрди рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖рд┐рджреНрдзрд╡рд░реНрдЬрдирд╛рд░реНрдерд╛рдкрд┐ рд╕рддреА рд╕рддреНрдпрд╢рдкрдердкреНрд░рд╢рдВрд╕рд╛рд░реНрдерд╛ рд╕рдореНрдкрджреНрдпрдд рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд╡рд┐рдкрд░реНрдпрдпрдГ ред рд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЕрд╕реНрдп рдорд┐рдереНрдпрд╛рд╢рдкрдерд╕реНрдп рд╕рд░реНрд╡рддреНрд░ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╡рд╛рдпрд╣реЗрддреБрддреНрд╡реЗ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреЗ; рдпрддреНрд░ рддрдиреН рдиреЗрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╡рд╛рдпрд╣реЗрддреБрддреНрд╡рдореН рдЕрд╕реНрдп, рддрддреНрд░реЗрджрдВ рддрджреН рдЕрдкрд╡рд╛рджрд╛рд░реНрдердореН рдЖрд░рднреНрдпрддреЗ рее рео.резрезреи рее

111 Let no wise man swear an oath falsely, even in a trifling matter; for he who swears an oath falsely is lost in this (world) and after death.

There is no serious offence in swearing to women, or in connection with marriages, fodder for cows, or fuel, or for the sake of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa.тАФ(112)

рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рдзрд╛рддреН рдкрд░рд┐рддреНрд░рд╛рдгрдореН рдЙрдХреНрддрдВ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрдореН ред рдЕрднреНрдпреБрдкрдкрддреНрддрд┐рд╕реН рддреБ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡ ред рд╕рд╛ рд╣рд┐ рдзрдирд▓рд╛рднрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд╕рдВрднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рд╕рд░реНрд╡рддрд╢реН рдЪ рдкрд░рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд┐рд╖реБ105 рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рд╕реНрд╡реН рдПрд╡рдВрд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рд╕реБ рд╢рдкрдерд╛рднреНрдпрдиреБрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирдореН рдЙрдкрд╛рдпрд╛рдиреНрддрд░реЗрдг рддрддреНрд╕рд┐рджреНрдзреНрдпрд╕рдВрднрд╡ рдПрд╡ рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╡реНрдпрдореН рее рео.резрезреи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШK─Бmin─лс╣гuтАЩтАФтАШK─БmaтАЩ is a particular form of pleasure caused through the tactile organ; and those who are productive of such pleasure are called тАШK─Бmin─л,тАЩтАФwhich is a terra that stands for wife, courtesans and so forth. To these if one swears, for the fulfilment of his desireтАФin such words as тАШI do not love any other woman, thou art the queen of my heart,тАЩ etc.,тАФthere is nothing wrong in this; though, if after meeting the women, and on being asked by her to give a certain thing, he swears falsely that he would give it to her,тАФthen this is certainly wrong.

тАШ┼Ъapathe,тАЩ тАШin swearingтАЩ;тАФthe Locative here signifies the subject, and not the purpose. Hence the meaning is that there is nothing wrong, only in that form of oath which is sworn in connection only with that single woman with whom the man is in love. If, however, the Locative signified the purpose, then there would he nothing wrong in swearing for the purpose of robbing others of their property; and in that case what is declared (in 121 below) regarding the heavier punishment, in the case of perjury through lust, being тАШten timesтАЩ would not be proper.

Even in the case of the woman, if the man swears falsely in a dispute with her, relating to other matters,тАФhe commits a sin. Similarly in other cases.

тАШIn connection with marriagesтАЩ;тАФwhen one says тАШthis man has married another woman,тАЩ or тАШthat woman should ho married by you,тАЩ and so forth; such lying, also in connection with the marriage of friends and others, is not sinful, but not so the concealing of the real caste of the bride and such details.

тАШFodder for cowsтАЩ;тАФwhen, for the sake of obtaining fodder for cows, one has been constrained to commit theft, but denies it,тАФthen if called to bear testimony, if the witness should swear to his not having done the act,тАФthere is nothing wrong in this.

Similarly with тАШfuel.тАЩ

тАШFor the sake of Br─Бhmaс╣Зas,тАЩтАФfor conferring some benefit on Br─Бhmaс╣Зas.

тАЬLying for the sake of all castes having been already permitted (in 104), why should this be repeated here?тАЭ

Some people offer the following explanation:тАФIn the case of Br─Бhmaс╣Зas false swearing is permitted, while in that of the ┼Ъ┼лdra and other castes, it is simple lying that is sanctioned.

This however is not right; as under 104, it has been declared that тАШsuch lying is preferable to truthтАЩ; so that what is sanctioned there is not lying at all. The fact of the matter is that the said verse is not a prohibition; it provides an exception to the prohibition of false swearing contained in the preceding verse; and hence there should he nothing wrong in swearing for the sake of any caste.

тАЬWhy then should the declaration in the present verse be made?тАЭ

What has been permitted under 104 is lying with a view to save the men from death, which refers to all castes; for the purpose of conferring a benefit, however, it is permitted only in the ease of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa; as in the case of the other castes, the man might be prompted to lie also by greed for money and other motives.

In all these oases also the permission of false oath applies to only those eases where the purpose cannot he served without it, by any other meansтАФ(112)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 229), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШK─Бmin─лс╣гu,тАЩ when conversing with a woman in secret one may swear falsely for the purpose of satisfying her;тАФsimilarly for the purpose of bringing about a marriage, for obtaining food for cows, for obtaining fuel necessary for offerings, and for saving a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa;тАФand in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 406).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (16.35).тАФтАШMen may speak an untruth in marriage, during dalliance, when their lives are in danger, or the loss of their entire property is imminent, and for the sake of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa.тАЩ

Gautama (23.29-31).тАФтАШSome declare that an untruth spoken in marriage, during dalliance, in jest, or while one is in severe pain, is not reprehensible. But that is certainly not the case when the untruth concerns the guru; for if one lies even in his heart to his guru, regarding even small matters, he destroys himself, his seven descendants and seven ancestors.тАЩ

B├╝hler

112 No crime, causing loss of caste, is committed by swearing (falsely) to women, the objects of one’s desire, at marriages, for the sake of fodder for a cow, or of fuel, and in (order to show) favour to a Brahmana.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In as much as the act of тАШswearingтАЩ consists in invoking upon oneself evil consequences,тАФsuch as тАШIf I do this may such and such an evil befall me,тАЩтАФwhen a man is made to say тАШI swear by truth,тАЩ what is meant isтАФтАШmay all my merit due to truthfulness become futile.тАЩ

тАШConveyancesтАЩ and тАШweaponsтАЩ also are the means of swearing in this same sense; when one swears by these it meansтАФтАШmay these be useless for me.тАЩ

тАШCattle, grains and gold,тАЩтАФthe Vai┼Ыya should be made to swear by touching these; which would mean тАШmay these be useless for me.тАЩ

тАШThe ┼Ъ┼лdra by all sinsтАЩ;тАФthe ┼Ъ┼лdra should be made to sayтАФтАШmay the following sins befall me.тАЩтАФ(113)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.73), which adds the following notes:тАФTo the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa he should administer the oathтАФтАШIf you tell a lie your truthfulness shall perishтАЩ; to the Kс╣гatriya, тАШyour conveyances and weapons shall be futileтАЩ; to the Vai┼Ыya, тАШyour cattle, seeds and gold shall be useless;тАЩ to the ┼Ъ┼лdra, тАШif you tell a lie all the sins shall accrue to thee.тАЩ It adds that verse 102 provides an exception to the rule here laid down.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 19), and again on p. 38;тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 78);тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 611), which adds the following notes:тАФThe Br─Бhmaс╣Зa he shall cause to take the oath in the form тАШwhat I say is quite true,тАЩ and what he says after this should be accepted as true;тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 336);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (62a);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 88b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (8.20-23).тАФтАШThe Br─Бhmaс╣Зa witness should be asked to declare: the Kс╣гatriya to declare the truth; the Vai┼Ыya should be addressed thusтАФтАЬThy kine, grain and gold shall yield thee no fruit if thou wert to lieтАЭ: the ┼Ъ┼лdra should be addressed thusтАФтАЬThou shall have to atone for all heavy crimes if thou wert to lie.тАЭтАЩ

N─Бrada (1.248).тАФтАШLet him cause the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa to swear by truth, the Kс╣гatriya by his conveyance and by his weapons, the Vai┼Ыya by his gold, grains, cows and so forth; or all by venerable deities or deified ancestors, or by their own pious gifts or meritorious deeds.тАЩ
