тАШHe shall make him fetch waterтАЩтАФwith the hand, with only the leaf of the fig tree intervening. As for the other details, regarding the man going seven steps and so forth,тАФall this may be found in other Smс╣Ыtis (e.g., Y─Бj├▒avalkya, Vyavah─Бra, 103, and N─Бrada 2.296). The matter being well known by tradition, our author has simply stated the тАШfetching of fire.тАЩ

тАШHe,тАЩ i.e., the JudgeтАФтАШshall make him dive under water.тАЩ

тАШHe shall make him touch the heads of his son and wife, secerally,тАЩтАФthe man shall touch the head with his hand; and as this occurs in the context dealing with тАШoaths,тАЩ the man should be made to utter the swearing words also.

тАШSeverallyтАЩтАФseparately, one by one.тАФ(114)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 694);тАФthe second half in Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 611);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 71b and 88b), which says that the touching of the head is to be done with the right hand.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 8.114-116)
**

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.96-113).тАФтАШThe Balance for women, children, aged persons, the lame, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and the invalid; Fire or Water or seven Yavas or seven Poisons for the ┼Ъ┼лdra. Neither the Plough-share nor the Poison nor the Balance shall he used in suits whose value is less than a thousand paс╣Зas; hut in connection with the business of the King, or when one is accused of heinous crimes, the pure men shall always use these. (Then follows the detailed procedure of the ordeals.)тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (Chapters 10 to 14).тАФ[Rules regarding ordeal by Balance in Chap. 10, regarding that by fire in Chap. 11: тАШThat man whose hands are burnt ever so little should be deemed guilty; but if he remains wholly unburnt, he is freed from the charge regarding that by Water, in Chap. 12: тАШThe defendant should enter water;…… if he is not seen above the water during the time that a man brings back a discharged arrow, he is proclaimed innocent; hut in the contrary case, he is declared guilty, even though only one limb of his may have become visible;тАЩтАФregarding that by Poison in Chap. 13:тАФand regarding that by Sacred Libation, in Chap. 14.]

N─Бrada (1.251-253).тАФтАШHoly Manu has ordained that five kinds of ordeals should be administered to those involved in a doubtful case, specially if the matter under dispute is of a recondite nature. The Balance, Fire, Water, Poison and fifthly, Consecrated Water are the ordeals ordained for the purgation of high-minded persons. Those ordeals have been ordained by N─Бrada, for the purpose of proving the innocence of criminals who are defendants in a law-suit, and in order that right may be discerned from wrong.тАЩ [Then follow detailed instructions regarding the ordeals, up to verse 348.]тАФтАШIf the members of the court should declare him unhurt, he shall he honourably released as innocent; if he is burnt, he shall receive due punishmentтАЩ (363).тАФтАШIf the man returning with the discharged arrow does not see the defendant rising in water, the defendant should he acquitted; otherwise he is guilty; even though only one limb of his may have become visibleтАЩ (311-312).

Bс╣Ыhaspati (10.4-2).тАФтАШThe Balance, Fire, Water, Poison, and fifthly, Sacred Libation, sixthly grains of rice, seventhly, a hot piece of gold, are declared to he ordeals;тАФthe Plough-share is mentioned as the eighth; the ordeal by Dharmas the ninth. Truth, a vehicle, weapons, cows, grains, gold, venerable gods and Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, the heads of sons and wives,тАФby these have oaths to be taken. When a dispute between two litigants has arisen regarding a debt or some other matter, that ordeal is to be administered which is in keeping with the amount of the sum in dispute and with the character and strength of the person to he examined. The ordeal by Poison should he administered where property worth a thousand has been stolen; that by Fire when it is a quarter less than that; when the charge concerns four hundred, the Hot Piece of Gold should be administered; when three hundred, Grains of Rice should be used; and the Sacred Libation, when it is half of that; when a hundred has been stolen, or falsely denied, purgation by Dharma should be administered; thieves of cows should be subjected, by preference, to ordeal by the Plough-share.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.493 et seq.).тАФтАШWhen the plaintiff is not prepared to accept the result of the ordeal as final, the ordeal shall not be administered: an ordeal is to be administered to the Accused only; never shall the judge ask the accuser to go through the ordeal; but if he so wills it, he may be put through it. In the case of those who have been suspected by the King, ordeal may be prescribed. In cases of adultery and incestuous intercourse, and of heinous offences, ordeal shall be administered; there is no other proof. In the case of those against whom there is a presumptive charge of theft, the ordeal of lifting a small piece of metal out of boiling oil is ordained. In the case of indictment for murder, even though human evidence be available, if the accuser volunteers to have recourse to ordeal, the human evidence may be ignored. Where the witness that is produced is suspected of dishonesty, the King shall, before admitting his evidence, test him by means of an ordeal.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (8.40).тАФтАШWhenever a perjured witness has given false evidence in a suit, the King must reverse the judgment; and whatever has been done should be regarded as undone.тАЩ

N─Бrada (2.40).тАФтАШWhen a man has lost his cause through the dishonesty of witnesses or judges, the cause may be tried anew.тАЩ

He whom the blazing fire burns not, or whom the water does not throw up, or who does not speedily suffer some misfortune, should be regarded as pure on his oath.тАФ(115)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рддрдкреНрддрд╛рдпрд╕рдкрд┐рдгреНрдбреЛ рд╜рдпрдореН рдЕрдирд╡рджреНрдп108 рдЧреГрд╣реАрддреЛ рди рджрд╣рддрд┐ ред рдЖрдкрд╢реН рдЪ рдиреЛрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рдВ рдкреНрд▓рд╛рд╡рдпрдиреНрддрд┐ ред рд╕рддреНрдпрд╢рдкрдереЗ рдХреЛрд╢рд╛рджреМ109 рди рдирд╛рд░реНрддрд┐рдореН рдЛрдЪреНрдЫрддрд┐ рдкреАрдбрд╛рдВ рди рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрдиреЛрддрд┐ ред “рд░реЛрдЧреЛ рд╜рдЧреНрдирд┐рдГ” (рдореНрдзреН рео.резрежрео) рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрддреНрд░реЛрдХреНрддрд╛рдВ110 ред рд╕ рд╢реБрджреНрдзрдГ рд╢реБрдЪрд┐рд░реН рдирд┐рд░реНрджреЛрд╖рдГ ред рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрд░рдВ рдЪрддреБрд░реНрджрд╢ рд╡рд╛рд╣рд╛рдиреНрдпреН рдЕрд╡рдзрд┐рдГ рд╕реНрдореГрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд░рд╛рддреН рее рео.резрезрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШBlazingтАЩтАФflaming.

A red-hot iron-ball, when held by an innocent person, does not burn him; the water does not make him float on the surface, if he has sworn truly; he also does not suffer тАШmisfortune,тАЩтАФi.e. trouble, in regard to his hair and other parts of his body. тАШIllnessтАЩ has already been mentioned before.

Such a person is to тАШbe regarded as pureтАЩтАФi.e., innocent.

тАШSpeedilyтАЩтАФi.e., within a period of fourteen days,тАФas declared in another Smс╣Ыti.тАФ(115)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

See Atharva Veda 2.12; Ch─Бndogya Upaniс╣гad 6.16.1.

тАШKс╣гipramтАЩтАФтАШWithin fourteen daysтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi); тАШwithin three fortnightsтАЩ (R─Бghav─Бnanda).

This verse is quoted in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (62b).

рдХрдердВ рдкреБрдирд░реН рдЕрдЧреНрдирд┐рд░реН рди рдзрдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддрд┐, рдЖрдкреЛ111 рдиреЛрдиреНрдордЬреНрдЬрдпрд┐рд╖реНрдпрдиреНрддрд┐ ред рди рд╣рд┐ рдорд╣рд╛рднреВрддрд╛рдирд┐ рд╡рд┐рдкрд░рд┐рдпрдиреНрддрд┐ рд╕реНрд╡рднрд╛рд╡рддреЛ рд╜рдЪреИрддрдиреНрдпрд╛рджреН112 рдЗрддрд┐ рдкрд░реНрдпрдиреБрдпреЛрдЧрдореН рдЖрд╢рдЩреНрдХреНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджреЗрдиреЛрдХреНрддрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдердВ рджреГрдвреАрдХрд░реЛрддрд┐ ред рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрдпрдореН рдЕрдиреНрд╡рдпрд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХрд╕рдордзрд┐рдЧрдореНрдпреЛ рд╜рд░реНрдердГ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдХрд╖рд╡реЗрджреНрдпреЛ113 рд╡рд╛ рддрдерд╛рдкрд┐ рдзреВрд░реНрддрдХрд▓реНрдкрд┐рддреЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рдЬрд╛рд▓рд╡рджреН рднрд╛рд╡рд┐рддрдореН рдЙрдЧреНрд░рдмрд┐рднреАрд╖рд┐рдХрд╛рд╕рдЮреНрдЬрдирдорд╛рддреНрд░рдВ рдлрд▓рдВ114 рд╢рдкрдерд╛рдЧреЛрд░рдгрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рдордиреНрдпрдорд╛рдиреЛ рд╡реИрджрд┐рдХрдВ рдирд┐рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдореН рдЙрдкрдиреНрдпрд╕реЗрддреН330 ред рднрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрддреНрддрд╛рд░реЛ рд╜рд░реНрдерд╛рдЧрдореЗрди рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╡реГрддреНрддрджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рджреН рджреГрдврддрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрджреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред

  • рд╡рддреНрд╕реЛ рдирд╛рдо рдХрд╛рдгреНрд╡ рдЛрд╖рд┐рд░реН рдЕрднрд╡рддреН ред рд╕ рдЪ рдХрдиреАрдпрд╕рд╛ рд╡реИрдорд╛рддреНрд░реЗрдг рднреНрд░рд╛рддреНрд░рд╛рднрд┐рд╢рд╕реНрдд115 рдЖрдХреНрд░реБрд╖реНрдЯрдГ “рди рддреНрд╡рдореН рдЕрд╕рд┐ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрдГ рд╢реВрджреНрд░рд╛рдкреБрддреНрд░рдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд╕ рддрдВ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпреБрд╡рд╛рдЪ “рд╕рддреНрдпреЗрдирд╛рдЧреНрдирд┐рдВ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд┐рд╢рд╛рдорд┐ рдпрджрд┐ рди рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрд╕реНрдпреЗрджрдореН рдЙрдХреНрддрд╡рддрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╕реНрдп рдирд╛рдЧреНрдирд┐рд░реН рджрджрд╛рд╣ рд░реЛрдорд╛рдкрд┐ ред рдХрдердореН ред рд╕рддреНрдпреЗрди рд╣реЗрддреБрдирд╛ ред

рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рддреН рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рд╡рдЪреН рдЫрдкрдереЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпреЗрддрд╡реНрдп ред рддреЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╣рд┐ рдХрджрд╛рдЪрд┐рдиреН рдорд┐рдереНрдпрд╛рд╡рджрдиреНрддрд┐126 ред рди рднрдпрдкреНрд░рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдорд╛рддреНрд░рдореН рдПрддрддреН ред рдпрдерд╛рд╕реНрдерд╛рдирд░реВрдврд╛рдГ127 рд╢рдкрдерд╛ рдЙрдХреНрддрд╛рдГ рд╕рддреНрдпрдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реНрдардд рдЗрддрд┐ рее рео.резрезрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Question.тАФ тАЬHow can it be that fire shall not burn or that water shall not throw up? Certainly elemental substances never renounce their natural functions, being as they are unconscious entities.тАЭ

It is in anticipation of this objection that the author corroborates his statement by means of a commendatory story. Though the matter in question is one that can he ascertained either by positive and negative induction, or by direct perception,тАФyet there may he people who would regard such phenomena in the same light as a magical performance, and so would be inclined to take all that is said regarding oaths and ordeals merely as intended to frighten the person into telling the truth; just in the same way as verbal threats and angry staring, etc., are used to make men tell the truth;тАФand it is in view of this contingency that the author has cited an instance from the Veda; as there are men who become convinced of the truth of a statement when it is corroborated by past occurrences.

Vatsa was a sage of the family of Kaс╣Зva; he was тАШaccusedтАЩтАФblamedтАФby his younger step-brother, of being not a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, but a ┼Ъ┼лdra, whereupon he saidтАФтАШBy truth, I enter fire, if I be not a Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩ; when having said this, he entered the fire, тАШthe fire did not burn even his hairтАЩ;тАФand why?тАФтАШbecause of truth.тАЩ

The question arising as to how fire can know the truth?тАФthe answer isтАФтАШfire is the worldтАЩs spy.тАЩ The man who, keeping his real character concealed, comes to know what is done and what is not done by others, is called тАШspy,тАЩ known also by such names as тАШc─БraтАЩ, тАШpraс╣ЗidhiтАЩ and so forth. The God Agni moves within all living beings, and as such, is cognisant of all that is done or not done. We read in the T─Бс╣Зс╕Нya Br─Бhmaс╣Зa that тАЬAgni is one who lies within the gods as well as the Asuras;тАФGautama, approaching fire, said тАШMay you Sir, operate within all beingsтАЩ; and then he goes on to sayтАФтАШMay you Sir, move about here as a spy.тАЩтАЭ A similar passage from the Pa├▒caviс╣Г┼Ыa-Br─Бhmaс╣Зa may he quoted;тАФтАЬVatsa and Medh─Бtithi were two sons of Ka┼Ыyapa; Medh─Бtithi insulted Vatsa by sayingтАФтАШthou art not a Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩ; and the only remedy of this was Fire.тАЭ

Objection.тАФтАЬAs a matter of fact however, it is found that real thieves are not burnt by fire (when undergoing the ordeal) while innocent persons are actually burnt. How then can any reliance he placed upon oaths and ordeals?тАЭ

Our answer is as follows:тАФThe principle here laid down cannot be rejected simply on the strength of a perceptible miscarriage; because such miscarriages are very rare. In fact, even in the case of perception and other forms of valid cognition, such miscarriages are met with; and yet these are not regarded as untrustworthy. Further, it has been declared that тАШwhat is found to be wrong does not deserve the name of Perception, etc.; what is found to ho wrong is not Perception; and what is Perception is never wrongтАЩ; and on the analogy of this statement, it may be asserted that тАШwhat miscarries is not an ordeal, and what is an ordeal never miscarries.тАЩ For what is an тАШordealтАЩ? It is that wherein the full procedure is observed, all obstructions in the shape of spells neutralising the force of the fire and so forth duly examined and removed; what is contary (contrary) to this is not an ordeal.

And certainly an ordeal of the said kind never miscarries. Even though there be some such miscarriage, it must be regarded as the result of some past act of the man; in fact even a real criminal comes to be acquitted by virtue of some previous meritorious act; while an innocent man becomes convicted by virtue of an evil deed committed in his past life. The causes leading up to the fruition of past acts are truly strange. But with all this, it is only in one ease among a thousand that an ordeal is found to fail; as a rule it is infallible; and it is exactly the same with the Putreс╣гс╣нi, the K─Бr─лr─л and such other Vedic sacrifices.

From all this it follows that reliance should be placed upon oaths and ordeals also, just as on witnesses; for these latter also speak falsely sometimes.

Thus then, what has been said regarding ordeals is not meant simply to frighten the man. In fact, in the case of the said ordeals, it is the truth that prevails.тАФ(116)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАЬThis story is told in Pa├▒caviс╣Г┼Ыa Br─Бhmaс╣Зa of the S─Бma VedaтАЭтАФHopkins.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In a suit where a decision should have been taken on the strength of lying witnesses,тАФthat decision shall be reversed.

тАШWhat is done shall be undone i.e., even though the creditor may have received the amount of debt claimed, he should be made to refund it; and the debtor shall be excused the fine that may have been imposed upon him. In a case where the victory was merely verbal, the verdict being simply тАШyou are defeated,тАЩтАФthe same shall be declared to be reversed.

The decision, carried into effect, even to the realisation of the fine,тАФis what is said to be тАШdoneтАЩ; and this тАШshall ceaseтАЩ, тАШbecome undoneтАЩ; the repetition of the same idea serving the purpose of filling up the metre.тАФ(117)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.77), to the effect that even though the case may have been decided, yet if, even subsequently it is found out that the witnesses had deposed falsely,тАФthe decision should be upset;тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 337);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (p. 65a);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 39b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

(verses 8.118-123)

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.337).тАФтАШThe man who hears false evidence, and the man who suppresses evidence are to receive double punishment.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.193-97).тАФтАШOne who, weighed down by the consciousness of his guilt, looks as if he were ill, or shifts his position constantly, runs after everybody:тАФwho walks involuntary and without reason, and draws deep sighs; who scratches the ground with his feet and who shakes his arms and clothes;тАФwhose countenance changes colour, whose forehead sweats, whose lips become dry and who looks about and above himself;тАФwho makes long and irrelevant speeches as if he were in a hurry, and without being asked;тАФsuch a person may be recognised as a false witness, and the King should punish that sinful man.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (8.18).тАФтАШA false witness may be known by his altered looks, by his countenance changing colour, and by his talk wandering from the subject.тАЩ

Do. (Apar─Бrka, p. 680).тАФтАШOf false witnesses, the whole property should be confiscated.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.81).тАФтАШForgers and false witnesses should be separately punished with line which is double the value of the suit; but the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa should be banished. The witness who having made a statement before others, conceals it from the court, through folly,тАФshould be made to pay a fine eight times the value of the suit; but the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa should he banished.тАЩ

M G add: tu

M G: bhayena; DK omits: mad─лyena

M G J: vy─Бr┼лс╕Нhaс╕е

M G: vicintayato; J: svabh─Бvato

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

When the man deposes falsely after receiving a bribe from another person, his motive is greed.

тАШThrough embarrassment.тАЩтАФThough the man may be quite truthful, habituated to speak in strict accordance with what he has actually seen, yet on account of some distraction of the mind, at the time of his examination, he may be so confused as to be unable either to comprehend the question or to recall the exact facts of the case, and thereby he may make statements that are not true; in this case the reason is тАШembarrassment.тАЩ

тАШFrightтАЩ is fear, in the form of the suspicionтАФтАШif this man was to lose the case through my telling the truth, he would ruin me by injuring my relations, or by making me suffer financially.тАЩ

тАШOne thousand;тАЩтАФwhat is that to which this number appertains is to be learnt from other passages: they are тАШpaс╣Зas.тАЩ

тАШLowest amercementтАЩтАФi.e. 250 paс╣Зas, as described under 138 below.

тАШTwo middling onesтАЩтАФi.e., amercements; the number being changed into the dual.

тАШFour times the first,тАЩтАФi.e. 1,000 paс╣Зas.

It is through metrical considerations that the same idea is expressed in various ways.тАФ(120)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 82);тАФand in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.811), which adds the following notesтАФтАШLobhaтАЩ is greed for wealth,тАФтАШmohaтАЩ, wrong information,тАФтАШbhayaтАЩ, fear,тАФтАШmaitr─лтАЩ, too much affection,тАФтАШk─БmaтАЩ, longing for intercourse with women,тАФтАШkrodhaтАЩ, anger. It adds that the 1,000 and other numbers refer to so many copper paс╣Зas.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 680), which adds the following notes:тАФThe numbers here mentioned refer to k─Бrс╣г─Бpaс╣Зas. Some people might think that there are two kinds of perjuryтАФone through greed and the rest, for which the penalty shall he as prescribed by Manu, and another due to other causes, for which the penalty would be that prescribed by Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.81). But this would not he the right view, because as already shown by Manu (in 118), people commit perjury only through greed and other causes enumerated therein.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 191), which says:тАФIf the witness lie, through avarice, he should he fined 1,000 paс╣Зas,тАФif through delusion, 250 paс╣Зas,тАФif through fear 1,000 paс╣Зas,тАФif through friendliness 1,000 paс╣Зas;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (37a), which says that тАШthousandтАЩ paс╣Зas are meant,тАФтАШmoh─БtтАЩ means тАШthrough absent-mindednessтАЩтАФthat тАШp┼лrva s─БhasaтАЩ stands for 250 paс╣Зas,тАФтАШdvau madhyamauтАЩ means тАШdvau madhyamau s─БhasauтАЩ, which means 1,000 paс╣Зas,тАФтАШp┼лrvamтАЩ means тАШfirst amercementтАЩ, four times of which means 1,000 paс╣Зas.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШLust,тАЩтАФ sexual love: when females happen to be parties to the suit, the person who loves one of them, deposes falsely; and such a person should be fined 2,500 Paс╣Зas.

тАШIf through anger, three times the next;тАЩтАФthe тАШlowest amercementтАЩ having been mentioned before, its тАШnextтАЩ is the тАШmiddling amercement.тАЩ Or, on the basis of ordinary usage, тАШparaтАЩ may stand for the тАШhighest.тАЩ

тАШThrough ignoranceтАЩ;тАФhe who, through mistake, should say what is contrary to busts, on the spur of the moment,тАФand not during his regular examination,тАФhis punishment shall consist of тАШtwo hundred.тАЩ This is meant to be merely suggestive of some sort of punishment to be inflicted; and hence it is not contrary (to what has been declared regarding the lowest fine to consist of 250).

тАШChildishnessтАЩтАФ is childish character. The man who has not acquired steadiness of mind is called тАШchildish.тАЩ The punishment here laid down is for one who has just passed his minority; one who is still a minor cannot be a witness at all.тАФ(121)

рдЙрднрдпрдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдиреЛ рджрдгреНрдб рдЗрддрд┐ рджрд░реНрд╢рдпрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд╡рд╢реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╖реНрдареЗрдпрддреНрд╡рд╛рдп ред рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рдЪрд╛рд░рдирд┐рд░реВрдврд╛ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛ рдзрд░реНрдордГ, рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╡реНрдпрднрд┐рдЪрд╛рд░реЛ рд╜рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рд░реН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рее рео.резреиреи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

With a view to indicating that it is necessary to inflict the punishments, the author shows that punishment serves two purposes.

Decision taken in strict accordance with Law and Usage is тАШJusticeтАЩ; and its тАШnon-failingтАЩ consists in its not being thwarted;тАФand for this purpose the witnesses have to be punished. Though the real purpose of all this is the finding out of what has been done and what not done; and it is this that is reiterated here (in different words).тАФ(122)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╕рдХреГрджреН рдЕрдкрд░рд╛рджреНрдзрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЛ рджрдгреНрдбрдГ ред рдЕрднреНрдпрд╛рд╕рд╛рддреН рдкреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддрдорд╛рдирд╛рдирд╛рдВ рджрдгреНрдбрдпрд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд╛рд╕рдирдВ рд░рд╛рд╖реНрдЯреНрд░рд╛рдиреН рдирд┐рд╖реНрдХрд╛рд╕рдирдореН, рдорд░рдгрдВ рд╡рд╛рд░реНрдерд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░реЗ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЧрджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рддреН рддрджреНрд░реВрдкрддреНрд╡рд╛рдЪреН рдЪ рджрдгреНрдбрд╡рд┐рдзреЗрдГ ред рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрдВ рддреБ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╕рдпреЗрддреН ред рд╡рд╛рд╕рд╕реЛ рд╜рдкрд╣рд░рдгрдВ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╕рдирдВ рдЧреГрд╣рднрдЩреНрдЧреЛ рд╡рд╛ ред рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╕рд╕рдВ141 рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╕рдВ рд╡рд╛142 рдХрд░реЛрддрд┐ “рддрддреН рдХрд░реЛрддрд┐” рдЗрддрд┐ рдгрд┐рдЪрд┐ рдгрд╛рд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╡рджреН рдЗрддрд┐ рдЯрд┐рд▓реЛрдкреЗ рд░реВрдкрдореН ред рддреНрд░реАрдиреН рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╛рдиреН рдЗрддрд┐ рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд╛рджрдпрд╕реН рддреНрд░рдпрдГ, рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдп рджрдгреНрдбрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рдирд╛рддреН рее рео.резреирей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The penalties prescribed above are for the first offenders; for repeated offenders there is fining, followed by тАШbanishment,тАЩтАФi.e., expulsion from the kingdom;тАФor death; rules regarding the inflicting of such penalty being met with in political science.

тАШBut the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa he shall deprive of his clothesтАЩ;тАФтАШviv─БsanaтАЩ meaning depriving of clothes, or of dwelling. The verb is formed from the noun тАШviv─Бsa,тАЩ тАШhomeless,тАЩ тАШclothesless,тАЩ with the causal affix тАШс╣Зic,тАЩ which makes the nominal verb тАШmakes viv─Бsa.тАЩ

тАШThe three CastesтАЩтАФthe Kс╣гatriya and the rest;тАФsince for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa a separate punishment is prescribed.тАФ(123)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШPrav─БsayetтАЩтАФтАШBanishтАЩ (all concur). But Medh─Бtithi suggests тАШput to deathтАЩ, as an alternative; this is accepted by Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (see below).

тАШViv─БsayetтАЩтАФтАШShould deprive him of his clothes (Medh─Бtithi and Govindar─Бja),тАФтАШor homesteadтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, alternative);тАФтАШbanish (without fining, as in the case of the other three castes)тАЩ (Kull┼лka).

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.81), which adds the following notes:тАФThis rule is meant for repeated offence, as is clear from the present participle affix in тАШkurv─Бс╣З─БnтАЩ (which implies habit); on the three castes, Kс╣гatriya and the rest, the king should impose the aforesaid fine and then put them to death;тАФthe root тАШprav─БsaтАЩ is used in the sense of killing in works dealing with political science; and this part of the law-book is a treatise on that science. This putting to death is of various kindsтАФcutting the lips, cutting the tongue and actual killing; which one of these is to be adopted in any particular case will depend upon the nature of the case in regard to which the man may have given false evidence. The Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, on the other hand, is to be fined and banished, removed from the kingdom; or тАШviv─БsayetтАЩ may mean deprive him of his clothes, strip him naked;тАФor again тАШv─БsaтАЩ meaning the dwelling house, тАШviv─БsayetтАЩ may mean тАШshould deprive him of his houseтАЩ, his house should be demolished. In the case of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa also, if the offence is the first one of its kind, and the man is not found to have been actuated by any such sordid motive as тАШgreedтАЩ and the rest,тАФonly simple fine is to be imposed; but if the offence is repeated, there is to be fine and also тАШviv─БsanaтАЩ, i.e., banishment, or stripping naked, or rendering homeless; which one of these three is to be adopted will depend upon the character of the parties, the nature of the subject-matter of dispute and so forth. If the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa is not found to have been actuated by greed or any such motive, if the offence is the first of its kind, and if the subject-matter of the dispute is a petty one,тАФthen he also is to be only slightly fined, like the Kс╣гatriya and other lower castes; but if the subject-matter of the dispute is an important one, then he is to be banished. In the case of the offence being repeated, the punishment for all the castes is to be as prescribed by Manu.

This verse is quoted also in Apar─Бrka (p. 680), which explains the meaning as follows:тАФThe three lower castes are to be fined and banished, while the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa is to be only banished) not fined;тАФthough if the offence is repeated, or if the issues involved in the case are important, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa also may be fined.

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 82);тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 119);тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 191), which adds the note:тАФтАШIf a Kс╣гatriya or a Vai┼Ыya or a ┼Ъ┼лdra is found to depose falsely repeatedly, he should, in addition to the aforesaid fines, be banished from the country,тАФand in the ease of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, he should be banished with all his belongingsтАЩ;тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (37b), which explains тАШviv─БsayetтАЩ as тАШshould he banished from the kingdomтАЩ;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 57a), which adds the explanation thatтАФpersons of the three castes other than the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa are to he fined and then killedтАФthe тАШkillingтАЩ consisting either in cutting off the lips or lopping off the tongue or down-right killing, in accordance with the gravity of the offence;тАФthe Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, is to be banished or rendered naked,тАФthe verb тАШviv─БsayetтАЩ meaning тАШdeprived of v─Бsa, habitation or clothesтАЩ. It adds that all this refers to cases of repeated perjury.

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╕реНрдерд╛рдирд╢рдмреНрджреЛ рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдпрдГ ред рдПрддреИрдГ рдкреНрд░рджреЗрд╢реИрдГ рдкреАрдбрдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ рдкреНрд░рдпрдкрд░рд╛рдзрдореН143 ред рд╢рдмреНрджреЗрди рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдп рдзрдирджрдгреНрдбрд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рдирд╛рджреН рдЕрдХреНрд╖рддрддреНрд╡реЛрдкрджреЗрд╢рдГ рд╢рд░реАрд░рдкреАрдбрд╛рдкрд░рд┐рд╣рд╛рд░рд╛рд░реНрдердГ рдХрд▓реНрдкрддреЗ, рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдзрдирд╕реНрдп рджрд╢рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛рдирд░реНрднрд╛рд╡реЗ ред

рд╡рдпрдВ рддреБ рдмреНрд░реВрдордГ “рд╕рдордЧреНрд░рдзрдирдореН рдЕрдХреНрд╖рддрдореН” (рдореНрдзреН рео.рейреореж) рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрддреНрд░ рдзрдирдкреАрдбрд╛рдкрд┐ рдирд┐рд╖рд┐рджреНрдзреИрд╡ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдп ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдпрдГ рд╕рдХреГрддреН рдХрдердВрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрдкрд░рд╛рджреНрдзрдГ рд╢реНрд░реБрддрд╢реАрд▓рд╛рднрд┐рдЬрдирдпреБрдХреНрддрд╕реН рддрд╕реНрдп рдзрдирджрдгреНрдбреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪ рдЧреМрддрдорд╕реН рддрд╛рджреГрд╢рдореН рдПрд╡ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрдореН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХреГрддреНрдп “рджреНрд╡реМ рд▓реЛрдХреЗ рдзреГрддрд╡реНрд░рддреМ”144 (рдЧреНрдзреН рео.рез) рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдкрдХреНрд░рдореНрдп, “рд╖рдбреНрднрд┐рдГ рдкрд░рд┐рд╣рд╛рд░реНрдпрд╢реН рдЪ” (рдЧреНрдзреН рео.резреи) рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐ рее рео.резреирек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The term тАШsth─БnaтАЩ тАШplace,тАЩ is synonymous with тАШsubjectтАЩ; the meaning being that the man should be made to suffer pain on these spots.

In as much as for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa also pecuniary punishment has been directly prescribed, it follows that what is said here in regard to his departing тАШunscathedтАЩ is with reference to corporal punishment, which is forbidden in his case; even though тАШpropertyтАЩ also is included (in the next verse) among the тАШten places.тАЩ

Our opinion however is that, in as much as one can be called тАШunscathedтАЩ only when he has all his property also intact, pecuniary punishment also must be taken as forbidden in the case of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa; hence if a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, endowed with learning, character and noble birth, should, by chance, happen to commit a crime, there is no pecuniary punishment either. In fact, it is in reference to such a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa that Gautama, having begun with the statementтАФтАШIn this world there are two men firm in their vow,тАЩ (8.1)тАФgoes on to say,тАФтАШHe should be excused from six.тАЩ (8.13).тАФ(124)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.26), as laying down the forms of тАШdeath,тАЩ which means тАШcorporal punishment;тАЩ B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л adds that тАШvrajetтАЩ means тАШshould go away from home or from the cityтАЩ;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 630), which explains тАШakс╣гataс╕етАЩ as тАШwithout corporal sufferingтАЩ;тАФin V─лramitrodaya (R─Бjan─лti, p. 293), as laying down the spots of the body where corporal punishment is to be inflicted upon all offenders, except the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa;тАФand in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (─Аc─Бra, p. 399 and Vyavah─Бra, p. 155), as laying down the ten forms of corporal punishment.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 8.124-125)
**

Gautama (12.46-47).тАФтАШCorporal punishment must not be inflicted on the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa.тАФDesisting from the deed, publicly proclaiming his crime, banishment and branding are the punishments to which a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa may be subjected.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (5.1-8).тАФтАШGreat criminals should all be put to death. In the case of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa no corporal punishment should be inflicted. A. Br─Бhmaс╣Зa should be banished from his own country, his body having been branded;тАФfor murdering another Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, let the figure of a headless body be branded on his forehead; for drinking spirits, the flag of a wine-seller; for stealing gold, a dogтАЩs foot; for incest, a female part;тАФif he has committed any other capital offence, he shall be banished, taking with him all his property, and unhurt.тАЩ

N─Бrada (114.8-10).тАФтАШFor a crime of violence of the highest degree, a fine amounting to no less than a thousand Paс╣Зas has been ordained. Moreover, corporal punishment, confiscation of the entire property, banishment from the town, branding, as well as amputation of the limb, is declared to be the punishment for a violent crime of the highest degree. This gradation of punishments has been ordained for all castes indiscriminately, excepting only corporal punishment in the case of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, who should never he subjected to corporal punishment. Shaving his head, banishing him from the town, branding him on the forehead with a mark of the crime of which he has been convicted, and parading him on an ass, shall he the Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩs punishment.тАЩ

Do. (15-16.20).тАФтАШThe Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and the King are exempt from censure and corporal punishment.тАЩ

Do. (15-16.22-31).тАФтАШIf a ┼Ъ┼лdra insults a member of a higher caste with invectives, he shall have his tongue cut out; if he refers to their name or caste contemptuously, an iron-rod ten inches long shall be thrust red-hot into his mouth;тАФif ho is insolent enough to teach duty to a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, the King shall have hot oil poured into his mouth and ears. With whatever limb a low caste man offends against a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, that very limb of his shall be cut off; such shall be the atonement for his crime. If a low-born man tries to place himself on the same seat as his superior, he shall be branded on his hip and banished; or he may have his backside gashed. If, through arrogance, he spits on his superior, the King shall have both his lips cut off; if he urinates on him, then his penis; if he breaks wind against him, the buttocks. If he pulls his superior by the hair, he shall have his hands cut off; likewise if he seizes him by the feet, beard, neck or scrotum. If a man censures a King who is devoted to the discharge of his duties, he shall have his tongue cut out, or his entire property confiscated. When an evil-minded person assails even a wicked king, he shall be fastened on a stake and burnt in fire.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Punishments, 41-439).тАФтАШLet him not on any account kill a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, though convicted of all crimes; he may at pleasure cause him to be banished; let the King take his entire wealth from him, or leave a fourth part of it; for four offences of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, branding has been ordained.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (21.8).тАФтАШFor killing, capital punishment.тАЩ

Do. (21.15).тАФтАШIf persons begotten in the inverse order of castes, and members of the lowest caste, should insult a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, they shall be corporally punished, and shall never be amerced in fine.тАЩ

Do. (22.10).тАФтАШJudges passing an unjust sentence, those who take bribes, and those who betray confidence,тАФall such shall be banished.тАЩ

Do. (22.17).тАФтАШHouse-breakers shall be impaled on a stake, and highwaymen shall be bound and hanged by the neck from a tree.тАЩ

Do. (22.20).тАФтАШStealers of grass deserve to have a hand cut off.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Punishments, 36-37).тАФтАШSv─Бyambhuva Manu has declared ten spots of punishment which should be selected in punishing the lower castes; a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa should remain uninjured always;тАФthose places are the privy parts, the belly, the tongue, the two hands, and fifthly, the two feet; as well as the eye, the nose, the two ears, the property and the body.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (27.9-10).тАФтАШBoth hands, both feet, the male organ, the eye, the tongue, the ears, the nose, the neck, the half of the foot, the thumb and the index finger, the forehead, the lips, the hind part and the hips;тАФthese fourteen spots of punishment have been indicated. For a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, branding on the forehead is the only kind of punishment. A Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, though a mortal sinner, shall not suffer capital punishment; the King shall banish him and cause him to be branded and shaved.тАЩ

124 Manu, the son of the Self-existent (Svayambhu), has named ten places on which punishment may be (made to fall) in the cases of the three (lower) castes (varna); but a Brahmana shall depart unhurt (from the country).

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЙрдкрд╕реНрдердВ рдкреНрд░рдЬрдирдзрд░реНрдордГ рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдкреБрдВрд╕рдпреЛрдГ ред рдЙрджреНрджреЗрд╢рдорд╛рддреНрд░рдореН рдЗрджрдВ рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдпреЛрдЧрд╕реН рддреВрддреНрддрд░рддреНрд░ рднрд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдпрддрд┐ ред рдпрддреНрд░ рдЪ рджрдгреНрдбрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЛ рдирд╛рдореНрдирд╛рддрд╕реН рддрддреНрд░ рдпреЛ рдпреЗрдиреИрд╡рд╛рдЩреНрдЧреЗрдирд╛рдкрд░рд╛рджреНрдзрдГ рд╕ рддрддреНрд░реИрд╡ рдкреАрдбрдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдЧрдореНрдпрд╛рдЧрдорди рдЙрдкрд╕реНрдердирд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ ред рдЪреМрд░реНрдп рдЙрджрд░рдд рдЖрд╣рд╛рд░рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ ред рд╡рд╛рдЧреНрджрдгреНрдбрдкрд╛рд░реБрд╖реНрдпреЗ рдЬрд┐рд╣реНрд╡рд╛рд╣рд╕реНрддрдпреЛрдГ ред рдкрд╛рджрдмрд▓реЗрди рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рд╛рдордиреН рдкрд╛рджрдпреЛрдГ ред рд╡рд┐рд╡реГрддреНрдп рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд░рдмреНрдзрдВ рд░рд╛рдЬрджрд╛рд░рд╛рдиреН рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдорд╛рдгрд╢реН рдЪрдХреНрд╖реБрд╖реЛрдГ ред рдЕрдиреБрд▓реЗрдкрдирдЧрдиреНрдзрдореН рдЖрдЬрд┐рдШреНрд░рдиреН рдирд╛рд╕рд┐рдХрд╛рдпрд╛рдореН ред рд░рд╣рд╕рд┐ рд░рд╛рдЬрд╛рдирдореН рдордиреНрддреНрд░рдпрдорд╛рдгрдВ рдХреБрдбреНрдпрдкрдЯрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рд┐рдд рдЙрдкрд╢реГрдгреНрд╡рдиреН рдХрд░реНрдгрдпреЛрдГ ред рдзрдиреЗ рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзреЛ рджрдгреНрдбрдГ ред рджреЗрд╣реЗ рдорд╛рд░рдгрдВ рдорд╣рд╛рдкрд╛рддрдХрд┐рдирдГ рее рео.резреирел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШThe genital organтАЩтАФmale and female. Here the places are only named; the exact form in which the punishment is to be inflicted on each тАШplaceтАЩ shall be described later on. If, with reference to any тАШplace,тАЩ no particular form of punishment has been prescribed, the law is that the culprit shall suffer by that limb whereby he may have committed the wrong. Hence in cases of incest, punishment is inflicted on the genital organ;тАФin theft it is inflicted upon the stomach, in the form of starvation, etc.;тАФin the case of defamation, on the tongue, and in that of assault, on the hands;тАФwhen he trespasses with his feet, it is to be inflicted on the feet;тАФif he openly and fearlessly stares at the kingтАЩs wife, his punishment is inflicted on the eyes,тАФby smelling the (forbidden) odour of sandal-paint, he is punished on the nose;тАФif he should be found listening behind the wall or the curtain, while the king is holding secret council, the punishment should fall on his ears;тАФpunishment regarding тАШpropertyтАЩ is well known;тАФthe killing of the тАШbodyтАЩ is done only in the case of the gravest offenders.тАФ(125)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 156);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (─Аc─Бra, p. 399);тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 630), which adds that this should not be taken to be an exhaustive list;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (R─Бjan─лti. p. 293), which adds that the punishment should be inflicted upon that part of the body by which the crime might have been committed.

It has been quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.26), which makes the remark that has been reproduced in V─лramitrodaya; тАФB─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л adds the following notes:тАФтАШDhanaтАЩ is mentioned among the тАШsth─БnasтАЩ with a view to indicate that when the crime committed pertains to wealth, the punishment also should pertain to that only; or it may be that the punishment here meant is different from тАШfineтАЩ (which is what has gone before), and may be taken to stand for that physical pain which is caused by the confiscation of some property; in the crime of adultery the punishment should fall on the sexual organ,тАФin that of eating improper food, on the stomach, such as starvation and so forth,тАФin defamation, on the tongue, such as cutting it off,тАФin theft, on the hands,тАФin misbehaviour with the feet, such as walking ahead of a superior person, on the feet,тАФin trying to look at the kingтАЩs harem, on the eyes,тАФin stealthily smelling his scents, on the nose,тАФin eaves-dropping on the kingтАЩs councils, on the ears,тАФin the case of heinous crimes, on the body, i.e., death.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This verse forms the basis for all penalties and offences, described above; and it is in accordance with this that all punishment is to be determined.

тАШMotive,тАЩ тАШanubandha,тАЩ literally means repealed action or that which leads to repeated action; the meaning thus is that the king shall ascertain what it was that led the man to commit the offence, i.e., he shall find out if he was urged to it by the starving condition of his family, or by association with criminals, or by reason of his being addicted to drink and gambling,тАФand if he did it intentionally or by mistake,тАФif he was urged to it by another person, or he did it voluntarily. These are the points to be considered in the ascertaining of the manтАЩs тАШmotive.тАЩ

тАШPlace,тАЩтАФa village, forest, granary or pasture-ground.

тАШTimeтАЩтАФwhether it was night or day; whether it was a time of scarcity or of plenty; whether the criminal is a youth or a full-grown person.

тАШCondition,тАЩтАФcapability or otherwise to suffer the penalty,тАФwhether he is rich or poor.

^(тАШ)OffenceтАЩтАФunder which of the eighteen categories the act falls.

Having, in due order, considered all this, the king shall тАШinflict the punishment,тАЩтАФso that the condition of the society may not suffer.тАФ(126)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШAnubandhamтАЩтАФтАШMotive or frequencyтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi and Govindar─Бja)тАФтАШfrequencyтАЩ (Kull┼лka and N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

тАШS─Бr─Бpr─БdhauтАЩтАФNandana reading тАШS─Бr─Бs─Бrau,тАЩ explains it as тАШstrength or weakness of the offender.тАЩ

Tins verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 627), which explains тАШS─БraтАЩ as strength and тАШanubandhaтАЩ as тАШrepetition of the improper act.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Gautama (12.51).тАФтАШThe award of punishment must be regulated by a consideration of the status of the criminal, of his bodily strength, of the nature of the crime, and whether the offence has been repeated.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (1.367).тАФтАШOn those deserving punishment, the King shall inflict punishment after having considered the nature of the crime, the time, place and strength of the criminal, as also his age, conduct and wealth.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Punishments, 38).тАФтАШAfter carefully considering the nature of the offence, the place and time, and after examining the ability of the offender, and his motive, he shall inflict the punishments.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (27.4-7).тАФтАШWhen he has discovered a man to be an offender, the King should inflict on him, reprimand, reproach or corporal chastisement, or one of the four grades of fines. He shall inflict gentle reprimand when the offence is very light; harsh reproach for a crime of the first degree; a fine for a crime of the middlemost degree, and arrest in the case of high treason. Banishment also may be resorted to by a king desirous of promoting his own welfare;…… and all the various forms of punishment should be combined in the case of one who has committed a mortal sin. The King should punish elders, domestic priests and persons commanding respect, with admonition only; other litigants he should punish with fine, when they are found guilty; and on the perpetrators of a heavy crime, he should inflict corporal punishment.тАЩ

126 Let the (king), having fully ascertained the motive, the time and place (of the offence), and having considered the ability (of the criminal to suffer) and the (nature of the) crime, cause punishment to fall on those who deserve it.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Unjust punishment is destructive of reputation among men and subversive of fame; in the other world also it leads to loss of heaven; he shall therefore avoid it.тАФ(127)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЕрдзрд░реНрдордкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирджрдгреНрдбрдирдореН150 рдЕрдзрд░реНрдорджрдгреНрдбрдирдореН151 ред рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЛрдХреНрддрдореН рдЕрдирдкреЗрдХреНрд╖реНрдпреЗрджрдВ рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдкрд╛рдардорд╛рддреНрд░реЗрдг152 рд░рд╛рдЬреЗрдЪреНрдЫрдпрд╛ рд░рд╛рдЧрджреНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рд░реН рд╡рд╛ ред рддрджреН рдпрд╢реЛрдирд╛рд╢рдХрдВ рдХреАрд░реНрддреЗрд╢реН рдЪ рд╡рд┐рдЪреНрдЫреЗрджрдХрдореН ред рд╕реНрд╡рджреЗрд╢реЗ рдЧреБрдгрдЦреНрдпрд╛рддрд┐рд░реН рдпрд╢рдГ, рджреЗрд╢рд╛рдиреНрддрд░реЗ рдХреАрд░реНрддрд┐рдГ ред рдЬреАрд╡рддреЛ рд╡рд╛ рдкреБрдгреНрдпрд╢рдмреНрджреЛ рдпрд╢рдГ, рдЙрддреНрддрд░рдХрд╛рд▓рд┐рдХреА рдХреАрд░реНрддрд┐рдГ ред рдирд┐рд░реНрджреЛрд╖рдЧреБрдгрд╡рддреА рдХреАрд░реНрддрд┐рдпрд╢рд╕реА ред рдЕрдиреНрдпреЛ рд╡рд╛ рднреЗрдж рдЙрдиреНрдиреЗрдпрдГ, рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН ред рдЕрд╕реНрд╡рд░реНрдЧреНрдпрдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд░реНрдЧрдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреМ рдХрд░реНрдорд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдЬрдиреНрдпрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдмрдиреНрдзрдХрдореН ред рдкрд░рддреНрд░рд╛рдкреАрддрд┐ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдкреВрд░рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердореН, рд╕реНрд╡рд░реНрдЧрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдореБрд╖реНрдорд┐рдХрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН153 рее рео.резреирен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШUnfair punishmentтАЩ is that punishment, that savours strongly of injustice;тАФi.e., one that takes no account of what has been just said, and which is determined cither entirely on the basis of the letter of the law, or by the kingтАЩs whim, or by love, hatred and such other feelings.

Such a punishment is тАШdestructive of reputation,тАЩ also тАШsubversive of fameтАЩ; тАШreputationтАЩ consists in the manтАЩs good qualities being known in his own country, while тАШfameтАЩ in their being known in foreign countries. Or тАШreputationтАЩ may consist in oneтАЩs good name during life.тАФOr the passage being a purely commendatory one, some other distinction may be drawn.

тАШLeads to loss of heavenтАЩ;тАФi.e., obstructs the passage to heaven, that might have been opened by other meritorious deeds.

тАШIn the other worldтАЩ;тАФthis has been added for filling up the metre; тАШheavenтАЩ itself being the other world.тАФ(127)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 649).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 8.127-128)
**

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (19.42-45).тАФтАШIf an innocent person is punished, the domestic priest shall perform a Kс╣Ыcchra penance; and the King shall fast during three days and nights.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (1.356, 358).тАФтАШPunishment illegally inflicted by the King destroys heaven, fame and worldly prosperity; legally inflicted, it brings to the King heaven, fame and victory. If the King punishes those who deserve punishment, and if he kills those who deserve to be killed, he offers, thereby, sacrifices at which excellent sacrificial fees are given.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Punishments, 61).тАФтАШLet the King, faithful to the tenets of the sacred law, practise the duties of his office and follow the rule of inflicting punishment. Let him destroy, as governor, the evil-doers, after having traced them by cunning stratagems and arrested them.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 649).тАФтАШBy not chastising evil-doers, and by punishing those who are already submissive, kings and ministers incur sin.тАЩ

127 Unjust punishment destroys reputation among men, and fame (after death), and causes even in the next world the loss of heaven; let him, therefore, beware of (inflicting) it.

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЗ рд╜рдиреБрдмрдиреНрдзрд╛рджрд┐рдирд┐рд░реВрдкрдгрд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдГ154 ред рдЕрдиреЗрди рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдирдкрд░рд╛рдзрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рджрдгреНрдбрдирдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖рд┐рдзреНрдпрддреЗ рд╕рд╛рдкрд░рд╛рдзрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдЪ рд╡рд┐рдзреАрдпрддреЗ ред рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдерддрд╛рдВ155 рджрдгреНрдбрд╕реНрдп рдордиреНрдпрдорд╛рдиреЛ рд╜рдиреБрдЧреНрд░рд╣реЗрдг рдорд╛ рд╣рд╛рд╕реАрджреН рдЗрддрд┐156 рее рео.резреирео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The preceding verse was supplementary to the injunction regarding the consideration of the тАШmotiveтАЩ and other things; while the present verse prohibits the punishing of persons who are not guilty of any offence, and enjoins that of those who are guilty;тАФand this is emphasised because of the possibility of the king regarding punishment as futile and hence omitting to inflict it, which would lead to much evil.тАФ(128)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 649);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (─Аc─Бra, p. 391), as prohibiting the punishment of the innocent;тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 25);тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.1), to the effect that the non-investigation of cases as well as the wrong investigation of them,тАФboth bring sin upon the king;тАФin N─лtimay┼лkha (p. 59);тАФand in Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 5a).

рдпрдд рдЖрд╣ ред

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If the guilty person is a good man and has committed a slight offence, and for the first time, then he is only reprimanded: тАШyou have not acted well, do not do it again.тАЩ

If, on being thus reprimanded, the man does not desist, or goes on to say тАШwhat is there wrong in this?тАЩтАФthen he is rebuked with such harsh reproachful words as тАШfie,тАЩ тАШshameтАЩ and so forth.

If he does not desist even when thus rebuked, he should be punished with fine, in accordance with the Law.

If he does not mind the fine either through folly or pride of wealth,тАФthen he should be killed. This тАШdeath-penaltyтАЩ consists in the cutting off of certain limbs, etc., and not necessarily in actually killing the man; as is clear from what follows in the next verse.тАФ(129)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (1.366), which, in quoting it, transposes, тАШv─Бgdaс╣Зс╕НamтАЩ and тАШdhigdaс╣Зс╕Нam,тАЩтАФsuch reading is more in keeping with Y─Бj├▒valkyaтАЩs text (1.356),тАФand it explains тАШdhigdaс╣Зс╕НaтАЩ as addressing such terms as тАШfie upon thee,тАЩтАФand тАШv─Бgdaс╣Зс╕НaтАЩ as тАШpronouncing a terrible curse

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 156); as laying down the order of sequence among the various forms of punishment; it explains v─Бgdaс╣Зс╕Нa as pronouncing a terrible curse (reproducing the exact words of Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б) and тАШdhigdaс╣Зс╕НaтАЩ as тАШchiding with such words as fie and the like.тАЩ

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 630), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШv─Бgdaс╣Зс╕НaтАЩ, тАШthou hast not done right,тАЩтАФтАШdhigdaс╣Зс╕НaтАЩ, тАШfie upon thee, damned sinner.тАЩ

It is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (R─Бjan─лti, p. 273), which adds the following notes:тАФThe first two forms of punishment are meant for light offences; тАШvadhadaс╣Зс╕НaтАЩ means corporal punishment, which has to be inflicted upon all except the Br─Бhmaс╣Зas.

рдорд╛рд░рдгрдВ рдЪреЗрджреН рд╡рдзрдГ рдХрд┐рдВ рддрджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрджреН рдпреЗрди158 рд╢рдХреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдХрдердВ рдЪреИрдирдВ159 рдкрд╛рдкрдВ рдирд┐рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрддреЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдкрд░реБрд╖рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдВ рджреБрд░реНрд╡рд┐рдиреАрддреЗрд╖реБ рдзрдирджрдгреНрдбрд╡рдзреМ рд╕рдореБрдЪреНрдЪреЗрддрд╡реНрдпреМ ред рдХреГрддреЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╢рд░реАрд░рджрдгреНрдбреЗ рдпрджрд┐ рдирд╛рд╡рддрд┐рд╖реНрдарддреЗ рддрддреЛ рди рдХреГрддрдирд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣ рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрддреНрд╕реГрдЬреЗрджреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рддреБ рд╕ рд╡рдзрджрдгреНрдбрдГ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рдзрдирд╡рдзрджрдгреНрдбрдпреЛрд╢реН рдЪ рдкреБрдирдГрдкреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдереЛ рд╜рдпрдореН рдЖрд░рдореНрднрдГ ред рд╡рд╛рдЧреНрджрдгреНрдбреЗ160 рдореГрджреБрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рдХрдГ рдкреГрдЪреНрдЫрддрд┐ ред рдзрдиреЗрди рдЪ рдирд┐рдЧреГрд╣реАрддрд╕реНрдп161 рдкреБрдирд░реН рд╡рдзреЛ рджреГрд╖реНрдЯреЛ “рдЕрдЩреНрдЧреБрд▓реАрд░реН162 рдЧреНрд░рдиреНрдерд┐рднреЗрджрд╕реНрдп” (рдореНрдзреН реп.реиренрен) рдЗрддрд┐ рее рео.резрейреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If actual killing were meant by тАШdeath-penalty,тАЩ then what would be there that could not be done by it? How too would the penalty not restrain a crime?

On persons not resuming good behaviour after being rebuked, тАШтАФfineтАЩ and the тАШdeath-penalty,тАЩ i. e., corporal punishment, should be conjointly inflicted. If, even after corporal punishment, the man does not desist, the king shall not ignore him,тАФunder the impression that he has already inflicted the legal punishment,тАФbut he shall inflict actual тАШdeath-penalty.тАЩ

The present verse has been added with a view to indicate that the matter of fines and death-penalty is going to be taken up again later on.

As regards verbal punishment, it being too gentle, who would mind it? If the man has been punished with a fine, and even then does not desist, the тАШdeath-penaltyтАЩ shall be inflicted in the form of the cutting off of the fingers and so forth, as described below under 9.277.тАФ(130)

I am going to describe fully, for the sake of business-transactions, those technical terms that are used in the world in connection with silver and gold.тАФ(131)

тАШThe dust-mote discernible in the sunbeam passing through a lattice is called Trasareс╣Зu;тАФ three Trasareс╣Зus make one nit; 3 nits make 1 Black mustard-seed. 3 Black mustard seeds make 1 white mustard seed. 6 white mustard seeds make 1 Barley-corn. 3 Barley-corns make 1 Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зala. 5 Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зalas make 1 M─Бс╣гa. 12 M─Бс╣гas make ┬╜ Akс╣гa. ┬╜ Akс╣гa plus 4 M─Бс╣гas make 1 Suvarс╣Зa. 4 Suvarс╣Зas make 1 Niс╣гka. 2 Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зalas make 1 Silver M─Бс╣гaka. 16 Silver-M─Бс╣гakas make 1 Dharaс╣Зa of silver. 1 Karс╣гa or 80 Raktikas of copper make 1 K─Бrс╣г─Бpaс╣Зa. 250 Copper Paс╣Зas make the first or lowest amercement. 500 Copper Paс╣Зas make the middlemost amercement. 1,000 Copper Paс╣Зas make the Highest amercement.

тАШOne Dust-mote in the SunтАЩs beam makes 1 Trasareс╣Зu, 8 Trasareс╣Зus make 1 Likс╣г─Б, 3 Likс╣г─Бs make 1 R─Бjasarс╣гapa (black mustard seed), 3 Black mustard seed make 1 White mustard seed, 6 White mustard seeds make 1 Barley-corn, 3 Barley-corns make 1 Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зala, 5 Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зalas make 1 M─Бс╣гa, 16 M─Бс╣гas make 1 Suvarс╣Зa, 4 or 5 Suvarс╣Зas make 1 Pala, 2 Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зalas make 1 M─Бс╣гa (silver), 16 M─Бс╣гas (silver) make 1 Dharaс╣Зa, 10 Dharaс╣Зas make 1 ┼Ъatam─Бna or Pala (silver), 4 Suvarс╣Зas make 1 Niс╣гka, Copper, ┬╝ Pala (gold) in weight make 1 Paс╣Зa (copper), 1080 Paс╣Зas make the highest amercement, 540 Paс╣Зas make the middlemost amercement, 270 Paс╣Зas make the lowest amercement.тАЩ

тАШ10 Dh─Бnya-m─Бс╣гaka or 5 Gu├▒j─Бs = 1 Suvarс╣Зa-m─Бс╣гaka. 16 Suvarс╣Зa-m─Бс╣гakas = 1 Suvarс╣Зa or 1 Karс╣гa. 4 Karс╣гas = 1 Pala. 80 white mustard seeds = 1 M─Бс╣гaka (silver). 16 M─Бс╣гaka (silver) or 20 ┼Ъambya berries = 1 Dharaс╣Зa. 20 Rice-grains = 1 Dharaс╣Зa (Diamond).

рдЕрде рдЪреИрд╡рдВ рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдГ рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ ред рдпрд╛рдГ рд╕рдВрдЬреНрдЮрд╛ рднреБрд╡рд┐ рдкреНрд░рдерд┐рддрд╛рд╕реН рддрд╛ рд▓реЛрдХрд╕рдВрд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рд╛рд░реНрдердВ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрд╛рдорд┐ ред рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрдп рд▓реЛрдХрд╕реНрдпрд╛рднрд┐рд░реН рдПрд╡ рд╕рдВрд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЛ рдпрдерд╛ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рджреН рджрдгреНрдбрд╛рджрд┐рдирд┐рдпреЛрдЧрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрд┐рдГ рее рео.резрейрез рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Objection.тАФтАЬSuch terms as тАШlikс╣г─БтАЩ (Louse-egg) and the rest, pertaining to copper and other metals are already well known in the world; what is the use of propounding a scriptural definition? They could he learnt from the usage of experienced men, just as the exact denotation of such words as тАШcowтАЩ and the like is learnt.тАЭ

It is in view of this objection that the author has added the phrase тАШfor the sake of business-transactionsтАЩ; тАШsakeтАЩ here denotes sphere; hence the meaning is that what is adopted as the basis here is usage in actual business (and not ordinary usage).

тАЬIn that case, standing on the same footing as such words as тАШcowтАЩ and the like, they would he learnt from actual business-usage; what is the use of setting forth a scriptural injunction?тАЭ

The answer to this is that the Injunction is put forth for the purposes of restriction. There being several other such terms in use in connection with iron, bell-metal, gold and other metals, it is with a view to preclude these that the author has laid down the present injunction; as also for precluding the difference in the measures, which is met with in certain localities. For instance, in some localities, a pala is regarded as made of 40 m─Бс╣гas, while in others of 64, and in others again of 108, and so forth. And all this diversity is precluded and one definite measure is laid down here.

The verse is to be construed as followsтАФтАШthese terms that are used in the world, I am going to describe for the sake of business-transactions,тАЩтАФso that the business-transactions of all men may be carried on with the help of those same technical terms; and incidentally the rules relating to these also would become clearer.тАФ(131)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 115);тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 665), which explains the construction as тАШthose that are generally used, these I am going to describe, explain, for the purpose of transactions among menтАЩ;тАФin Hem─Бdri (Vrata, p. 53);тАФand in Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (D─Бna, p. 4a).

рддрддреНрд░реЛрдкрдЪрд┐рддрдкрд░рд┐рдорд╛рдгрд╛рдГ164 ред рди рдкреБрдирд░реН рдЕрдпрдВ рд▓рд┐рдХреНрд╖рд╛рд╢рдмреНрджрдГ рд╕реНрд╡реЗрджрдЬрдХреНрд╖реБрджреНрд░рдЬрдиреНрддреБрд╡рдЪрдирдГ ред рддрд╛рд╕реН рддрд┐рд╕реНрд░реЛ рд▓рд┐рдХреНрд╖рд╛ рдПрдХреЛ рд░рд╛рдЬрд╕рд░реНрд╖рдкрд╛рдЦреНрдпрдкрд░рд┐рдорд╛рдгрдкрджрд╛рд░реНрдердГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдпреЛрдЬрдиреАрдпрдореН ред рддрддрд╢реН рдЪ рд╡реНрдпрднрд┐рдЪрд╛рд░рдпрдиреНрддрд┐ рди рдпрдереЛрдХреНрддрдкрд░рд┐рдорд╛рдгрд╛ рдпрд╡рд╛рджрдпреЛ рд╜рд░реНрдерд╛ рдЗрддрд┐ рддреЗ рдирд┐рд░рд╕реНрддрд╛ рднрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ ред рди рд╣рд┐ рдпрд╡рд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдореН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдкрд░рд┐рдорд╛рдгрдореН ред рдХрдердВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐ рдпрдереЛрдХреНрддрдкрд░рд┐рдорд╛рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердГ165 ред рдпрдерд╛ рдЪреЛрдкрдХреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрд╕рдВрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрд╛рдорд┐ рдкрд░рд┐рдорд╛рдгрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддреНрд░рд╕рд░реЗрдгреБрд╢реН рдЪрд╛рд░реНрдереЛ рдирд┐рдпрддрдкрд░рд┐рдорд╛рдгрд╕реН рддреЗрдиреИрддрддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪреЗрдпрдореН ред рд╢рдХреНрдиреБрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ рдЪ рдирд┐рдкреБрдгрд╛рд╕реН рддреНрд░рд╕рд░реЗрдгреВрдиреН рд╕рдВрд╣рдиреНрддреБрдореН166 рдЗрддрд┐ рдирд╛рдирд╛рд░рднреНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдереЛрдкрджреЗрд╢рдГ ред рдПрддрддреН рд╕реНрд╡рд░реНрдгрдХрд╛рд░рд╛рднрд┐рдорд╛рдирд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛рд╕реНрдореГрддрд┐рд░реВрдкрдВ рдирд┐рд░реНрдмрд╛рдзрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рддрдд рдПрд╡ рд╡рд╕реНрддреБ рдирд┐рдкреБрдгрддреЛ рд╜рд╢реЗрд╖рддреЛ рд╜рд╡рдзрд╛рд░рдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН рее рео.резрейрей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The gradually ascending measures are now described.

The term тАШlikс╣г─Б,тАЩ тАШlouseтАЩ does not stand for the sweat-born insect, when it is said that тАШthree Louse-eggs make one Black MustardтАЩ; what is meant is that the three of the measures known as the тАШLouse-eggтАЩ make one of that particular measure which is known as тАШBlack Mustard.тАЩ This meets those objectors who argue that the тАШbarley-grain,тАЩ etc., that we see are not found to be exactly of the same size as those described here. Because the measure here described is not of the barley and other grains; what is meant is that these terms constitute the names of those particular measures. The subject has been introduced also with the wordsтАФтАШI am going to describe the measures.тАЩ

The тАШTriadтАЩ is an object whose measure is fixed; and through this Triad all the other measures are to be determined. Clever men are capable of forming compounds of тАШTriadsтАЩ; so that the text has not put forward anything impossible or unknown. What is here described becomes clear by referring to the opinions and ideas current among goldsmiths. In fact the details of the subject can be ascertained only by referring to them.тАФ(133)

рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдХреГрд╖реНрдгрд▓рд╛ рдЕрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рд╕рдиреНрддрд┐ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдХреГрд╖реНрдгрд▓рд┐рдХрдГ169 ред “рдЕрдд рдЗрддрд┐ рдардиреМ” рдЗрддрд┐ рдЯрдиреН рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред “рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдХреГрд╖реНрдгрд▓рдХрдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ рдкрд╛рдареЗ рдХрдмрдиреНрддреЛ рдмрд╣реБрд╡реНрд░реАрд╣рд┐рдГ ред рддреЗ рдХреГрд╖реНрдгрд▓рд╛рдГ рд╖реЛрдбрд╢ рдПрдХрдГ рд╕реБрд╡рд░реНрдгрдГ рее рео.резрейрек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАЬThe term тАШmiddlingтАЩ is likely to lead to mistakes. If the names here put forward are meant to be denotative of the size of the objects named, then the addition of the epithet тАШmiddlingтАЩ has some meaning,тАФthe sense being that the size of the тАШMustardтАЩ here meant is that of a mustard grain which is neither too large nor too small. If, on the other hand, the terms are put forward as mere technical names, then there can be no sense in the term тАШmiddling,тАЩтАФthe term тАШbarleycornтАЩ being a mere technical name (standing for the grain).тАЭ

This is not right. This is not a prose-treatise, that we should seek for the justification of every expression used; it is a metrical treatise, and as such sometimes even irrelevant expressions are introduced for the purpose of filling up the metre. As a matter of fact, however, there is some relevancy in the present case; if it were something wholly irrelevant it would interfere with the comprehension of the sentence as a whole, and would thereby vitiate its authority. But there is nothing irrelevant here; the fact is that the тАШbarley-cornтАЩ being mentioned in the middle of the entire table of measuresтАФbeginning with the тАШTriadтАЩ and ending with the тАШ┼Ъatam┼лna,тАЩтАФthe epithet тАШmiddlingтАЩ has been added to it in the sense that the particular measure known as the тАШbarleycornтАЩ occurs in the middle of the whole table of measures.

The term тАШpa├▒cakс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗalikaтАЩ is formed with the тАШс╣нhinтАЩ affix, the sense being тАШthat which is made up of five тАШKс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зalas.тАЩ If the reading is тАШpa├▒cakс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зalika,тАЩ it should be treated as a Bahuvr─лhi compound, ending with the тАШkapтАЩ affix.

Sixteen of these тАШgu├▒j─Б-berriesтАЩ make one тАШgold-piece.тАЩтАФ(134)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

The Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зala is the same as the Raktik─Б (Vern. Ratti), equivalent to 122 grammes or 1.875 grains.

тАЬThe tines in court were reckoned as so many paс╣Зas, one paс╣Зa being the same as a karс╣гa = 16 M─Бс╣гa = 80 Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зala. Some of the weights mentioned are, confined to gold тАФSuvarс╣Зa and Niс╣гka; some to silver тАФPur─Бс╣Зa and ┼Ъatam─Бna; and some are used for bothтАФkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зala, paс╣Зa m─Бс╣гa, pala, dharaс╣Зa, the last at times of copper.тАЭтАФHopkins.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 666) which explains тАШmadhyaс╕етАЩ as тАШneither large nor smallтАЩ;тАФand in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 115), which adds that the name тАШm─Бс╣гaтАЩ is applied to the sixteenth part of the тАШsuvarс╣ЗaтАЩ, and тАШkс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗalaтАЩ to the third part of the тАШkaс╣ЫsaтАЩ, which latter is the fifth part of the тАШm─Бс╣гaтАЩ. It remarks that тАШkarс╣гaтАЩ is one of the names of silver.

It is quoted in Hem─Бdri (Vrata, p. 53);тАФand in Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (D─Бna, 4a).

рдкрд▓рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рдВрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирд┐рд░реНрджреЗрд╢рдГ ред рд╕реБрд╡рд░реНрдгрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рдВрдЬреНрдЮреА ред рдЪрддреНрд╡рд╛рд░ рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгрдореН ред рдзрд░рдгрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рдВрдЬреНрдЮрд╛ ред рджрд╢ рдкрд▓рд╛рдиреАрддрд┐ рд╕рдВрдЬреНрдЮреА ред рджреНрд╡реЗ рдХреГрд╖реНрдгрд▓реЗ рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рдВрдЬреНрдЮрд╛ ред рд░реВрдкреНрдпрдорд╛рд╖рдХ рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рдореБрджрд╛рдпрд╕рдВрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдВ171 рдордиреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдирдиреБ рд░реВрдкреНрдпрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрдорд╛рд╖рдХрдирд┐рд░реНрджреЗрд╢реЗ рджреНрд╡реЗ рдХреГрд╖реНрдгрд▓реЗ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрддреНрддрд╡реНрдпреЗ рдЗрддрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЬрд╛рдиреАрддреЗ ред рддрддрд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрдпрдГ172 ред рд╕рдордзреГрддреЗ ред рддреБрд▓рд╛рд╕реВрддреНрд░рдХреЗ рдЙрдиреНрдорд╛рдирд╛рджрд┐рд╣реАрдиреЗ173 рдпрджрд┐ рдзрд╛рд░реНрдпреЗрддреЗ ред рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирдВ рдордзреНрдпрд╢рдмреНрджрд╡рддреН (рдореНрдзреН рео.резрейрек), рдпрддреЛ рд╜рд╕рдордпрд╛рджреН рдзрд╛рд░реНрдпрдорд╛рдгрддрдпрд╛ рдкрд░рд┐рдорд╛рдгрд╛рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрдпрдГ рее рео.резрейрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШPalaтАЩ is the name, and тАШgold-pieceтАЩ the thing named, тАШfourтАЩ is its qualifying adjunct.

тАШTwo kс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗalasтАЩ is the thing named, and the compound term тАШSilver-BeanтАЩ the name.

тАЬWhat the text declares is that when we come to ascertain the exact measure of the тАШBeanтАЩ in connection with silver, we have to understand it us being equal to тАШtwo gu├▒ja-berries.тАЩ Now this makes the measure indefinite.тАЭ

It is in view of this that the text has added the epithet тАШof equal weightтАЩ; i.e., the two are to be held on each pan of the weighing-scale, without any other kinds of measure. The sense of this epithet has to be explained on the same lines as that of the epithet тАШmiddlingтАЩ (in verse 134); and its use lies in the fact that if unequal beans were meant, the weight would remain indefinite.тАФ(135)

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 115);тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 666), which adds that the construction is тАШda┼Ыapal─Бni dharaс╣ЗamтАЩ;тАФin Hem─Бdri (Vrata, p. 58);тАФand in Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (D─Бna, 4a).

рдпреЛ рд░рд╛рдЬрд╕рднрд╛рдпрд╛рдореН рдЖрдиреАрддреЛ рдзрд░реНрдореЗрдг рдЛрдгрдВ рджреЗрдпрддрдпрд╛ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЬрд╛рдиреАрддреЗ “рд╕рддреНрдпрдореН рдЕрд╕реНрдореИ рдзрд╛рд░рдпрд╛рдорд┐,” рд╕ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдХрдВ рд╢рддрдореН рдЕрд░реНрд╣рддрд┐ рджрдгреНрдбрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╢реЗрд╖рдГ ред рдЕрдиреЗрди рд╕рдВрдХрд▓реНрдкрд┐рддреЗрди рд╡рд┐рдВрд╢рддрд┐рддрдореЛ рднрд╛рдЧреЛ рджрдгреНрдбреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдХрд┐рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред “рдорддреНрд╕рдХрд╛рд╢рдореН176 рдЙрддреНрддрдорд░реНрдгрдГ рдкреНрд░реЗрд╖рд┐рддреЛ рдмрд╣рд┐рд░реН рдПрд╡ рдХрд╕реНрдорд╛рдиреН рди рдкрд░рд┐рддреЛрд╖рд┐рддрдГ” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрддреЛ рд╜рдиреЗрди рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдореЗрдг рджрдгреНрдбрдореН рдЕрд░реНрд╣рддрд┐ ред рдпрд╕реН рддреБ рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдорд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдВ рдХрд░реЛрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд╣реНрдиреБрддреЗ “рдирд╛рд╣рдореН рдЕрд╕реНрдореИ рдзрд╛рд░рдпрд╛рдорд┐” рдЗрддрд┐, рд╕ рддреИрдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрд╛рджрд┐рддрд╕реН рддрджреНрджреНрд╡рд┐рдЧреБрдгрдВ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рддреН рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдХрд╛рджреН рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЧреБрдгрдВ рджрд╢рдХрдВ рд╢рддрдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рддрдиреН рдордиреЛрдГ рдкреНрд░рдЬрд╛рдкрддреЗрд░реН рдЕрдиреБрд╢рд╛рд╕рдирдВ рд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рдХрд╛рд▓рдкреНрд░рднреГрддрд┐рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛ рдиреАрддрд┐рд░реН рдЗрддрд┐ рдпрд╛рд╡рддреН ред

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреБ рддрдЪреНрдЫрдмреНрджреЗрди рджреЗрдпрдореН рдПрд╡ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╡рдореГрд╢рдиреНрддрд┐ ред рдпрд╛рд╡рддреН рддрд╕реНрдореИ рджреЗрдпрдВ рддрджреНрджреНрд╡рд┐рдЧреБрдгрдореН ред рддреЗрди рдпрд╛рд╡рджреН рдЛрдгрдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреЗрдиреИрдХрд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛ рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрднреЗрджрдГ ред рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛рдирд┐рд░реНрджреЗрд╢рд╛рджреН рдПрдХрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрддреНрд╡реЗ рд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрдиреЛрддрд┐ ред

рд╕ рдЪ рди рдпреБрдХреНрддреЛ рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЧреБрдгрд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреНрдпрдиреНрддрдмрд╣реБрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН ред рдЕрд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдирд┐рд░реНрджреЗрд╢реЗ рддрд╕реНрдп рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпреЛ рджрд░реНрд╢рдиреАрдпрдГ,177 рддрд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╛рд╕рдиреНрдиреЗ178 рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдХрдореН рдЗрддрд┐, рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рддреН179 рддрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡рд╛рдиреБрдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╡рдорд░реНрд╢реЛ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдГ рее рео.резрейреп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

When the debtor, on being summoned to the KingтАЩs Court, admits the debt as legally due by him, sayingтАФтАШI do really owe this to him,тАЩтАФthen тАШi.e., deserves five per cent.тАЩ тАШas fineтАЩ;тАФthis has to be added. By this rule, the man is to be fined the twentieth part of the amount of debt claimed. The man deserves this fine on account of his having transgressed the law by not satisfying the creditorтАЩs claims outside the Court and thereby forcing him to come up to the king.

When the man commits a further transgression by denying the claim, sayingтАФтАШI do not owe anything to this person,тАЩтАФthen, on the claim being proved, the man is to be fined тАШtwice as muchтАЩ; i.e., double of five per cent.; i.e., ten per cent.

тАШSuch is the ordinance of ManuтАЩтАФPraj─Бpati; i.e., the Rule or Law propounded by him from the very beginning of creation.

Others have explained the term тАШas muchтАЩ as referring to the total amount of the claim, i.e., double the sum that is due to the debtor; as it is only thus that the syntactical connection with the term тАШdebtтАЩ is maintained; otherwise there is a syntactical split; and as no different subject has been mentioned, if it referred to the same subject, then the result would be an option.

This however is not right; for the double of the amount of debt would he too much. Even though the subject is not definitely mentioned, yet on account of juxtaposition, it is only right that it should be taken as referring to тАШfive per cent.тАЩтАФ(139)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШTaddviguс╣ЗamтАЩтАФтАШDouble of 5 p. c., i.e., 10 p. c.тАЩ This is the explanation, accepted by all the commentators. But Medh─Бtithi mentions тАШothersтАЩ as explaining the meaning to be тАШdouble of the amount of the debtтАЩ This latter would be more in keeping with what has gone before in verse 59.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 77), which adds the following notes:тАФThe meaning is as follows: If the debt is at first denied, and subsequently admitted, then the debtor should be fined 5 per cent on the amount of debt; but if he does not admit it even subsequentlyтАФand yet the debt becomes proved by the evidence adduced,тАФthen the man shall be fined the тАШdouble of that,тАЩ i.e., 10 per cent. It proceeds to add a note which serves to explain the inconsistency of this rule with what has gone in verse 59:тАФthe diversity is due to considerations of the nature of the debtorтАЩs motives.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 34), which adds the explanation that тАШwhen a debt is denied at first and subsequently admitted, the debtor is to he fined 5 per cent, and if the man continues to deny the debt which is subsequently proved, the fine is to be 10 per cent; and adds that this refers to cases where the debtor is poorтАЩ;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (81a), which has the following explanation:тАФ(a) If the man has denied the debt but admits it when sued in Court, then he is to be fined 5 p. c., (b) if he continues to deny it in the Court, but the debt is subsequently proved, then the fine is 10 per cent;тАФthis refers to cases where the former denial has been based upon some misapprehension on the part of the debtor; the case where the denial is through perversity and intentional, has been dealt with under 59.

It is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 111a), which explains the meaning to be тАШwhen the man having denied the debt at first, admits it when sued and brought before the Court, he should pay a fine of 5 p. c. and if he continues to deny it, but is subsequently forced by evidence to admit, then 10 p. c.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (6.20-22).тАФтАШIf a creditor goes before the King and fully proves his demand, the debtor shall pay as fine to the King a tenth part of the sum proved. The creditor, on receiving the sum, shall pay the twentieth part of it. If the whole demand has been contested by the debtor, and even a part of it has been proved against him, he must pay the whole.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.44).тАФтАШOut of the sum proved against him, the King shall make the debtor pay ten per cent, (as fine) and the creditor, on having realised his dues, shall pay five per cent,тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.132-134).тАФтАШIf a wealthy debtor, from malice) refuses to pay his debt, the King shall compel him to pay it by forcible means, and shall take five in the hundred for himself. If the debtor acknowledges the debt with his own mouth, the King shall take from him ten per cent, of the debt as fine; and twice as much if he has been convicted. If the debtor, owing to a calamity, has not means sufficient to discharge the whole debt, the claim of the creditor shall be entered in a legal document, specifying the caste of the debtor and of the creditor, their names, and the names of their neighbours.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (11.60-02).тАФтАШWhen the time fixed for pay ment has elapsed, and the accruing of interest has ceased, the creditor may either recover his loan or cause a new bond to bo written in the form of compound interest. This rule concerns an acknowledged debt; but a debtor denying his liability shall be compelled to pay, on the debt being proved in a court, by a document or by witnesses.тАЩ

Yama (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 78).тАФтАШIf a wealthy debtor refuses to repay the debt, through ill-will, he should be compelled by the King to pay, after having realised from him double the amount of the claim.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШHe shall take, etc.тАЩ (the second half of the verse) represents the injunction; and what is said regarding its being тАШsanctioned by Vasiс╣гс╣нhaтАЩ is merely commendatory;тАФthe sense being that тАШVasiс╣гс╣нha, the revered sage, cognisant of all that happens at the three points of time and devoid of greed, accepted interest, hence it is commendable.тАЩ тАШBy its means oneтАЩs capital increases, and yet there is no impropriety in it on the ground of its being indicative of greed.

тАШStipulate,тАЩтАФEmploy; at the time that he is advancing money to the debtor, he should clearly stipulate the rate of interest.

In the case of all things that can be counted or measured,тАФsuch as clothes, grains, gold and so forth- the rate of interest is to be as here laid down. In the case of liquor, however, the rate of interest has been declared to be eight times of the principal,тАФand this is an exception to the limit that the total amount of the debt shall not exceed the double of the principal, as we shall explain later on.тАФ(140)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This rule, here attributed to Vasiс╣гс╣нha, actually occurs in Vasiс╣гс╣нha-Dharma┼Ы─Бstra, 2.51.

тАЬAccording to Kull┼лka, (on 142), N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa, R─Бghav─Бnanda and Nandana, this rule refers to a debt secured by a pledge, find the correctness of this view is proved by the parallel passage of Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.37).тАЭтАФBuhler.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 7, which explains тАШm─Бs─БtтАЩ as тАШafter the lapse of one month,тАЩ and adds that this refers to debt that is secured by a pledge that can be enjoyed (by the creditor).

Smс╣Ыtitattva (p. 349) quotes the second half and adds that тАШof 100 k─Бrс╣г─Бpaс╣ЗasтАЩ, the тАШeightieth partтАЩ would be 20 paс╣Зas.

It is quoted in Pr─Бya┼Ыcittaviveka (p. 420), which explains тАШa┼Ы─лtibh─БgamтАЩ as 20 paс╣Зas;тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 325);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 91b), which says that this refers to cases of mortgage, and the meaning is that when 100 rupees have been advanced, the creditor should charge 1┬╝ rupee after the lapse of one month.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 8.140-142)
**

Gautama (12.29-30).тАФтАШThe legal interest for money lent is five m─Бс╣гas a month for twenty k─Бrс╣г─Бpaс╣Зas. Some declare that this rate should not he paid longer than one year.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (2.48).тАФтАШThey quote the followingтАФ2, 3, 4 or 5, in the hundred, he may take as interest per month, according to the order of the castes.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (2.51).тАФтАШThe interest for a money-lender declared by Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha is five m─Бс╣гas for twenty K─Бс╣Ыс╣г─Бpanas, per month.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.37).тАФтАШIn the case of loans with pledges, the interest per month shall be the eightieth part; in those without pledges, it shall be 2, 3, 4 or 5 per cent, respectively for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, the Kс╣гatriya, the Vai┼Ыya and the ┼Ъ┼лdra.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.99-101).тАФтАШLet a money-lender take, in addition to the principal, the interest fixed by Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha, viz., an eightieth part of a hundred every month. 2, 3, or 5 (in the hundred) is the legitimate rate of interest; let him take as much in the shape of interest, every month, in the direct order of the four castes. Or let him take 2 in the 100, remembering the practice of the virtuous.

Bс╣Ыhaspati (11.3).тАФтАШAn eightieth part of the principal accrues as interest on it every month; and it is doubled by such interest within six years and eight months.тАЩ

Artha-┼Ъ─Бstra (p. 61).тАФтАШThe legal interest, per month, on every 100 Paс╣Зas, is 1┬╝ Paс╣Зas; it is 5 Paс╣Зas in business transactions; 10 Paс╣Зas for people trading in forests; and 20 Paс╣Зas for those trading on the seas.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (6.1-5).тАФтАШA creditor shall receive his principal back from his debtor exactly as he had lent it to him. As regards interest, he shall take, in the direct order of the castes, 2, 3, 4 or 5 percent., per month, if no pledge has been given; or the debtor of any caste may pay as much as has been promised by him. After the lapse of one year, let them pay interest according to the afore-mentioned rule, even though it may not have been agreed upon. By the use of the pledge, interest becomes forfeited.тАЩ
