рдЕрде “рдЖрд╣реГрддрд╛” рдЗрддрд┐322 рдкрд╛рдард╛рдиреНрддрд░рдореН ред рддрдерд╛рдкрд┐ рд╕рдХреГрдЪреНрдЫрдмреНрджреЛ рди рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддрд╛рд░реНрдереЛ рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпрд╕реН323 рддреБ рдкрд░рд┐рддреНрдпрдХреНрддрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рдХреГрддрд╢реН рдЪ рдкрд╛рдардГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреН рди рдорд╛рдирд╡реА рд╕реНрдореГрддрд┐рд░реН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддреИрд╡ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛ рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпреНрдпрд╛ ред

рдзрд╛рдиреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рд╖реБ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрддрд╛рдВ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдЧреБрдгрддрд╛рдореН рдирд╛рддреНрдпреЗрддрд┐ ред рд╕реНрдореГрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд░реЗ рдзрд╛рдиреНрдпреЗ рдЪрддреБрд░реНрдЧреБрдгреЛрдХреНрддрд╛ “рд╣рд┐рд░рдгреНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдзрд╛рдиреНрдпрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рд░реН рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреНрд░рд┐рдЪрддреБрд░реНрдЧреБрдгрд╛рдГ” (рдиреНрд╕реНрдореН рез.репреи) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛- рдпрджрд┐ рджрд░рд┐рджреНрд░рднреВрддрдГ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд╛ рдЧреНрд░рд╣реАрддрд╛ рдЪ рдорд╣рд╛рдзрдирд╕рдВрдкрдиреНрдирд╕реН рддреЗрди рдзрд╛рдиреНрдпреЗрди рдорд╣рд╛рдиреНрддрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдердВ рдХреГрддрд╡рд╛рдВрд╕реН рддрджрд╛ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдЧреБрдгрд╛рдиреНрдпрдерд╛ рдЪрддреБрд░реНрдЧрдгрд╛ ред рд╕рджрдВ324 рдлрд▓рдВ рд╡рд╛рд░реНрд╖рдореН, рдзрд╛рдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдп рдкреГрдердЧреБрдкрд╛рджрд╛рдирд╛рддреН ред рд▓рд╡325 рдЙрджреАрдЪреНрдпреЗрд╖реВрд░реНрдгрд╛рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдГ ред рд╡рд╛рд╣реНрдпреЛ рдЧрд░реНрджрднреЛрд╖реНрдЯреНрд░рдмрд▓реАрд╡рд░реНрджрд╛рджрд┐рдГ рее рео.резрелрез рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШKus─лda,тАЩ тАШmonetary loansтАЩтАФthe advancing of money for earning interest; or the money advanced may itself be called тАШKus─лdaтАЩ; i.e., the money which is advanced with the idea тАШhaving advanced a small amount I shall get back a larger amount.тАЩ

The interest on such loans тАШshall not exceed the doubleтАФthe creditor, having advanced the money to the debtor, shall receive from him only such an amount as may be the double of his principal.

тАЬWhat the text says is that the interest should become тАШDoubleтАЩ; and this, along with the principal itself, should make the total amount received thrice the principal.тАЭ

It is not so; in the term тАШDviguс╣Зa,тАЩ тАШdouble,тАЩ the term тАШguс╣ЗaтАЩ signifies part; and when we come to look out for a whole of which it would be the тАШpart,тАЩ it is the principal which, from the context, appears to us as the тАШwhole.тАЩ Hence when the text speaks of the тАШdouble,тАЩ what is meant is the double of the capital advanced. To this end we have other Smс╣Ыti-textsтАФ(a) тАШWhen there is delay, the capital advanced shall become doubledтАЩ (Gautama, 12. 81); and (b) тАШThe deposit is to be redeemed when the principal has become doubledтАЩ (Y─Бj├▒avalkya, Vyavah─Бra, 64).

тАШInterestтАЩ is paid in several forms:тАФ(1) when coins are advanced, interest is paid in coins; (2) sometimes it is paid in the form of progeny; as in the case of female cattle; (3) sometimes in the form of the use of pledges, in the shape of cattle, land and the like.

The doubling of the interest is, according to some people, meant to pertain to those cases where the interest paid is of the same kind as the capital advanced; and the reason for this lies in the fact that it is only in such cases that the exact тАШdoubleтАЩ can be ascertained; while in the case of interest in the form of тАШprogenyтАЩ of animals, it cannot be ascertained whether the тАШdoublingтАЩ is to be computed by number, or size or measure; as in the case of such animals as elephants and horses, it is found that when they are bought or sold, their price depends upon their size; as a rule animals of larger size fetching higher prices.

тАЬThere is similarity of kind in the progeny also; the progeny of the cow is of the same species as the cow. So that there is no justification for any distinction as that into (a) тАШinterest of the same kindтАЩ and (b) тАШprogeny.тАЩтАЭ

The answer to this is as follows:тАФтАШSameness of kindтАЩ does not depend only upon belonging to the same species; in fact it depends upon similarity of age, size and other factors. Hence the distinction is quite correct. Further, in the case of interest in the form of the use of deposits also, how would the тАШdoubleтАЩ be determined? And when cows and lands are pledged, the benefit derived from the use of the cow is in the form of milk, while in the case of land, it is in the form of fodder and other produce; so that in these cases also what sort of тАШdoubleтАЩ would there be? In actual usage it is found that if the principal gold is not paid, land continues to be used and enjoyed for hundreds of years. Says Y─Бy├▒avalkya (Vyavah─Бra, 90)тАФтАШThe pledge continues to be enjoyed so long as the capital is not paid off.тАЩ [From all this it is dear that the limit of тАШdoubleтАЩ cannot he applicable to all cases.]

Our answer to this explanation of some people is as follows:тАФWhen what is asserted is the тАШdoublingтАЩ in regard to тАШinterestтАЩ in general, how can we restrict it to any particular kind of interest only? When the words of the text afford a certain meaning in a general form, we cannot restrict it to any particular case, unless there is some authority for doing it. As regards the argument that тАЬthere can be no doubling,тАЩ in the case of progeny,тАЭтАФju st please make an effort to understand the matter: when an animal is pledged, its value is duly determined, and certainly the value of its progeny also could be similarly determined. Similarly in the case of the enjoyment of landed property also, when the fodder and grains become ripened, it can he easily determined when their value becomes equivalent to the principal.

Then again, the term тАШGuс╣ЗaтАЩ (contained in тАШdviguс╣Зa,тАЩ тАШdoubleтАЩ) signifies usefulness also. тАЬin that case what is there that would be as useful as the principal?тАЭ It can always be found if a certain thing serves any useful purpose at all. And if the interest accruing he computed only at the price obtained from the sale of the grain and fodder produced from the land,тАФthen also it would be possible for the interest to become equivalent to the principal,тАФeven though there may be no exact equality of size and other details.

As for the тАШlocal customтАЩ that you have put forward,тАФthat argument has been answered by yourself, when you called it тАШlocal.тАЩ further, whenever there is any chance of customs being abandoned, it is Smс╣Ыti-texts that serve the useful purpose of affording the requisite check.

As regards the textтАФтАШthe pledge is enjoyed so long as the principal is not paid up,тАЩтАФthe phrase тАШso long as the principal is not paid upтАЩ can he taken to mean тАШso long as it has not become doubled.тАЩ In fact, with a view to reconciling it with other Smс╣Ыti-texts, it is best to take it in this sense. This has been fully explained by us elsewhere.

тАШStipulated at one timeтАЩтАФi.e., what has been fixed upon at one time, in eases of the renewal of the loan. тАШStipulatingтАЩ means fixing; and what is settling by verbal contract is also fixing. The loan is renewed, when the principal has become doubled and is not paid up. Even after the principal has been doubled, if the creditor is willing to earn further interest on it, and the debtor also wishes to retain the money for the purpose of currying on some large business, he renews the deed, entering as principal, the former principal along with the accrued interest, and thenceforward it is on this principal that the interest begins to accrue. And in that case, the principal, even though doubled, continues to grow further.

It continues to grow also when transferred to another person; for instance, when the principal has become doubled and the creditor has need of the money and asks the debtor to pay, the latter takes him to a third party, and says^(тАШ)this man will make the payment for me in so many daysтАЩ; and in this case during these additional days, further interest shall accrue. The third party in this case is not a тАШsuretyтАЩ for payment, but only a тАШtrustee,тАЩ the man who actually does the payment. This is what has been explained by с╣Ъju to be the meaning of the debt being тАШtransferred to another person.тАЩ

Or. тАШtransference to another personтАЩ may refer to the following transaction:тАФEven before the principal has become actually doubled, if the pledge is banded over to another person,тАФwhen the money with accrued interest has become doubled, then it is only right and proper that the pledge should be redeemed; but in this case it is taken away before the principal has reached the limit,тАФthen, interest begins to accrue from that date, and the limit of тАШdoubleтАЩ shall be computed upon the total amount of the principal along with the interest accrued up to the date of the transference. That is, when the creditor, with the sanction of the debtor, hands over the latterтАЩs pledge to a third party and receives his due from him, then the interest continues to accrue.

In both these cases (of тАШtransference to another personтАЩ), before the doubling of the principal, the money-lender is, somehow or other, made to agree to receive payment from another person; or, тАШtransference to another personтАЩ may mean that case where the debtor takes a further loan from the creditor, but having to go away to foreign lands, transfers the loan by means of another document.

с╣Ъju however holds that, except in the case of the same debtor renewing the loan, no interest beyond the doubling of the principal can accrue. It is in accordance with this view that he has declaredтАФтАШIn the case of transference to another person, there should be renewal of the deed, and the need for this we shall explain.тАЩ

Some people have held the following view:тАФтАЬThe rule laid down in the present text refers to a case where the whole amount of interest accruing during the year is paid at one time [this being the meaning of the phrase тАШsakс╣Ыd─Бhiс╣н─Б ]; whereas if all the interest that has fallen due is not paid off wholly, then it will go on accruing, even beyond the limit of тАШdouble the principal.тАЩтАЭ

But in this explanation, neither the negative particle тАШnaтАЩ nor the term тАШ─БhitaтАЩ retains its real meaning. For if the interest accrued during the first year has been received, and at the end of the second year, the interest is again brought up for payment,тАФwhere would there be any chance of the principal becoming doubled?

тАЬThe prohibition of excess may apply to a case where the debtor brings up for payment the amount of the principal which has become doubled with accrued interest. Even before the principal becomes doubled, if the debtor is able to pay up the interest only, he can do so, and there can be no limit placed upon the principal to be accepted.тАЭ

This view also is nothing. When the debtor is ready to pay up, he deserves favourable consideration, and he should not be made to pay more; and if a debtor is forced by the king to pay up, it cannot be right to remit the excess in his case. Nor does the term тАШ─Бhit─БтАЩ of the text mean this.

If the word is read as тАШ─Бhс╣Ыt─Б,тАЩ then the exact signification of the term тАШsakс╣ЫtтАЩ would be doubtful; reason would be scattered to the wings, and the text would he a self-conceived one, and not the one propounded by Manu.

From all this it follows, that the most reasonable conclusion is as explained by us above.

In the case of grains and other things, it does not exceed the тАШquintupleтАЩтАФi.e., five times.

Another Smс╣Ыti text lays down тАШquadrupleтАЩ in the case of grains:тАФтАШIn the case of gold, cloth and grains, the interest is to be double, triple and quadruple respectivelyтАЩ (N─Бrada, 107). And the law on this point is as follows: If the moneylender has become reduced to poverty, and the debtor has become opulent with much wealth, having earned much wealth by means of the grain he had borrowed,тАФthen the interest is to be five times; and in other cases it is to be only four times.

тАШSadaтАЩтАФstands for the fruit of trees,тАФтАШgrainsтАЩ being mentioned separately.

тАШLavaтАЩтАФstands, among northerners, for wool.

тАШBeasts of burdenтАЩтАФass, camel, ox and so forth.тАФ(151)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШSmс╣ЫtyantareтАЩтАФ(Medh─Бtithi, p. 967, l. 30)тАФsee Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2. 39 )тАФтАШVastradh─Бnyahiraс╣Зy─Бn─Бm catustridviguс╣З─Б par─БтАЩ, and in N─Бrada (107)тАФтАШHiraс╣Зyadh─Бnyavastr─Бс╣З─Бm vс╣Ыddhirdvitricaturguс╣З─Б.тАЩ

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 2.39), which adds the following notes:тАФCapital invested for increase is called тАШkus─лdaтАЩ,тАФthe increase thereof is called тАШvс╣ЫddhiтАЩ;тАФand this never goes beyond, exceeds, the double,тАФif it is the first original investment; in the case of the investment being one that has been transferred from one person to another, it can exceed the double,тАФas it becomes, in tins case, a fresh transaction.тАФIf we adopt the reading тАШ─Бhс╣Ыt─БтАЩ (in place of тАШ─Бhit─БтАЩ), the meaning would he that the amount cannot exceed the double only in the case where the interest is paid all at one time, and that in a case where it is paid by gradual instalmentsтАФdaily, monthly or yearly,тАФit does exceed the double. It goes onтАФтАШThe rule applies to cases where the loan has been advanced in one instalment, and is also paid back in one instalment; in cases where the loan has been transferred to another person, or a fresh transaction is entered into by the same parties after certain additions and subtractions, the interest does go on accumulating even after the principal, along with the interest, has reached the amount which is double of the original principal.тАФOn the second half of the verse it remarks that in the case of grains and roots and flowers and fruits, the quantity payable may become five times of the principal. It explains тАШ┼ЫadaтАЩ as agricultural products, fruits, flowers etc.,тАФтАШlavaтАЩ as the wool of sheep, the hair of the camar─л cow find so forth,тАФтАШv─БhyaтАЩ as тАШbullocks, horses and the like.тАЩ Interest on these cannot go beyond five times the principal.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 643), which adds that the term тАШsakс╣ЫtтАЩ makes it clear that the amount can exceed the double, in a case where with the consent of the debtor the accrued interest is added on to the principal and a fresh transaction entered into. It adds that this applies only to transactions in gold.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 76), which adds that Vij├▒ane┼Ыvara and others have held that in a case where interest has been paid by instalments at intervals, the total amount of the amount to be paid ultimately may exceed the double.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 17), which adds the following explanatory notes:тАФтАШDh─БnyeтАЩ, barley, vr─лhi and the rest,тАФтАШsadeтАЩ, fruits and other products from trees,тАФтАШlaveтАЩ, wool of the sheep, hair of the Camar─л and so forth, the etymological meaning being тАШwhat is shornтАЩ, тАШl┼лyateтАЩ;тАФтАШv─БhyeтАЩ, тАШwhat is drivenтАЩ, the horse and so forth;тАФif any of these things is lent, on interest, like gold and silver,тАФthe amount to be paid should not exceed five times the principal. It is just possible that some one may borrow a hundredweight of grains, or a hundred horses, on loan at the rate of 2 per cent interest;тАФsuch a debtor, even after a very long time, can repay only five hundred, not more. The present text lays down тАШfive timesтАЩ as the limit in the case of grain; but Bс╣Ыhaspati has fixed this limit at тАШfour timesтАЩ; while тАШthree timesтАЩ is the limit fixed by Viс╣гс╣Зu, Mar─лci, Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha and H─Бr─лta. In view of these alternative limits, the decision in any particular case will have to be determined by the character of the debtor concerned, or the nature of the time, and consideration of scarcity or affluence.

This verse is quoted in Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, 18b);тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 326), which explains тАШsadaтАЩ as the produce of cultivation, other than, corn,тАФe.g., fruits and other things,тАФтАШv─БhyaтАЩ as тАШbullock and the restтАЩ,тАФand тАШlavaтАЩ as тАШwool and the like;тАФand in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 11), which says that at one transaction, in the case of gems and things of that kind also, the interest cannot go beyond the double;тАФthat in grains etc. it can go upto fivefold; but in repeated transactions it can go beyond the said тАШdoubleтАЩ; it notes the reading тАШsakс╣Ыd─Бhit─БтАЩ; it explains тАШv─БhyaтАЩ asтАШbullock and the likeтАЩ,тАФтАШ┼ЫadaтАЩ as тАШfield-prodceтАЩ,тАФтАШlavaтАЩ as тАШthat which is lopped offтАЩ, i.e., wool, except that of the sheep.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Gautama (12.31, 36).тАФтАШIf the loan remains outstanding for a long time, the principal may bo doubled; after which the interest ceases. The interest on animal-products, on wool, on agricultural produce, and on beasts of burden shall not increase more than the live-fold value of the object lent,тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (6.11-14, 16, 17).тАФтАШOn gold, the interest shall rise no higher than to make the debt double; on grain, three-fold; on cloth, fourfold; on liquids eight-fold; on substances from which spirituous liquor is extracted, on cotton, thread, leather, weapons, bricks, and charcoal, the interest is unlimited; on objects other than those just mentioned, it may be double.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.39).тАФтАШFor cattle and for women, the interest consists in the form of their offspring; in the case of clarified butter and other Rasas, the highest limit of interest is eight-fold; in that of cloth, fourfold; in that of grains, threefold; and in that of gold, double.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 643).тАФтАШThe money-lender shall receive double the amount lent.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.105-107).тАФтАШThere are special rules according to the local usages of the country where the loan has been made. In some countries the loan may grow till the amount of the principal has been reached; in other countries it may grow till it becomes three, or four, or eight times as large as the principal. The interest on gold, grain and clothes may rise to two, three, or four times the principal. On liquids, the interest may become octuple; of women and cattle, their offspring forms the interest.

Bс╣Ыhaspati (11.13-16).тАФтАШOn gold and other precious metals, the interest may make the debt double; on clothes and base metals, treble; on grain, it is allowed to rise to four times the original amount; and so on edible plants or fruits, beasts of burden and wool. It is allowed to make the debt quintuple on pot-herbs; sextuple, on seeds and sugarcane; and octuple, on salt, oil and spirituous liquor. Likewise on sugar and honey, if the loan he of old standing. On grass, wood, bricks, thread, substances from which spirits may he extracted, leaves, hones, leather, weapons, flowers and fruits, no interest is ordained.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.631).тАФтАШWhen the amount drawn from the debtor in the form of interest has reached twice the principal, then the King shall make the debtor pay only the principal and nothing more than that.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 17).тАФтАШFor gems, pearls, corals, for gold and silverтАФand for agricultural products and for insect-products (silk, etc.),тАФthe interest shall stop at double of the principal. For oils, wines, clarified butter, molasses and salt, it shall go up to eight-fold.тАЩ

151 In money transactions interest paid at one time (not by instalments) shall never exceed the double (of the principal); on grain, fruit, wool or hair, (and) beasts of burden it must not be more than five times (the original amount).

рдЕрдиреБрд╕рд░рдиреНрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреБрдзрд╛рд╡рдиреНрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреБрд╡рд░реНрддрдиреНрддреЗ рд╕рд░реНрд╡ рдПрд╡рд╛рд░реНрдерд╛ рдПрддрдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреБрд╕рд╛рд░рдГ ред рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░реЛрджрд┐рддрдГ рд╕рдорд╛рдЪрд╛рд░рдГ ред рд╕ рдЪ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд┐рдзреЛ рд╜рд╢реАрддрд┐рднрд╛рдЧрд╛рджрд┐рдГ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдХрд╢рддрдкрд░реНрдпрдиреНрддрдГ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рдГ рдХреГрддрд╛ рдпрд╛рд╡рддреН рддрдерд╛рдзрдорд░реНрдгреЗрдиреЛрддреНрддрдорд░реНрдгрд╕реНрдп рди рд╕рд┐рдзреНрдпрддрд┐ ред рдХреБрддрдГ, рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░рд┐рдХреНрддрд╛ рдпрддрдГ рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдмрд╛рд╣реНрдпреЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред

  • рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдореН рдЖрд╣ ред рдХреБрд╕реАрджрдкрдердореН рдЖрд╣реБрд╕реН рддрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдХреБрдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╛ рдпрддреНрд░ рд╕реАрджрдиреНрддрд┐ рдХреБрд╢реАрджрдореН ред рдзрд░реНрдореЗрдг рддрджреН рдзрдирд┐рдиреЛ рд▓рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдХреБрд╢реАрджреАрдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдпрдВ рдкрдиреНрдерд╛ рдорд╛рд░реНрдЧреЛ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЛ рди рд╕рд╛рдзреВрдирд╛рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рдирд┐рдиреНрджрд╛ ред рдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╡рд╢реНрдпрдореН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛ тАФ рдорд╣рджреН рдзрд┐ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдореН рдЕрдпрдВ рдорджреАрдпреЗрди рдзрдиреЗрди рд╕рд╛рдзрдпрддреАрддрд┐ рдмреБрджреНрдзреНрдпрд╛ тАФ рддрджрд╛ рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдореН рдЕрдирдкреЗрдХреНрд╖реНрдп326 рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдХрдВ рд╢рддрдВ рдЧреНрд░рд╣реАрддреБрдореН рдЕрд░реНрд╣рддрд┐ рд▓рд┐рдкреНрд╕реЗрддреН, рддрджрд░реНрдердореН327 рдЗрджрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред

рдкрд╛рдард╛рдиреНрддрд░рдореН “рдХреГрддрд╛ рддреБ рд╕рд╛рд░рд╛рджреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛”328 рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдХрд┐рдВрдЪрдирд╕реНрдп рд╕рддрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рд▓реНрдкрд╛ рдХреГрддрд╛, рддреЗрдиреИрд╡ рдзрдиреЗрдирд╛рдиреНрдпрдерд╛ рд╡рд╛ рдорд╣рд╛рд░реНрдерддрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд╕реН рддрд╕реНрдп рдпрд╛ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╕рд╛рд░рд╛рджреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛329 рди рд╕рд┐рдзреНрдпрддрд┐, рдпрдГ рдкрд░рдВ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдХрд╢рддрдореН рдЕрд░реНрд╣рддрд┐ рее рео.резрелреи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШAnus─БraтАЩ is that which is followed in all matters; i.e., the law laid down by the scriptures. The law in relation to interests is diverse: one lays down the rate as the eightieth part of the hundred, and another as five per cent, if the rate of interest is stipulated тАШin contravention ofтАЩтАФ in excess ofтАФthese sanctioned rates,тАФit is тАШnot payableтАЩтАФby the debtor to the creditor.тАФWhy?тАФBecause it is тАШexcessiveтАЩтАФi.e., against the law.

In support of this the text puts forward a commendatory declarationтАФтАШthis they declare to be the usurerтАЩs way.тАЩ The term тАШkus─лdaтАЩтАФmeans that which is followed by evil persons; and then the persons themselves. This тАШwayтАЩтАФpath, conductтАФis of evil persons, and not of good men. This is a deprecation of the act referred to.

If the lender is anxious to make as much money as possible out of the transaction, under the impression that the borrower is going to carry on extensive business with the help of the capital he is going to lend, then he may obtain five per cent., irrespectively of the caste of the borrower. What is meant is that this is all that he should seek to obtain.

Another reading is тАШkс╣Ыt─Б tu s─Бr─Бdadhik─БтАЩ; and the meaning of the text would in that case he thatтАФтАШif, at the outset, on account of the manтАЩs poverty, a low rate of interest is fixed, but subsequently, the man having acquired much wealth, if, on account of his opulenceтАФтАШs─Бr─БtтАЩтАФa large rate is demanded, this cannot he payable, since all that the man is entitled to is five per cent.тАФ(152)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse in quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 14), which adds the following explanations:тАФAny interest, over and above what has been prescribed in the scriptures,тАФsuch as

2 per cent and so forth,тАФcannot be permitted, even though agreed to by the debtor;тАФwhy?тАФbecause they declare this to be the тАШusurious wayтАЩ. If, under the stress of business, the creditor wishes to reap a large profit out of the debtor, then the utmost that he can recover is 5 per cent,тАФand not more, even though the debtor may have agreed to it;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (p. 68b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Bс╣Ыhaspati (11.9, 10-12).тАФтАШThat interest has always to be paid which has been stipulated by the debtor himself, over and above the ordinary rate of interest, and has been promised in times of distress; when such special interest has been stipulated in any other manner, it must not be paid by any means. The use of a pledge after twice the principal has been realised from it, compound interest, and the exaction of the principal and interest together (as principal) are usury and are reprehensible.тАЩ

рдХрд╛рдпрд┐рдХрд╛ рдХрд╛рдпрдХрд░реНрдордгрд╛ рд╕рдВрд╢реЛрдзреНрдпрд╛ ред рдХрд╛рдпрдЬреАрд╡рд┐рдХрд╛ рдЪ, рдПрд╖рд╛рдВ рдХреНрд░рдореЗрдг рдХреНрд░рдореЗрд▓рдХрд╛рджрд┐рдЬреАрд╡рд┐рдирд╛рдореН350 рее рео.резрелрей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШS─Бmvatsar─лтАЩтАФmeans тАШpertaining to the samvatsara,тАЩ тАШannualтАЩ; what is in excess of this тАШis atis─Бmvatsar─л,тАЩ тАШbeyond the annualтАЩ; the idea of pertinence being implied by the nominal affix. Or we may first form the compound тАШatisamvatsaraтАЩ in the sense of тАШbeyond the year,тАЩ and then have the vowel-changes, giving the form тАШatis─Бmvatsar─л.тАЩ

The interest that has been sanctioned in connection with all castes,тАФat the rate of 5 per cent, shall be realised for one year, and after the lapse of the year. Or, the meaning may be that no interest shall be realised during the year,тАФand after the year the debtor shall not delay the payment of interest.

тАШNirharet,тАЩ тАШshall pay,тАЩтАФi.e., taking out of his own stock, offer to the creditor; what is paid before the year has expired would also be тАШbeyond the annual.тАЩ

Or, the meaning may be that at the time of the transaction itself, it shall be determined whether the interest shall be computed monthly or yearly. It would not be right for a man desirous of earning interest for two years, to make the other party accept the loan for that long period the idea in his mind beingтАФтАШwhat would be the use of earning the interest for a few months only?тАФif the principal is allowed to remain with him for two years, then I shall earn a decent interest.тАЩ In such a case the man would so arrange the advance to the debtor that the interest would be paid after two years. That such a course would not be right is clearly indicated by such texts asтАФтАШone shall neither pay, nor cause another to pay, interest in such a single instalment as may be beyond the power of the man to pay.тАЩ In the case of interest payable monthly, the debtor is made to pay the interest on the second day after the lapse of the month; similarly when the stipulation is that the interest shall be paid yearly, it should be paid on the second day after the lapse of the year,тАФand not computed by any longer time.

Nor shall he receive what is тАШadс╣Ыс╣гс╣н─БтАЩ тАШunapprovedтАЩ;тАФi.e., a rate not sanctioned by the scriptures;тАФi.e., rates above 5 per cent., such as 10 per cent., or 11 per cent.

Some people hold that this is only a reiteration of what has been said (under 152) that тАШan excessive rate of interest is not payable.тАЩ

The right explanation of тАШadс╣Ыс╣гс╣н─БтАЩ therefore is тАШunaccumulatedтАЩ;тАФthe meaning being that interest shall not be received by the clay, or by the month, until it has accumulated during several months.

тАЬBut under 142 it has been declared that one may take тАШmonthly interest.тАЩтАЭ

What is meant by that is that the interest shall he computed by the month, and not that it shall be received month by month.

тАШCompound interestтАЩ:тАФthe various kinds of interest from here down to the тАШcorporeal,тАЩ should be construed with тАШhe shall not pay.тАЩ Though the prohibition is literally addressed to the debtor, yet it is really meant to be addressed to the creditor; for the debtor, being in distress,тАФwhat is there that he may not do?

Or, what is directly meant by тАШnirharetтАЩ is receiving itself; so that the prohibition would he addressed literally to the creditor directly.

тАЬIn as much as the rates of interest have been fixed at 2, 3, 4 or 5 per cent, there is no possibility of тАШcompound interestтАЩ being paid or received: what then is the need of the present prohibition?тАЭ

Our answer is as follows:тАФThis prohibition itself is indicative of the fact that it is open to the creditor to charge such interest also. Just as the prohibition that тАШthe Br─Бhmaс╣Зa shall not sing S─Бman during Fire-layingтАЩ is indicative of the fact that though no such Sama-singing is actually prescribed in connection with Fire-laying, yet it is open to the priest to do it. Thus the possibility of the various kinds of interest here mentioned being charged is indicated by this prohibition itself. For instance, in the case of men carrying on inferior kinds of business, the тАШcompoundтАЩ and other interests are actually paid; it is thus that in connection with traders on land and water, etc., varying rates of interest have been prescribed: тАШThose trading in forests should pay ten per cent., those on the sea twenty per cent.; or among all castes people may pay any interest that has been stipulated among themselvesтАЩ (Y─Бj├▒avalkya, Vyavah─Бra, 38). тАШInterest stipulated among themselvesтАЩ has thus been sanctioned by this other Smс╣Ыti-text among all castes, in relation to only those that trade in the forest, etc.; so that тАШcompound interestтАЩ is not permissible in other eases.

Interest charged on interest is called тАШcompound interest,тАЩ тАШcakravс╣Ыddhi.тАЩ Others however explain the term тАШcakravс╣ЫddhiтАЩ as тАШwheel-interestтАЩ; that in the case of wheeled conveyances, like the cart, etc., interest is paid only for those days on which they are used; and on days when the man has to go by boat, in the crossing of large rivers, no interest is paid. In the case of oxen and other things that are used as conveyances, interest is paid in this same manner and it is this that is called тАШwheel-interest.тАЩ

тАШPeriodical interestтАЩ;тАФтАЬInterest computed month by month is called тАШperiodicalтАЩтАЭтАФsays a text. But тАШmonthтАЩ is mentioned only by way of illustration; what is meant is that interest which is not allowed to accumulate, being realised day by day, or month by month, and no time is allowed. Another kind of тАШperiodical interestтАЩ is that in which the creditor has stipulatedтАФтАШif you do not pay the interest at such and such a time, my principal shall become doubled.тАЩ

тАШPrivately stipulatedтАЩ;тАФwhen the creditor and the debtor tlx upon a special rate of interest, in view of each otherтАЩs requirements. This also is possible only in the case of distant traders. As for others, it has been declaredтАФтАШsuccessive interest is not payableтАЩ and тАШhe is entitled to only 5 per cent.тАЩ

Or, when what is lent is gold, and what is received in interest is clothтАФwhose real character is that of a deposit,тАФit is a case of тАШprivately stipulatedтАЩ interest; and this would have the character of usufruct, in the case of what has not been kept as a pledge.

тАШCorporealтАЩтАФpayable by bodily labour. This would be possible only in the case of labourers…… (?)тАФ(153)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШA creditor may take, for the term of a year, interest which has been settled by the following agreementтАФтАЬwhen one, two or three months have passed, the interest on the capital shall be calculated and paid to me at one timeтАЭ; but he shall not take the interest according to the agreement, if the year has passedтАЩ (Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШIf the creditor does not take the money due for two or three years, and the debtor pays then, the creditor shall not take more interest than for one yearтАЩ (Govindar─Бja).

тАШAdrс╣гс╣нamтАЩтАФтАШNot found (in the ┼Ъ─Бstras)тАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШnot accumulated by the lapse of several monthsтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, alternatively and N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

тАШK─Бlavс╣Ыddhiс╕етАЩтАФтАШPeriodical (i.e., monthly) interestтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, Govindar─Бja, N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Kull┼лka, who is not rightly represented by Buhler).тАФSee N─Бrada тАФтАШPratim─Бsam bhavant─л y─Б vс╣Ыddhiс╕е s─Б k─Бlik─Б sс╣Ыmt─Б (smс╣Ыta?)тАЩ (тАШk─Бlik─БтАЩ being the technical name for monthly interest, k─Бlavс╣Ыddhiс╕е).

тАШK─Бyik─БтАЩтАФтАШTo be paid by bodily labourтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi),тАФor тАШby the use of a pledged animal or slaveтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, alternative, Kull┼лka, R─Бghav─Бnanda and Nandana).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 9), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШAtis─Бс╣Гvatsar─лтАЩ is that which has gone beyond a year. The meaning is that if the creditor, suspecting an early repayment of the loan, should stipulate that the loan must continue for a certain time, then he cannot stipulate for more than a year. Hal─Бyudha, however holds the meaning to be that however much be the eagerness of the creditor to earn much interest, he should receive payment before one year passes, and not beyond that.тАФNor should he receive an interest that is тАШadс╣Ыс╣гt─Б,тАЩ тАШnot permitted by the scriptures.тАЩтАФThere are four kinds of interest not permitted,тАФcakravс╣Ыddhi, k─Бlavс╣Ыddhi, k─Бrit─Б and k─Бyik─Б; these he should not take.

It is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 229);тАФin V─лdhanap─Бrij─Бta (II, p. 252);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (─Аhnika, 36a);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (67b), which adds the explanation.тАФтАШThe interest is to be calculated from the first month upto the end of the year, and not beyond that.тАЩ

Gautama (12.30, 34-35).тАФтАШSome declare that the said rates of interest should not be paid longer than a year. The following are the special forms of interest:тАФCompound interest, Periodical interest, Stipulated interest, Corporal interest, Daily interest and interest in the shape of using the pledge.тАЩ

N─Бrada (l.102-104)тАФтАШInterest has been declared in lawbooks to be of four kinds:тАФPeriodical, Stipulated, K─Бyik─Б, and Compound. That which runs by the month is Periodical interest; that promised by the debtor himself is Stipulated interest; interest at the rate of one Paс╣Зa and a quarter, paid regularly without diminishing the principal, is denoted K─Бyik─Б interest; interest upon interest is called Compound interest.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (11.4-12).тАФтАШInterest has been declared by some to be of four kinds; by others, of five kinds; and by others again, of six kinds. K─Бyik─Б, K─Бlik─Б, Cakravс╣Ыddhi, K─Бrit─Б, ┼Ъikh─Бvс╣Ыddhi, and Bhogal─Бbha. K─Бyik─Б interest is in the form of bodily labour; K─Бlik─Б is what is due every month; Cakravс╣Ыddhi is interest on interest; K─Бrit─Б is interest promised by the debtor; when interest is received every day, it is called ┼Ъikh─Бvс╣Ыddhi; because it grows constantly like hair, except on the loss of the head, that is, the payment of the principal. The use of a mortgaged house, or the produce of a field, is termed Bhogal─Бbha. Sikh─Б interest, K─Бyik─Б interest and Bhogal─Бbha interest shall be realised by the creditor so long as the principal remains unpaid. But the use of a pledge after twice the principal has been realised, compound interest, and the exaction of the interest and the principal together are usury and are reprehensible.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.638).тАФтАШCreditors take away peopleтАЩs wealth by the compound rate of interest; so the King should protect the people from them.тАЩ

153 Let him not take interest beyond the year, nor such as is unapproved, nor compound interest, periodical interest, stipulated interest, and corporal interest.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

He who, unable to repay the debt, wishes to renew the contract, shall change the bond, after paying the accrued interest.тАФ(154)

If by lapse of time the debtor becomes bereft of the capacity to pay, he should be made to pay the debt according to hit capacity, taking into consideration the time and place and the rate of interest.

рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрдзрдорд░реНрдгреЛ рджреИрд╡рджреЛрд╖рд╛рдиреН рдирд┐рд░реНрдзрдиреАрднреВрддрд╕реН рддрджрд╛ рди рджреБрд░реНрдЧрд╛рд╡рд░реЛрдзрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрд╛ рдкреАрдбрдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рдпрджрд╛рд╕реНрдп рдХрдердВрдЪрд┐рджреН рдзрдирдВ рднрд╡реЗрддреН рддрджрд╛ рдпрдерд╛рд╕рдВрднрд╡рдВ рд╢рдиреИрдГ рд╢рдиреИрд░реН рджрд╛рдкрдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред “рдкреНрд░реЗрдХреНрд╖реНрдп рд╢рдХреНрддрд┐рдореН” рдзрдирд╡рддреНрддрд╛рдВ356 рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рддреНрд╡реЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рджрд╛рдкреНрдпреНрдГ рдЙрдЪрд┐рддрд╕реНрдп ред рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддрд┐ “рдХрд░реНрдордгрд╛рдкрд┐ рд╕рдордВ рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рддреН” (рдореНрдзреН рео.резренрен) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рддреН рдХрд╛рд░рдгрдкрд░рд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреМ357 рдпрджреН рдПрд╡реЛрдХреНрддрдореН рдЕрд╕реНрдорд╛рднрд┐рд╕реН рддрджреН рдПрд╡ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирдореН рее рео.резрелрек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If a man, having his wealth reduced, is unable to pay the doubled principal, he should be made to renew the contract, and to тАШchange the deedтАЩтАФi.e., the document properly attested. But he should pay the interest that has already accrued.

This is an exception to what has been said as to the creditor not receiving more than double of bis principal;тАФsince the loan-transaction remains in force.

тАЬHow does it follow that there is an exception to the non-exceeding of the double?тАЭ

Because in this case there is nothing to show whether further interest accrues upon the principal along with the accrued interest, or upon the principal only; all that is mentioned is the тАШrenewal of the contract,тАЩ which is explained in other wordsтАФтАШhe shall change the bond.тАЩ

тАЬIf further interest does not accrue on past interest, for what purpose should the bond be altered?тАЭ

The answer is as follows:тАФWhen interest has ceased to accrue, and the money is not paid, there is every possibility of laxity (on the part of the debtor), and of the witnesses (of the old document), forgetting all about the transaction; and a debt thus ignored for ten years would become non-payable; as has been declared in the following text.тАФтАШWhere a document is ignored for ten years, there can be no suit on its basis; especially in the case of assaults (?).тАЩ

This is how it has been explained by older writers.

The following verse (from N─Бrada, 131) lays down the favour that the king may show towards the debtor:

If by lapse of time the debtor becomes bereft of the capacity to pay, he should be made to pay the debt according to hit capacity, taking into consideration the time and place and the rate of interest.

[The meaning of this is as follows]тАФ

If, through evil fate, the debtor becomes reduced to poverty, he shall not he chastised with imprisonment in the jail and soforth. тАЬWhat is there to be done?тАЭ Whenever he should happen to have any property at all, he should be made to repay the debt by small instalments;тАФthis is what is meant by the phrase тАШaccording to his capacity.тАЩ This is what is going to be described asтАФтАШthe debt should he liquidated even by bodily labour, etc., etc.тАЩ (8.177.)

In view of this text, the use of altering the bond is just as we have explained above.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

Karaс╣ЗaтАЩтАФтАШWritten bondтАЩ (Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШwritten bond and witnessesтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi).

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 193), which adds the following explanation:тАФтАШWhen the time for repayment arrives, if the debtor, find himself unable to pay the whole amount dueтАФthe principal along with accrued interest,тАФand the creditor is unwilling to keep the loan hanging,тАФand should wish to renew the transaction on the same terms, he should pay the accrued interest and renew the bond, dated afresh with the new date.тАЩ

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 72), as laying down one of the methods of тАШcompound interest.тАЩ It adds the following notes:тАФтАШNirjit─Бm,тАЩ legally due to the creditor; of this accrued interest he should pay either the whole, or a part only, and add the remainder to the principal and renew the bond for the total;тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, 19b);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (80a), which explains тАШnirjit─БmтАЩ as тАШdetermined to have already accrued to the creditor,тАЩтАФand тАШkaraс╣З am parivartayetтАЩ as тАШshould write another document attested by fresh witnessesтАЩ;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 104a).

At the end of Adhy─Бya VIII, Mandlik has printed the following verse with Medh─БtithiтАЩs explanation thereuponтАФ

atha ┼Ыaktivih─лnaс╕е sy─Бd с╣Ыс╣З─л k─Бlaviparyay─Бt |
┼Ыakyaprekс╣гam с╣Ыс╣Зaс╣Г d─Бpyaс╕е k─Бle de┼Ыe yathodayam ||

This verse, though commented upon by Medh─Бtithi, has been omitted by all other commentators.

It is found in N─Бrada (131.) It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 71) as from N─Бrada; it explains тАШ┼Ъaktivih─лnaс╕етАЩ as тАШwithout ability to repay the debt,тАЩ and тАШk─Бlaviparyay─БtтАЩ as тАШon account of famine and so forth.тАЩ

The verse is not ManuтАЩs, it is N─БradaтАЩs; and it has been only quoted by Medh─Бtithi and explained by him in course of his comment on verse 159.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 8.154-155)
**

N─Бrada (1.131, 134).тАФтАШWhen a debtor has been disabled by a reverse of fortune (from paying the debt), he shall be made to discharge the debt gradually, according to bis means, as he happens to gain wealth. If the debtor, owing to a calamity, has not means sufficient to discharge the whole debt, the claim of the creditor shall be entered in a legal document, specifying the caste (of the parties), their names and names of their neighbours.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (11.47, 60).тАФтАШA loan shall be restored on demand, if no time has been fixed; or on the expiry of the time, if time has been fixed; or when interest ceases. When the time fixed for payment has elapsed, and the interest has ceased, the creditor may either recover his loan or cause a new bond to be written in the form of compound interest.тАЩ

Bh─Бradv─Бja (Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava-Vyava., p. 193).тАФтАШIf the debtor has no money to repay the debt, he shall liquidate it by giving grains, gold, or cattle, or clothes, slaves or conveyances.тАЩ

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЕрджрд░реНрд╢рдпрд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛ рд╣рд┐рд░рдгреНрдпрдореН, рдЕрджрддреНрд╡рд╛ рдирд┐рд░реНрдзрдирддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рд╣рд┐рд░рдгреНрдпрдореН,358 рддрддреНрд░реИрд╡ рдкреБрдирдГ рдХрд░рдгрдВ рдкрд░рд┐рд╡рд░реНрддрдпреЗрддреН ред рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рд╕рдордХреНрд╖рдореН рдПрд╡рдВ рдмреНрд░реВрдпрд╛рддреН “рдПрддрд╛рд╡рдиреН рдореБрд▓рдореН рдЕрд╕реНрдореИ рдзрд╛рд░рдпрд╛рдорд┐, рдПрддрд╛рд╡рддреА рдЪ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдкрддреНрд░реЗ рдЪрд╛рд░реЛрдкрдпреЗрддреН359 ред рдпрд╛рд╡рддреА рд╕рдВрднрд╡реЗрджреН рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рд░реН360 рдЗрддрд┐ рддрд╛рд╡рджреН рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЪрдХреНрд╖рддреЗ ред рдкреБрдирдГ рдХрд░рдгреЗ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рд╕рд╣рд┐рддрдореВрд▓реАрднреВрддреЗ рд▓рдШреАрдпрд╕реА рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рдГ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛, рдпрд╛рд╡рддреНрдпрд╛ рд╡реГрджреНрдзреНрдпрд╛ рдирд╛рддрд┐рдкреАрдбреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЧреН рдЖрд╕реАрддреН рддрддреЛ рдиреНрдпреВрдиреЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред

рдпрдЬреНрд╡рд╛рд╕рд╣рд╛рдпрдирд╛рд░рджрд╛рдирд╛рдВ361 рддреБ рдорддреЗ рдХрд╛рдХрд┐рдгреАрдорд╛рддреНрд░рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╢рдХреНрддрдГ рдХрд░рдгрдкрд░рд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рдХрд╛рд▓реЗ рджрд╛рдкрдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рдпреЗрди рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрдГ рди рд╢реНрд░рд╡рдгрдорд╛рддреНрд░реЗ362 рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рддреНрд╡рдореН, рджрджрд╛рддрд┐363 рддрддреНрд╕рдордХреНрд╖рдореН рдЕрдзрдорд░реНрдгреЛ рд╜рд░реНрдерд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдХреНрд╖реАрднрд╡рддрд┐364 ред рдпрддрдГ рд╢реНрд░рд╡рдгрд╛рддреН рд╕реНрд░рд╡рдгреЗ365 рдЪ рдХреГрддрд╛ рднрд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдпрдиреНрддрд┐, рддрд╛рддрд╢реН рдЪрд┐рддреНрддреЗ366 рддрд┐рд╖реНрдарддрд┐ рдзрдирдВ367 рджрд╢рд╡рд░реНрд╖реЛрдкреЗрдХреНрд╖рд┐рддрдореН рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдирд╢реНрд╡рд░рдВ рднрд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдпрддрд┐ рее рео.резрелрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШNot having brought forwardтАЩтАФpaid upтАФтАШthe gold,тАЩтАФi.e., the amount of gold due as interest,тАФтАШhe should renew the bondтАЩ;тАФi.e., in the presence of witnesses he should make the declarationтАФтАШI owe this man so much principal and so much interest,тАЩтАФand should put this down in writing also; entering the amount of interest for one year;тАФso explain some people.

And in the new bond, when the principal along with accrued interest has been entered as the principal, the rate of interest stipulated should he very low; just such as may not become too much of a burden for the man; that is, it should be lower than the former rate.

Yajvan, Asah─Бya and N─Бrada hold that at the time of the renewal of the bond the debtor should be made to pay even a shell, if he is able to do so; so that the witnesses may not be witnesses to a mere verbal statement, but to the actual payment of even a small amount as interest; so that they actually see the money-transaction; and when they come to be examined,тАФwhich may be any time during ten years,тАФthey may have their mind firm, on account of being able to recall what they had heard and also actually seen with their eyes.тАФ(155)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 73), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШadar┼Ыayitv─Б hiraс╣ЗyamтАЩ, not bringing up the gold for payment,тАФnot even a single pice,тАФand hence not paying even the interest, he should add the accrued interest to the original principal, and making this total the new principal, he should enter it in the new bond that he should write. Though the entire interest is actually due to be paid at the time, yet, if he is unable to pay the whole, he may pay just that much of it which he may be able to pay;тАФthis is what is meant by the clause тАШy─Бvat─л sambhavet etc.тАЩ

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 194), which adds the following explanation:тАФтАШHiraс╣Зyam adar┼Ыayitv─БтАЩ,тАФnot having paid the interest that has been earned,тАФhe should have it included in that same bond;тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (80a), which explains тАШhiraс╣Зyam adar┼Ыayitv─БтАЩ as тАШnot paying any part of the accrued interest to the Creditor,тАЩ the meaning is that he should pay as much of the accrued interest as hew can, and then make out a fresh document;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 104a).

**

“рд╡рд╛рд░рд╛рдгрд╕реАрдВ рдпрд╛рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдорд┐ рддреНрд╡рджреАрдпрд╛ рдпреБрдЧреНрдпрд╛368 рдореЗ рднрд╛рдгреНрдбрдВ рдЪ рдиреЗрддреБрд░реН369 рдПрд╖рд╛ рдЪ рддреЗ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрддреНрд░ рдпрджрд┐ рдХрд╛рдиреНрддрд╛рд░рдирджреАрд╕рдВрддрд░рдгрд░рд╛рд╖реНрдЯреНрд░реЛрдкрдкреНрд▓рд╡рд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛370 рддрдВ рджреЗрд╢рдВ рди рдЧрддрд╕реН рддрддреЛ рд╜рд░реНрд╡рд╛рдЧреН рджреЗрд╢рд╛рддреН рдХрд┐рдпрддрд╛ рд▓рд╛рднреЗрди рдкреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рд╡реГрддреНрддрд╕реН рддрджрд╛ рдпрдерд╛рдирд┐рд░реВрдкрд┐рддрд╛ рд╡реГрджреНрджрд┐рд╣рд┐рд░реН рди рджрд╛рдкреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрддрд╕реН рддрдВ рджреЗрд╢рдВ рдпрд╛рд╡рджреН рд╡рд╣рддрд╛рдВ рдпрд╛ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рд░реН рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ371 рд╕рд╛ рдХрдердВ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рджреАрд░реНрдШрдореН рдЕрдзреНрд╡рд╛рдирдВ рд╡рд╣рддрд╛рдВ рдпреБрдЧреНрдпрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдорд╣рд╛рдиреН рдХреНрд▓реЗрд╢рдГ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдирд╢реН рдЪ рддрд╛рд╡рдиреНрддрдВ рдХрд╛рд▓рдВ рдХреГрддреИрд╡ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рд░реН рдпреБрдЧреНрдпреЛрдкрдХрд╛рд░рдГ ред рд╢реАрдШреНрд░рдВ рддреБ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдирдГ рдкреБрдирд░реН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд░реЛрдкрдХрд╛рд░рдгрдВ рд╕рдВрдкрджреНрдпрдд рдПрд╡ ред рдПрд╖ рдПрд╡рд╛рддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдордГ ред

  • рдПрд╡рдВ рдХрд╛рд▓рд╛рддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдордГ- “рдорд╛рд╕рдореН рдореЗ рд╡рд╣рдиреНрддреБ372 рдмрд▓реАрд╡рд░реНрджрд╛ рдЗрдпрддреА рддрд╡ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрддреНрд░ рдпрджрд┐ рдкрдХреНрд╖рд╛рддреН рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпреЗрддрд┐, рддрддреНрд░ рдЪрдХреНрд░рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рдореН рдЕрдзрдорд░реНрдгрдГ рд╕рдорд╛рд░реВрдврдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрдиреНрдиреЛ рд╜рдЩреНрдЧреАрдХреГрддрд╡рд╛рдиреН рдЗрддрд┐ рдпрд╛рд╡рддреН ред рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдВ рд╡реГрджреНрдзреМ рджреЗрд╢рдХрд╛рд▓реМ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдерд┐рддреМ рдпрддреН рддрдпрд╛ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЛрдХреНрддреЗрди рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд░реЗрдг рджреЗрд╢рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдВ рдХрд╛рд▓рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдВ рд╡рд╛ рдЖрд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд╡рд╛рдиреН,373 рди рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгрдореН рдПрд╡ рдХреГрддрд╡рд╛рдиреН, рд╕ рдПрд╡рдВрд╡рд┐рдзреЛ рд╜рдзрдорд░реНрдгрд╕реН рддреМ рджреЗрд╢рдХрд╛рд▓реМ рдЕрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдордиреН374 рди рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрдиреБрдпрд╛рддреН рддрддреНрдлрд▓рдВ рд╡реГрджреНрдзреНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрдВ рдирд╛рдкреНрдиреБрдпрд╛рдиреН рди рднрдЬреЗрдд рди рджрджреНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ рее рео.резрелрем рее

рдХрд┐рдВ рддрддреНрд░ рдиреИрд╡рд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рд░реН рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдХрдВ рд╢рддрдореН ред рдиреЗрддреНрдпреН рдЖрд╣ ред

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШI am going to Benares,тАФmy purpose being the acquiring of merit as well as trading in vessels; and such and such an amount shall be the interest paid upon the wheeled conveyance you supplyтАЩ;тАФthis contract having been entered into, if the man does not actually proceed to Benares, being forced back with only a little profit, by difficulties in the form of forests, river-crossings and anarchism,тАФthen he should not be made to pay the entire amount of interest stipulated; for how can the reward that would be due to those who have gone to Benares be due to those who never went to that place? When the oxen go a long distance, it involves much labour on their part; so that it is right that the reward of their owner should he commensurate with that labour; but when they have returned sooner than stipulated, it is open to the owner to make further profit on them by hiring them out afresh.

This is what is meant by тАШfailureтАЩ in the text.

Similarly as regards time also, the contract beingтАФтАШThese oxen may work for me for a month, and your interest shall be so much,тАЩтАФif the man returns the bullocks in a fortnight (the man does not have to pay the full reward).

In both these cases, the debtor has тАШentered into the wheel-ccntractтАЩтАФi.e., accepted its termsтАФand in this contract a special place or time has been stipulated,тАФif then, on account of reasons described above, he has not kept up to the stipulated place or time, and has thus тАШfailedтАЩ in regard to them,тАФтАШhe shall not sufferтАЩтАФhave to payтАФтАШthe reward,тАЩ in the form of the stipulated interest.тАФ(156)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШCakarvс╣ЫddhiтАЩ;тАФтАШInterest on wheeled carriageтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, Govindar─Бja, Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШcompound interestтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa as also тАШothersтАЩ in Medh─Бtithi on verse 157).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 73), which gives a totally different explanation:тАФтАШDe┼Ыak─Бlavyavosthitaс╕е cakravс╣Ыddhim sam─Бr┼лс╕Нhaс╕етАЩ means тАШhaving entered into an agreement regarding cakravс╣ЫddhiтАЩ to the effect that тАЬat such and such a place and time I shall take d├╢uble this amount,тАЭтАФif the creditor asks for repayment of his dues with compound interest, before the stipulated time, or at a place other than the stipulated one, then he shall not receive his dues with compound interest;тАЩтАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (80a), which explains тАШsam─Бr┼лс╕НhaтАЩ as тАШstipulated, agreed upon,тАЩ and тАШtatphalamтАЩ as the effect of the cakravс╣Ыddhi;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 104a).

Artha┼Ы─Бstra (p. 64).тАФтАШFor 100 Paс╣Зas, the proper interest is ┬╝ Paс╣Зa; 5 Paс╣Зas for traders; 10 Paс╣Зas for dealers in forests; 20 Paс╣Зas for dealers on the seas.тАЩ

156 He who has made a contract to carry goods by a wheeled carriage for money and has agreed to a certain place or time, shall not reap that reward, if he does not keep to the place and the time (stipulated).

рд╕рдореБрджреНрд░рдпрд╛рдирдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рдпрд╛рддреНрд░реЛрдкрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред рд╕реНрдерд▓рдкрдерд┐рдХрд╛375 рд╡рд╛рд░рд┐рдкрдерд┐рдХрд╛рд╢реН рдЪ рд╡рдгрд┐рдЬреЛ рдпрд╛рдВ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рдВ рд╕реНрдерд╛рдкрдпрдиреНрддрд┐ рд╕рд╛ рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдзрд┐рдЧрдордирдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐ рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрдпрдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐ ред рд╕реИрд╡ рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪреЗрддрд╡реНрдпреЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рджреЗрд╢рдХрд╛рд▓рд╛рд░реНрдерджрд░реНрд╢рд┐рдиреЛ рд╜рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдкреНрд░рджреЗрд╢ рдЗрдпрд╛рдиреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд▓рд╛рднреЛ рд╜рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдЗрдпрд╛рдиреН рдЗрддрд┐ рдпреЗ рдкрд╢реНрдпрдиреНрддрд┐ рдЬрд╛рдирддреЗ, рди рддреБ рд╕рдореБрджреНрд░рдпрд╛рди рдПрд╡ рдЪ рдпреЗ рдХреБрд╢рд▓рд╛рдГ рдХрд░реНрдгрдзрд╛рд░рд╛рджрдпрдГ ред

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдореН рдПрд╡рдВ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЪрдХреНрд╖рддреЗ рдпрджреГрдЪреНрдЫрд╛рдзреНрдпрд╛рд╣рд╛рд░реЗрдг ред рдЕрдзрдорд░реНрдгреЗрди рдпрд╛ рджреЗрд╢рдХрд╛рд▓рдВ рдЪрд╛рд╢реНрд░рд┐рддрд╛ рддрд╛рдВ рдЪ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрдп рддрджреНрджреЗрд╢реЛрджрд┐рддрдВ рдлрд▓рдВ рд▓рд╛рднрд╛рдЦреНрдпрдВ рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН376 рджреЗрд╢рд╛рджреН рдпрджрд┐ рдирд╛рдкреНрдиреБрдпрд╛рддреН, рддрджрд╛ рдХреАрджреГрд╢реА рддрддреНрд░ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рд░реН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЖрдХрд╛рдЩреНрдХреНрд╖рд╛рдпрд╛рдореН рдЙрддреНрддрд░рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдГ ред рдЪрдХреНрд░рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рдХрд╛рд░рд┐рддрд╛рдпрд╛ рдЕрдкрд┐ рдкреНрд░рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред

рд▓реЛрднрд╛рддрд┐рд╢рдпрднрд╛рдЬрд╛рдВ рд╡рдгрд┐рдЬрд╛рдВ рдХреНрд╖рдпрд╡реНрдпрдпрд╛рдпрд╕рдВрд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдГ377 рдкрд░рд╕реНрдкрд░рд╕реНрдп рдпрд╛рдВ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рдВ рд╕реНрдерд╛рдкрдпреЗрдпреБрд╕реН рддрд╛рдВ рд░рд╛рдЬрд╛ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгреАрдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдзрд┐рдЧрдордВ рдкреНрд░рддреАрддрд┐ ред рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдГ рдХрд░реНрдордкреНрд░рд╡рдЪрдиреАрдпреЛ рд╜рдзрд┐рдЧрдорд╕реНрдп рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН “рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгреЗрддреНрдердВрднреВрддрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рдиреЗ” (рдкрд╛рдгреН рез.рек.репреж) рддрджреНрдпреБрдХреНрддреЗ рдЪ рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпрд╛ рее рео.резрелрен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The present verso is an answer to the questionтАФтАЬIn the case cited above, is there to be paid no interest at all? Or is it to be 5 per cent?тАЭ

тАШSea-voyageтАЩ has been mentioned only by way of illustration; the sense is that whatever interest is fixed by traders who know all about journey by land and water, should be determined as the exact amount to be paid.

тАШThose capable of calculating the profits in connection with a particular place and time,тАЩтАФpersons who know what amount of profit is to be made whore,тАФand not only those, pilots and others, who are expert in sea-voyages.

Others have explained the foregoing verses in the following manner, making gratuitous additions to its words:тАФThe last verse (157) is in answer to the question.тАФтАЬIn a case where the debtor has entered into a contract on the strength of profits to be made at a particular place or time,тАФbut on reaching that place, he does not make the profit that he had expected,тАФthen what amount of interest should he pay?тАЭ And the mention of the term тАШcakravс╣ЫddhiтАЩ (which, in this interpretation would not mean тАШwheel-interest,тАЩ but тАШcompound interest,тАЩ which the debtor agrees to pay, on expectation of large profits) would include the тАШprivately stipulatedтАЩ interest also. In such a case, the king shall decide as due that amount of interest which may be fixed by those tradesmen who know each otherтАЩs circumstances and the chances of profit and loss.

тАШAs regards the exact amount to be paid,тАЩ тАШadhigamam prati,тАЩтАФтАШPratiтАЩ is a proposition denoting тАШindication,тАЩ and as such governs the Accusative in тАШadhigamam,тАЩ according to P─Бс╣Зini 1.4.90.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 11), which adds that the term тАШSamudray─Бnaku┼Ыal─Бс╕етАЩ stands for all merchants;тАФтАШde┼Ыak─Бl─Бrthadar┼Ыinaс╕е,тАЩ those who know that in such and such a country such and such profit is to be made;тАФтАШadhigamaтАЩ is тАШdecisionтАЩ i.e., тАШby that is the interest to be determined;тАЩтАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (68a), which has the following notes:тАФтАШSamudray─Бnaku┼Ыal─Бс╕етАЩ stands for tradesmen in general,тАФтАШde┼Ыak─Бl─Бrthadar┼Ыinaс╕е,тАЩ one who knows what profit is obtained at what time,тАФтАШadhigamaтАЩ is decision, finding.

**(verses 8.156-157)
**

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЛрдгрдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЧреЗ рджреНрд╡рд┐рд╡рд┐рдзреЛ378 рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд░рдореНрднрдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднреВрд░реН рдЖрдзрд┐рд░реН рд╡рд╛ ред рддрддреНрд░ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднреВрдкрдХреНрд╖ рдЗрджрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддреНрд░рд┐рд╡рд┐рдзрд╢реН рдЪ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднреВрдГ рджрд░реНрд╢рдиреЗ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдпреЗ рджрд╛рдиреЗ рдЪ ред рддрддреНрд░ рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднреБрд╡рдореН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХреГрддреНрдпреЗрджрдореН рдЖрд╣ ред рдпрд╕реНрдп рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рдп рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднреВрд╕реН рддрд┐рд╖реНрдареЗрджреН рдЕрдореБрд╖реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдкреНрд░рджреЗрд╢реЗ рдордпреИрд╖ рддрд╡ рджрд░реНрд╢рдиреАрдпрдГ, рд╕ рддрдерд╛ рдХреБрд░реНрд╡рдиреН рд╕реНрд╡рдзрд╛рдирд╛рддреН рддрд╕реНрдп рдЛрдгрдВ рдпрддреЗрдд рдкреНрд░рдпрддреНрдирдВ рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рджреН рджрд╛рддреБрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╢реЗрд╖рдГ ред рджрджреНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЗрддрд┐ рдпрд╛рд╡рддреН ред рдЛрдгрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рд╡рд╕реНрддреБрдорд╛рддреНрд░реЛрдкрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред рддреЗрди рдпрд╛рд╡рдиреНрддреЛ рд╜рд░реНрдерд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрд╛ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЗ рд╜рдиреБрдХреНрд░рд╛рдореНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ,379 рддрджреН380 рд╡рд╕реНрддреБ рджрджреНрдпрд╛рджреН рджрд░реНрд╢рдиреЗрдирд╛рдиреНрдпрддрд░реЗрдгрд╛рднрд┐рдпреБрдХреНрддрдГ ред рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдкрд╛рд░реБрд╖реНрдпрд╕рдВрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╛рджреМ рдкрдгрдкрд░рд┐рднрд╛рд╖рд╛ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛ ред рдпрджрд┐ рди рджрд░реНрд╢рд┐рддрдВ рдЪреЗрддреН рддрдиреНрдордпрд╛381 рджрд╛рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рдЕрдХреГрддрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рддреБ рдкрд░рд┐рднрд╛рд╖рд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рд░рд╛рдЬрджрдгреНрдбрдореН рдПрд╡ рджрд╛рдкреНрдпрдГ ред рд╢рд░реАрд░реЗ рддреБ рдирд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣реЗ рддрдиреНрдирд┐рд╖реНрдХреНрд░рдпрдгрдВ382 рд╕реБрд╡рд░реНрдгрдореН рее рео.резрелрео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In the case of Loan-transactions there are two kinds of securityтАФa Surety and a Pledge. The present verse deals with the case where the security is in the form of a surety.

There are three kinds of SuretyтАФ(1) for appearance, (2) for guarantee and (3) for payment. The present text refers to the surety for appearance.

тАШIf a man stands surety for the appearance of a personтАФsaying тАШI shall produce him at such and such a placeтАЩтАФif he fails to do so, he shall pay the debt out of his own property.

The term тАШdebtтАЩ stands for all objects of dispute. The meaning therefore is that in suits relating to any object, the surety should have to make good that object. In the case of defamation, assault, adultery and other offences, if the surety has given the undertaking that тАШif I do not produce the accused I shall pay such and such a sum,тАЩ then he shall have to pay that sum; but in the event of there being no such undertaking, he should he made to pay only the fine that the king imposes upon the accused…… (?)тАФ(158)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 185).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (6.41).тАФтАШSureties are ordained for appearance, for honesty and for payment; the first two kinds of surety must pay the debt on failure of their engagements; as for the last, their sons also may be made to pay.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.53).тАФтАШSurety has been ordained for appearance, for honesty and for payment; the first two should he made to repay the debt on the failure of their engagements; as for the last, his sons also may be made to pay.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.244-248).тАФтАШHaving noticed that the defendant brought up by the Bailiff has other engagements, the King should take a suitable surety for his appearance. тАЬI shall pay what is not paid by this man,тАФI shall present him before you,тАФI shall make him deliver a pledge,тАФYou have no fear from him;тАФI shall do what he fails to do;тАФsuch and such are his occupations;тАФhe does not swear falsely.тАЭтАЩ

N─Бrada (1.118-119).тАФтАШFor appearance, for payment, and for honesty; these are the three different purposes for which three sorts of sureties have been ordained by the sages. If the debtors fail to discharge the debt, or if they prove dishonest, the surety for payment and for honesty must pay the debt; and so must the surety for appearance, if he fails to produce the debtor.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (11.39-42).тАФтАШFor appearance, for honesty, for payment, and for delivering the assets of the debtorтАФit is for these four different purposes that sureties have been ordained by the sages in the legal system. The first of these says, тАЬI shall produce the manтАЭ; the second says, тАЬHe is a respectable personтАЭ; the third says, тАЬI shall pay the debtтАЭ; the fourth says, тАЬI shall deliver his assets.тАЭ If the debtors fail in their engagements, the first two sureties must pay the sum lent at the appointed time; both the last two sureties, and in default of them, their sons, are liable for the debt, when the debtors break their promise. The creditor should allow time for the surety to search for the debtor who has absconded,тАФa fortnight, a month, or a month and a half, according to the distance of the place where the man may he supposed to he hiding.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava-Vyavah─Бra, p. 186).тАФтАШFor the searching of the absconding debtor, the surety should be given time, extending up to a month and a half; if he produces him by that time, he should he absolved from responsibility. If, even on the lapse of the time, he is unable to produce him, he should be made to pay the debt.тАЩ

  • рдЕрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддрдореН рдЖрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдХрдореН, рд╕рднрд┐рдХрд╛рдп рдпрджреН рдзрд╛рд░реНрдпрддреЗ рд╜рдиреНрдпрддреЛ рд╡рд╛ рдпрддреН рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирдВ392 рддрджреН рдЧреГрд╣реАрддрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╢рдХреНрдпрддреЗ рдЬреНрдЮрддреБрдореН ред рддрд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред рдпрдГ рдкрд░рд┐рддреНрдпрдХреНрддрдмрд╛рдиреНрдзрд╡реЛ рд╜рдХреНрд╖рдорд╛рд▓рд╛рд╕реНрд╡реН рдПрд╡ рд╢рдпреНрдпрд╛рд╕рдирд╡рд┐рд╣рд╛рд░реА рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдГ рдХреНрд░реАрдбрдирдХрд╕реН рддрджреГрдгрдореН рдЖрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдХрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╢рдХреНрдпрддреЗ рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪреЗрддреБрдореН ред

рд╕реБрд░рд╛рдкрд╛рдирдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддрдВ рд╕реМрд░рд┐рдХрдореН ред рд╕реБрд░рд╛рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рдорджреНрдпреЛрдкрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред рддреЗрди рдпрдГ рдкрд╛рдирд╢реМрдгреНрдбреЛ рд╜рддреНрдпрдиреНрддрдорджреНрдпрдкрд╕реН рддрджреГрдгрдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред

рджрдгреНрдбрд╢реБрд▓реНрдХрдпреЛрд░реН рдЕрд╡рд╢реЗрд╖рдГ ред рдпрддреНрд░ рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛ рджрдгреНрдбрд╛рдВрд╢рдГ рд╢реБрд▓реНрдХрд╛рдВрд╢рд╢реН393 рдЪ рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рджреН рджрддреНрддрдГ рдкрд░рд┐рдкреВрд░реНрдгреМ рджрдгреНрдбрд╢реБрд▓реНрдХреМ рди рджрддреНрддреМ, рддрд╛рджреГрд╢рд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред

рдпрддреНрд░ рддреБ рди рдХрд┐рдВрдЪрд┐рддреН рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛ рджрддреНрддрдВ394 рддрджреН рджрд╛рдкреНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╕реНрдореГрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд░реЗ рд╜рдкреНрдпреН рдЕрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЗрдгреЛрдХреНрддрдореН- “рдкреНрд░рд╛рддрд┐рднрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд╡рдгрд┐рдХреНрд╢реБрд▓реНрдХрдорджреНрдпрджреНрдпреВрддрджрдгреНрдбрд╛рдГ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдиреН рдирд╛рдзреНрдпрд╛рднрд╡реЗрдпреБрдГ”395 (рдЧреНрдзреН резреи.рекрез) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрдГ ред рдорд╣рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд░рд╛рдзреЗ рдорд╣рддрд┐ рдЪ рдзрдиреЗ рдкреИрддреНрд░рд┐рдХреЗ рд╜рд╡рд╢реЗрд╖рд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред рд╢реБрд▓реНрдХреЗ рд╜рдкреНрдпреН рдПрд╡рдореН ред рд╕реНрд╡рд▓реНрдкреЗ рддреБ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрдп рее рео.резрелреп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШPr─Бtibh─БvyamтАЩ is that which is due from the surety,тАФi.e., the paying off of the debt due by the party for whom he has stood surety; it is this that is called тАШsurety-money.тАЩ

What is denied here is the sonтАЩs liability; and the denial of liability implies the denial of its being his duty to pay; and in as much as a man never pays what it is not his duty to pay, the meaning of the text is that he should not pay. The sense of (the root тАШarhтАЩ is to be thus explained in accordance with the sense of the infinitive verb with which it occurs.

тАЬBut how could there be any idea of the sonтАЩs liability to pay the surety-money, etc., when these were not debts incurred by his father?тАЭ

There is no force in this objection. When a man has undertaken to pay a certain sum it is as good as a тАШdebt,тАЩ since the result is the same. And when definitely known, it is a тАШdebt,тАЩ and as such may he considered as being due to be paid by the son. That is why this liability has got to be denied.

тАШFutile giftтАЩ;тАФGift promised in joke or under similar circumstances, made in some such form as тАШI request you to have this man paid such and such an amount by such and such a banker.тАЩ If a messenger has been sent with this message, but the payment is not actually made, either on account of the bankerтАЩs absence, or of some other reason,тАФand the father dies in the meantime,тАФthe son cannot be made to pay the gift.

Debts incurred in gambling are тАШgambling debtsтАЩ; i.e., the amount that has been actually lost at play, or the money that can he proved to have been borrowed for the purpose of gambling, shall not he paid. In the case of a person who abandons his family and relations and lives and sleeps constantly at gambling dens, and is known to be always playing,тАФit can he easily ascertained that his debts are all due to gambling.

Debts due to drinking are said to be, тАШdue to liquorтАЩ; тАШliquorтАЩ standing for all sorts of intoxicating drugs. Hence the present denial partains to the debts of a man who is an inveterate drunkard.

тАШBalance of fines and dutiesтАЩ;тАФif the father has paid a part of the fine or part of the duty,тАФbut did not pay the entire amounts,тАФthen the balance cannot be realised from the son. That is, he cannot be made to pay what the father did not pay.

Another Smс╣Ыti text lays it down in general termsтАФтАШthe son shall not be made to pay surety-money, trade-duties, debts due to gambling and drinking, and lines.тАЩ ( Gautama, 12.41.)

Thus then, there is an option. If the crime for which the fine had been inflicted was a serious one, or the property inherited from the father is a large one, then the balance only of the fine, as of the duties, shall be remitted; but if they have not. been serious, then the whole shall be remitted.тАФ(159)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШVс╣Ыth─Бd─БnamтАЩтАФтАШGifts promised in jest, or to clowns, bards and such personsтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Kulluka).тАФтАШgifts promised not for religious purpose, but to singers and the likeтАЩ (Nandana).тАФ

тАЬVa┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (16.31) gives this verse as a well-known quotation. So Gautama (12.41).тАЭтАФHopkins.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 57), which adds the following notes:тАФThe term тАШpr─Бtibh─БvyamтАЩ refers here to sureties of both kindsтАФsurety for appearance, and surety for trust;тАФтАШvс╣Ыth─Бd─БnamтАЩ is useless gifts;тАФтАШ─Бkс╣гikam,тАЩ that due to gambling;тАФтАШsaurikamтАЩ, that due to wine-drinking;тАФthe тАШgamblingтАЩ and тАШdrinkingтАЩ meant here are of the improper kind;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (76b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 8.159-162)
**

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (16.31).тАФтАШThey quote the following:тАФтАЬA son need not pay money due by a surety, anything idly promised, money due for losses at play or for spirituous liquor, nor what remains unpaid of a fine or a toll.тАЭтАЩ

Gautama (12.41).тАФтАШMoney due by a surety, a commercial debt, a marriage-fee, debts contracted for spirituous liquor or in gambling, and a fine shall not involve the sons.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (6.41).тАФтАШSurety is ordained for appearance, for honesty, and for payment; the first two themselves (not their sons) shall pay the debt on failure of the engagement; but of the last, the sons also would be liable to pay.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2-47, 53, 54).тАФтАШThe son shall not pay his fatherтАЩs debt involved in connection with wine, or love or gambling, or with balances of line and toll, or with idle gifts…… Surety is ordained for appearance, for honesty and for payment; on failure of the engagement, the first two shall pay the debt, and in the case of the last, his sons also shall be liable to pay. In a case where the surety for appearance or the surety for honesty has died, his son shall not he made to pay the debt; but in the case of one for payment, the sons should pay.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (11.39-42).тАФ(See under 158.)

Do. (11.51).тАФтАШSons shall not he made to pay a debt incurred by their father for spirituous liquor, for losses at play, for idle gifts, for promises made under the influence of love or wrath, or for suretyship; nor the balance of a fine or toll.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1.118-19).тАФ(See under 158.)

Do. (1.10).тАФтАШThe son must pay the debt contracted by the father, excepting those debts which have been contracted from love or anger, or for spirituous liquor, games or bailments.тАЩ

Vy─Бsa (Apar─Бrka, p. 656).тАФтАШThe son shall pay the sum due by reason of suretyship.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Do., p. 656).тАФтАШThe debt contracted by the father in connection with suretyship must be paid by the son.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.55, 56).тАФтАШIf there are several sureties, each shall pay to the creditor his own proportionate share of the debt. If each one of them has stood surety for the whole amount, the creditor may realise it from them in any way he chooses. In a case where the surety has been publicly compelled to pay the creditor, the debtor should pay to the surety double of the amount paid by him.тАЩ

N─Бrada (1. 120, 121).тАФтАШWhen there is a plurality of sureties, they shall pay each proportionately, according to agreement. If they were hound severally, the payment shall be made by any of them, as the creditor pleases. Twice as much as the surety, harassed by the creditor, has given to the creditor, shall the debtor pay hack to the surety.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (11.44).тАФтАШWhen a surety, being harassed, pays a proved debt which he has vouched for, the debtor shall pay him twice as much, after the lapse of a month and a half.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 657).тАФ(Same as Bс╣Ыhaspati.)

The law laid down in the preceding verse shall apply to the case of тАШSurety for appearanceтАЩ; in the case of the death of the тАШSurety for paymentтАЩ however, the king shall make the heirs also to pay up.тАФ(160)

рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЗ рдпреЛ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд░реН рдордпрд╛ рдЪреЛрджрд┐рдд рдЙрдХреНрддрдГ, рдпрдерд╛ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдВ рди рднрд╡рддрд┐ рдкреИрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рддрд┐рднрд╛рд╡реНрдпрдореН, рддрджреН рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдкреНрд░рд╛рддрд┐рднрд╛рд╡реНрдпреЗ ред рдпрджреНрдпреН рдПрд╡рдВ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдпрдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднреБрд╡рдГ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛ рджрд╛рдкреНрдпрдиреНрддрд╛рдореН, рдЕрдд рдЖрд╣ рджрд╛рдирдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднреБрд╡рд┐ рдкреНрд░реЗрддреЗ рджрд╛рдпрд╛рджрд╛рдГ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛ рджрд╛рдкреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ, рдирд╛рдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН ред

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдпрджреНрдпреН рдПрд╡рдВ рдкреНрд░рдердореЛ рд╜рд░реНрдзрд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЛ рд╜рдирд░реНрдердХрдГ ред рджрд╛рдирдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднреБрд╡рдГ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдВ рд╕рд╛рдзрди рдЙрдХреНрддреЗ396 рд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдп397 рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднреБрд╡реЛ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдВ рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдз рдЗрддрд┐ рдЧрдореНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЕрде рд╡рд┐рд╕реНрдкрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрдердореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдпрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рдЗрддрд░рдерд╛ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзреЗ398 рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╛рджреН399 рд╡рд┐рдзреМ рдЪ рджрд╛рдирдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╛рджреН рдЙрднрдпрдкрд░рд┐рднреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╕реНрдп рдХрд┐рдВ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд░реН рдЙрдд рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдз400 рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рдВрд╢рдпрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рд╕рдВрд╢рдпрдГ, рд╕реНрдореГрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд░реЗ рд╕реНрдкрд╖реНрдЯрдореН рдЙрдХреНрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН-

  • рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднреВрд░реН рдпрддреНрд░ рдореГрддрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╛рддреНрдпрдпрд┐рдХреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╡рд╛ ред

  • рди рддрддреНрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛ рдЛрдгрдВ рджрджреНрдпреБрд░реН рджрджреНрдпреБрд░реН рджрд╛рдирд╛рдп рдпреЗ рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд╛рдГ рее рдЗрддрд┐ ред (рдпреНрдзреН реи.релрем)

рдЗрд╣рд╛рдкрд┐ рджрд╛рдирдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднреБрд╡реАрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕реНрдп рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд┐рдГ ред рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдореН рдЙрдкрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред рдЕрдиреБрд╡рд╛рджреЗ рдЪреЛрдкрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрддреНрд╡рдореН рдЕрджреЛрд╖рдГ ред рдХрд┐рдВрдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рдЪреЗрддреН, рд╡рд┐рдЪрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдХреГрддрд┐рд░реН рдорд╛рдирд╡реА рее рео.резремреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The тАШlaw laid downтАЩтАФby meтАФтАШin the preceding verse,тАЩтАФviz., тАШthe surety-money due from the father shall not be payable by the sonтАЩтАФapplies only to the case of тАШsurety for appearance.тАЩ

This assertion might give rise to the idea that the son should be made to pay in the case of тАШsurety for guarantee,тАЩтАФhence the author proceeds to addтАФтАШIn the case of the death of the surety for payment,тАЩ the heirs are made to pay up, and not in the case of any other kind of surety.

тАЬIf such is the meaning, then the first half of the verse is superfluous; for when it is declared that the son is liable only for the dues by the Surety for Payment, it follows that he is not liable for the dues by any other form of surety. If it be argued that it is for the purpose of making things clear that the first, half is added,тАФthen the case of тАШsurety for guaranteeтАЩ also should have been added, otherwise, it would be doubtful whether the denial (contained in the preceding verse), excluded as it would be from the two cases of surety, is a prohibition or a positive injunction.тАЭ

There can be no such doubt; since the matter has been clearly stated in another Smс╣ЫtiтАФтАШIn a case where the surety for appearance, or the surety for confidence, has died, the sons should not pay the dues, but they should pay in the case of the Surety for Payment,тАЩ (Y─Бj├▒avalkya, Vyavah─Бra, 54). In the present text also, as the assertion тАШin the case of the death of Surety for Payment, etc.,тАЩ is in the form of a positive injunction, it cannot become applicable to the case of any other form of surety. There is nothing wrong however in the implications of merely re-iterative assertions (as the first half of the verse is) being extended (to cases other than those directly mentioned). If the question is raised, as to the purpose for which such re-iteration should have been made,тАФour answer is that it is a peculiarity of ManuтАЩs style of writing.тАФ(160)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

The first half of this verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 57), which adds that тАШdar┼Ыanapr─Бtibh─БvyaтАЩ includes the surety for trust also [this is clear from Y─Бj├▒avalkya, 254, where both are put on the same footing]тАФthe second half is quoted on p. 43 where тАШd─Бnapratibh┼лтАЩ is explained as тАШthe surety who had promised I shall pay,тАЩтАФand тАШd─Бy─Бd─БnтАЩ as тАШsons.тАЩ

(1) тАШDar┼Ыana-pratibh┼лтАЩ is the person standing surety with the promise тАШI shall produce this man when requiredтАЩ;тАФ(2) Pratyayapratibh┼л is one who says тАШgive him the loan on my trustтАЩ;тАФ(3) D─Бnapratibh┼лтАЩтАФwho says тАШgive him the loan, which, if he does not pay, I shall pay.тАЩ

The verse is quoted in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (74a and 76b).
