тАШThisтАЩ refers to all that has been said above.

тАШMannerтАЩтАФmethod.

тАШDeciding them with the help of witnesses and other evidence,тАЩтАФтАШDecidingтАЩ is to be construed with each of the two names тАШs┼лkс╣гiтАЩ (witness) and тАШpratyayaтАЩ (evidence);тАФтАШevidenceтАЩ standing for inferences and ordeals.

тАШDisputesтАЩтАФNot only the non-payment of debts, but others, also.

тАШSettle,тАЩтАФi.e., remove the differences of opinion between the plaintiff and the defendant: and restore them to agreement.

The treatment of the тАШnon-payment of debtsтАЩ has been finished. This also is the end of all suits; victory or defeat in all of them being adjudicated on the same lines. Even in the тАШHeads of DisputeтАЩ that follow there is no other means available for deciding except тАШwitnesses And the restтАЩ; the only difference that there is is in regard to the character of the punishment to be inflicted, whose exact nature has got to be prescribed; and it is for this purpose that we have the following sections; and in course of this it shall also be determined what is meant by тАШSelling without Ownership,тАЩ тАШRescission of SaleтАЩ and so forth.тАФ(178)

рд╕реБрд╣реГрджреН рднреВрддреНрд╡реЛрдкрджрд┐рд╕рддрд┐ рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрдореН ред рдирд╛рдпрдореН рдЕрджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрдереЛ рд╜рд╖реНрдЯрдХрд╛рджрд┐рд╡рджреН рдЙрдкрджреЗрд╢рдГ ред рдИрджреГрд╢рд┐ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖реЗ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрддрд╕реНрдп рди рд╡рд┐рдкреНрд░рд▓рдпреЛ[^релремрей] рднрд╡рддрд┐, рдПрд╡рдВрд╡рд┐рдзреЗ рди рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрддрдореН рдЕрдиреЗрдиреЗрддрд┐ рд╢рдЩреНрдХрд╛ рди рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рдпрд╕реН рддреБ рдирдЧреНрдирдХрд┐рддрд╡рдкрд╛рдирд╢реМрдЮреНрдбрд╛рджрд┐рдГ рд╕ рдХреЗрдирдЪрд┐рджреН рдЖрдХреГрд╖реНрдЯреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдорддреНрдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛рд╕реНрдп[^релремрек] рд╣рд╕реНрддреЗ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрддрдВ рдордпрд╛ рдЪреЗрддрд┐ рди рд╢рдЩреНрдХрд╛рд╕реНрдкрджрдореН, рд╕реБрд╡рд░реНрдгрд╛рджреЗрд░реН рдорд╣рддреЛ рдзрдирд╕реНрдп рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрдзрд╛рд░рдХ рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдХрд╛рдХрдгреА рдорд╛рддреНрд░рд┐рдХреЗрднрд┐рдпреБрдЬреНрдпрдорд╛рдиреЗ[^релремрел] рднрд╡рддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡ рее рео.резренреп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

He whose birth and family are well known,тАФwhose forefathers are known to have been learned, righteous and rich,тАФwho never have recourse to improper acts, being mindful of the reputation of their family. In fact such a person is incapable of hearing the slightest blame; and yet it is such people! that are subject to severest criticism at the hands of the people.

тАШVс╣ЫttaтАЩ is character, conduct; i.e., being naturally mindful of public opinion.

тАШCognisant of the lawтАЩ;тАФwho has become acquainted with the true meaning of Smс╣Ыtis, Pur─Бс╣Зas and Itih─Бsas by repeatedly studying them.

тАШTruthfulтАЩтАФwho has found, in all business-relations, to speak in strict accordance with real facts.

тАШHas a large following,тАЩтАФhe who is held in high esteem by his friends and relations, as also by the officers of the king,тАФand is, as such, not amenable to be approached by dishonest state-officials.

The тАШwealthyтАЩ man avoids the misappropriation of other peopleтАЩs property, with a view to safeguard his own possessions, and also through fear of transcendental results; the idea in his mind beingтАФтАШI have enough wealth of my own, why should I think of the property of others? If I were detected, I would be punished.тАЩ

тАШHonourable,тАЩ who always acts righteously, or who is of a straightforward nature.

The nominal affix тАШgha├▒тАЩ (in the noun тАШnikс╣гepa,тАЩ тАШdepositтАЩ) has the force of the passive, and makes the word stand for the gold and other property that are kept as deposits.

тАШShall entrustтАЩтАФPlace.

тАШThe wise manтАЩ;тАФthe man who entrusts deposits in the said manner is тАШwiseтАЩ; otherwise he becomes a fool.

The Author here is ottering an advice in the manner of a friend; and the advice has no spiritual purpose behind it, as there is in the case of such acts as the Aс╣гс╣нak─Б and the like.

When a тАШdepositтАЩ is placed with such a person, it is never lost; nor is there any doubt as to who has placed it and with whom. On the other hand, if a person is a pauper, a notorious cheat or drunkard,тАФeven if he he dragged up, no one would even believe that a deposit had been placed with him; when the man is not possessed of a single farthing, how could it he believed that he would have been entrusted with gold or such large properties?тАФ(179)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (82b), which explains тАШmah─Бpakс╣гaтАЩ as one who has a large family;тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 204);тАФand in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 85), which explains тАШmah─Бpakс╣гaтАЩ as тАШone having a large familyтАЩ,тАФand тАШnikс╣гepamтАЩ as тАШnikс╣гepyam,тАЩ i.e., the thing deposited;тАФand in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 36), which explains тАШmah─Бpakс╣гaтАЩ as тАШone who has a large number of relatives.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

N─Бrada (2.1, 2)тАФтАШWhen a man entrusts any property of his own to another, in confidence and without suspicion, it is called by the learned a Deposit. A sensible man should make a deposit with one who belongs to a respectable family and who is virtuous, acquainted with his duties, veracious, influential, wealthy, and honourable.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspasti (12.2, 4).тАФтАШWhen any chattel is deposited in the house of another man, through fear of the King, robbers or other dangers, or for the purpose of deceiving oneтАЩs heirs, it is called a Deposit. Let a man make a deposit, after duly considering the place, house, master of the house, the power, means, quality, veracity and kindred of the depositary.тАЩ

рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрд┐рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╡рд┐рдзреНрдпрд░реНрдердГ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдГ ред рдХреБрд▓рдЬреЗ рдкреНрд░рдХреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рднрд┐рдЬрдиреЗ ред [рд╡реГрддреНрддрд╕рдВрдкрдиреНрдиреЗ] рдЖрдЪрд╛рд░рд╡рддрд┐ ред рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрд╛рджреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЗ, рдЗрддрд░рддреНрд░ рд╡рд╛ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдЪрд╛рд░реНрдерд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЗ рд╢реБрдЪрд┐рд░реН рднрд╡рддрд┐ рдпрджрд┐ рдзрд░реНрдордЬреНрдЮрддрдпрд╛ рд╕рддреНрдпрд╡рд╛рджреА рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪ рд╕рддрд┐ рд╡реГрддреНрддрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгрдореН рдЗрджрдВ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдореН ред рдПрд╡рдВрд╡реГрддреНрддреЛ рдпрджрд┐ рднрд╡рддрд┐ рддрддреЛ рд╜рдпрдВ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрдпреЛрдЧреНрдпрдГ рд╕рдВрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдорд╣рд╛рдкрдХреНрд╖рд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдЧрдореНрдпрд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдЯрд╡рд┐рдХрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐, рд╕реНрд╡рдкрдХреНрд╖рдкрд░рд╛рднрд╡рднрдпрд╛рдЪреН рдЪ рди рд╡рд┐рдХрд╛рд░рдВ рдпрд╛рддрд┐ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдЪ рдзрдирд┐рддреНрд╡реЛрдкрджреЗрд╢реЛ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпреЗрдпрдГ ред рдЖрд░реНрдпрд╢реН рдЪреИрд╡рдВрд╡реГрддреНрддрдГ рд╢реВрджреНрд░реЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдГ, рдЕрд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рддреНрдордХрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреБ рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рдореН рдЖрдЪрдХреНрд╖рддреЗ, рддрд╕реНрдп рдЪрд╛рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрдердВ рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдореН рдЖрд╣реБрд░реН рдЗрддрд┐ рее рео.резренрео рее

179 A sensible man should make a deposit (only) with a person of (good) family, of good conduct, well acquainted with the law, veracious, having many relatives, wealthy, and honourable (arya).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In the form in which one shall deposit a thing in the hands of another person, in that same form shall that thing be received back; as the delivery so the recovery.тАФ(180)

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдирдиреБ рдЪ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рдкрд╣реНрдирд╡ рдПрд╡ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рд╡рд┐рддреЛ рдЬрд┐рдд рдПрд╡ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдГ ред

рд╕рддреНрдпрдореН ред рдпрддреНрд░рд╛рд╡рд┐рдирд╛рднрд╛рд╡рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдореН, рдпрдерд╛ рдореБрд╖рд┐рддреЗ рдЧреНрд░рд╛рдореЗ рджреЗрд╡рджрддреНрддреЛ рд╜рднрд┐рдпреБрдЬреНрдпрддреЗ[^релремреп] “рддреНрд╡рдпрд╛рдиреНрдпреИрд╢реН рдЪреЛрд░реИрдГ рд╕рд╣рд╛рдореБрд╖реНрдорд┐рдиреНрдиреН рдЕрд╣рдирд┐ рд╕ рдЧреНрд░рд╛рдореЛ рд╣рддрдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд╕ рдЖрд╣ “рдиреИрд╡ рддрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреНрдиреН рдЕрд╣рдирд┐ рддрдВ рдЧреНрд░рд╛рдордореН рдЕрд╣рдореН рдЕрдЧрдордореН” ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рднрд┐рд░реН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН “рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрдВ рддрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреНрдиреН рдЕрд╣рдирд┐ рддрддреНрд░ рдпрдиреН рдореБрд╖реНрдЯрдВ рддрддреН рддреБ рди рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрдореН” ред рддрддреНрд░ рджреЗрд╡рджрддреНрддреЗрди рдореЛрд╖реЛ[^релренреж] рд╜рдкреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд╣реНрдиреБрддрд╕реН рддрджрд╣рд░реН рдЧреНрд░рд╛рдорд╕рдВрдирд┐рдзрд╛рдирд╕рд┐рджреНрдзреЗрдГ ред рд╕реНрдлреБрдЯреЗ рдЪ рдХрд╛рд░рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрд░реЗ рд╕рдВрдирд┐рдзрд╛рд╡реН рдЕрдиреБрдкрд▓рднреНрдпрдорд╛рдиреЗ рд╕рдВрдирд┐рдзрд╛рдирд╛рджреЗрд╢рджреЗрд╢рд╛рдЪреН рдЪреМрд░рддреНрд╡рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рддреБрдореН ред рдЗрд╣ рддреБ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рджрдирд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдирд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдВ рдореБрджреНрд░рд┐рддрдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрддрдореН рдЕрдореБрджреНрд░рд┐рддрдореН рдПрд╡ рдиреАрдпрддреЗ ред
рдпрдерд╛ рджрд╛рдпрд╕реН рддрдерд╛ рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ ред рдХреЛ рдореЗ рд╜рднрд┐рдпреЛрдЧрд╛рд╡рд╕рд░ рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдирдпрд╛ рдмреБрджреНрдзреНрдпрд╛ рд╕рдВрднрд╡рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд╣реНрдирд╡рдГ ред рди рд╣рд┐ рд╢рдХреНрдиреЛрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рддреБрдореН ред рдпрджрд╛рдкрд┐[^релренрез] рдХрдердВрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рдкрдпреЗрддреН рдкрд░рд┐рдорд╛рдгрдВ рддреБ рди рд╡рд┐рдирд╛ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдВ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрддрд╡рдЪрдирд╛рджреН рдПрд╡ рд╕рд┐рдзреНрдпрддреАрддрд┐ рдпреБрдХреНрддреЛ рджрд┐рд╡реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рддреЛ[^релренреи] рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрдпрдГ ред рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдерд╛ рдп рдПрдХрджреЗрд╢рд╛рдиреНрддрд░реЗрдг рди рд╕рдВрднрд╡рддрд┐ рддрддреНрд░реИрд╡реИрдХрджреЗрд╢рдкрд░рд╛рдЬрд┐рдд рдЗрддрд┐ рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрдпрдГ рее рео.резреореж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШYath─Б,тАЩтАФin the form; i.e., sealed or unsealed, with witnesses or without witnesses and so forth.

тАШIn that same formтАЩ should the thing be received back; the thing should be recovered in the same form in which it had been delivered.

In a case where it is generally known that the party concerned always keeps deposits properly sealed,тАФif a dispute arises, and the deposit is found to be unsealed, if the trustee were to say тАШthis man never seals his deposits, he forces them upon me and goes off,тАЩ he would be suspected of dishonesty and would lose his case; there being no room for any other evidence so far;тАФbut when, on the seal being found broken, the question arises as to what part of the property has been extracted, the king should call other kinds of evidence; the guilty man however is to be punished in the first place, with the penalty prescribed for dishonest dealing in general;тАФand secondly, another penalty in connection with the тАШdepositтАЩ has to be imposed after the exact amount extracted has been determined.

тАЬin the case of a dishonest dealing, the man deserves to be mulcted of the entire amount involved.тАЭ

True; but this is so only in cases where the entire guilt is clearly indicated by proofs. For instance, a certain village has been robbed, Devadatta is accused of having colluded with other thieves and robbed the village on that day,тАФthereupon he pleadsтАФтАШon that day I did not go to that village,тАЩтАФwitnesses declare that he had been seen in the village on that day, but it had not been seen that he had actually committed the robbery,тАФfrom this the deduction is that the man having denied the robbery as well as his presence in the village, since his presence had been proved, the denial of the robbery also was not true; so that when there was other evidence clearly proving the manтАЩs presence in the village, it was safe to infer that he had committed the robbery also.

In the present case however, it may he that the seal was broken through carelessness (and not necessarily intentionally), (so that the penalty need not always be severe).

тАШAs the delivery so the recovery,тАЩтАФi.e., what was delivered тАШsealedтАЩ should be received back also тАШsealed.тАЩ

Fraudulent denial may be made by a man who might think that there would be no occasion for his being hauled up. The presence of such fraudulent intention may be inferred; but the exact amount involved cannot be determined entirely on the assertion of the depositor, except through other kinds of evidence. So in such cases the right course would be to arrive at a decision with the help of ordeals. And (as for the actual award), it is only where no certainty is possible in regard to the entire claim that a partial decree is awarded.тАФ(180)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 86), which explains тАШd─Бyaс╕етАЩ as depositing and тАШgrahaс╕етАЩ as receiving;тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 205), which explains тАШd─Бyaс╕етАЩ as giving, depositing,тАФand тАШgrahaс╕етАЩ as receiving;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 113b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Y─Бj├▒avalkaya (2.65, 67).тАФтАШIf something contained in a basket is made over in deposit to another person, without the contents being declared, it is called a Scaled Deposit; it shall be restored to the owner in exactly the same form in which it had ben deposited. This same rule applies to ordinary deposits also.тАЩ

N─Бrada (2.3).тАФтАШIn whatever form may a man have delivered any of his effects to another, in the same form shall that article be restored to the owner; as the delivery so the recovery.тАЩ

N─Бrada (2.5).тАФтАШIf one article concealed in another is deposited in another manтАЩs house, without stating what it is, it is then a Sealed Deposit.тАЩ

N─Бrada (2.6).тАФтАШDeposits must he restored in precisely the same condition.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (12.3).тАФтАШWhen a chattel enclosed in a cover and marked with a seal is deposited, without describing its nature and quantity, and without showing it, it is termed a Sealed Deposit.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (12.9).тАФтАШA deposit must be returned to the very man who hailed it, in the very manner in which it was hailed.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 662).тАФтАШPurchase-money, what is deposited by one going on a long journey, a pledge, something handed over for being delivered to a third party, what is given to another for the making of something else, what is paid in connection with loan-transactions, all this is called Deposit.тАЩ

When requested to restore the deposit, if the trustee do not restore it to the depositor,тАФthen, on the departure of that depositor, in the event of there being no witnesses, the judge shall actually deposit gold (with the trustee) through spies of proper age and appearance, under some pretexts, and then ask him to restore it.тАФ(181-182)

ред рд╡рдпрд╕рд╛ рд╕рдордиреНрд╡рд┐рддрд╛541 рдпреЗрди рдмрд╛рд▓рд╛ рди рднрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐, рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рд╣рд┐ рдкрд░реИрдГ рдкреНрд░реЗрд░рд┐рддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮреЛрдкрджреНрд░рд╡рдЧреНрд░рд╛рдордЧрдордирд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐- “рдЕрдиреЗрди рд╣реЗрддреБрдирд╛ рддреНрд╡рдпрд┐ рд╕рдВрдкреНрд░рддрд┐ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкрд╛рдореН” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреГрддрд╕рдВрднрд╡рд╛рддреН рдХрд╛рд░рдгрдХрдердирдореН рдЕрдкрджреЗрд╢рдГ ред рдПрддрдЪреН рдЪ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЩреН рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкреНрддреБрд░реН рдЕрд╕рдВрдирд┐рдзреМ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН рее рео.резреореи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 8.181-182)
**

From what has gone before people might be led to think that in a case where there are no witnesses, recourse should at once be had to ordeals;тАФand it is to guard against this that the author adds these texts.

The meaning is that in the case of non-payment of debt and other disputes, the judge has recourse to ordeals as soon as it is found that no witnesses are available;тАФbut this is not what should be done in the case in question; in such cases the character of the man is tested through spies. If, on being so tested, it is found that the man does not trip in his dealings, then he shall not be disgraced With having to undergo an ordeal. If, on the other hand, he does trip, then it is only right that he should be suspected of having misappropriated the deposit; and in this case he should be made to undergo ordeals; because the mere fact of his having misappropriated one deposit does not necessarily prove that he had misappropriated another deposit also; for it is just possible

that on account of some urgent need he might have been led to commit misappropriation in one case, while in another ease, either by reason of his needs having been supplied or on account of repentance, he might have restored it honestly.

The present verses are to be taken as forbidding the course of hurriedly making the trustee undergo ordeals; and they are meant to point out a new line of evidence. Then again even though in the case of the man misappropriating the judgeтАЩs deposit, there is immediate punishment, yet it does not follow that the same punishment shall be inflicted upon him in connection with the alleged, but uncertain, misappropriation of that belonging to the plaintiff. For if such penalty were to be inflicted even in cases of uncertainty, there would be no laws laying down the means of arriving at certain conclusions. Hence it has been considered necessary that decisions should be arrived at by means of reasonings.

For these reasons verse 181 should not be taken in its literal sense (that the man shall be made to pay тАШy─Бcyaс╕етАЩ); but it should be interpreted in a different manner, being construed along with verse 182.

The verbal construction of the verse we explain now as follows:тАФтАШon the departure of that depositorтАЩтАФby whom the deposit had been placed,тАФтАШhe shall be asked by the judge to restore it.тАЩ

There being no witnesses,тАФwhen the depositor asks for the restoration of his deposit and the trustee denies the deposit, saying тАШyou never deposited anything with meтАЩтАФand being appealed to by the depositor, the king shall not at once put the trustee to the ordeal;тАФwhat then shall he do?тАФThe judge shall deposit his own or some one elseтАЩs gold or silver with the man, through spies, and then ask for its restoration.

The term тАШjudge,тАЩ here stands for any person who has been deputed by the king to investigate the ease.

тАЬIs he to be asked directly by the Judge himself?тАЭ

No; it should be done through spies,тАФthose same through whom the deposit has been placed.

тАШOf propet age and appearanceтАЩ;тАФthey should he of тАШproper age,тАЩ so that they may not be minors; for if such minors were to go to transact business, the man would suspect that they had been put up by others to cheat him; whereas if they were full-grown people, no such suspicion would arise.

Similarly they should be of тАШproper appearanceтАЩ;тАФin the case of some people their very appearance is indicative of their fickle nature; that appearance is to be regarded as тАШproperтАЩ which indicates freedom from love or hatred.

Thus the meaning comes to be that the spies chosen should be such that the trustee may not suspect that the whole business was a trick to entrap him.

тАШUnder some pretexts.тАЩтАФThat is, they may say, for instance,тАФтАШThe man who is depositing this good is leaving the city from fear of harrassment by the king, that is why I am placing this deposit with you.тАЩ This untrue representation is what is called тАШpretextтАЩ here.

All this is to be done, when the original depositor (the original plaintiff) is not present.тАФ(182)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

(verses 8.181-182)

These verses are quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 664);тАФand in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 94), which explains them to mean thatтАФтАШIf the person who calls himself the Depositor demands the deposit from the person called the Deposit-holder,тАФand the latter denies it, saying тАШnothing was deposited with meтАЩ,тАФand there are no witnesses to the transaction;тАФthen the king, with a desire to ascertain the facts, should have recourse to the following stratagem:тАФThrough spies of the proper age and appearance, trustworthy in word and appearance, he should by some pretext deposit his own gold with the accusal person;тАФafter some days, he should have that deposit demanded from him.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 8.181-184)
**

N─Бrada (2.4, 7).тАФтАШIf the depositary fails to restore the deposit to the depositor as he ought, he shall be compelled by forcible means, to restore it, after his guilt has been proved by ordeals or other modes of proof. The wicked man who does not restore a deposit, on being asked to do so by the depositor, shall be punished by the King. If the deposit has been lost, he shall make good its value.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (12.13).тАФтАШHe who, after receiving a deposit, denies the fact, and is convicted by the evidence of witnesses or ordeal, shall be compelled to give up the deposit and to pay a fine equal in amount to the same.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.66).тАФтАШIf on the depositor demanding it, the deposit be not restored, on account of its having been lost, the depositary should be made to pay to the depositor the value of the deposit, and also a fine of the same amount.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 664).тАФтАШIf after having received a deposit, one fails to restore it on being asked to do so, he should he punished and compelled to restore it.тАЩ

Matsyapur─Бс╣Зa (Apar─Бrka, p. 664).тАФтАШIf after having received a deposit, the depositor refuses to restore it and dishonestly denies the deposit, he should be arrested and compelled to restore the deposit and also pay a fine.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The man having been charged with the wordsтАФтАШThis man is refusing to restore my deposit, because there are no witnesses to it,тАЩтАФif he admits it тАШin the form and shape,тАЩ etc.тАФThe distinction between тАШform and shapeтАЩ is based upon the deposit hearing or not bearing a secret seal;тАФor it may he based upon the action of the Receiver and the Depositor.

The deposit should be restored as unhesitatingly and quickly as it had been received;тАФthat is, there should be no delay in the restoration.тАФ(183)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 664), which explains the meaning to be that the man should be punished by being made to surrender the two deposits as also their values.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 94) which explains the meaning to be as followsтАФтАЬIf, however, the man does not surrender the gold deposited by the kingтАЩs spies, then the king should regard the charge as proved against him and should make him surrender also the former deposit, the subject-matter of the former charge.тАЭ

It is quoted also in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 209), to the effect that if, relying on his power, the depository does not surrender the deposit, he should be punished by the king and forced to deliver it.

рдиреАрддреНрд╡рд╛ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкреНрддреБрд░реН555 рди рджрддреНрддрдВ рддрджрд╛ рддреЗрди рдкрд░реНрдпрдиреБрдпреБрдХреНрддрд╕реНрдп рдзрд╛рд░рдгреНрдпрдХрд╕реНрдп рдХрд┐рдореН рдЙрддреНрддрд░рдореН ред “рддреНрд╡рджреАрдпреЗрди рднреНрд░рд╛рддреНрд░реИрддрджреН рдзрдирдВ рд╕рд╛рдзрд╛рд░рдгрд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдирд╛ рдиреАрддрдореН” рдЗрддрд┐ рдиреИрддрджреН рдЙрддреНрддрд░рдореН ред “рдпрдерд╛ рджрд╛рдпрд╕реН рддрдерд╛ рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ” (рдореНрдзреН рео.резреореж) рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН ред рдпреЗрдиреИрд╡ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрддрдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдирд╛рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдирд╛ рд╡рд╛ рддрд╕реНрдорд╛ рдПрд╡ рджреЗрдпрдВ рддрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡рд╛рдпрдВ рдкреНрд░рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдГ ред рдпрджрд┐ рддреБ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдирдиреНрддрд░реЛ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдВ рди рдЧрдЪреНрдЫреЗрддреН рддрджрд╛ рддрджреНрджрд╛рдиреЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рди рджреЛрд╖рдГ ред рддрджреН рдЖрд╣** рдЕрдирд┐рдкрд╛рддреЗ рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдирд╛рд╢рд┐рдиреМ** ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╣реНрдпреН рдЕрд╕реНрддреНрдпреН рдЙрддреНрддрд░рдВ рдорд╛рдирд╢рддреН556 рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдЕрд░реНрдкрдпрд╛рдорд┐ ред рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдирдиреНрддрд░реЗрдг рдиреАрддреЗ рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдкрд╛рддреЗ рдЪ рддрд╕реНрдп рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкреНрддреНрд░реЗ рдпрд╛рдЪрдорд╛рдирд╛рдп557 рд╕реНрд╡рдзрдирдВ рджрд╛рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрд╛рд░реНрдердГ рее рео.резреорел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШNext-of-kin,тАЩтАФof the depositor; i.e., his son, or brother, or wife. If the depositor has the right of ownership, so has his wife also; the son also has a right over the property of his grandfather; and the brother also, who is still united in property, has a right over it. Hence, if the depositor happens to be sent, any one of these relatives may tell the depositoryтАФтАШgive the deposit to me, it belongs to meтАЩ;тАФon this the depository may hand it over to him thinkingтАФтАШthis is their joint property, one has deposited it and another is taking it away, what harm is there in this?тАЩтАФand it is with a view to guard against this that the text saysтАФтАШDeposits, open or sealed, shall not be handed over to the next-of-kin.тАЩ

A hortatory argument is addedтАФтАШIn the event of a mishap occurring, they become los t,тАЩтАФтАШmishapтАЩ in the form of the kinsman going out of the country and so forth,тАФif any such happens тАШthey become lost.тАЩ If the kinsman, having received the deposit, did not make it over to the person who had deposited it, then, on being charged by the latter, what answer could the depositary give? It would be no answer to sayтАФтАШit was taken away by your brother, who was the joint owner of itтАЩ; because it has been declaredтАФтАШas the delivery so the recoveryтАЩ (180); so that the deposit should be restored to the person who actually deposited it, be he the rightful owner or not. This is the simple fact that is set forth in this detail.

If however nothing happens to the тАШnext-of-kinтАЩ then there would be no harm in restoring the deposit to him; this is what is meant by the assertion.тАФтАШThey do not become lost, if no mishap occurs.тАЩ Because in this case the answer of the depositary would beтАФтАШI restored it to him as otherwise it might become lost with me.тАЩ

What the text means is thatтАФтАШif the deposit has been taken away by the depositorтАЩs kinsman, then, on being asked by the depositor to restore it, the depositary shall make it good out of his own property.тАЩтАФ(185)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 87), which adds the following explanation:тАФIf the depositor is living, deposits, sealed or open, should never be given by the depository to any such near relative of the depositor as may have a share in the property,тАФduring the absence of the depositor himself; for if the said relative happen to die, the deposits become lost, i.e., they do not reach the depositor himself; though if the relative does not die, they may perhaps reach him. So that in the event of the relativeтАЩs death, it would be open to the original depositor to demand from the depository the value of the deposits; and in order to guard against this, the depository should always return the deposits to the depositor himself, while he lives.

It is quoted in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (83a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Bс╣Ыhaspati (12.9).тАФтАШA deposit must he restored to the very man who kept it, in the very manner in which it was delivered; it must not be restored to the next of kin (of the depositor).тАЩ

рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкреНрддрд░рд┐ рдЬреАрд╡рддрд┐ рддрддреНрдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдирдиреНрддрд░реЗ рдкреБрддреНрд░реЗ рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░рд┐ рд╡рд╛ рддрджреАрдпрдзрдирд╛рд░реНрд╣реЗ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкреЛрдкрдирд┐рдзреА рди рджреЗрдпреМ, рдкреНрд░рд╛рд░реНрдердпрдорд╛рдирд╛рдп ред рдпреЗрди рди рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдирдиреНрддрд░рд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╡рд┐рдирд╛рд╢реЗ рд╜рд╕реНрддрд┐ рдЧрддрд┐рдГ ред рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдирдиреНрддрд░рд╕реНрдп рд╡рд┐рдирд╛рд╢реЗ рддреБ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрдзрд╛рд░реА рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкреНрддреНрд░рд╛ рдпрд╛рдЪрд┐рддрдГ рдХрд┐рдореН рдЙрддреНрддрд░рдВ рджрд╛рд╕реНрдпрддрд┐ рддрд╕реНрдп ред рдпрддреЛ рди рддрд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдирдиреНрддрд░рджрд╛рдирдВ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН рее рео.резреорек рее

185 An open or a sealed deposit must never be returned to a near relative (of the depositor during the latter’s lifetime); for if (the recipient) dies (without delivering them), they are lost, but if he does not die, they are not lost.

If the man restores it himself to the next-of-kin of the deceased depositor,тАФhe should not be harassed by the king, or by the depositorтАЩs relatives.тАФ(186)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЬреАрд╡рддрд╕реН рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рдиреН рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкреНрддреБрдГ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдирдиреНрддрд░рджрд╛рдирдВ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддреАрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН ред рдореГрддрд╕реНрдп рддреБ рдпрд╕реН рддрджреН рдзрдирдореН рдЕрд╕реНрддреАрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд╡рд┐рдЬрд╛рдирддреЗ рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдВ рджрджреНрдпрд╛рдиреН рди рд╕ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рд▓реЗрдЦрдирд╛рджрд┐рдХреНрд▓реЗрд╢рдиреАрдпреЛ рд╜рдиреНрдпрджреН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕реНрддрд┐ рди рд╡реЗрдж рд╡реЗрддрд┐ ред рдпрджрд┐ рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рднрд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдпрджреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрдореН рдЗрджрдореН рдЗрд╡ рддрджреН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрджрд╛рд╕реНрдпрджреН558 рдЗрддрд┐ рди рдХреНрд▓рд┐рд╢реНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЕрддреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрдпреН рдЖрд╢рдЩреНрдХрд╛ рдпрджрд┐ рди рдирд┐рд╡рд░реНрддреЗрдд “рдорд╣рд╛рдзрдиреЛ рд╜рд╕рд╛рд╡реН рдЕрднреВрдиреН рди рдЪрд╛рдиреНрдпреЗрди рд╕рдордВ рдкреНрд░рдпреБрдЬреНрдпрддреЗ,559” рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдВ рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрдпрд╛рдп рд╡рд┐рдЪрд╛рд░рдгреАрдпрдореН ред рд╡рд┐рд╖рд╛рдЧреНрдиреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рдГ рд╢рдкрдереИрд░реН рдирд╛рд░реНрджрдиреАрдпрдГ ред рдШрдЯрдХреЛрд╢рд╕рддреНрдпрддрдгреНрдбреБрд▓рд╛рд╕реН рддреБ рди рд╡рд┐рд░реБрдзреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рди рд╣рд┐ рддреЗ рдЕрддрд┐рдХреНрд▓реЗрд╢рдХрд░рд╛рдГ ред “рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрднрд╛рд╡реЗ” (рдореНрдзреН рео.резреореи) рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрддреНрд░ рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпреЛ рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕рдГ ред рдпрд╢реН рдЪ рддрдпреЛрд░реН рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕рдГ рд╕ рдЗрд╣рд╛рдкрд┐ рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╡реНрдпрдГ рее рео.резреорем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

It has been just declared that while the depositor is still alive, the deposit shall not be handed over to his тАШnext-of-kin.тАЩ But when he is dead, if the depositary should himself restore the property to his heir, who does not know that it belongs to him, then he shall not be made to undergo the trouble of a law-suit and all that follows in its wake.

If there be a suspicion that there may he something more with the man,тАФon the ground that the deceased was a wealthy man and he did not keep his property with any other person,тАФthen other kinds of evidence shall be considered, but the man shall not be harassed with oaths or ordeals with poison, etc.; though there would he nothing wrong in the employment of such test as the тАШghaс╣нako┼Ыa,тАЩ the тАШsatyataс╣Зс╕НulaтАЩ and so forth (which are not so humiliating).

The condition of тАШthe absence of witnessesтАЩ (mentioned in 182-183) should be taken as applicable here also.тАФ(186)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 87), whieh adds the following explanation:тАФOn the death of the depositor, if the depository deliver the deposit to the depositorтАЩs heir, he should not be blamed either by the king or by the dead manтАЩs relatives. The term тАШsvayamevaтАЩ implies that during the depositorтАЩs life-time, he should not deliver it to the heir, even though asked to do so by the latter;тАФand that on his death he should give it to the heir even without being asked to do so;тАФand in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 37).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

N─Бrada (11.10).тАФтАШThe depositor being dead, if the depositary restores the deposit to his next of kin of his own accord, he must not be harassed, either by the King or by the relations of the depositor.тАЩ

рдЕрд╡рд┐рджрд┐рддрдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрдВ рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдВ рдкреНрд░рдпрдЪреНрдЫрддреЛ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддреНрдпреН рдЕрднрд┐рдпреЛрдЧрдГ ред рдЕрде рддреВрджреНрднрд╛рд╡рдХрдГ рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрддреНрд░рд╛рд░реНрдердВ рджрд░реНрд╖рдпреЗрджреН (?) рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрдореН, рддрддрдГтАФ рее рео.резреорел рее

In doubtful cases he should try to obtain it without artifice and in a friendly manner; or having ascertained his character, he should settle the matter by gentle means.тАФ(187)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

(рдЕрдЧреНрд░реЗ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рдирдореНред)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

(This verse, as also the Bh─Бс╣гya on it is wanting in Mandalik, S, N and I. O.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАЬAccording to N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa, the verse refers to cases where one believes a deposit to be with another but has not made it over himself; according to Govindar─Бja and Kull┼лka, to cases where there may be error. Govindar─Бja and Kull┼лka think that the person who should act in the manner described is the king, and they explain тАШanvicchet by тАШhe should decide.тАЩ N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and R─Бghav─Бnanda, on the other hand, think that the depositor should act thus.тАЭтАФBuhler.

This verse has been omitted entirely by Medh─Бtithi; neither the verse nor its commentary is found in the Mss.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 94), according to which the verse refers to what the depositors should do; it means that тАШthe depository should keep the deposit honestly and lovingly; all the more so if the depositor is found to be a man of thoroughly good character.тАЩ

It is also quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 209), which says that this lays down what should be done by the successor of the depositor, if the depository does not of his own accord, surrender the deposit, after the depositorтАЩs death.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Bс╣Ыhaspati (12.14).тАФтАШWhen a dispute arises with regard to a deposit privately made, the performance of an ordeal is ordained for both parties, to establish the facts of the case.тАЩ

N─Бrada (2.11).тАФтАШThe rightful owner shall try to recover the deposit amicably, without resorting to stratagems. Or, he shall explore the depositaryтАЩs mode of living and cause him to restore it by friendly expostulations.тАЩ

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In the case of open deposits тАШthe method of restorationтАЩ shall be as just described in [verses 182 et seq.]

The depositary shall not incur the censure of the debtor, as regards the deposit to be restored.

This same rule should be applicable to the case where the article deposited has been destroyed by rats, etc. For instance, the article deposited having been wrapped up in a piece of cloth and placed in a wooden vessel, if rats, with their sharp teeth, should cut through the wood and devour the article,тАФit is no fault of the depositaryтАЩs. Then again, if the article is deposited in the form of a bundle sealed in a basket,тАФon account of its being such as cannot be contained in a wooden box,тАФthen also if it is eaten by rats, it is no fault of the depositaryтАЩs. This is specially so, if it is known to the depositor, who has been informed by the depositary that he possesses no wooden box (where the article would be safe from rats, etc.),тАФor if the depositor knows the manтАЩs character and is close by (and hence is in a position to know that the article has been really damaged by rats).тАФ(188).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

The second half of this verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 86), which adds the explanation that if the deposit has been handed over to the depository sealed,тАФthen, unless the latter extracts anything from it, he shall incur no blame; but if he does extract anything, then he certainly becomes open to censure. In the case of an unsealed deposition the other hand, even though he may have extracted something, if he delivers it before the depositor, he does not incur blame.

Bс╣Ыhaspati (12.15).тАФтАШThe same set of rules applies in the case of a bailment for delivery to a third party, a loan for use, an article made over to an artisan, a pledge and a person offering himself for protection.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.67).тАФтАШThe same law applies to the other forms of deposit- the Y─Бcita, the Anv─Бhita, the Ny─Бsa and the Nikс╣гepa.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШCarried away by waterтАЩтАФi.e., moved away from its place of keeping, to some other place.тАФ(189)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka, (p. 663), which adds that if out of the property, the man extracts not even a small part (then he shall not have to make it good);тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 88), which also addsтАФтАШif out of the deposited property, the depository does not extract, take out, anything;тАЩтАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 206), which addsтАФтАШif he extract even the smallest part of the deposit, then he shall have to make it good;тАЩтАФand in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 37), which says that in a case where the deposit-holder takes for himself a portion of the deposit and keeps the remainder secretly in some other place with a view to evade the return of the trust,тАФthen he is to be made to refund the entire deposit.

It is quoted in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (p. 83 a), which explains тАШtasm─Бt na saс╣ГharatiтАЩ as тАШdoes not take for himself any part of the deposit.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.66).тАФтАШThe depositary should not be made to pay anything, if the deposit has been taken away by the King, or by accidents or by thieves. When the depositor asks for it, if it is not restored, and is found to be lost, the depositary shall be made to pay its value and also a fine equal to it.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 663).тАФтАШWhere a deposit has been destroyed by anarchy or by accidents, it is held to have been lost to the depositor.тАЩ

N─Бrada (2.12).тАФтАШIf the deposit has been stolen by thieves, carried away by water, or burnt by fire, it need not he restored, unless the depositary should have appropriated some portion of it.тАЩ

N─Бrada (2.9).тАФтАШIf a deposit is lost, together with the property of the depositary, the loss shall he the depositorтАЩs. The same rule shall obtain if the loss has been caused by accidents or by the King; unless the depositary shall have acted fraudulently.тАЩ

Do. (2.8).тАФтАШIf the depositary derives profit from a deposit, by using it without the consent of the depositor, he shall be fined, and shall restore the profit with interest, to the depositor.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (12.10-12).тАФтАШWhen a deposit is destroyed, together with the goods of the depositary, by the act of God or of the King, the depositary is not to blame. If the depositary should suffer the deposit to be destroyed by his want of care or indifference, or should refuse to restore it on being asked for it, he shall he made to pay the value of it with interest. Should the depositary secure any advantage for himself through the article deposited with him, he shall be fined by the King and compelled to pay its value with the interest.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 663).тАФтАШIf the deposit has been destroyed by the fault of some one, that person should be made to pay the value of the deposit along with interest.тАЩ

The appropriator of a deposit, as also one who has not deposited anything (and yet asks for it),тАФthe king shall test by all methods, as also by means of oaths and ordeals prescribed in the scriptures.тАФ(190)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╣рд░рддрд┐ рдпреЛ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрддрдЕрдореН рдЕрд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдХрдореН, рдпреЛ рд╜рдкреНрдпреН рдЕрдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрдп562 рдиреАрддреНрд╡рд╛ рд╡рд╛ рдпрд╛рдЪрддреЗ рддрдореН рдЕрдиреНрд╡рд┐рдЪреНрдЫреЗрддреН ред рдЕрдиреНрд╡реЗрд╖рдгрд╛ рддрддреНрддреНрд╡рдкрд░рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдиреЗ рдпрддреНрдирдГ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкрд╛рд░реЗрдг ред рдЙрдкрд╛рдпрд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрд╛рдирд┐563 рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рджрдпреЛ рд╡рд╛ ред рддреЗрди рдЪрд▓рд┐рддрд╡реГрддреНрддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрд╛рджреНрдпрдорд╛рдирд╕реНрдп рддрд╛рдбрдирдмрдиреНрдзрдирд╛рджреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдорд╣рддрд┐ рдзрдиреЗ рдЪреЛрд░рд╡рддреН рддрддреНрддреНрд╡рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрддреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердВ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬреНрдпрдореН ред рди рддрддреНрддреНрд╡рд╛рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрдпреЗ рдирд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ ред рд╡реИрджрд┐рдХрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рд╕реНрддреБрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердореН рее рео.резрепреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

He who appropriates the deposit placed with him, in the absence of witnesses, and he who, having received it back, asks for it again,тАФboth these the king shall тАШtestтАЩ;тАФтАШtestingтАЩ stands for trying to find out the truth,тАФby employing тАШall methodsтАЩ;тАФтАШmethodsтАЩ stands for proofs. So that if the man is found to have fallen from the path of rectitude and denies the deposit,тАФthen recourse may he had to heating and imprisonment also; specially when the property involved is a large one, the same methods have to be employed as in the case of thieves. But no punishment shall lte inflicted if there is uncertainty in the matter.

The epithet тАШprescribed in the scripturesтАЩ has been added only by way of praise of the means to be employed.тАФ(190)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

рдЪреЛрд░рд╡рдЪреН рдЫрд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд┐рдГ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЗрдгреЛрдХреНрддрд╛ ред рддрдпрд╛ рдЪ рд╢рд░реАрд░рдирд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рд╕реН рддрддреНрд╕рдордзрдирдВ рд╡реИрдХрд▓реНрдкрд┐рдХреЗ566 рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рднреЗрджреЗрди рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд░ рдкреНрд░рджреЗрд╢ рдЙрдХреНрддреЛ рд╜рдиреЗрди рдирд┐рд╡рд░реНрддреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдкреБрдирд░реН рд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рдиреЗрди рдЪреЛрд░рд╡рдЪреНрдЫрд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд┐рд░реН рд╡рд╛рдЧреНрджрдгреНрдбрдзрд┐рдЧреНрджрдгреНрдбрд╛рджрд┐рд░реВрдкреИрд╡ рд╕рдореБрдЪреНрдЪреАрдпрддреЗ рдзрдирджрдгреНрдбреЗрди рдирд╛рдЩреНрдЧрдЪреНрдЫреЗрджрд╛рджрд┐рд░реВрдкрд╛ ред рди рдЪ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд┐ рд╡реИрдХрд▓реНрдкрд┐рдХреЗ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЗрдг рд╢рд╛рд░реАрд░рджрдгреНрдбреЗ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреЗ рддрдиреНрдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердВ рдкреБрдирд░реНрд╡рдЪрдирдореН рдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН, рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдпреЗрди рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдп рд╢рд░реАрд░рджрдгреНрдбрдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрд╛рддреН- “рди рдЬрд╛рддреБ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрдВ рд╣рдиреНрдпрд╛рддреН” (рдореНрдзреН рео.рейреореж) рдЗрддрд┐ ред

рдЙрдкрдирд┐рдзрд┐рдГ рдкреНрд░реАрддреНрдпрд╛ рдпрджреН рднреБрдЬреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЕрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЗрдг рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдВ рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рдВ рдЪ рдирд╛рдкреЗрдХреНрд╖реЗрдд567 ред

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдЕрдиреНрдпреИрд╕реН рддреВрдкрдирд┐рдзрд┐рдГ рдкрд░рд┐рднрд╛рд╖рд┐рддрдГ ред

рд╕ рддрддреНрд░реИрд╡ рдиреЗрд╣ ред рдкрд░рд┐рднрд╛рд╖рд╛рдпрд╛ рдЕрдХрд░рдгрд╛рд▓реН рд▓реМрдХрд┐рдХрд╛рд░реНрде рдПрд╡ рдЧреНрд░рд╣реАрддреБрдВ рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпреНрдпрдГ ред рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддрд┐ рдЪ “рдкреНрд░реАрддреНрдпреЛрдкрдирд┐рд╣рд┐рддрд╕реНрдп рдЪ” (рдореНрдзреН рео.резрепрем) рдЗрддрд┐ рее рео.резрепреи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The preceding verse has laid down the punishment to be like that of the thief; under that rule there are two alternativesтАФcorporeal punishment and fine equal in value to the property involvedтАФto he determined according to the caste of the accused. So that in the case of castes other than the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, it would, under the said rule, he open to the king to inflict either of the two forms of punishment. And it is this possibility that is precluded by the present verse, which restricts the punishment to fine only; so that from among the penalties inflicted on thieves, what may be added to the fine is only admonition or reprimand, and not mutilation and other corporeal punishments.

It will not be right to take the present verse as precluding corporeal punishment from the case of Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, who also would be subject to both kinds of alternative punishments sanctioned by the preceding verse. Because corporeal punishment has been already generally prohibited in the case of Br─Бhmaс╣Зas;тАФin such texts as тАШone shall not strike a Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩ (8.380).

тАШUpanidhiтАЩ here stands for what is used through friendship.

тАШIn all cases,тАЩтАФi.e., irrespectively of the nature of the property or the caste of the person involved.

Others have given a technical meaning to the term тАШupanidhiтАЩ; but that meaning is applicable elsewhere, not here. Because, in the absence of any convention, fixing the technical sense of a term, the right course is to take it in its ordinary sense. This same тАШupanidhiтАЩ is going to be mentioned again as тАШfriendly loanтАЩ (under 196).тАФ(192)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse appears to be a mere repetition of 191. According to Medh─Бtithi, 191 lays down two alternative punishmentsтАФcorporal punishment (thiefтАЩs penalty) and fine; and 192 excludes the тАШthiefтАЩs punishmentтАЩ by specifying the fine only. He repudiates the explanation that has been attributed to him by HopkinsтАФviz., 192 is for the sake of freeing the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa from the corporal punishment prescribed in 191. Nor is there anything in Medh─Бtithi to show that he takes 192 as referring to fresh offences,тАФa view that has been attributed to him by Buhler.тАФBoth these views are found in Kull┼лka.

тАШUpanidhiтАЩтАФтАШSealed depositтАЩ (Kull┼лka);тАФтАШsomething lent in a friendly spiritтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, who repudiates, in the present context, the technical meaning of тАШsealed deposit.тАЩ)

тАШAvi┼Ыeс╣гeс╣ЗaтАЩтАФтАШIrrespective of the character of the property or the caste of the personтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШirrespective of casteтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Nandana).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 92), which adds the following explanation:тАФThe reiteration of тАШfine equal in value to the depositтАЩ hereтАФto the exclusion of the тАШthiefs penalty,тАЩ with which it has been coupled in the preceding verse,тАФshould be understood as meant for the case where the misappropriator of the deposit is a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa. The terms тАШtath─БтАЩ and тАШavi┼Ыeс╣гeс╣ЗaтАЩ mean that all that has been said in regard to the misappropration of the deposit, should he understood to be applicable to that of the Upanidhi also,тАФthe misappropriation of both standing on the same footing.

It is quoted also in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 85);тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (83b);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 113a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШFraudulent means,тАЩ тАШdeceit,тАЩ and тАШpretenceтАЩ are synonymous terms: and this тАШfraudтАЩ is of several forms:тАФ(1) тАШaltering the thingтАЩ: having shown saffron, the man substitutes the kusumbha flower for it,тАФ(2) тАШusing short weights and measures,тАЩ and so forth. The rule regarding these forms of тАШfraudтАЩ is going to be laid down later on, under 203 et seq. The forms of тАШfraudulent moansтАЩ meant here areтАФ(a) тАШthreatening,тАЩ (b) promising rewards from the king, (e) promising to secure the love of a maiden, and so forth.

The man makes such false assertions to the other person asтАФ(a) тАШrobbers shall rob you, if I do not protect you,тАЩ or (b) тАШthe king was very angry with you, and I have tried much to appease him,тАЩ or (c) тАШI shall obtain for you from the king the post of the city-officer,тАЩ or (d) тАШI shall secure for you some other great benefit,тАЩ or (e) тАШmy daughter is very much in love with you and has sent you this presentтАЩ;тАФunder these pretexts he brings to the man some presents and takes away from him much more valuable things in return;тАФand in the presence of this other party he whispers something to the king, or to some other high official, and says to the manтАФтАШI have been talking regarding your business.тАЩ

The man who, by such fraudulent means, enjoys the property of others, for him the punishment is that he shall be punished тАШpubliclyтАЩтАФon the public roadтАФwith such тАШmodes of death,тАЩ as тАШdecapitation with the axe,тАЩ тАШimpalement,тАЩ тАШtramling (trambling?) by elephantsтАЩ and so forth.

Others have held, on the strength of the тАШcontext,тАЩ that what is said here pertains to the case of тАШDepositsтАЩ; in this sense the тАШfraudulent meansтАЩ would consist in putting off the restoration by such pretexts asтАФтАШI do not remember where I kept the thing,тАЩ тАШthe article was kept by another person, who is not here now, he shall come to-morowтАЩ and so forth; and the man who thus puts it off is said to тАШappropriateтАЩ it.тАФ(193)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 92), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШUpadh─Бbhiс╕е,тАЩ by fraud;тАФтАШsah─БyaтАЩ is one who helps in the misappropriation of otherтАЩs property by fraud;тАФтАШprak─Б┼ЫamтАЩ, in the public square and such places;тАФit is quoted again at p. 316;тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 39), which explains тАШupadh─БтАЩ as тАШfraudтАЩтАФтАШsah─БyaтАЩ as тАШabettor in the fraudulent appropriation,тАЩтАФand тАШvadhaтАЩ as тАШbeating, imprisonment and so forthтАЩ;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (84a).

рдп рдЗрддрд┐ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрдпрдорд╛рдгрджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдЬрд╛рддрд┐рдирд┐рд░реНрджреЗрд╢рдГ ред рдпрд╛рд╡рд╛рдиреН рдЗрддрд┐ рдкрд░рд┐рдорд╛рдгрд╕реНрдп ред рдп рдЖрд╣- “рд╕реБрд╡рд░реНрдгрдореН рдПрддрд╕реНрдп рд╣рд╕реНрддреЗ рдордпрд╛ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрддрдВ рдХрд╛рдВрд╕реНрдпрдВ рджрджрд╛рддрд┐, рд╢рддрдВ рдЪ рд╕реНрдерд╛рдкрд┐рддрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдзрдВ рджрджрд╛рддрд┐” ред рд╕ рдкреГрдЪреНрдЫреНрдпрддреЗ- “рдХрд┐рдВ рд░рд╣рд╕реНрдпреН рдЙрдд рдХрд╕реНрдпрдЪрд┐рддреН рд╕рдордХреНрд╖рдореН” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд╕ рдЪреЗрджреН рдЖрд╣- рдХреБрд▓рд╕рдВрдирд┐рдзреМ ред рдХреБрд▓рдВ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрдГ ред572 рддрддреНрд░ рддреЗ рдкреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛ рдпрджрд╛рд╣реБрд╕реН рддрджреН рдПрд╡ рд╕рддреНрдпрдореН ред рд╡рд┐рдмреНрд░реБрд╡рдиреН рд╡рд┐рд░реБрджреНрдзрдВ рдмреНрд░реБрд╡рд╛рдгреЛ рджрдгреНрдбреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдкрд┐ рдпрджрд┐ рдмреНрд░реВрдпрд╛рддреН рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рд╕рдордХреНрд╖рдВ рд░реВрдкреНрдпрдВ573 рддреИрд░реН рд╡рд┐рдирд╛рдиреНрдпрддреН рд╕реНрдерд╛рдкрд┐рддрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрд╕реНрддреНрдпреН рдЕрддреНрд░ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкрд╛рд░рдгрд╛рд╡рд╕рд░рдГ ред рдЕрдпрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЛ рдирд╛рдзрд┐рдХрд╡рд┐рдзреНрдпрд░реНрдердГ рее рео.резрепрек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШCertainтАЩ refers to the kind or quality of the substance, and тАШas muchтАЩ to its quantity, e.g., one party saysтАФтАШI had deposited gold with him and he is giving me back bell-metal; I had deposited a hundred and he is giving me only half of itтАЩ;тАФon being askedтАФтАЬDid you hand over the deposit in secret or before witnesses?тАЭтАФif he says тАШin the presence of a number of menтАЩтАФi.e., witnessesтАФthen what these men, on being questioned, should declare, should be regarded as the truth.

тАШMisrepresentingтАЩтАФi.e., asserting otherwise than this, the party is punished.

If however the complainant says that the deposit was not handed over in the presence of witnesses, there is an occasion for the admitting of other kinds of proof.

This verse also prescribes nothing new.тАФ(194)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 664), which explains тАШvibruvanтАЩ as тАШtelling what is not true;тАЩтАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 94), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШVibruvan,тАЩ declaring it to be more when it was less; from a parity of reasoning, it follows that if the depository also declares the deposit to be less where it was really more, he also should be fined;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (85a).

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

“рдпреЛ рдпрдерд╛ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреЗрддреН” (рдореНрдзреН рео.резреореж) рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреЗрди рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрддрд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд░реН рдЕрдпрдореН рдЙрдХреНрддрдГ574 ред рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗрд╖реБ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпреЗрд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреЗрди рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЛрдгрд╛рджрд╛рдиреЛрдкрдирд┐рдзрд┐рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпрд╛рджреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдпреЗрди рдпрд╛рджреГрд╢реЗрди рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд░реЗрдг рдХреГрддрдВ рддрд╛рджреГрд╢реЗрдиреИрд╡ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд░реНрдкрдгреАрдпрдореН ред рд░рд╣рд╕рд┐ рдХреГрддрд╕реНрдп рд░рд╛рдЬрдХреБрд▓реЗ рд╜рдВрд╢рдорд╛рд░реНрдЧрдгрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд╢рдирдВ рди рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рддреЗрди рд╕реНрд╡рд╣рд╕реНрддрд▓реЗрдЦреНрдпреЗрди рдЛрдгреЗ рдЧреГрд╣реАрддреЗ рди рд░рд╛рдЬрдХреБрд▓реЗ рд╜рдВрд╢рдВ рджрд╛рдкреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЙрддреНрддрдорд░реНрдгрдзрдирдВ рдХреНрд╖рдкрдгреАрдпрдореН ред

рдЕрдиреЗрдиреИрд╡ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкреЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзреЗ рддрддреНрд░ рдкреБрдирд░реНрд╡рдЪрдирдВ рдирд┐рддреНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред рддреЗрди рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд░ рд░рд╣рд╕рд┐ рдХреГрддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрддреНрддреНрдпрд╛рд╢рдЩреНрдХрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд╢рдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рджрд╛рдирдВ рдХрджрд╛рдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрд╕реНрддрд┐ ред рдЕрде рд╡реЗрд╣рд╛рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд╢рдХреГрддрд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд╢реАрдХрд░рдгрдВ рдирд┐рд╖рд┐рдзреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрддреНрд░ рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреНрдпреЛ рд╜рд░реНрдердГ рд╕рдореБрджреНрд░реЛ рд╜рд╕рдореБрджреНрд░ рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐ рддреЗрдирд╛рдкреМрдирд░реБрдХреНрддреНрдпрдореН ред

рдорд┐рдердГрд╢рдмреНрджреЛ рд░рд╣рд╕рд┐ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдГ ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рдкрд░рд╕реНрдкрд░рдВ рдорд┐рдердГ ред рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдВ рджреНрд╡рд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдВ рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдпрдВ рджрд╛рдирд╛рджрд┐ рдкрд░рд╕реНрдкрд░рдореН рдПрд╡ рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрдд рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдкреБрдирд░реНрд╡рдЪрдирдВ рддреГрддреАрдпрдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред рджрд╛рдпрд╢рдмреНрджрдГ рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдпрд╢рдмреНрджреЛ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╛рдиреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпрд╛рджреАрдиреН рдЖрд╣ рее рео.резрепрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Verse 180 has laid down the rule regarding deposits; and the present verse lays down what is to be done in the case of other transactions.

In the case of debts, friendly loans and sales, the restoration or repayment should be in the same manner in which it had been contracted. So that if it has been given privately, it should not be made public by seeking for re-payment through a court of justice; and when a loan has been given on the strength of a document written by the debtor alone, then its payment should not be sought for through court. If this were done, the creditorтАЩs property should be made to suffer.

The case of deposits also being covered by this same rule, the addition of a rule in regard to them separately is meant to indicate that in their case the rule is absolute; hence in the case of transactions other than deposits, when effected in private, if subsequently suspicion should arise regarding the possibility of dispute, it may he right and proper to make it public.

Or the repetition may he justified on the ground that what is done in the present verse is the prohibition of making public what has been done in private, while in the preceding verse what has been said concerns тАШsealed or open deposits.тАЩ

The term тАШmithaс╕етАЩ means тАШin private,тАЩ or тАШmutuallyтАЩ As all transactions are done between two parties, the addition of this adverb is meant to deny the presence of a third party.

тАШD─Бya,тАЩ тАШTrust,тАЩ though a generic term, stands here for transactions other than тАШdeposits,тАЩтАФsuch, for instance, as sale and the like.тАФ(195)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 113b), which has the following notes:тАФтАШD─Бya,тАЩ handing over, pledging, depositing,тАФтАШgraha,тАЩ receiving the deposit

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

N─Бrada (2.6).тАФтАШDeposits are of two kindsтАФattested and unattested. They must be restored precisely in the same condition in which they were delivered.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (12.5).тАФтАШA deposit is of two kindsтАФattested and deposited in private; it must be guarded with the same care as a son.тАЩ

Do. (12-14).тАФтАШWhen a dispute arises with regard to a deposit privately made, the performance of an ordeal is ordained for both parties, to establish the facts of the case.тАЩ

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгреЛрдкрд╕рдВрд╣рд╛рд░реЛ рд╜рдиреЗрди рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ ред рдкреНрд░реАрддреНрдпреЛрдкрдирд┐рд╣рд┐рддрд╕реНрдп рд╕реНрдиреЗрд╣реЗрди рдХрд┐рдВрдЪрд┐рддреН рдХрд╛рд▓рдВ рднреЛрдЧрд╛рд░реНрдердВ рджрддреНрддрд╕реНрдп, рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕реЛ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрд╕реН рддрд╕реНрдп рдзрд╛рд░рдгрдХреЛ рдпрдерд╛ рди рдкреАрдбреНрдпрддреЗ рддрдерд╛ рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрдГ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдп рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгреНрд╡рдиреНрдиреН рдЕрдкреАрдбрдпрдиреН ред

рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреНрд░рд╛рдГ[^ремрезреп] рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрд╛ рдирд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрдХрд░рдгреЗ рд╡рд┐рдзреНрдпрд░реНрдерд╛рдГ ред рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддрдГ рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдВ рд╕реМрд╣рд╛рд░реНрджреЗрдиреЛрдХреНрддрдореН[^ремреиреж] рее рео.резрепрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This verse sums up the section.

тАШWhat is given as friendly loanтАЩтАФi.e., what is given, through friendship, for being used for some time.

The cases have to be decided in such a way as noс╣н to cause injury to the keeper of the pledge or deposit. тАШAkс╣гiс╣ЗvanтАЩтАФwithout causing injury to.

In the whole of this section on тАШdepositsтАЩ only two or three verses are mandatory in their character, all the rest is purely commendatory,тАФmentioning things already known, in a friendly spirit.тАФ(196)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The text now proceeds to deal with the head of dispute called тАШSale without Ownership.тАЩ

The тАШpropertyтАЩтАФarticlesтАФthat belongs to another person,тАФif a person, who is not the ownerтАФi.e., who is not the son or any such relative of the owner,тАФand who has not obtained the consent of the owner,тАФтАШsells,тАЩтАФhim the judge shall regard as a тАШthiefтАЩ; though the person who buys it from him may not regard him as a thief.

Him the judge тАШshall not admit as a witness,тАЩтАФ shall not call him as a witness; because he is just like a thief; and being a thief, he is not fit for being called as a witness.

The present exclusion is meant to be, not only from being called as a witness, but from all such acts as are to be done by a gentleman.

When a property is sold by one who is not its owner, without the consent of the real owner, it does not become the property of the buyer;тАФthis fact being already known, the forbidding of such a transaction by means of asserting that such a person is not fit for being called as a witness, is meant to be only a diversified way of saying thingsтАФ(197)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЗрдг рд╕рд╛рдзреБрдЬрдирдХрд░реНрддреГрдХрд╛рд╕реБ рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рд╕реБ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдЕрд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрдХрд╛рд░рд┐рдгрд╛рдореН рдЕрдирд░реНрд╣рддреЛрдХреНрддрд╛ ред рдЕрдиреЗрди рд╖рдЯреНрд╢рддреЛ рджрдгреНрдб рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╖рдЯреНрдХрд╛рд░реНрд╖рд╛рдкрдгрд╢рддрд╛рдирд┐ рдЕрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реНрдпреЛ рджрд╛рдкрдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпреЛ рджрдгреНрдбреНрдп рдЗрддрд┐ рдпрд╛рд╡рддреН ред рд╕рд╛рдиреНрд╡рдпрдГ ред рдЕрдиреНрд╡рдпреЛ рд╜рдиреБрдЧрдордирд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдГ ред рд╕ рдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рдкреБрддреНрд░рднреНрд░рд╛рддреНрд░рд╛рджрд┐рдГ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдиреЛ рд╜рдиреБрдЧрддрдГ рд╕рд╛рдиреНрд╡рдпрдГ ред рд╕ рд╣реНрдпреН рдЕрдирдиреБрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рддреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реАрдгрд╛рдиреЛ рди рд╕реНрдлреБрдЯрдЪреЛрд░реЛ рдпрддрд╕реН рддрд╕реНрдпреЗрдпрдВ рдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рд░реН рдорджреАрдпрдореН рдПрд╡реИрддрджреН рдпрддреН рдкрд┐рддреБрд░реН рдЗрддрд┐, рддрдВ рдкреНрд░рддреАрдпрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕рдВрднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рддрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реАрдп рдореВрд▓реНрдпрдВ рджрджрд╛рддрд┐ ред рдпрд╕реН рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд╛рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдГ рд╕ рдирд┐рд░рдиреНрд╡рдпрдГ ред рдЪреМрд░рдХрд┐рд▓реНрдмрд┐рд╖рдВ рдирд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдВ рдирд┐рдГрд╕рдВрд╢рдпрдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрдГ ред рдЕрдирдкрд╕рд░рдГ ред рдпрджрд┐ рддрджреНрдЧреГрд╣рдВ рддрд╕реНрдп рдирд╛рдкрд╕реГрддрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ рддрджреНрдЖрдирдкрд╕рд░рд╢реН рдЪреМрд░рд╡рджреН рджрдгреНрдбреНрдпрдГ ред рдпрджрд┐ рддреБ рддрджреНрдЧреГрд╣рд╛рджреН рдПрд╡ рдХреЗрдирдЪрд┐рджреН рджрддреНрддрдВ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реАрддрдВ рд╡рд╛ рддрд╕реНрдп рддреЗрди рд╡рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН576 рддрддреНрдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЧреГрд╣реАрддрдВ рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд╢рдХреНрд░рдпреЗрдг рд╡рд╛ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реАрддрдВ рддрджрд╛ рди рдЪреМрд░рд╡рджреН рджрдгреНрдбреНрдпрдГ ред рд╖рдЛрд╢рддрдореН рдПрд╡реН рджрд╛рдкреНрдпрдГ ред

рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рдЕрдиреНрд╡рдпреЛ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реАрдгрд╛рддрд┐ рддрд╕реНрдп рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реЗрдпрджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреНрдпрддрдГ рдХреНрд░рдпрдГ рдЕрдкрд╕рд░рдГ рдХреНрд░рдпрд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рд╛рджрд┐рд░реН рдЖрдЧрдордГ ред рдПрддрджреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рдпрджрд┐ рддреЗрди рддрдиреН рди рдХреБрддрд╢реНрдЪрди рдХреГрдИрддрдВ рдирд╛рдкрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЧреГрд╣рд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд▓рдмреНрджрдВ рддрджрд╛ рдЪреМрд░рдГ рее рео.резрепрео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The preceding verse has declared that the man who sells the property of another person is not fit to be admitted to any transaction done by gentlemen, such as the giving of evidence and so forth; and the present verse prescribes for him the penalty of the fine of six hundred. He shall be made to payтАФfinedтАФsix hundred coins.

тАШIf a relative,тАЩ тАШs─БnvayaтАЩ;тАФтАШanvayaтАЩ means relation; he who has some relationship is a тАШrelative,тАЩтАФsuch as the son, the wife, the brother and so forth. If such a relative, even though not actually permitted to sell, sells a property, he is not quite a thief; for he is likely to have the idea тАШif it belongs to my father, it is mineтАЩ; and in his case it is likely that he will hand over the sale-proceeds to the rightful owner.

The man who has absolutely no relationship with the owner is said to be тАШnot a relative,тАЩ тАШniranvayaс╕етАЩ; and such a person тАШincurs the guilt of a thiefтАЩтАФi.e., deserves to be punished as such, undoubtedly. Specially so if he is тАШnot one having accessтАЩ; i.e., if he has no free access to the household of the owner, he should certainly be punished as a thief. If, on the other hand, the property sold by him has been obtained from the household itself,тАФhaving been given or sold by some one in the house,тАФand he has received it through ignorance or folly,тАФor if he has bought it in an open sale,тАФthen he shall not be punished as a thief; he shall only be fined six hundred.

Or the term тАШapasara,тАЩ тАШaccess,тАЩ may be taken as standing for modes of acquisition other than purchase,тАФsnoh as gift and the like. The meaning thus isтАФтАШHe is to be regarded as a thief, if he has not purchased it from anyone, nor acquired it through gift or other modes of acquisition.тАЩтАФ(198)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 103), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШAvah─Бryo bhavet,тАЩ should be fined;тАФтАШsv─Бnvayaс╕етАЩ (which is its reading for тАШs─Бnvayaс╕етАЩ) a son or some relation of the rightful owner;тАФтАШс╣гaс╣н┼Ыatam,тАЩ six hundred paс╣Зas;тАФтАШniranvayaс╕е,тАЩ not related to the rightful owner;тАФтАШanapasaraс╕е,тАЩ means the removing of the property from the ownerтАЩs house;тАФand the man who does this and sells what belongs to another should be fined six hundred paс╣Зas. If this seller is not a relative of the owner,тАФand if the removing of the property from the ownerтАЩs house has been done, not by any person related to the owner, but by the seller himself,тАФthen he should be punished like a thief. If however the removing has been done by some one else, but the selling is done by the ownerтАЩs relative, then the fine may be even more than six hundred paс╣Зas.тАФThe author of

Kalpataru has explained тАШapasaraтАЩ as the justification for moving the article from the ownerтАЩs possessionтАФsuch as its being a gift and so forth by which property moves away from the ownerтАЩs possession (apasarati anena); and he who has no such justification is тАШanapasaraтАЩ; and this writer adds that this view has the support of Bh─Бguri, Medh─Бtithi and the Vс╣Ыttik─Бra.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 41) which has the following notes:тАФтАШAvah─Бryaс╕е,тАЩ should be made to give up,тАФтАШs─Бnvayaс╕етАЩ belonging to the family of the owner of the property concerned,тАФтАШniranvayaс╕е,тАЩ not a member of the ownerтАЩs family,тАФтАШanapasaraс╕е,тАЩ тАШwho has not received the property by any equitable method of acquisition, such as gift and the likeтАЩтАФтАШс╣гaс╣н┼Ыatam,тАЩ he is to be fined 600 paс╣Зas;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (85b), which explains тАШavah─Бryaс╕етАЩ as тАШshould be made to payтАФтАШs─Бnvayaс╕етАЩ, as тАШalong with his brothers and relatives,тАЩтАФтАШс╣гaс╣н┼Ыatam,тАЩ i.e., 600 paс╣Зas.тАФIt goes on to say what has been quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (above).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

(verses 8.198-199)

Artha┼Ы─Бstra (p. 95).тАФтАШWhen the rightful owner has found the article that he had lost or which had been stolen from him, he shall have the man in possession of it arrested by the Judge. If the exigencies of time and place do not permit of this procedure, he may himself arrest the man and take him to the Judge;тАФthe Judge shall ask the man in possession тАФFrom where did you obtain this thing? If the man explains the manner of his acquisition, but fails to produce the man who had sold it to him, he should be let off after he has surrendered the property; if the vendor is produced, the vendor should he made to pay the price obtained to the purchaser, and also a penalty for theft.тАЩ

N─Бrada (7.4, 5).тАФтАШThe purchaser must not make a secret of the way in which he came by a chattel purchased by him. He becomes free from blame if he can point out the way in which the chattel was acquired by him. In any other case, he is equally guilty with the vendor and shall suffer the punishment of a thief. The vendor shall restore the property to the rightful owner, and shall pay to the purchaser the price for which he had sold it; besides that, he shall pay a fine to the King.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (13.3, 4).тАФтАШWhen the vendor has been produced and cast in the suit, the judge shall make him pay the price to the buyer and a fine to the King, and to restore the property to the owner. When the former owner comes forward and makes good his claim to the thing sold, the vendor shall be produced by the purchaser, who thereupon becomes cleared.тАЩ

Vy─Бsa (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 202).тАФтАШWhen the purchaser has shown the person from whom he had purchased the article, he shall not be blamed in any way; after that, the dispute shall he between that person and the rightful owner of the lost article.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.168, 169, 170).тАФтАШIf oneтАЩs property has been sold by another person, the property shall be restored to him; the purchaser becomes guilty if he cannot produce the seller; and he shall be dealt with as a thief, if he bought the thing either in secret, or at a very low price, or at an improper time. If a man comes by his property that had been lost or stolen, he should have the possessor arrested; or if the time or place does not permit of this, he shall arrest him himself and produce him before the court; the man becomes absolved from blame on producing the seller; and from the seller, the owner recovers his property,тАФthe purchaser, the price that he had paid, and the King, a fine.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (13.11)тАФтАШThat should be regarded as Fraudulent Purchase which is made at an unreasonably low price, or in the interior of a house, or outside of the village, or at night, or in secret, or from a dishonest person.тАЩ

рди рдХреЗрд╡рд▓рдореН рдЕрд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рд╕рдХрд╛рд╢рд╛рджреН рдпрддреН рдХреНрд░реАрддрдВ рддрдиреН рди рд╕рд┐рдзреНрдпрддрд┐, рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЧреГрд╣реАрддрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ ред рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣реЗрдг рдкреНрд░реАрддреНрдпрд╛ рд╡рд╛ рджрд╛рдирдВ рджрд╛рдпрдГ, рд╕реЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рди рд╕рд┐рдзреНрдпрддрд┐ ред “рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реАрдгреАрддреЗ рдкрд░рд╕реНрдп” (рдореНрдзреН рео.резрепрен) рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреЗрди рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реЗрддреБрдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣реАрддреБрд╢реН рдЪрд╛рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореНрдпрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред “рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореА рд░рд┐рдХреНрдердХреНрд░рдп” (рдЧреНрдзреН резреж.рейреп) рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореНрдпрд╛рд╢рдЩреНрдХрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреЛ рд╜рдпрдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░ рдПрд╖рд╛ рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд┐рд░реН рдирд╛рддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдордгреАрдпрд╛ рее рео.резрепреп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

It is not only purchase from one who is not the owner that is invalid,тАФbut also what is received as тАШgiftтАЩтАФa тАШgiftтАЩ is that which is given either as charity or as a friendly present,тАФis not valid.

Verse 197 has declared that neither the buyer nor the seller is the owner of the property; and the present verse denies the ownership in cases where it may be considered as having been acquired, in accordance with the law thatтАФтАШone becomes the owner, through inheritance, purchase, partition and giftтАЩ (Gautama, 10.39).

Such is the rule of judicial proceedings, and it should not be transgressed.тАФ(199)

This verse is quoted (as N─БradaтАЩs) in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 40);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (86a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In a case where, in connection with such things as cattle, gold, lands and so forth, one man is found to have тАШpossession,тАЩтАФwhile the тАШtitle,тАЩ arising from inheritance, gift and other sources, indicates the ownership of another man,тАФit is тАШtitleтАЩ that is to be regarded as more authoritative; and mere possession is no proof of ownership.

тАШSuch is the settled rateтАЩ;тАФthe eternal rule is that mere possession does not create ownership; what sort of possession does create ownership has been explained before, under verse 147; and the seeming incompatibility of the present verse with that has also been explained under that same verse.тАФ(200)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 635), which says that what is meant is that what proof of ownership is, not mere possession, but possession accompanied by тАШtitleтАЩтАФi.e., something that indicates actual ownership.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.171).тАФтАШBy title and by possession shall the rightful owner establish his claim to a lost property; if he fails to establish his claim, he shall be fined; he should be made to pay a fine the fifth part of the value of the article concerned.тАЩ

If a man obtains a property from the market, in the presence of witnesses, he acquires that property with a clear title obtained by legal purchase.тАФ(201)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдпрд╛рджреГрд╢реЗрди рдХреНрд░рдпреЗрдг рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореНрдпрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ рддрдВ рджрд░реНрд╢рдпрддрд┐ ред рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реАрдгрддреЗ рд╜рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рд┐рдг рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпрдГ рдЖрдкрдгрднреВрдорд┐рдГ, рддрддреЛ рдпреЛ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрдпрд╛рджреН рдзрдирдВ рдЧрд╡рд╛рджрд┐ рдХреНрд░реАрдпрдорд╛рдгрдВ рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдВ рдореВрд▓реНрдпрдВ рд╡рд╛ рд╕ рд▓рднрддреЗ рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпрддрдГ рдХреНрд░рдпреЗрдг ред рдХреБрд▓рд╕рдВрдирд┐рдзреМ рд╡рд┐рд╢реБрджреНрдзрдореН ред рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпрддрдГ рдХреНрд░рдп рдЙрдЪрд┐рддреЗрди рдореВрд▓реНрдпреЗрди ред рдЕрд╕рдВрднрд╛рд╡реНрдпрдкрд╛рдкрдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╛рдХреБрд▓рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреНрдпрд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд░реНрддреГрдореЗрд▓рдХрдХрд╛рд░рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╕рдореВрд╣рд╕реНрдп рд╕рдордХреНрд╖рдВ рдЧреГрд╣реАрддрдВ рд▓рднрддреЗ рдирд╛рдкрд╣рд╛рд░рдпрддрд┐ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдирд╛ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпреЗ1 рддреБ рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдиреАрдпрддреЗ2, рдХрд┐рдВ рддреБ рдореВрд▓реНрдпрдВ рд▓рднрддреЗ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдпрд╕реН рддрд╕реНрдп рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпреА рд╕реЛ рд╜рдиреНрдпрдпрддрдГ3 рдХреНрд░рдпреЗрдг рддреБ рджрдгреНрдбреНрдпрддреЗ рдореВрд▓реНрдпрдВ рдЪ рд╣рд╛рд░рдпрддрд┐ ред рдПрддрджреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН ред

  • рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реЗрддреБрд░реН рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рдЪреН рдЫреБрджреНрдзрд┐рдГ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореА рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдВ рдиреГрдкреЛ рджрдордореН ред

  • рдХреНрд░реЗрддрд╛ рдореВрд▓реНрдпрдореН рдЕрд╡рд╛рдкреНрдиреЛрддрд┐ рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдпрд╕реН рддрд╕реНрдп рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпреА рее (рдпреНрдзреН реи.резренрек)

рдПрд╖ рдПрд╡рд╛рд░реНрдердУ рд╜рдиреЗрди4 рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЗрди рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрд╛рджреНрдпрддреЗ рее рео.реирежрез рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The present verse shows by what sort of purchase real ownership is produced.

тАШVikraya,тАЩ тАШmarket,тАЩ is the place where people sell their goods. If one obtains from the market, some property,тАФgoods put up for sale, in the shape of cattle and the rest,тАФor the price is paid for it,тАФтАШhe acquires itтАЩтАФ by тАШlegal purchase,тАЩ by paying the proper price,тАФтАШin the presence of witnessesтАЩтАФin the shape of intermediaries and brokers; and thus тАШhe acquires it,тАЩ and does not forfeit it. If the thing has been purchased from one who is not the rightful owner of it, then the property is restored to the rightful owner, and the bonafide purchaser obtains the price he had paid from the person who had sold it to him. In the event of his purchase being not bonafide, he is punished and also forfeits the property. This is what is thus assertedтАФтАШThe purchaser proves his bonafides by producing the seller, the rightful owner receives the property, and the king receives the fine paid by the seller, the purchaser receives back the price he had paid from the purchaserтАЩ (Yaj├▒avalkya, 2.170).

This same idea is set forth in the present verse.тАФ(201)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 103), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШVikray─Бt,тАЩ from the market-place;тАФтАШKulasannidhau,тАЩ in the presence of trustworthy traders and brokers;тАФтАШNy─Бyataс╕е,тАЩ qualifies тАШkrayeс╣ЗaтАЩ;тАФтАШvi┼Ыuddhaс╕етАЩ (which is its reading for тАШvi┼Ыuddham,тАЩ) faultless;тАФтАШlabhate dhanamтАЩ, i.e., from the seller;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (85b), which has the following notes:тАФтАШVikray─Бt,тАЩ тАШfrom the тАШmarket place,тАЩ the word being explained as тАШvikr─лyate asmin iti vikrayaс╕е,тАЩтАФтАШkulasannidhau,тАЩ in the presence of a number of business-men,тАФтАШny─Бyataс╕етАЩ is to be construed with тАШkrayeс╣Зa,тАЩ and means a bona fide purchase, on payment of the proper price.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Bс╣Ыhaspati (13.7, 8, 10).тАФтАШWhen a purchase has been made before an assembly of merchants, the kingтАЩs officers also being aware of it,тАФbut from a vendor whose habitation is unknown, or when the purchaser is dead,тАФthe owner may recover his own property by paying half the price tendered; the custom in that case being that one half of the value is lost to each of the two parties. When a man purchases a commodity at a fair price, and the purchase has been announced to the King, there is no wrong about it.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (12.3, 4).тАФтАШWhen the vendor has been produced and has been cast in the suit, the judge shall cause him to pay the price to the buyer, a fine to the King, and to restore the property to the owner. When the former owner comes forward and makes good his claim to the article purchased, the vendor shall be produced by the purchaser; by doing so, the purchaser may clear himself.тАЩ

N─Бrada (7.2-5)тАФтАШNo blame attaches to a sale effected in public; but a clandestine sale is viewed in the same light as theft, according to law. The purchaser must not make a secret of the way in which he came by a chattel purchased by him. He becomes free from blame if he can point out the way in which the chattel was acquired by him. In any other case he is equally guilty with the vendor, and shall suffer the punishment of a thief. The vendor shall restore the property to the rightful owner, and shall pay to the buyer the price for which it was sold to him; besides that, he shall pay a fine to the King.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпрддрд╕реН рддреБ рдХреНрд░рдпрдГ рдХреБрд▓рд╕рдВрдирд┐рдзрд╛рд╡реН рдЙрдЪрд┐рддреЗрди рдореВрд▓реНрдпреЗрди рд╕рдВрднрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЪреН рдЪ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╛рддреН ред рдПрддрдЪреН рдЪ рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдирднрд┐рдпреЛрдЧрдВ рдзрдирд▓рд╛рднрд╢реН рдЪ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рдпрд┐рддрд╛рдп рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпрдХрд╛рд░рд┐рдгрдГ рее рео.реирежреж рее

B├╝hler

201 He who obtains a chattel in the market before a number (of witnesses), acquires that chattel with a clear legal title by purchase.
