рдЕрде рдореВрд▓рдореН рдЕрдирд╛рд╣рд╛рд░реНрдпрдВ
рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд╢рдХреНрд░рдпрд╢реЛрдзрд┐рддрдГ ред
рдЕрджрдгреНрдбреНрдпреЛ рдореБрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрд╛
рдирд╛рд╖реНрдЯрд┐рдХреЛ рд▓рднрддреЗ рдзрдирдореН рее рео.реирежреи рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If the source cannot be traced, the person (buyer), whose conduct has been cleared by the fact of the sale being public, is let off without punishment, but the man who lost the property shall receive it back.тАФ(202)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЕрд╕рдВрднрд╛рд╡реНрдпрдкрд╛рдкрд╛рддреН рддреБ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╛рджреН рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐ рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпрддрдГ рдХреНрд░рдп рдЙрдХреНрддрдГ ред рд╕ рдЪреЗрджреН рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реЗрдд рд╢рдХреНрдп рдЖрд╣рд░реНрддреБрдВ рддрджрд╛ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЛрдХреНрддреЛ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдГ “рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореА рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдореН” (рдпреНрдзреН реи.резренрек) рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐ ред рдЕрде рд╕ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпреА рдЧрддрдГ, рдпреЗрди5 рдХреНрд░реАрддрдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рдирд╛ рдЪрд┐рд╣реНрдиреАрдХреГрддрдВ рддреЗрди рдЪ рдореВрд▓рдВ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реЗрддрд╛ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖ рдЖрд╣рд░реНрддреБрдВ рди рд╢рдХреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд╢рдВ рдЬрдирд╕рдордХреНрд╖рдВ рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрд╛рдпрд╛ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпрднреБрд╡рдГ рдХреНрд░реАрддрдореН рдЕрдд рдИрджреГрд╢реЗрди рдХреНрд░рдпреЗрдг рд╢реЛрдзрд┐рддреЗ рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпреЗ рд╢реБрджреНрдзрдГ рдХреНрд░реЗрддрд╛ рдЕрджрдгреНрдбреНрдпреЛ рдореБрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдзрдирдВ рддреБ рдирд╛рд╖реНрдЯрд┐рдХрдГ6 рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореА рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдкрд┐рддрд╕реНрд╡рдВ рд╡рд╛ рд▓рднрддреЗ ред рдирд╖реНрдЯрдореН рдЕрдиреНрд╡реЗрд╖рддреЗ рдирд╛рд╖реНрдЯрд┐рдХрдГ ред рдирд╖реНрдЯрдореН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╕реНрддреАрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡рдВ рдардирд┐ рдХреГрддреЗ рдкреНрд░рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рджрд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рд░реНрдерд┐рдХреЛ рд╜рдгреН рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рдирд╖реНрдЯрдВ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирдореН рдЕрд╕реНрдпреЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд╛ ред рддреЗрдирд╛рдпрдВ рд╕рдВрдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрдГ-7 рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд╢рдХреНрд░рдпреЗ рддреБ рджрдгреНрдбреЛ рди рд╕реНрдпрд╛рджреН рдзрдирдирд╛рд╢рд╕реН рддреБ рд╕реНрдерд┐рдд рдПрд╡ рее рео.реирежреи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

It has been laid down that purchases shall be made from persons not suspected of dishonesty; hence where the seller is capable of being produced, the rule just quoted becomes applicable; but if the m in having sold the property goes away,тАФand тАШthe source,тАЩтАФthe sellerтАФcannot be produced by the man who bought from him the property that is now recognised by its real owner as his own,тАФthen the purchaser has his character cleared by the fact that he made the purchase in the open market,тАФin the presence of a large number of men; and on that account he is let off without punishment.

But the property is restored to the rightful owner, тАШthe person who had lost itтАЩ and then recognised it as his own.

The term тАШn─Бс╣гс╣нikaс╕етАЩ means he who has lost, derived from the participial noun тАШnaс╣гс╣нaтАЩ with the possessive affix тАШс╣нhanтАЩ and then the reflexive affix тАШaс╣ЗтАЩ; or it may be explained as meaning тАШhe who is seeking for his lost property.тАЩ

The sense in brief is this:тАФIn the case of a public sale, there is to be no punishment, but the loss of the price paid remains.тАФ(202).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 103), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШM┼лlam,тАЩ the original seller, who sold the article which did not belong to him;тАФif he is тАШan─Бh─БryaтАЩ, incapable of being produced by the purchaser, by reason of his being in a foreign country;тАФbut the purchaser is one who had made his purchase openly,тАФthen this latter is not to be punished;тАФbut the actual owner shall receive back his property which had been fraudulently sold.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 87), which reading тАШan─Бh─БryaтАЩ for тАШan─Бh─БryamтАЩ, explains it as тАШnot producing;тАЩтАФthe meaning being тАШeven though the buyer is unable to produce the original seller, if his purchase is found to be bona fide by reason of its having been done in public.тАЩ

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka, (p. 776), which adds the following explanation:тАФтАШM┼лlamтАЩ is the original seller;тАФif he is incapable of being produced by reason of his whereabouts being unknown.

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 215), which adds that the rightful owner is to receive his property from the purchaser, only on paying to him one half of the price that had been paid for it;тАФthis opinion being based upon a clear declaration to that effect by K─Бty─Бyana;тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 43), which adds the following explanation:тАФтАШWhere the selling has been done openly,тАФand yet the original owner proves his claim to the property concerned,тАФand the property concerned is not returnable, by reason of its having been exported to foreign lands, and so forthтАФthen the bona fide purchaser is not to be punished, but he is to be made to refund the price to the real ownerтАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (86a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

(See the texts under [verses 198-199] and [verse 201].)

Viс╣гс╣Зu (5.164-165).тАФтАШHe who buys unawares in open market the property of a person other than the rightful owner is not to blame; but the owner shall recover his property.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.169-170).тАФ(See under 198-199.)

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 176).тАФтАШOne should make a purchase and pay its price openly.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

Any commodity that is mixed up with another should not be sold; nor what is without substance, nor what is deficient, nor what is at a distance, nor what is concealed.тАФ(203).

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЕрд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рд╡рд┐рдХрд░реНрдпрдкреНрд░рд╕рдЩреНрдЧреЗрдирд╛рдиреНрдпреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпреЗ рдзрд░реНрдо рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдирд╛рдиреНрдпрддреН10 рдХреБрдВрдХреБрдорд╛рджрд┐рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдВ рдХреБрджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпреЗрдг рддрджрд╛рднрд╛рд╕реЗрди рдХреБрд╕реБрдВрднрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрдВ рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реЗрдпрдореН ред рдпрдЪреН рдЪ11 рдЕрд╕рд╛рд╡рджреНрдпрдВ рдЪрд┐рд░рдХрд╛рд▓рдВ рднрдгреНрдбреЗ рд╜рд╡рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд╡рд┐рднрд╛рд╡рдВ рдЬреАрд░реНрдгрдореН рдЕрдЬреАрд░реНрдгрд╛рднрд╛рд╕рдВ рд╡рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рджрд┐ ред рди рдЪ рдиреНрдпреВрдирдВ рддреБрд▓рд╛рдорд╛рдирд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ ред рджреВрд░реЗ12** **рджреВрд░рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрдВ рдЧреНрд░рд╛рдореЗ рдордо рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ рд╡рд╛рд╕рд╛рдВрд╕рд┐ рдЧреБрдбрд╛рджрд┐ рд╡рд╛ рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рддрд┐рд░реЛрд╣рд┐рддрдВ рд╕реНрдердЧрд┐рддрдВ рд╡рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛рдиреНрддрд░реНрд╣рд┐рддрдореН, рдпрд╕реНрдп рд╡рд╛ рд╕реНрд╡рд░реВрдкрдВ рдХреЗрдирдЪрд┐рджреН рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрд░рд╛рдЧреЗрдгрд╛рдиреНрддрд░реНрдзреАрдпрддреЗ рдкреБрд░рд╛рдгрдВ рдирд╡рд╡рддреН рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднрд╛рддрд┐ рддрддреН рддрд┐рд░реЛрд╣рд┐рддрдВ рди рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реЗрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рдЗрджрдВ рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдореН рдИрджреГрд╢рдВ рдЪ рдкреНрд░рджрд░реНрд╢реНрдп рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпрдГ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛рдХреГрддрд╕реН рддреБ рди рдХреГрддреЛ рджрд╢рд╛рд╣рд╛рджреН рдКрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд░реНрдкрдгреЗ рди рджреЛрд╖рдГ ред

  • рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдп рджрдгреНрдбрд╕реНрдпреЗрд╣рд╛рдирд╛рдореНрдирд╛рддрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН “рдЙрдкрдзрд╛рднрд┐рдГ” (рдореНрдзреН рео.резрепрей) рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╖ рджрдгреНрдбрдГ ред

рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрднреЗрджреЗрди рдкрдард┐рддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН, рдЕрд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпрджрдгреНрдб рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рее рео.реирежрей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In course of the treatment of тАШSale without Ownership,тАЩ the author proceeds to lay down other rules also in connection with sales.

тАШAny commodityтАЩтАФsuch as saffronтАФтАШthat is mixed up with anotherтАЩтАФcommodity, which is of an inferior quality, and which is only similar to itтАФsuch as the kusumbha flowerтАФтАШshould not he sold.тАЩ

тАШNor what is without substanceтАЩтАФi.e., which, having been kept closed in a vessel for a long time, has lost its substance, has become defective and decays, though appearing as fresh; e.g., cloth and other commodities.

тАШNor what is deficientтАЩ;тАФi.e., less in weight or measure.

тАШNor what is at a distanceтАЩтАФaway from the place of sale; and described as тАШclothes or sugar or such things lying in my house in the village.тАЩ

тАШNor what is concealedтАЩтАФtied up and hidden in a piece of cloth; or the real form of which is hidden by the colour of another substance; what is old but appears to be new is also called тАШconcealed.тАЩ

Commodity of these kinds should not be sold; it shall be sold after having been fully exposed and described; sales effected otherwise are invalid; and there would be nothing wrong in such being revoked even after the lapse of ten days.

Since no penalty in connection with this is here prescribed, it shall be understood to be what has been laid down in 193 in connection with тАШfraudulent transactionsтАЩ in general.

Others, however, hold that since that penalty is laid down in another context, that in connection with what is referred to here must he what has been prescribed for тАШselling without ownership.тАЩтАФ(203)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШTirohitamтАЩтАФтАШConcealedтАЩтАФтАШin cloth or some such coverтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi and N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa),тАФтАШin the earthтАЩ (Nandana),тАФтАШcovered with paintтАЩ (Govindar─Бja, Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 199), which reads saс╣Гsс╣Ыс╣гс╣нam r┼лpam for тАШsaс╣Гsс╣Ыс╣гс╣нar┼лpamтАЩ and adds the following notes:тАФтАШAnyatтАЩ, saffron and such costly tilings,тАФтАШanyenaтАЩ the Kusumbha flower and such cheaper tilings,тАФтАШsaс╣Гsс╣Ыс╣гс╣нam,тАЩ adulterated,тАФтАШr┼лpam,тАЩ commodity,тАФтАШs─Бvadyam,тАЩ defective,тАФthis last is meant to include all defects other than those just specified;тАФтАШny┼лnam,тАЩ less in weightтАФтАШdure,тАЩ being at a distance and hence incapable of having its defects detected,тАФтАШtirohitam,тАЩ covered by cloth or some such thing;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (110a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.245).тАФтАШIn the sale of medicines, oils, salts, perfumes, grains, molasses and such things, if the vendor mixes inferior stuff, he shall be fined 16 Paс╣Зas.тАЩ

Katy─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 776).тАФтАШOne should make a purchase and pay its price openly.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

203 One commodity mixed with another must not be sold (as pure), nor a bad one (as good), nor less (than the proper quantity or weight), nor anything that is not at hand or that is concealed.

After one damsel has been shown, if another be given to the bridegroom, then he should marry both of them for the same single price,тАФso Manu has ordained.тАФ(204)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдпрдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд░рддреНрд╡рд╛рдЪреН рдЫреБрд▓реНрдХрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рджрд╛рдирд╕реНрдп рдЕрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреНрдиреН рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгреЗ13 рдзрд░реНрдо рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╢реБрд▓реНрдХрдХрд╛рд▓реЗ рд░реВрдкрд╡рддреАрдВ рджрд░реНрд╢рдпрд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛ рдЧреГрд╣реАрддрд╢реБрд▓реНрдХреЛ рдпрд╕реНрдп14 рд░реВрдкрд╣реАрдирд╛рдВ рджрджрд╛рддрд┐ рд╡рдпреЛрд╣реАрдирд╛рдВ рдЧреВрдгрд╣реАрдирд╛рдВ рд╡рд╛ рддрд╕реНрдпреНрдУрднреЗ15 рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╢реБрд▓реНрдХрджреЗрдиреНрдРрдХреЗрди рд╢реБрд▓реНрдХреЗрди рд╣рд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпреЗ16 ред рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдПрд╡рд╛рдпрдВ рдзрд░реНрдордГ ред рдЧрд╡рд╛рд╢реНрд╡рд╛рджрд┐рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдгрд╛рдВ рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдореЗ рд╜рдиреНрдпреЛ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд░реН рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ рее рео.реирежрек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Since the present context is dealing with matters relating to sales, it lays down certain rules relating to maidens given in marriage for a price.

At the time of receiving the price, if the man shows a beautiful girl, but after having received it, he gives an ugly one, or one not of proper age, or of inferior qualifications,тАФthen for that same price, the bridegroom shall marry both the girls.

The rule here laid down pertains to the case of girls only, that relating to similar frauds in connection with the selling of cattle and other goods shall be laid down later on.тАФ(204)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАЬYet he has emphatically inveighed against the sale of women 3.51, 9.98тАЭтАФsays Hopkins. But he forgets that тАШ┼ЫulkaтАЩ is not price, Buhler also has been similarly misled.

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (1.66).тАФтАШIf a man gives away his daughter in marriage, without mentioning her defects, he should be fined the highest amercement.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Apar─Бrka, p. 95).тАФтАШIf a man gives away a defective girl in marriage, without mentioning the defect, he should be punished by the King with the first amercement; the defects of a girl being presence of chronic and loathsome disease, shortness of limbs, loss of virginity, immodesty, attachment to another man.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

By the declaration that one does not deserve punishment by giving a girl suffering from the defects of insanity and the rest, after having openly declared them,тАФwhat is meant is that by giving her without declaring the defects, one does become liable to punishment.

Not only in the case of the girl given for a price, but also in that of others, who is going to be married by the тАШBr─БhmaтАЩ and other forms,тАФthe betrothal becomes invalidated, and the penalty is that тАШthe man becomes guilty of theftтАЩ (verse 198),тАФif he does it intentionally; the case in which it is done unintentionally does not fall within the scope of the present context (which deals with тАШfraudтАЩ).

The construction is as follows:тАФтАШIf the man openly declares, at the time of betrothal, the defect of the тАШinsaneтАЩ girl, i.e., insanity,тАФof the тАШleprousтАЩ girlтАФi.e., leprosyтАФof the girl who тАШhas suffered copulationтАЩтАФi.e., loss of virginity,тАФby saying тАШthis girl has such and such a defect,тАЩтАФthen he is not liable to punishment.тАФ(205)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╕рдВрднреВрдпрд╕рдореБрддреНрдерд╛рдирд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рдХреНрд░рдореЛ рд╜рдпрдореН ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╡реИрджрд┐рдХрдВ рддрд╛рд╡рддреН рд╕рдВрднреВрдпрдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдореН рдЙрджрд╛рд╣рд░рддрд┐ ред рдпрдЬреНрдЮреЛ рдЬреНрдпреЛрддрд┐рд╖реНрдЯреЛрдорд╛рджрд┐рдГ ред рддрддреНрд░ рдпрд╛рдЧрд░реВрдкрд╛рдиреЗрдХрд╛рдЩреНрдЧрдХрд░реНрдордирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд░реНрддрдирд╛рд░реНрдердореН рдЛрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЧреН рд╡реГрддрдГ “рддреНрд╡рдпрд╛ рдордореЗрджрдВ рд╣реМрддреНрд░рдВ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН рдЖрдзреНрд╡рд░реНрдпрд╡рдореН рдФрджреНрдЧрд╛рддреНрд░рдВ рд╡рд╛” рдЗрддрд┐20 рд╢реНрд░реМрддреЗрди рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдирд╛рдиреБрд╖реНрдареЗрдпрдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдкрдЧрдорд╢реН рдЪ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддрд┐рддрдГ ред рдХрдердВрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрдкрд╛рдЯрд╡рд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд╕рд╛рдорд┐рдХреГрддрдВ21 рдпрддреН рдкрд░рд┐рд╣рд╛рдкрдпреЗрддреН рддреНрдпрдЬреЗрддреН рддрджрд╛рдиреАрдВ рддрд╕реНрдп рджреЗрдпреЛ рджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгреНрдЖрдВрд╢рдГ рдХрд░реНрдорд╛рдиреБрд░реВрдкреЗрдг ред рдпрд╛рд╡рддреА рддрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдХреНрд░рддреМ рджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛ рддрд╛рдВ рдирд┐рд░реВрдкреНрдп рдЪрддреБрд░реНрдереЗ рднрд╛рдЧреЗ рдХрд░реНрдордгрдГ рдХреГрддреЗ рдЪрддреБрд░реНрдердГ рддреГрддреАрдпреЗ рддреГрддреАрдп22 рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрджреН рдЖрдиреБрд░реВрдкреНрдпрдореН23 ред рд╕рд╣ рдХрд░реНрддреГрднрд┐рдГред рдХрд░реНрддрд╛рд░рдГ рддрддреНрдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╛рдГ24 рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирд░реНрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрд╛рдВ25 рд╣реЛрддреНрд░реБрджреНрдЧрд╛рддреНрд░рд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ26 рдкреНрд░рд╕реНрддреЛрддреГрдореИрддреНрд░рд╛рд╡рд░реБрдгрдкреНрд░рднреГрддрдпрдГ рее рео.реирежрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This verse introduces the head of тАШJoint ConcernsтАЩ: and as an example, the author takes up the ease of тАШJoint actionтАЩ at Vedic rites.

тАШSacrificeтАЩтАФThe Jyotiс╣гс╣нoma and the rest. For the proper performance of the numerous details of these sacrifices, when a certain тАШpriest has been appointed,тАЩтАФwith the wordsтАФтАШyou should perform the duties of the тАШHotс╣Ы,тАЩ or тАШof the Adhvaryu,тАЩ or тАШof the Udg─Бtс╣Ы,тАЩтАФand the further condition is madeтАФтАШyou should do the work according to the ┼Ыrauta-rulesтАЩ;тАФif, on account of his inefficiency or other causes, he happens to abandon it after it has been half-done,тАФthen the share of the sacrificial fee payable to him shall be in accordance with the amount of work done by him. For instance, if the man goes away after having done only a fourth part of his work, he should be paid the quarter of the third part of the entire тАШfeeтАЩ prescribed in connection with the particular sacrifice concerned. This would be тАШin accordance with the work done.тАЩ

тАШBy h is associatesтАЩтАФi.e., the other priests, the Hotс╣Ы, the Udg─Бtс╣Ы and the rest.тАФ(206)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 836);тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 118), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШSvakarma parih─Бpayet,тАЩ i.e., through sickness or such causes, a part of the sacrificial fee shall be paid to him, after duly considering the total fee payable for the entire sacrifice and the part of the work that may have been done by him;тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 222), which explains тАШsahakartс╣Ыbhiс╕етАЩ as тАШby his colleaguesтАЩ;тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 48), which says that тАШif a priest, through disease or other disability, is unable to perform his work, then he is to be paid his fee in proportion to the work actually done by him;тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (89b);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 120a), which explains тАШsahakartс╣Ыbhiс╕етАЩ as тАШby his collaborators,тАЩтАФor the meaning may be тАШhe should be paid his share of the fee, along with, at the same time as, the other priests are paid.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

[(See Manu below, 388.)]

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.265).тАФтАШAmong a company of joint workers, if one happen to be dishonest, the others should expel him without payment; if he happen to omit his share of the work on account of his inability to do it, then he should have it done by another. This same rule applies to the case of sacrificial priests, cultivators and artisans.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (Apar─Бrka, p. 836).тАФтАШIf the Sacrificial Priest fails to officiate at a sacrifice, or if a Teacher fails to teach, he should be abandoned; one becomes degraded if he abandons them in other circumstances.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Apar─Бrka, p. 836).тАФтАШIf the Sacrificial Priest happen to be in trouble, some one else may officiate for him and receive a proportionate share out of the fee payable to the former.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 117).тАФтАШFrom among men employed in a common work, if one happen to die, his share of the work should be done by a relation of his, or by his colleagues collectively.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita (Do.).тАФтАШIf on the approach of the Savana, a priest should happen to die, what should be done is that his work should be completed by his Sagotra or by his pupil; if he has no relations, then the sacrificer should appoint another Priest.тАЩ

рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирд░реНрддреНрд╡рд┐рдХреН рдкреНрд░рдХреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрдХрд░реНрдорд╛ рдпрджрд┐ рдкрд░рд┐рд╣рд╛рдкрдпреЗрддреН рд╕реНрд╡рдХрд░реНрдо рджреЗрд╢рд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдЧрдордирд╛рдкрд╛рдЯрд╡рд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рд░реН рдЕрд░реНрдерд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгреИрдГ рддрд╕реНрдп рдХрд░реНрдорд╛рдиреБрд░реВрдкреНрдпреЗрдг рджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рдВрд╢рдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдХрдердореН ред рдХрд░реНрдордг[рд╢реН рдЪрддреБрд░реНрдереЗ рдХреГрддреЗ рджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛]рдпрд╛ рдЕрдкрд┐ рдЪрддреБрд░реНрднрд╛рдЧрдГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рддреНрд░рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрд╛рджрд┐рд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдпреЛрдЬреНрдпрдореН ред рд╕рд╣ рдХрд░реНрддреГрднрд┐рд░реН рдЗрддрд┐ [рдкреНрд░рддрд┐]рдкреНрд░рд╕реНрдерд╛рддреГрдкреНрд░рднреГрддреАрдВрд╕реН рддрддреНрдкреБрддреБрд╖рд╛рдиреН рдЖрд╣ ред рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд╡рд╛рджрдГ тАФ рее рео.реирежрел рее

206 If an officiating priest, chosen to perform a sacrifice, abandons his work, a share only (of the fee) in proportion to the work (done) shall be given to him by those who work with him.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

He who abandons his work after the fees have been paid, should receive his full share; and the work should be got done by another.тАФ(207)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдорд╛рдзреНрдпрдиреНрджрд┐рдиреЗ рд╕рд╡рдиреЗ рджрдХреНрд╖реАрдирд╛ рджреАрдпрдиреНрдд рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрдд рдЙрдкрд░рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╛рддреН рдХрд░реНрдо рддреНрдпрдЬрддрд╛рдореН рдЕрдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╛рд╣рд░рдгреАрдпрд╛рдВ27 рд▓рднреЗрдд, рджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╢реЗрд╖рдГ,28 рди рдкреНрд░рддреАрдкрдВ рддреНрдпрд╛рдЬрдпреЗрджреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╛рдВ рднреГрддрд┐рдВ рджрддреНрд╡рд╛ рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗрди рдкреБрд░реБрд╖реЗрдг рдпрдЬрдорд╛рдирд╕реН рддрддреНрдХрд░реНрдо рд╕рдорд╛рдкрдпреЗрддреН ред рдЛрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЧреНрднрд┐рдГ рдХрд░реНрдо рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдВ рд╡рд░рдгрд╛рдЪреН рдЪ рдЛрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЬреЛ рднрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ ред рддрдЪреН рдЪ рдирд┐рдпрддрдХрд╛рд▓реЗ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдХреН рдХрд░реНрдордг рдЖрд░рдореНрднрд╛рддреН ред рдЕрддрдГ рдХреНрд░рддреБ рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрдорд╛рдгрдВ рд╡рд┐рдЧреБрдгрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐, рд╕рдорд╛рдкреНрддрд┐рд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдкрд┐ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпреЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдЧреБрдгрдВ рдЪреЗрддреН рд╕рдорд╛рдкрдиреАрдпрдореН рдЕрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдиреНрдпреН рдПрд╡ рддрджрдиреНрдпрдХрд░реНрддреГрдХрд╛рдгрд┐ рдХрд░рд┐рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдореАрддрд┐ рдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердореН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗрдиреИрд╡реЗрддрд┐ ред рддрд╛рд╡рджреН рдПрд╡ рд╡рд┐рдЧреБрдгрдВ рдпрджреН рдЕрд╢рдХреНрдпрдореН, рд╢рдХреНрдпрдВ рддреБ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред

рдХреЗрдЪрд┐рддреН рдХрд╛рд░рдпреЗрджреН рдЗрддрд┐ рдЛрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЬреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдореН рдЖрд╣реБрдГ ред рдЧреГрд╣реАрддреНрд╡рд╛ рджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рдВ рд╡рд╛рдзрд┐рдХрд╛рдВ рджрджреНрдпрд╛рддреН рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдореН рдЕрд╢рдХреНрдиреБрд╡рдиреН ред рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЧреН рджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рднреНрдпрдГ рд╢реЗрд╖рдХрд░реНрдорд╕рдорд╛рдкрдиреЗ рдпрдЬрдорд╛рди рдПрд╡рд╛рдзрд┐рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ рее рео.реирежрен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The sacrificial fees are paid at the тАШMid-day ExtractionтАЩ; if a priest gives up his work after that, the fee paid to him shall not be refunded; he тАШshould receive itтАЩтАФi.e., he should not be made to refund it.

The work should be completed by the sacrificer, through another person, paying him an additional fee. This has been added with a view to preclude the following notionтАФтАЬEverything in connection with sacrifices should be done by priests,тАФpersons become priests when they have been appointed as such,тАФthis appointment can be made only at the prescribed time, which is before the commencement of the performance, so that if an appointment were to be made during the performance, it would become defective,тАФand yet the performance has got to be finished,тАФand if it has to be finished in a defective form, I shall get only those details performed which can be done by the priests other than the one who has gone away.тАЭ The sense is that only that much of deficiency has to be admitted as cannot be avoided; and every little detail that can he done should be done.

Some people have held that the verb тАШshould be got doneтАЩ is to be construed with the тАШpriestтАЩ; the meaning being that the sacrificer shall pay to the remaining priests higher fees and get the abandoned work done by them, if he cannot do it himself; but, as before the payment of the final fee, the burden of finishing the performance rests with the sacrificer.тАФ(207)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШK─БrayetтАЩтАФтАШThe sacrificer should have it done by another priestтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШthe defaulting priest should have it done by another (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa, Kull┼лka, R─Бghav─Бnanda and Nandana).

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 837);тАФin Para┼Ы─Бram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 222), which explains тАШanyenaтАЩ as тАШby some from among that group of priests to which he himself belongsтАЩ;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 118);тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 49), which saysтАФтАШif the priest leaves his work after, having received the fee after the midday rites, then he is to return the entire fee, and get the work completed by his son or othersтАЩ;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (89b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.265).тАФ(See under 206.)

┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 120).тАФтАШAfter a Priest has been appointed, if the sacrificer appoint another, the fee shall be paid to the former; if he happen to go out for some time, then his return shall be awaited, and the sacrificer shall not go on with the performance during his absence. If the completion of the performance becomes urgent, he may have it completed; and on his return, the priest may be given some fee.тАЩ

N─Бrada (3.8-11).тАФтАШWhen an officiating priest has met with an accident, another priest shall officiate for him, and receive from him his part of the fee. Where an officiating priest forsakes a sacrificer, who is no offender and is free from guilt,тАФor when a sacrificer forsakes a faultless priest,тАФthey shall both be punished. There are three sorts of officiating priests: hereditary, appointed by the sacrificer himself, and one who performs the priestly functions of his own accord, through friendship; the above law applies to the hereditary and appointed priests; no sin attaches to the forsaking of the priest acting of his own accord.тАЩ

рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╡рд┐рд╕реЗрд╖рд╛рд╢реНрд░рдпрд╛ рдЕрдЩреНрдЧреЗрд╖реБ рджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдЩреНрдЧрджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рдГ ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рд╡реАрдкреНрд╕рд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдЩреНрдЧреНрдЕрд╢рдмреНрджрдГ ред рдЕрдЩреНрдЧрдореН рдЕрдЩреНрдЧрдореН рдЖрд╢реНрд░рд┐рддрд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдГ ред рд╕ рдПрд╖ рддрд╛ рдЖрджрджреАрдд ред рдореБрдЦреНрдп рдПрд╡ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╕реНрдп рджрджрд╛рддрд┐рдирд╛ рд╕рдВрдпреЛрдЧ рдЙрдд рдХрд░реНрддреГрддреНрд╡рд╛рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рднрдЬреЗрд░рдВрд▓реН рд▓рднреЗрд░рдиреН, рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рдпрд╛ рдЗрд╡, рдЗрддрд┐ рдХрдердпрд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╢реНрдирдГ ред рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдореН рдЙрдХреНрддрд╛рд╕реН рддрджрд░реНрдерд╛ рдПрд╡реЗрддрд┐ рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрдГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рджрджрд╛рддрд┐рд░реН рдореБрдЦреНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдереЛ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╕рдВрдпреЛрдЧрд╢реН рдЪ рдирд╛рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрдердГ34 рее рео.реирежрео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This verse adds something more in connection with Vedic rites, which is relevant to the present context.

In connection with rites, fees are as a rule proscribed for them as a whole, and not with reference to each priest,тАФthe injunction being in the form тАШthe fee for it shall he twelve hundredтАЩ; this same injunction becomes applicable by тАШtransferenceтАЩ also to such sacrifices as grow out of, and are analogous to, that in connection with which the fee has been prescribed;тАФsuch sacrifices, for instance, as the ll─Бjas┼лya and the rest;тАФnow in connection with these latter, it is found that with reference to certain parts of the rite, distinct speci├▒c fees have been prescribed as to be paid to a particular priest specifically,тАФe.g., тАШthe bright gold shall be given to the AdhvaryuтАЩ;тАФthese are what are called (in the text) тАШspecific fees for its several parts.тАЩ

Now the question arisesтАФIs the gift, like the other sacrificial fees, connected with the Adhvaryu, only in the sense that he is one among four partners, and it belongs to all the priests, the Adhraryu being only the channel? or that it belongs to the Adhvaryu alone, the others receiving a share only out of the main fee?

This is the question propounded by the verse.

The term тАШpratyaс╣Еgadakс╣гiс╣З─БтАЩ means the fees directly prescribed in so many words in connection with special rites as to be given to particular persons. Or the term тАШpratyaс╣ЕgaтАЩ may mean for each several part.

тАШWill one man take all these,тАЩтАФthe gift being connected with the chief priest only,тАФor shall others all тАШshare them,тАЩтАФthose, equally with the chief priest, having officiated at the performance;тАФjust as they do in the case of the main sacrificial fee?тАФSuch is the sense of the question.

The answer to this is that when a certain fee has been prescribed for a particular person, it is to be taken by him alone: as it is only thus that the prescribed act of тАШgivingтАЩ could he regarded as fulfilled. The mention of the particular recipient in the rule could not be intended to serve any transcendental purpose (and no other purpose could it serve, if the fee were not actually meant to be received by that person alone).тАФ(208)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 119) which adds the following notes:тАФтАШPraiyaс╣Г┼Ыadakс╣гiс╣З─Бс╕етАЩ (which is its reading for тАШpratyaс╣Еgadakс╣гin─Бс╕етАЩ), the fees that have been prescribed for a particular priest, in connection with particular sections of an elaborate sacrifice; e.g., at the ceremony of anointment two golden vessels are given to the Adhvaryu priest;тАФin regard to these, the question isтАФIs the whole of that special fee to be taken by that one priest in reference to whom it has been prescribed? Or that individual is only the formal recipient, and the fee has to be equally divided among all the priests taking part in the performance?

It is quoted in Kс╣Ыtyakalapataru (90a), which explains тАШpratyaс╣Г┼Ыadakс╣гiс╣З─БтАЩ (which is its reading for тАШpratyaс╣Еgadakс╣гiс╣З─БтАЩ) as тАШthe fees that have been prescribed as the special shares of particular priestsтАЩ, and it adds that this rule is meant to raise the question whether when, e.g., two gold Prak─Б┼Ыas are prescribed as to be given at the Abhiс╣гecan─лya Rites, to the Adhvaryu,тАФare the two articles to be taken by that priest, or are they to be divided among all the priests concerned?

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 120).тАФ(Same as Manu).

Bс╣Ыhaspati (Apar─Бrka, p. 837).тАФ(Same as Manu).

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдЩреНрдЧрджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рдГ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рджрд╛ рд╕рдВрд╢рдпреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдХрд┐рдореН рдЕрдореАрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЛрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдирд┐рдпрдорд╢реН рдЪрд╛рддреБрд░реНрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдпреБрдХреНрддрдкрд╛рджрд┐рдХрдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╡рддреН, рдЙрдд рдкрджрд╛рд░реНрдерд╕реНрд╡рд░реВрдкрд╕реНрд╡рд╛рднрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд╛рддреН рддрджрд░реНрдереЗрдиреЗрддрд┐ рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпрд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкреЛ рд╜рдиреВрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрд╛рджрд░реНрдереНрдпрдкрдХреНрд╖рдВ рдЪрд╛рд╢реНрд░рд┐рддреНрдпреИрддрджреН рдЕрдзреБрдиреЛрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рее рео.реирежрен рее

208 But if (specific) fees are ordained for the several parts of a rite, shall he (who performs the part) receive them, or shall they all share them?

рд░рдердВ рд╣рд░реЗрддреН рдЪрд╛рд╜рдзреНрд╡рд░реНрдпреБрд░реН
рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдорд╛рдзрд╛рдиреЗ рдЪ рд╡рд╛рдЬрд┐рдирдореН ред
рд╣реЛрддрд╛ рд╡рд╛рдкрд┐ рд╣рд░реЗрджреН рдЕрд╢реНрд╡рдореН

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

At Fire-laying, the Adhvaryu shall take the chariot, and the Brahman the horse; or the Hotс╣Ы shall take the house: and the Udg─Бtс╣Ы shall take the cart at the Soma-purchase.тАФ(209)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд░рдердореН рдЕрдзреНрд╡рд░реНрдпреБрд░реН рдЖрдзрд╛рдиреЗ рд╣рд░реЗрддреН ред рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдорд╛ рдЪ рд╡рд╛рдЬрд┐рдирдВ рд╡реЗрдЧрд╡рдиреНрддрдореН рдЕрд╢реНрд╡рдореН ред рд╣реЛрддрд╛ рд╡рд╛ рдЕрд╢реНрд╡рдВ рд╡реГрд╖рдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрдВ рд╡рд╛ ред рдХрд╛рд╕реБрдЪрд┐рдЪреН рдЫрд╛рдХрд╛рд╕реНрд╡реН рдЖрдзрд╛рди рдПрддрд╛ рджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рдГ ред рдЕрддрдГ рд╕реЛрдордХреНрд░рдпреЗ рдпрдЪреН рдЫрдХрдЯрдВ рддрджреН рдЙрджреНрдЧрд╛рддреБрдГ ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╢рдХрдЯреЗ рд╜рдиреНрдпрддрд░реЛ рд╜рдирдбреНрд╡рд╛рдиреН рдпреБрдХреНрддрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН, рдЕрдиреНрдпрддрд░реЛ рд╡рд┐рдпреБрдХреНрдд рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдкрдареНрдпрддреЗ ред рддреЗрди рдЪ рд╕реЛрдордГ рдХреНрд░реАрдд рдЙрдкрд╛рд╣реНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ ред

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдореН рдЕрди рдЖрд╣реБрд░реН рди рд╕реЛрдореЛрдкрд╛рд╣рд░рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердореН, рди рд╣рд┐ рдХреНрд░рдпреЗрдг рд╢рдХреНрдпрддреЗ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдпрд┐рддреБрдореН рее рео.реирежреп рее

рдПрд╡рдВ рддрд╛рд╡рддреН рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╕рдВрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рдиреАрдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдЩреНрдЧрджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд░реН рдЙрдХреНрддрдГ ред рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдпрддрдГ рд╢реНрд░реБрддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдЗрджрд╛рдиреАрдВ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдореН рдЖрд╣ ред

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

At the rite of Fire-laying the Adhvaryu shall take the chariot; and the Brahman or the Hotс╣Ы shall take the swift horse.

In certain rescensional texts, these form the тАШsacrificial feeтАЩ for the rite of Fire-laying.

At, the rite of тАШSoma-purchase,тАЩ there is a cart, which is to be taken by the Udg─Бtс╣Ы. To this cart one calf is yoked, and another unyoked: and it is on this cart that the purchased Soma is carried. Others hold that the rites laid down in connection with the тАШpurchase of SomaтАЩ have some transcendental purpose, and their use does not lie only in the obtaining of the Soma; because there is no new character produced in the Soma by its being purchased in the peculiar manner prescribed.

This verse has described how the fees prescribed in connection with the subsidiary details are to be distributed among the several persons concerned; the next verse is going to describe the rule concerning the distribution of the sacrificial fee prescribed in connection with all rites in general.тАФ(209)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 120), which adds the following notes:тАФFor the followers of certain recensions it is laid down in connection with the fire-kindling rites that the Adhvaryu is to receive the chariot the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa priest a swift horse, the Udg─Бtс╣Ы priest, the cart in which the Soma is carried.тАФтАШKrayeтАЩ means at the purchase of Soma.тАФHence the answer to the question raised in the preceding verse is that the special fee prescribed for a particular priest is to be given to that priest only; as it is only thus that the тАШgivingтАЩ would be done in its real sense; the mention of the priests in the texts prescribing the fees could not but be for this perceptible purpose; while in any other case such naming would have to be taken only as serving some transcendental purpose.

This verse is quoted also in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava, (Vyavah─Бra, p. 221), to the effect that it is only the general fee prescribed in connection with the performance as a whole that it is to be divided among the priests,тАФnot so the special fee prescribed in connection with a particular priest, who alone is to receive this latter fee;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (90a), which says that this answers the question raised in the preceding verse, the answer being that wherever the texts prescribe a certain article as to be given to a particular person, it has to be given to that person only.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 120).тАФ(Same as Manu).

Bс╣Ыhaspati (Apar─Бrka, p. 837).тАФ(Same as Manu).

рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЛрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрд╛рдВ рдпреЗ рдореБрдЦреНрдпрд╛рд╕реН рддреЗ рд╜рд░реНрдзрд┐рдирдГ ред рдпрд╛рд╡рддреА рддрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдХреНрд░рддреМ ред рджреНрд╡рд╛рджрд╢рд╕рдореБрджрд╛рдпреЗ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╡рддреН ред рдПрд╡рдВ “рддрдВ рд╢рддреЗрди рджреАрдХреНрд╖рдпрдиреНрддрд┐” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрддреНрд░рд╛рдкрд┐ рдХреврдкреНрддрд┐рдГ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛ ред “рдЕрд░реНрдзрд┐рдиреЛ рджреАрдХреНрд╖рдпрддрд┐, рдкрд╛рджрд┐рдиреЛ рджреАрдХреНрд╖рдпрддрд┐” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡рдорд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рдГ рд╢рдмреНрджреИрдГ ред рддрддреНрд░ рджреНрд╡рд╛рджрд╢рдХреНрд░рдорд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд░реН рдПрд╡ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд░ рд╢реНрд░реБрддреЛ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░ рдЗрд╣рд╛рдкрд┐ рддрдпреИрд╡ рд░реАрддреНрдпрд╛ рдХреГрдд рдЗрддрд┐ рее рео.реирезреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

From among the priests, тАШthe chief ones receive halfтАЩ; i.e., they receive half of the fee that is prescribed for the rite as a whole.

At the Soma-sacrifice there are sixteen priests; of these the chief ones are four: the Hotс╣Ы, the Adhvaryu, the Brahman and the Udg─Бtс╣Ы, and these receive one half of the total fee;тАФthe total fee being one hundred and twelve, fifty-six go to these four men.

Half of this, that is twenty-eight, go to the тАШnextтАЩ; i.e., those four whose appointment comes after that of the four mentioned above; i.e., the Maitr─Бvaruс╣Зa, the Pratiprasth─Бtс╣Ы, the Br─Бhmaс╣З─Бcchaс╣Гsin and the Prastotс╣Ы.

The тАШthirdersтАЩ receive the тАШthird part.тАЩтАФThe term тАШpartтАЩ here is synonymous with тАШhalfтАЩ; the term тАШhalfтАЩ does not always stand for two equal divisions; it is used also in reference to what is very near such equal divisions; hence the тАШthird partтАЩ of тАШfifty-sixтАЩ is understood to be sixteen; so that each of these four gets four.

Some people take the тАШthird partтАЩ as such that of the total fee; when others take it as that of fifty-six.

The four тАШthirdersтАЩ areтАФthe Acch─Бv─Бka, associated with the Hotс╣Ы, the Neс╣гс╣нс╣Ы connected with the Adhvaryu, the Agn─лd with the Brahman, and the Pratihartс╣Ы with the Udg─Бtс╣Ы.

The тАШFourthersтАЩтАФi.e., so called because they perform the fourth part of the rite, and also because they occupy the fourth place from the Maitr─Бvaruс╣ЗaтАФ receive тАШthe fourth partтАЩтАФi.e., twelveтАФof the whole; this number being got at in the same manner as before.

This same method of distribution is to be employed also in the case of the rite of Initiation, where the fee is laid down as тАШa hundredтАЩ; where also the тАШhalfersтАЩ and тАШfourthersтАЩ help in the performance.

The practice, that, we have found prescribed elsewhere we have described in connection with the present text also.тАФ(210)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

The total fee being 112, the shares are 56, 28, 16, 12 (Medh─Бtithi);тАФthe total being 100, the shares are 48, 24, 16, 12 (R─Бghav─Бnanda, N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Kull┼лka); [Buhler wrongly puts the last figure as 8];тАФthe total fee shall be divided into 25 shares and the several classes shall receive 12, 6, 4 and 3 respectively.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 118), which adds the following notes:тАФAt the Jyotiс╣гс╣нoma, 100 cows have been laid down as the fee for the 16 priests; and the present rule prescribes what part of it is to be given to which priest; the four тАШprincipalтАЩ priestsтАФe.g., the Hotс╣Ы, Adhvaryu Brahman and Udg─Бtс╣ЫтАФare тАШardhinaс╕етАЩ, entitled to one half; with a view to the total available, this тАШone half must be understood to be 48; so that 48 cows are to be given to the principal priestsтАЩ;тАФthe next class, consisting of the Maitr─Бvaruс╣Зa, Pratiprasth─Бtс╣Ы, Br─Бhmaс╣Зacchaс╣Гsi and Prastotс╣Ы are to receive half of the тАШhalf-sharersтАЩ, i.e., 24 cows have to be given to these;тАФthe next class, consisting of the Acch─Бv─Бka, Neс╣гс╣нr, Agn─лdhra and Pratihartс╣Ы, are entitled to a third part of the тАШhalf-sharersтАЩ; so that they are to receive 16 cows;тАФthe last class consisting of the Gr─Бvastotс╣Ы, Netс╣Ы, Potс╣Ы and Subrahmaс╣Зya, are to receive a quarter of the тАШhalf-sharersтАЩ; so that these receive 12 cows.тАФThis division, it adds, his based upon the text тАШardhino d─лkс╣гayatiтАЩ which actually names the priests тАШardhinaс╕е,тАЩ тАШhalf-sharersтАЩ, and so forth.

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.265), which lays down the same classification and division as the Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara. It raises the following question:тАФтАЬThis division cannot be acceptable, as we find neither any convention to the effect, nor is the fee of the nature of capital jointly raised, nor is there any Vedic text actually prescribing such shares. So that, under the circumstances, the most equitable division would be that every one should receive an equal share, according to the rule laid down in M─лm─Бс╣Гs─Б-s┼лtraтАФтАШSamam sy─Бt a┼Ыrutatv─БtтАЩ, тАШit must be equal, as nothing else has been directly prescribedтАЩ; or that each one should receive what is due to him in consideration of the work actually done by him.тАЭтАФIt answers this objection as follows:тАФUnless we accept the division suggested, we cannot account for the names тАШardhinaс╕етАЩ (half sharers), тАШTс╣Ыt─лyinaс╕етАЩ (third sharers), and тАШP─Бdinaс╕етАЩ(quarter sharers), which we find in a text in connection with the Dv─Бda┼Ы─Бha sacrifice, which has the Jyotiс╣гс╣нoma for its archetype; these names would be meaningless if they were not taken as indicating the share of the priests in the sacrificial fee.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 837), which adds that though the first class of priests gets only 48, which is not quite half of 100, yet it is very close to it; hence they may be called тАШHalf sharersтАЩ; it has the same division as in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б.

It is quoted in Smс╣Ыtitattva (p. 739);тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (90a), which adds the following explanation:тАФтАШSarveс╣г─БmтАЩ, among the sixteen priests engaged in the sarcrifice, out of the 100 cows, the prescribed sacrificial fee, one half is to go to the principal priests, viz., Hotс╣Ы, Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, Adhvaryu and Udg─Бtс╣Ы; even though they may receive a little less than the exact one half, they may be called тАШardhinaс╕етАЩ, тАШHalfersтАЩ; the second set, consisting of the Maitr─Бvaruс╣Зa, Br─Бhmaс╣Зacchaс╣Гsin, Pratiprasth─Бtс╣Ы and Prastotс╣Ы, are entitled to half of what is received by the former set; the third set, consisting of the Acch─Бv─Бka, Agn─лdhra, Neс╣гtс╣Ы and Pratihartс╣Ы, receive the third part of what is received by the first set;тАФand the fourth set, consisting of the Gr─Бvastut, Netс╣Ы, Unnetс╣Ы and Subrahmaс╣Зya, receive the fourth part of what is received by the first set.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In the sacrificial performance, the man who does the most laborious parts of the work and is employed to do what demands much effort, receives a larger fee, and he who does the easier parts receives loss; similarly among ordinary workmen also, those, e.g., employed in the building of houses and temples,тАФwhen they do the work тАШjointly,тАЩ as among the architect, the mason and the carpenter.тАФtheir several shares shall be alloted тАШby the application of these principlesтАЩ;тАФтАШprincipleтАЩ is rule laid down in the Veda, hence this phrase means тАШaccording to the rule laid down in the Veda in connection with sacrificial performances.тАЩ

Similarly in the producing of a drama, and such other business, the shares are to ho alloted among the dancers, the singers and the players of musical instruments.

Even though everyone of the persons concerned may be well versed in the science and quite capable of doing all the work, yet the shares are to be alloted in accordance with the work that is actually done by each, and according to the character of the man concerned.

Thus ends the treatment of тАШJoint Concerns.тАЩтАФ(211)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 221), which remarks that this distribution pertains to only cases where the thing to be divided is mentioned as common to all;тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (90a);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 119b), which says that this refers, not to the fee that is prescribed for individual priests, but to the common fee of 1200 cows, which is prescribed for all the officiating priests.

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.259).тАФтАШAmong traders carrying on a joint concern for profit, their profit and loss shall be commensurate with the share of capital contributed by each.тАЩ

N─Бrada (3.1-3).тАФWhen traders or others carry on business jointly, it is called Partnership. When several partners are jointly carrying on business for the purpose of profit, the contribution of funds towards the common stock of the association shall form the basis of their undertakings. Therefore let each contribute his proper share. The loss, expenses and profit of each partner are either equal to those of other partners or exceed them, or remain below them, according as his share is equal to theirs, or greater or less.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (14.3).тАФтАШAs an equal, smaller, or larger share of the joint stock has been contributed by a partner, in the same proportion shall he defray charges, perform labour and obtain profit.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.614-618).тАФтАШThose who deal in gold, grains and liquids, jointly, will have the earnings according to the amount of their share, greater, equal or less. Whatever portion has been stipulated beforehand,тАФequal, less or greater,тАФthat shall he accepted. Expenditure he shall pay and do the labour also proportionately, and take the profit also in the same manner.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

A man comes to the rich man prayingтАФтАШI am desirous of marrying for the sake of issue,тАЩ or тАШI wish to perform such and such a sacrifice,тАЩ тАШgive, me some moneyтАЩ;тАФand the money is given to him;тАФbut the man does not marry, and spends the money either in gambling or over prostitutes, or for something else, laying it out on interest or agriculture,тАФthen тАШit shall not be given to him.тАЩ

When the money has been given already, there can be no sense in forbidding the gift; (A) hence the sentence should be taken to mean that тАШit shall be taken back from him.тАЩ (B) Or the former clause itself may be taken in a figurative sentence,тАФthe word тАШgivesтАЩ being taken in the sense of тАШpromisesтАЩ; the meaning in this case would be that тАШthe promised money shall not be given.тАЩ In this sense we have the assertion of Gautama (5.23)тАФтАШEven after promising, no money shall be given to one who is found to be unrighteous.тАЩ

тАЬOf these two explanations (A & B), which is the more reasonable?тАЭ

Both are reasonable: the taking back of what has been given, and also not giving what has been promised. In another Smс╣Ыti -text we find both these courses laid down:тАФBeginning with the wordsтАФтАШI am going to perform such and such an act,тАЩ the text goes on to sayтАФтАШwhat is given in ignorance is as good as not givenтАЩ N─Бrada, 4.10-11). This means that when money has been given for a certain act, if that act is not done, the money, even though paid, shall ho brought back from the receiverтАЩs house; and the opinion of N─Бrada is that in this case there was only a promise of the gift, and its fulfilment would be dependent upon the actual fulfilment of the purpose for which it had been asked for.тАФ(212)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШKart─Бhametat karmetiтАЩтАФ(Medh─Бtithi, p. 1009, l. 5).тАФThe text of N─Бrada (4.10-11) isтАФтАШKart─Бhametat karmeti pratil─Бbhecchay─Б ca yat Ap─Бtre p─Бtramityukte k─Бrye v─Б dharmasaс╣Гhite Yaddattam sy─Бdavij├▒─Бn─Бdadattam tadapi smс╣Ыtam.тАЩ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 137), which explains the meaning to beтАФтАШIf the man begs money for the performance of a pious act, but having got it, he does not do the act, then the gift should be recovered from him.тАЩ

It is quoted in Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 348), to the effect that when money has been given to a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa who has begged it for the purpose of performing a sacrifice or some such act,тАФbut he does not do such an act,тАФthen the money is to be taken back from him;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (94a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

─Аrtha┼Ы─Бstra (6.94).тАФтАШIn some cases the resumption of a gift is permitted; if one has given away his entire property, or his wife and son, or his own self, it should be restored to him; if a gift has been promised to a certain person under the impression that he is deserving of it, it may be resumed on his being found to be undeserving; u (?) if a gift was promised to a man for the purpose of helping him in the carrying on of such meritorious work as the tending of cows and the like, it may be resumed if he is found to be using it in stealing, adultery and such acts; if it has been promised to a man under the impression that he has rendered help to the giver, it may be resumed if the man is found either to have done him no good or to have actually done him harm; if a gift has been promised by virtue of certain special qualifications in the recipient, it may be resumed if he is not found to possess those qualifications. Clever judges shall permit such resumption of gifts in such a manner as neither the giver nor the recipient may be hit hard.тАЩ

N─Бrada (14.4 et seq.).тАФтАШA deposit, a pledge, joint property, a son, wife, the entire property of one having offspring, and what has been promised to another man:тАФthese have been declared to be inalienable by one even in the worst plight…… The price paid for merchandise, wages, a present offered for amusement, a gift made from affection, or from gratitude, or for sexual intercourse with a woman, and a respectful gift,тАФthese are valid gifts. The following are invalid gifts: what has been given under the influence of fear, anger, hatred, sorrow or pain; or as a bribe, or in jest, or fraudulently, under false pretences; or by a child, or by a fool, or by a person not bis own master, or by one distressed, or by one intoxicated, or by one insane, or in consideration of a reward, thinking this man will do me some service;тАФ and so is invalid what has been given from ignorance to an unworthy man thought to be worthy, or for a purpose thought to be virtuous. The donee who covets invalid gifts and accepts them through avarice,тАФand the donor of what ought not to be given,тАФboth deserve punishment.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (16.2, 8-11).тАФтАШThat which may not be given is of eight kinds: joint property, son, wife, pledges, oneтАЩs entire property, a deposit, wealth, what has been borrowed for use and what has been promised to another. The following eight are recognised as valid gifts:тАФwages for pleasure derived, price of merchandise, fee paid to or for a damsel, present to a benefactor, present through reverence, kindness or affection. What has been given by one angry or resenting an injury, or through inadvertence, or by one distressed, or by a junior, mad man, a terrified person, one intoxicated or overaged, or outcast or idiot, or one afflicted with grief or illness,тАФor what is given in jest;тАФall these have been declared to be void gifts. When anything has been given through desire for reward, or to an unworthy person mistaken for a worthy one, or for an immoral purpose,тАФthe donor may resume the gift.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Viv─Бdaratn─Бk─Бra, p. 129, p. 132, p. 135).тАФтАШA man may give away his entire property over and above what may be necessary for the maintenance of his family, excepting his house. If a man has promised a gift to a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa of his own accord, if he refuses to give it he should he made to pay it, and also pay the first amercement. A man may resume what he may have given under the influence of love or anger, or when he was not a free agent, or when he was distressed. Or one made by a eunuch, an intoxicated person, or under a misapprehension, or in jest. If a bribe has been promised for some work, it should never be given, even if the work may be accomplished.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2-175, 176).тАФтАШWith the exception of the wife and son, everything may he given away, in consonance with the interests of the family; if a man has offspring, he should not give away his entire property; nor may he give to one person what has been promised to another. The acceptance of a gift should he public, specially in the ease of immovable property; on having given or promised a gift, one should not resume it.тАЩ

Gautama (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 133).тАФтАШEven though he may have promised a gift, he shall not give it if the recipient is found to be unrighteous.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШSeeking to recover itтАЩтАФi.e., filing a suit before the King, with a view to recover it in the manner of a debt;тАФwhen, on being asked to pay back what he has already received, the man files an application before the King, saying тАШHaving given the money to me he seeks to take it away from meтАЩ; the тАШrecoveringтАЩ of the gift consisting, in this case, of its being confirmed.тАФThis is done cither тАШthrough arrogance or greedтАЩ;тАФthis describes the causes of the action mentioned before.

The penalty for the man who does this act shall be тАШone gold-pieceтАЩ;тАФтАШas an expiation for that theftтАЩ;тАФlest people think that the man, being regarded as a thief, should suffer the penalties prescribed for theft, the author has laid down the penalty as тАШone gold piece.тАЩ And yet he has used the word тАШtheftтАЩ with a view to preclude the notion that the man is not a тАШthief,тАЩ since what he has taken was given to him and he did not take it away himself. The meaning thus is that, though the man is a тАШthief,тАЩ yet his punishment, as here laid down, shall consist of тАШone gold pieceтАЩ only, but in all other respects, he is to be treated as a тАШthief.тАЩтАФ(213)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШSaс╣Гs─БdhayetтАЩтАФтАШIf he tries to enforce the fulfilment of the promise by a complaint before the kingтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФif he tries to obtain the money forcibly or refuses to refund itтАЩ (Kull┼лka, R─Бghav─Бnanda and Govindar─Бja);тАФтАШif he should withhold the repaymentтАЩ (R─Бmacandra, who reads тАШSandh─БrayetтАЩ);тАФтАШif the man should really perform the act for which he had begged, then the man who had promised to pay, but did not pay, (or having paid, took it back), should be made to pay to him a Suvarс╣Зa, by way of fine, for not fulfilling his promiseтАЩ (Nandana, who has been misrepresented by Hopkins).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 137), which explains the meaning to beтАФтАШif, through annoyance or greed, he should accomplish the purpose (artham s─Бdhayet), then he should be fined by the king one Suvarс╣Зa.тАЩ

It is quoted also in Apar─Бrka (p. 782), which adds the following explanation:тАФтАШIf on being asked to refund, the man, through annoyance or greed, does not refund the money, but complain before the king with a view to establish the fact that the gift should not be taken back,тАФthen he should be forced to refund the moneyтАЩ;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (94a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The first half sums up the foregoing Head of Dispute, and the second introduces the next head.

тАШThe non-misappropriation of gifts has been explained.тАЩтАФтАШMisappropriationтАЩ is non-fulfilment; and it is the negation of this that is expressed by the negative prefix; the sense being that if the gift is resumed in the manner described above, it does not mean its improper тАШmisappropriationтАЩ; such is the rule of all gifts.

тАШLawfulтАЩтАФnot against law.

тАЬWhen the gift, after being promised, is not paid,тАФhow does this not militate against law?тАЭ

Such a question should not be raised. Since the right and lawful course in the case is that it should not be paid, or if paid, it should be taken hack.

тАШExplainedтАЩтАФdescribed.

тАШYath─Бvat,тАЩ тАШfullyтАЩтАФi.e., in the right manner. The meaning is that тАШit has been expounded in the proper manner.тАЩ Or the term тАШyath─БтАЩ may be taken to mean propriety, so that тАШyath─БvatтАЩ would mean properly.

тАШWagesтАЩтАФ subsistence-allowance; and the тАШnon-misappropriationтАЩ of this is going to be described. That is, what I am going to describe now is the behaviour by which there is no improper misappropriation of duty on the part of those who work on wages.тАФ(214)

If a hireling, without being ill, does not perform the stipulated work, through arrogance,тАФhe should be fined eight тАШKс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зalas,тАЩ and should not receive his wages.тАФ(215)

  • рдХрд╛рд▓реЗ рд╜рдкреВрд░реНрдгреЗ рддреНрдпрдЬрдиреН рдХрд░реНрдо рднреГрддрд┐рдирд╛рд╢рдирдореН рдЕрд░реНрд╣рддрд┐ рее рдиреНрд╕реНрдореН рем.релтАУрем рее рео.реирезрел рее

рдЕрдирд╛рд░реНрддрд╕реНрдп рджрдгреНрдб рдЙрдХреНрддреЛ рднреГрддрд┐рд╣рд░рдгрдВ рдЪ ред рдЖрд░реНрддрд╕реНрдпреЗрджрд╛рдиреАрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The man who does a stipulated work for a stipulated amount of wages is what is meant by the term тАШhirelingтАЩ here; i.e., the man who has been engaged to do a certain service, and who has agreed to do it within a definite time, if he is paid тАШfive rupeesтАЩ (for instance), if such a person does not finish the work, he should be fined eight тАШkс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗalaтАЩтАФof gold, or of silver, or of copper, in accordance with the nature of the work and other circumstances; and he should not receive the said rupees, which had been fixed as his wages.

But this applies to a case where the man is not ill, and omits to do the stipulated work, тАШthrough arrogance.тАЩ That is, the fine and the loss of wages are to be inflicted only upon the man who is not suffering from any illness, and who omits to do the work through sheer arrogance; so that it is not open to the man to retortтАФтАШPay me an amount commensurate with the labour already incurred by me.тАЩ

Some people hold that this same penalty is to be inflicted upon priests who leave off their work at their own will.

But this is not right; in the case of a sacrificial performance, the loss to the sacr ifi cer, caused by the rites being only half-done, is very great, so that the penalty in this ease should also be heavy; all that the sacrificer has lost should he made good, and the man should also compensate for the physical suffering involved in the saerificer having to repeat, the preliminary rites of the тАШD─лkс╣г─Б,тАЩ the тАШUpasadтАЩ and the тАШDevavrata.тАЩ

In a case where a mechanic approaches the rich man and urges him to undertake the digging of a tank, or the building of a temple, with the promise that he would supervise the work and see that it is completed, but subsequently slips off, then he shouldтАЭ make good all the loss of money and energy that his employer may have suffered; and thus according to the law of the тАШtrader and the carrier,тАЩ this law has been propounded by K─Бty─Бyana as being applicable to all cases: in his Sutra, be saysтАФтАШIf, through the fault of the carrier, the trader suiters some loss, it shall be borne by the carrier,тАФand so also the man who, having urged a man to invest his money on some undertaking, slinks off, after the work has been only half-done.тАЩ Here тАШinvestingтАЩ means applying t he money to the work; and one who makes the man do this, should make good the loss; such is the sense of the passage.

The law laid down in the verse applies to the person who is engaged on fooding only, for six months, or one year, to do a specified work. Says N─БradaтАФтАШIf a man does not do the stipulated work, he should be forced to receive his wages and do it; if he receives the wages, but does not do the work, he should suffer double the amount received in wages; if he abandons the work before the end of the stipulated time, he deserves to lose his wages.тАЩтАФ(215)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШKс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗalaтАЩтАФтАШOf gold, silver or copper, according to the nature of the caseтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi and Govindar─Бja); Kull┼лka also has тАШsuvarс╣З─БdiтАЩ, тАШgold and othersтАЩ, and not тАШgoldтАЩ only. Buhler has misrepresented him.

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─БтАЩ (2.198);тАФin тАШVyavah─Бramay┼лkhaтАЩ (p. 92);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 233), which notes that this is meant for a case where the hired man has left the work half undone; if he has done more than half, then only the wages have to be withheld (and there is to be no fine);тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 797), which notes that he should not receive the wages of even that part of the work which he may have done and in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (102a), which explains тАШan─Бrtaс╕етАЩ as not suffering from any disability imposed either by royal command or by supernatural causes.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 8.215-217)
**

─Аpastamba (2.28.2-3).тАФтАШA servant in tillage who abandons his work shall be flogged. The same punishment shall be inflicted on a herdsman leaving his work.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (5.153-154).тАФтАШA hired workman who abandons his work before the term has expired shall pay the whole amount of the stipulated wages to his employer; and he shall pay 100 Paс╣Зas to the King.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.193-198).тАФтАШIf a workman abandons his work after having received his wages, he shall refund double the amount received by him. If he abandons it before he has received any wages, he should pay to the employer the amount of the stipulated wages; but workmen may be allowed to retain their tools. If the employer has engaged a workman without settling his wages, he should be made by the King to pay the tenth part of the profit that he may have made in trade, in cattle or in agriculture, through the labours of that workman. In a case where the workman has worked beyond the stipulated time and place,тАФif this additional work decreases the profits of the employer, the latter may give him such wages as he likes for this additional work; but if it has tended to increase his profits, he shall give more. A man shall be paid his wages in accordance with the amount of work done: and neither party shall be stingy (of labour or payment); if the workman is sparing in his labour, he shall receive only what the employer may give him. In the case of a carrier, if he destroys the articles he is carrying, through neglect,тАФand not through any act of God or of the KingтАФhe should be made to replace it; if the employer puts obstacles in the way of his starting, he shall pay double the amount of the stipulated wages. If the carrier abandons the work after he has just started, he should be made to pay the seventh part of the stipulated wages; the fourth part, if he abandons it on the way; the whole of it if he abandons it after going half way of the journey. If the employer dismisses the carrier, he should be made to pay in the same proportion.тАЩ

N─Бrada (5.22).тАФтАШHired servants are of three kinds: highest, middlemost and lowest; the wages due for their labour are fixed in proportion to their skill and to the value of their services.тАЩ

Do. (6.2, 3, 5-9).тАФтАШA master shall regularly pay wages to the servant hired by him, whether it be at the commencement, at the middle, or at the end of his work, just as he had agreed to do. When the amount of the wages has not been fixed, the servant of a trader, a herdsman and an agricultural labourer shall take a tenth part of the profit derived from the trade, the product of the cows and of the grain respectively. If one fails to perform such work as he had promised to do, he shall be compelled to perform it, after first paying him the wages. If he does not perform it after receiving the wages, he must pay back twice the amount of the wages received. One who abandons merchandise which he had agreed to convey to its destination, shall give a sixth part of the wages. An employer who does not pay the wages that he had agreed to give shall forfeit those wages together with interest. A merchant who does not take a conveyance or beasts for draught of burden, after having hired them, shall be made to pay a fourth part of the hire, and the whole, if he leaves them half-way. And so shall a earner who fails to transport the goods entrusted to him forfeit his wages. He shall be compelled to pay twice the amount of his wages if he raises difficulties at the time of starting. When the merchandise has been damaged by the carrierтАЩs fault, he shall have to make good every loss,тАФnot including such losses as may have been caused by fate (accident) or by the King.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (16.8-20).тАФтАШThe servant for gain or pay is declared to be of many sorts; another is servant for a share of the grain…тАФA servant engaged for a day, a month, half-month, a six-month, two months, or a year, must do the work which he promised to do and receive the stipulated wages. A servant for a share of the grain is of two kindsтАФserving either a husbandman or an owner of cattle; ho shall receive a share of the grain produced, or of the milk; a third or fifth of the produce shall be given to the cultivator of the soil as his share. Let that cultivator to whom food and clothing are given take a fifth part of the crops; and let him who serves in consideration of the profit take a third part of the grain produced. Should a hired servant fail in the performance of ever so small a part of his employerтАЩs work, he forfeits his wages, and may be sued in court for his offence. When a servant does not perform his work after having received his wages, though he is able to work,… he shall be compelled to pay twice as much as his wages as a fine to the King, and to refund the wages to the employer. he who has promised to do work and does not perform it, shall he compelled to do so by forcible means even; and if, through obstinacy, such a servant should still not do it as engaged for, he shall be fined eight Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зalas, and his wages shall not he given to him. When a servant commanded by his employer does any improper act for the benefit of his employer, the latter shall be held responsible for it. When a master does not pay wages for the labour stipulated, after the work has been performed, he shall be compelled by the King to pay it, and a proportionate fine besides. A man hired for attendance on milch cows shall receive the whole milk every eighth day.тАЩ

But if he is ill and on recovering, completes the work as originally stipulated, he shall receive his wages for it, even after a long time.тАФ(216)

рдЖрд░реНрддреЛ рдпреЛ51 рднреГрддреЛ рд╜рд░реНрдзрдХреГрддрдВ рдХрд░реНрдо рдпрджрд┐ рд╣рд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛ рдЧрдЪреНрдЫреЗрддреН рд╕ рд╕реНрд╡рд╕реНрдердГ рд╕рдиреН рдкреБрдирд░реН рдЖрдЧрддреНрдп рдпрдереЛрдХреНрддрдореН рдЖрджреМ рддрддреН рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдмрд╣реБрдирд╛рдкрд┐ рдХрд╛рд▓реЗрди рдкреАрдбрдпрд╛ рдореБрдХреНрддрдГ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧрддрдГ рдХреГрддрдХрд░реНрдорд╢реЗрд╖реЗ рд▓рднреЗрддреИрд╡ рд╡реЗрддрдирдореН рее рео.реирезрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Forfeiture of the wages has been declared to be the penalty for the man when not ill; the present verse lays down the law regarding one who is ill.

If the labourer falls ill and gives up work after it has been half-done,тАФhut, on recovering, comes hack and completes the task as originally stipulated,тАФin this case, even though he may have taken a long time to recover from illness and return to work, the man shall, receive his wages, on having completed the work.тАФ(210).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, 24a):тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (102a), winch adds the explanation that the man who had stopped the work through some disabilityтАФif, on recovery, he comes and completes the stipulated work, then, if it were done after a lapse of time, he should receive his wages.

рд╕рдордпрдГ рд╕рдВрд╡рд┐рддреН56 рд╕рдЩреНрдХреЗрддрдГ- “рдЗрджрдВ рдордпрд╛ рднрд╡рддрд╛рдореН рдЕрдиреБрдорддреЗ рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддрдВ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрднреНрдпреБрдкрдЧрдордГ ред рддрдВ рднрд┐рдиреНрджрдиреНрддрд┐ рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рд╛рдордиреНрддрд┐ рддреЗ рд╕рдордпрднреЗрджрд┐рдирдГ ред “рд╕рдВрд╡рд┐рджрд╢реН рдЪ рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдордГ” (рдореНрдзреН рео.рел) рдЗрддрд┐ рдпрджреН рдЙрджреНрджрд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдВ рддрджреН рдЗрджрд╛рдиреАрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред

рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЗрдгрд╛рд░реНрдзреЗрди рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд░реЗрдгреЛрдкрд╕рдВрд╣рд╛рд░реЛ рд╜рдкрд░реЗрдг рдпрдереЛрджреНрджрд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рд╕реВрдЪрдирдореН рее рео.реирезрео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The term тАШvetan─Бd─Бnakarmaс╣Зaс╕етАЩ тАШthe action of nonpayment of wages,тАЩ only names the particular Head of Dispute; hence there is no room for any such objection as the followingтАФтАЬHow is it that the text speaks of having dealt with the action of non-payment of wages,тАФwhen the action of payment also has been dealt with?тАЭтАФBecause there is nothing wrong in the naming of a subject in accordance with anything that may he related to it; and every little detail does not necessarily enter into its name, for instance, in the Agni-hotra-rites, even though libations are actually offered to both Agni and Praj─Бpati, it is called тАШAgnihotra,тАЩ тАШoffering to AgniтАЩ; and similarly in the case of all such names as тАШSth┼лс╣З─Б,тАЩ тАШDar┼ЫaтАЩ and so forth?

тАШContractтАЩ is agreement, the stipulation or promise, in the formтАФтАШI shall certainly do such and such a thing, exactly in the manner in which you wish.тАЩ The тАШbreakersтАЩ of this are those who go against it.

What is referred to here is what has been mentioned above (under the Heads of Dispute) as тАШBreach of Contract?тАЩ

The first half of the verse sums up the foregoing section and the latter introduces the next.тАФ(218)

рдПрд╡рдВ рд╡рдгрд┐рдЩреНрдордардмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рджрд┐рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпреЗ рдИрджреГрд╢реЗ рдХреГрддрд╕рдВрдЗрддреН рддреЗрди рдирд╛рддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдорд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рдпрддреН рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдВ рдЧреНрд░рд╛рдорд╛рджреНрдпреБрдкрдХрд╛рд░рдХрдВ рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рдЪрд╛рд░рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдВ рдкреБрд░рд░рд╛рд╖реНрдЯреНрд░рд╛рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдзрд┐ рддрддреНрд╕рдВрд╡рд┐рджреНрд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдореЗ рджрдгреНрдбреЛ рд╜рдпрдореН ред

рд▓реЛрднрд╛рджреН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд╕реНрд╡реЗрдиреЛрдкрдХрд╛рд░рдЧрдиреНрдзреЗрди рдкрд░рдЧреНрд░рд╛рдордгреАрдХреГрддреЗрдирд╛рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рддрдиреНрддреНрд░реНрдпрдВ рд▓реЛрднрдГ ред рдЕрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирд╛рддреН рддреБ рд╡рд┐рд╕рдВрд╡рд╛рджрдорд╛рдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреНрдпрдГ60 рдХрд▓реНрдкрдГ рее рео.реирезреп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШVillageтАЩтАФis a group of households; and the term here stands for the inhabitants of the village; as it is only among men that there can he a compact. Similarly тАШcountryтАЩ is a group of villages.

тАШConfederationтАЩтАФa combination formed by persons professing the same faith or path, even though inhabiting different countries and belonging to different castes. For instance, there is the тАШconfederation of mendicants,тАЩ the тАШconfederation of traders,тАЩ the тАШconfederation of persons learned in the Vedas,тАЩ and so forth.

There are several kinds of business is which inhabitants of villages, etc., make a combination among themselves. For instanceтАФтАШour village is being encroached upon by the inhabitants of another village,тАФvery frequently they graze their cattle on our pasture-lands,тАФthey cut our embankments and carry away water,тАФif you be all agreed, then we shall prevent their doing all this,тАФand when we prevent them, it is possible that we may come to blows, or may have to appear before the тАШcourt;тАФif we remain combined in all this, then we shall go forward to prevent the encroachment; otherwise we shall let it be.тАЩ On this compact being proposed, men may agree to it, sayingтАФтАШyes; why should the ancient privileges of our village be trespassed by them?тАЩ Now, after having thus entered the compact and encouraged it, if some one were to shirk away and make common cause with the other party, and become lukewarm towards his own neighbours,тАФsuch a person should be banished by the king from his kingdom; i.e., he should not be allowed to live there any longer.

Similarly, in regard to the business of tradespeople or Br─Бhmaс╣Зas and others, when once a man has entered into a compact, he should not break it.

The penalty here laid down pertains to the breach of compacts relating to such work as is of public utility, in due accordance with law and custom, and not detrimental to the interests of the city and kingdom at large.

тАШThrough greedтАФтАШgreedтАЩ here stands for succumbing to oneтАЩs own selfish interests as served by the inhabitants of the rival village.

For cases of such breach, through ignorance, there is another remedy.тАФ(219)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 253), which explains тАШsatyenaтАЩ as тАШby swearingтАЩ;тАФin тАШMit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.187), which adds that this applies to cases where the cause of action is slight;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 182), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШGr─БmaтАЩ, is well-known;тАФтАШde┼ЫaтАЩ consists of a group of villages, a district;тАФтАШsaс╣ЕghaтАЩ is a corporation composed of several persons following one тАШdharma,тАЩ living in different places. It is also quoted in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (107a);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 132a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 8.219-221)
**

Viс╣гс╣Зu (5.168).тАФтАШHe who violates the established rule shall be banished.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.186-192).тАФтАШIf one misappropriates the property of a corporate body, or breaks the conditions of agreement, the King shall confiscate his entire property and banish him from the kingdom. What is declared by the members of the corporation should be obeyed by all component members; if any of them act contrariwise, he should be fined the first amercement……. This same rule applies to guilds, trading companies, corporations of heretics and other corporate bodies.тАЩ

N─Бrada (10.2-7).тАФтАШAmong heretics, followers of the Veda, guilds, corporations, troops, assemblages and other associations, the King shall maintain their usages and customsтАФwhatever be their laws, their duties, their rules regarding attendance, and the particular inodes of livelihood prescribed for them, that the

King shall approve of. The King shall prevent them from undertaking such acts as would be detrimental to the interests, either of their own associations or of the King himself, or despicable in their very nature. Mixed assemblages, unlawful wearing of arms and mutual attacks among these persons shall not be tolerated by the King. Those who cause dissension among the members of an association, shall undergo punishment of a specially severe kind.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (17.5, 10-16).тАФтАШA compact formed among villages, companies of artisans, and associations is called an agreement; such an agreement must be observed both in times of distress and for acts of piety. Two, three or five persons shall be appointed as advisers to the association; their advice shall be taken by the villagers, companies, corporations and other fellowships. When a stipulation has been entered in a document in the form, тАЬThe construction of a house or a shed, temple…… shall be undertaken by us in proportionate shares,тАЭтАФthat is lawful agreement. Such an agreement must be kept by all. he who fails in his agreement, though able to perform it, shall be punished with confiscation of his entire property and by banishment from the town. For one who has fallen out with his associates, or neglects his duties by them, a fine is ordained, amounting to six Niс╣гkas of four Suvarс╣Зas each. He who injures the joint stock, or insults a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa learned in the three Vedas, or breaks the mutual agreement, shall be banished from the town. An acrimonious or malicious person, and one who causes dissension or does violent acts, or who is inimically disposed towards the company, association or the King, shall be banished instantly from the town. Whatever is obtained by one man shall belong to all in common; whether it has been acquired a six-month or a month ago, it shall be divided in due proportion.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, pp. 793-795).тАФтАШOne who is addicted to acts of violence, one who sows dissension among the members of the corporation, and one who ruins the property of the corporation,тАФall these should be extirpated, after being proclaimed as such;тАФso says Bhс╣Ыgu. Whatever has been acquired for the corporation, belongs to all the members in equal shares.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 180).тАФтАШWhatever laws may have been prescribed for associations, the members thereof shall do all acts according to them, remaining firm in their duties.тАЩ
