  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдирдиреБ рдЪ рдЧрд╛рдиреНрдзрд░реНрд╡реЛ рд╜рдпрдВ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рдГ “рдЗрдЪреНрдЫрдпрд╛рдиреНрдпреЛрдиреНрдпрд╕рдВрдпреЛрдЧрдГ” (рдореНрдзреН рей.рейреи) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрддреНрд░ рди рдпреБрдХреНрддреЛ рджрдгреНрдбрдГ ред

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдХреЗрдиреЛрдХреНрддрдВ рдЧрд╛рдиреНрдзрд░реНрд╡реЗ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рджрдгреНрдбрдГ ред рдЕрдд рдПрд╡ рдирд╛рдпрдВ рд╕рддреАрдзрд░реНрдордГ, рди рдЪрд╛рдпрдВ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рдГ, рдЕрдЧреНрдирд┐рд╕рдВрд╕реНрдХрд╛рд░рд╛рднрд╛рд╡рд╛рддреН ред рдпрджреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╢рд╛рдХреБрдиреНрддрд▓реЗ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рд╕рд╡рдЪрдирдореН “рдЕрдордиреНрддреНрд░рдХрдореН рдЕрдирдЧреНрдирд┐рдХрдореН” рдЗрддрд┐ рддрджреН рджреБрд╖реНрдпрдиреНрддреЗрди рдХрд╛рдордкреАрдбрд┐рддреЗрдиреИрд╡рдВ рдХреГрддрдореН ред рди рдЪреЗрдЪреНрдЫрд╛рд╕рдВрдпреЛрдЧрдорд╛рддреНрд░рдВ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рдГ ред рд╕реНрд╡реАрдХрд░рдгреЛрдкрд╛рдпрднреЗрджрд╛рджреН рдЕрд╖реНрдЯреМ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рд╛рдГ, рди рдкреБрдирд░реН рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рднреЗрджрд╛рддреН ред рд╡реГрддреНрддрд╡рд░рдгрдВ рддрддреНрд░ рдкреБрдирдГ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН рдПрд╡рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред

рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рдЛрддреБрджрд░реНрд╢рдиреЛрддреНрддрд░рдХрд╛рд▓рдВ рдЧрд╛рдиреНрдзрд░реНрд╡рдГ ред рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЧреН рдЛрддреЛрдГ рд╢реБрд▓реНрдХреЛ рджрдгреНрдбреЛ рд╡рд╛ ред рдЕрде рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рдпрд╛рдГ рдХрд╛ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрддреНрддрд┐рдГ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛ рдПрд╡ рджреЗрдпрд╛ ред рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд╛рднрд┐рд▓рд╛рд╖рд╛ рдЪреЗрддреН рдХрд╛рдордореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд░ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрджреНрдпрд╛ ред рд╢реБрд▓реНрдХрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рдЪрд╛рддреНрд░рд╛рдкрд┐ рд╕рдХреГрджреН рдЙрдкрднреЛрдЧрдирд┐рд╖реНрдХреГрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердореН рдЕрд╕реНрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡ ред рд╡рд░рд╢реН рдЪреЗрдиреН рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд╛рднрд┐рд▓рд╛рд╖реЛ рд╣рдард╛рджреН рдЧреНрд░рд╛рд╣рдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ рее рео.рейремрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

It has been said that in the case of violating an unwilling maiden, all men, be they superior or inferior, should suiter death, with the sole exception of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa; and the present verse, they say, lays down the law relating to the violating of a willing maiden.

тАШSuperior,тАЩтАФin beauty, youth, caste and other points.

тАШInferiorтАЩтАФthe lowest.

The man is not to be killed if there is any equality between the parties.

If a man approaches a willing maiden who is equal to him in status,тАФhe shall pay to her father the nuptial fee, as is done in the case of the тАШAsuraтАЩ form of marriage. But if the father does not desire to receive the fee, that amount shall be paid as fine to the king.

тАЬIn as much as this would he a case of тАШG─БndharvaтАЩ marriageтАФmarriage by mutual consent,тАФit cannot be right to inflict any punishment.тАЭ

Who has said that there is to be no punishment in the case of marriage by mutual consent? In fact such an act would not be one befitting a chaste woman; nor would it he regarded as тАШmarriage,тАЩ for the simple reason that it would not have a sacramental character. As for the declaration in the Mah─Бbh─Бrata, in connection with ┼Ъakuntal─Б, to the effect that тАШthe G─Бndharva is a form of marriage, without fire and without mantras,тАЩтАФthis was an assertion made by Duс╣гyanta while he was suffering from the pangs of love. Further, mere тАШwilling intercourseтАЩ does not constitute тАШmarriage.тАЩ Marriage has been classified under eight heads on the basis of different methods used for taking a wife; and it does not mean that there are eight kinds of marriage. So that (in the G─Бndharva marriage also), the due selection of the bridegroom (even though he has been already chosen by the bride) and the subsequent rites have got to be performed.

Or, the тАШG─БndharvaтАЩ may be accepted as a тАШmarriageтАЩ only in the case of a maiden after puberty; and before that, the man is to pay the nuptial fee or a fine.

The question arisesтАФwhat is to be done with the maiden?

The answer is that she shall be given to that same man. But if she has ceased to love him, she may be given to another man. But in either case the тАШnuptial feeтАЩ has got to be paid, by way of compensation for the single act of intercourse.

If the man has ceased to love the girl, he shall be forced to accept her.тАФ(366)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 402), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШUttam─БmтАЩ has to be qualified by тАШif willingтАЩ;тАФтАШsam─Бm,тАЩ belonging to the same caste as himself;тАФтАШ┼ЫulkamтАЩ, fee agreed upon by both the parties, as in the тАШ─АsuraтАЩ form of marriage.

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 321), to the effect that when a man of the lower caste has intercourse with a maiden of a higher caste, whether willing or unwilling, his penalty is death, but when one has intercourse with a willing maiden of the same caste as himself, then he shall present to her father a cow and a bull, if the latter be willing to accept it (and the man has to marry the maiden in this case, adds B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л); but if the father is not willing to receive the fee, its equivalent shall be paid as fine to the king (and in this case also the maiden is to be married to the man).

It is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 157a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

But if any man wantonly defiles a maiden through sheer audacity, his fingers should be instantly clipped off, or he should be fined six hundred.тАФ(367)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕рдХрд╛рдорд╛ рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛ рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛рджрдпрд╕реН253 рддреБ рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдГ рд╕рдВрдирд┐рд╣рд┐рддрд╛рд╕реН рддрд╛рдиреН рдЕрдирд┐рдЪреНрдЫрддреЛ рд╜рднрд┐рд╖рд╣реНрдп рдЕрднрд┐рднреВрдп рджрд░реНрдкреЗрдг рдмрд▓реЗрди, “рдХрдГ рдХрд┐рдВ рдХрд░реНрддреБрдВ рдореЗ рд╢рдХреНрддрдГ”, рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд░рд╛рдЧрдорд╛рддрд╛рд╢реНрд░рд┐рддрдГ рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рдВ рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рджреН рд╡рд┐рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рджреН рджреВрд╖рдпреЗрддреН ред рдЕрдиреЗрдХрд╛рд░реНрдердГ рдХрд░реЛрддрд┐рдГ ред рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╢реБ рдХрд░реНрддреНрдпрд╛рдГ рдЫреЗрддреНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛ рдЕрд░реНрдзрд╛рдЩреНрдЧреБрд▓рдпрдГ, рд╖рдЯреНрд╢рддрд╛рдирд┐ рд╡рд╛ рджрдгреНрдбреНрдпрдГ ред

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреБ “рдпреЛ рд╜рдХрд╛рдорд╛рдВ рджреВрд╖рдпреЗрддреН” (рдореНрдзреН рео.рейремрек) рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡ рд╡рдзреНрдпрд░реНрдерд╕реНрдпреЛрдкрд╕рдВрд╣рд╛рд░реЛ254 рд╜рдпрдореН ред

рддрд╛рдбрдирд╛рддреН рдкреНрд░рднреГрддрд┐ рдорд╛рд░рдгрдВ рдпрд╛рд╡рджреН рд╡рдзреНрдпрд░реНрдердГ255 ред рддрддреНрд░реЗрдорд╛рдВ рдирд┐рдХреГрд╖реНрдЯрдЬрд╛рддреАрдпрд╛рдВ рдЪ рджреВрд╖рдпрдиреН рди рдорд╛рд░реНрдпрддреЗ, рдЕрдкрд┐ рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдЩреНрдЧреБрд▓реА рдЕрд╕реНрдп рдЫрд┐рджреНрдпреЗрдд рее рео.рейремрен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Even though the maiden may be willing, if her parents and other relatives are close hy, and their presence is not heeded by the man who, through sheer audacity, relying upon his force and having the idea тАШwho can do anything to me?тАЩтАФand relying solely upon the maidenтАЩs love for himтАФтАШdefiles her,тАЩтАФthe root тАШkс╣ЫтАЩ which has many meanings, stands here for the act of defiling, then тАШhis fingers should be clipped offтАЩ;тАФor тАШhe should be fined six hundred.тАЩ

Others have held that this verse sums up what has been said (under 361) regarding the violating of an unwilling maiden, to be punished with тАШdeath.тАЩ тАШKillingтАЩ in this connection stands for corporal punishmentтАФbeginning with beating and ending with actual killing; and what the present text means is that if a man defiles a maiden of a low caste, he shall not be killed.тАФhe shall have only his fingers clipped off.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 321), to the effect that two fingers are to be cut off if the man only defiles the maiden with his fingers;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 858), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШAbhiс╣гahyaтАЩ, forcibly,тАФтАШkury─Бt,тАЩ defile the maiden by the introduction of fingers,тАФthe two fingers (its reading being тАШkartye aс╣ЕgulyauтАЩ) with which he defiles her should be cut off at once, without delay;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 403), which has the following notes:тАФтАШAbhiс╣гahya,тАЩ insolently,тАФтАШkury─Бt,тАЩ should defile,тАФтАШkalpyeтАЩ (which is its reading for тАШkartyeтАЩ), should be cut off;тАФand in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.288), to the effect that when a man defiles an unwilling maiden of the same caste as himself by thrusting his fingers into her, he should be fined 600 and two of his fingers should be cut off.

It is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 157a).

рд╕рдХрд╛рдорд╛рдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ, рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд┐ рд╕рдХрд╛рдорд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрд╛рддреН ред рдЕрднрд┐рд╖рд╣реНрдп рдХрд░рдгреЗ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдВ рджрдгреНрдбрдГ,256 рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд╢рдВ рдЪреМрд░реНрдпрд╡рджреН рджреНрд╡рд┐рд╢рддреЛ рд╜рдЩреНрдЧреБрд▓реАрдЪреНрдЫреЗрджрд╡рд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрдГ ред рдЕрде рдХрд╕реНрдорд┐рдВрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреН рдкреБрд░реБрд╖реЗ рд╜рдиреБрд░рд╛рдЧрд╡рддреА рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛ рддреЗрди рд╕рдВрдпреБрдЬреНрдпрдорд╛рдирд╛ рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рддреНрд╡рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреМ рд╕рдХрд╛рдорд╛ рдпреЗрди рд╡рд┐рдХреГрддреАрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдпрдВ рджрдгреНрдбрдГ ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛257 рд╣рд╕реНрддрд╕реНрдкрд░реНрд╢рдорд╛рддреНрд░рдореН рдЗрд╣ рджреВрд╖рдг ред рдкреНрд░рд╛рд░реНрдердиреАрдпрд╛рдпрд╛рдГ рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рдпрд╛ рд╣рд╕реНрддрд╕реНрдкрд░реНрд╢рдГ “рдордпрд╛ рд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдВ рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рддреНрд╡рд╛ рдирд╛рдиреНрдп рдПрддрд╛рдореН рдЕрд░реНрдереИрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ рд╜рдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреНрдиреН рдЕрдиреБрд░рд╛рдЧрд┐рдгреАрдВ рдордиреНрдпрдорд╛рдирдГ” рее рео.рейремрео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Inasmuch as the foregoing verse also pertains to the case of a willing maiden, the penalty therein laid down applies to the case where the man defiles her through sheer audacity; while in a case where he does it by stealth, secretly like a thief, the punishment shall consist of the fine of two hundred, without the amputation of the fingers.

Or, the text may refer to the following caseтАФ

If the maiden happens to be in lore with a certain man, and having had intercourse with him has lost her virginity,тАФthen since the girl was willing, the man, for the crime of defiling her, shall suffer the penalty here laid down.

Or, the тАШdefilingтАЩ meant here may be taken as the touching of the hand and some such part of the body; the manтАЩs motive beingтАФтАШif people see me touching her hand, they will think that she loves me and then no one else will seek for her baud, and she shall be mine.тАЩтАФ(368)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 403), which adds that this applies to the case where the maiden is of a lower caste;тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 321);тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.288) as providing for a case where the finger-defilement occurs in the case of a willing maiden. B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л adds that тАШtulyaс╕етАЩ means a man of the same caste as the girl;тАФhe is to be fined 200 with a view to prevent repetition.

It is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 157a).

рдмрд╛рд▓рднрд╛рд╡рд╛рджреН рд░реВрдкрд╛рджрд┐рджреНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рджреН рд╡рд╛ рдХрдиреНрдпреИрд╡ рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рдВ рдирд╛рд╢рдпреЗрддреН рд╕рд╛ рджреНрд╡рд┐рд╢рддрдВ рджрд╛рдкреНрдпрд╛ ред рд╢реБрд▓реНрдХрд╢реН рдЪ рддреНрд░рд┐рдЧреБрдгрдГ ред

рдПрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддрдорд░реВрдкрд╕реМрдиреНрджрд░реНрдпрд╛рджреНрдпрдкреЗрдХреНрд╖рдВ258 рд╕реМрднрд╛рдЧреНрдпрд╛рдкреЗрдХреНрд╖рдВ рдЪ ред рд╢рд┐рдлрд╛ рд░рдЬреНрдЬреБрд▓рддрд╛рдкреНрд░рд╣рд╛рд░рд╛рдГ рее рео.рейремреп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Either through childishness, or through jealousy for her greater beauty, if a maiden pollutes another maiden, then she should be made to pay two hundred; and also the double of her nuptial fee.

What Is the amount of this fee?

It shall depend upon the beauty of the girl, or upon her fortune and other qualities.

тАШLashesтАЩтАФstrokes of rope or creeper.тАФ(369).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 321);тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 403), which adds that тАШdviguс╣ЗamтАЩ means тАШdouble of 200тАЩ;тАФand тАШ┼Ыiph─БтАЩ stands for тАШstrokes of creepers, ropes and such other thingsтАЩ;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 859), which adds the following explanation:тАФIf one maiden happen to penetrate another with her fingers or some such thing, she shall pay a fine of 200 to the king, and that fee or price which the defiled maiden is worth, three times (its reading being тАШtriguс╣ЗamтАЩ or тАШdviguс╣ЗamтАЩ) that shall be paid to her by the other girl, who is, in addition, to receive ten stripesтАФi.e., strokes of rope or creepers.

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.288) to the same effect; where it adds that тАШdouble the feeтАЩ (dviguс╣Зam ┼Ыulkam) is to be paid by the offending girl to the father of the defiled girl.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 1016);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 157a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If a woman destroys the virginity of a maiden, she shall have her head shaven off; or undergo amputation of her fingers.

тАШBeing carried by a donkeyтАЩтАФin the case of shaving. Some people hold that the different penalties are laid down in view of the caste of the girl, and the caste of the polluter;тАФthe three penalties applying to the three castes Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and the rest:

But there being no authority for such a view, it should be ignored.тАФ(370)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

According to тАШothersтАЩ in Medh─Бtithi and N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa, the verse describes three distinct penalties for women of the three distinct castes. Govindar─Бja and Kull┼лka hold that in any one case, whether one or the other of the three penalties shall be inflicted will depend upon the circumstances of that case.

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 321;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 403), which explains тАШstr─лтАЩ as a woman who is herself not a maiden;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 859), which says str─л meant here is тАШother than a maidenтАЩ, the тАШmaidenтАЩ having been already dealt with in the preceding verse;тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.288), which, explains тАШstr─лтАЩas тАШa grown up experienced womanтАЩ;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 157a), which explains тАШprakury─БtтАЩ as тАШcauses penetration.тАЩ

If the convicted man is accused again within a year, he shall be punished with a double fine. the same also in the case of intercourse with a тАШvr─Бty─БтАЩ or a тАШch─Бс╣Зс╕Н─Бl─л.тАЩтАФ(373)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШConvictedтАЩтАФcharged of the crime; when a man has committed adultery with a woman and has been punished, he is said to be тАШconvicted.тАЩ

If such a man, within a year, commits adultery with the same woman, then the man being thus convicted and accused again, the fine shall be double.

Another reading is тАШsaс╣Гvatsar─Бbhi┼ЫastasyaтАЩ in the compounded form. In this case also the passage may be construed somehow.

тАШтАЬThe same also in the case of intercourse with a тАЬvr─Бty─Б,тАЭтАЩтАФthat is, when accused again.

Such cannot be the meaning of the verse, we say. In the case of the intercourse in question, there are hound to be various grades of punishment, in the shape of the тАШlowest,тАЩ the тАШmiddleтАЩ and the тАШhighestтАЩ amercement. So that it is not clear the тАШdoubleтАЩ of which one is meant.

What therefore is meant by тАШthe sameтАЩ is that the line in the case of intercourse with the тАШvr─Бty─БтАЩ is to be тАШthe sameтАЩ as that in that of the тАШcaс╣Зс╕Н─Бl─лтАЩ; and for the latter case, the tine of тАШone thousandтАЩ has been prescribed under 385, below.

тАШVr─Бty─Б.тАЩтАФтАШVr─БtaтАЩ means host, crowd; so that the тАШvr─Бty─БтАЩ would be one who has intercourse with a large number of men; the term being explained etymologically as тАШvr─Бtena charatiтАЩ; or it may be explained as тАШvr─Бtam arhati,тАЩ the ya in the middle coming in in accordance with P─Бс╣Зini, 5.1.66. Who would be the woman that would be тАШvr─Бty─БтАЩ in this latter sense? The unchaste woman who has intercourse with several men; for it is only she that can be said to be fit for a host,тАЩ (тАШvr─Бtam arhatiтАЩ).

Or, the term тАШvr─Бty─БтАЩ may stand for the village slave-girl, who has several masters.

Some people explain тАШvr─Бty─БтАЩ as meaning unmarried.

But according to this view the term would not be held to be used in its primary sense. For the writers on Smс╣Ыti have used the term in the sense of тАШthose who have fallen off from the S─Бvitr─лтАЩ; and this cannot he applicable to women.

тАЬBut for the woman marriage has been declared to be the substitute for upanayana (initiation into S─Бvitr─л). So that she who has not been married, would be a тАШvr─Бty─Б.тАЩтАЭ

But in that case the term would be used in the figurative, not the primary, sense. Even though the term тАШupanayanaтАЩ has been used in the sense of marriage, which is not-upanayana, yet when it is declared that тАШthe man who is devoid of the upanayana is called a vr─Бtya,тАЩ it is never understood to mean that the man devoid of marriage is meant. Just as when it is said that тАШthis place is without a lion,тАЩ it is never understood to mean that тАШthe place is without the boy,тАЩтАФeveu though the term тАШlionтАЩ may have been figuratively used for the тАШboy.тАЩ

тАЬIn the latter case there is possibility of the primary moaning of the term тАШlionтАЩ being applicable, but in the case in question, there is no such for the term тАШupanayana.тАЩтАЭ

Figurative use does not depend entirely upon the impossibility of the primary meaning; it stands in need of other attendant circumstances also.

Then again, there is no doubt that the term тАШupana yanaтАЩ in the sense of marriage can be only figurative; but what reason can there be for regarding the term тАШvr─Бty─БтАЩ also (in the present text) as figurative? Even though it be figurative, it will he difficult to explain this as being based upon the fact of there being no marriage.

Further, it may be supposed that the woman born of a vr─Бtya,тАЩ is also a vr─Бty─Б on the analogy of the bird born of a crow being a crow, and that born of the kite being a kite. And the term тАШvr─Бty─БтАЩ would he applicable to the child by its relationship to the тАШvr─Бty─БтАЩ (the nominal affix denoting this relationship).

тАЬBut the wife of the vr─Бtya man cannot be called a тАШvr─Бty─Б,тАЩ even though she bear a relationship to him.тАЭ

But in the case cited the difficulty would be due to the case coming under P─Бс╣ЗiniтАЩs S┼лtra 4.1.18 (by which the feminine form would be тАШvr─Бty─лтАЩ). The case of тАШthe child born of the Vr─Бty─Б womanтАЩ however does not come under this S┼лtra.

Thus then, if the term тАШvr─Бty─БтАЩ is to be taken in a figurative sense, it is to be understood to stand for тАШthe woman born of a vr─Бty─Б woman.тАЩ If on the other hand, the term is used in its primary sense, then it must mean тАШshe who is fit for a vr─Бta or crowd,тАЩтАФThe тАШunmarried womanтАЩ on the other hand does not come in either as the primary or the figurative meaning. Further, there is no time fixed for the marriage of women, by transgressing which they would become vr─Бty─Б (in the sense in which the man transgressing the time-limit for Upanayana becomes known as vr─Бtya). As for the rule that girls should be married before puberty,тАФits transgression also is permitted by the sanctioning of the custom of тАШSvayaс╣Гvara,тАЩ тАШself-choice,тАЩ which can be done only when a woman is of a sufficiently advanced age, and hence has attained puberty. And further, if no girl were to be married after puberty, several girls would have to remain in their fatherтАЩs house till death.тАФ(373).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШVr─Бty─БтАЩтАФтАШ(a) A public woman, or (b) a woman who belongs, as slave, to several men, or (c) тАШunmarriedтАЩ (the last being rejected) (Medh─Бtithi who is misrepresented by Buhler);тАФтАШthe wife of a person, who, though of a twice-born caste, has not had his sacramentsтАЩ (Govindar─Бja ‘and Kull┼лka).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 394), which adds the following explanatory notes:тАФIf a man is found to persist in the intercourse for one year, after having been convicted of it,тАФhe should suffer double the penalty prescribed for the first offence of its kind; and the penalty should be enhanced in proportion to the period of duration of the connection. тАШVr─Бty─БтАЩ is the woman fallen from virtue, who has abandoned all meritorious acts; but Hal─Бyudha explains тАШvr─Бty─БтАЩ as a maiden that has passed her marriageable age.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Mah─Бbh─Бrata (12.165.66).тАФтАШOn having intercourse with a C─Бс╣Зс╕Н─Бla woman, a man of the three higher castes shall he branded with the sign of a headless body and banished; but the ┼Ъ┼лdra shall be only branded. A C─Бс╣Зс╕Н─Бla approaching an ─Аrya woman shall be put to death.тАЩ

373 On a man (once) convicted, who is (again) accused within a year, a double fine (must be inflicted); even thus (must the fine be doubled) for (repeated) intercourse with a Vratya and a Kandali.

A ┼Ы┼лdra having intercourse with a twice-born woman, protected or unprotected, shall be deprived of his limb and his whole property, in the case of the unprotected woman, and of everything in that of the protected.тАФ(374).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШ┼Ъ┼лdraтАЩтАФi.e., down to the Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla;тАФтАШhaving intercourseтАЩтАФsexualтАФтАШwith a twice-born womanтАЩ;тАФтАШprotected or unprotectedтАЩтАФby her husband,тАФshall be punished according to law.

What shall be the punishment?

If he has intercourse with an unprotected woman, he shall be deprived of his тАШlimb,тАЩ and also of тАШhis whole property.тАЩ

As to the question regarding what he is to be deprived of, the answer is provided by the epithet тАШaс╣Еgasarvasvi,тАЩ which mentions the тАШlimbтАЩ and the тАШwhole properlyтАЩ; especially as nothing else is mentioned, and no other thing is specified.

The limb of which he is to be deprived is that with which he has offended.

If he has intercourse with a тАШprotectedтАЩ woman, тАШhe is to be deprived of everything,тАЩтАФ not of only one limb, but of the whole body.

The present verse lays down the amputation of the limb, the confiscation of his entire property, and the inflicting of death, as forms of punishment,тАФthe sense being that punishment should be inflicted on the man. Says Gautama (12.2):тАФIn the case of intercourse with women, there should be amputation of the generative organ and also the confiscation of his entire property,тАФif she happens to be protectedтАЩтАФ(374)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra p. 378), to the effect that when a ┼Ъ┼лdra has intercourse with an unguarded woman of a higher caste, his organ is to be cut off and all his property confiscated, and if he has recourse to a guarded woman of the higher caste, he shall suffer death and his entire property shall be confiscated.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 395), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШDvaij─Бtam varс╣ЗamтАЩ, a woman of the twice-born caste,тАФтАШ─БvasanтАЩ, having recourse to,тАФтАШaguptaik─Бс╣Еgasarvasv─лтАЩ (which is its reading for тАШaguptamaс╣Еgasarvasv─лтАЩ), if the woman is one who is not guarded, the man shall be deprived of one limb and also of his entire property; and of his entire property as also of his entire body (if the woman is one who is guarded).

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.280), which has the same explanation as the one in para 1 above;тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 100), which also has the same explanationтАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 156a).

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.286, 294).тАФтАШIf one has intercourse with a woman of the same caste as himself, he shall be punished with the highest fine; if with a woman of a lower caste, with the middle fine; if with a woman of a higher caste, he shall be put to death and the womanтАЩs ears and nose shall be cut off. If a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla has intercourse with an ─Аrya woman, he shall be put to death.тАЩ

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЪрдХреНрд╖рддреЗ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрдкрд╛рджрд╛рдирд╛рддреН рд╕рдорд╛рдирдЬрд╛рддреАрдп рдПрд╡ рд╕рдВрд╡рддреНрд╕рд░рдирд┐рд░реЛрдзрдиреЗрди рджрдгреНрдбрд╛рдзрд┐рдХреНрдпрдореН ред рдпрджрд┐ рд╕рдВрд╡рддреНрд╕рд░рдореН рдЕрд╡рд░реБрджреНрдзрдВ рдХрд░реЛрддрд┐ рддрддреЛ рд╜рдпрдВ рджрдгреНрдбрдГ ред

рдЖрджреНрдпрдореН рдПрд╡ рддреБ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирдВ рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпреНрдпрдореН ред рди рдЪ рд╕рдорд╣реАрдиреЛрддреНрддрдорд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдХрдердВ рд╕рдорджрдгреНрдбрддреНрд╡рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд╛рдЪреНрдпрдореН ред рдпрдд рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН “рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдПрд╡ рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рджрд╛рд░рд╛ рд░рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддрдорд╛рдГ рд╕рджрд╛” (рдореНрдзреН рео.рейрелреп) рдЗрддрд┐ рее рео.рейренрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The confiscation of his entire property is the penalty prescribed for the Vai┼Ыya. Though all the twice-born castes are mentioned together here, yet the penalty here laid down is not meant for the case where the Vai┼Ыya has intercourse with a woman of the same caste; it is meant for cases of intercourse with Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and Kс╣гatriya women.

Similarly in the case of the Kс╣гatriya having intercourse with a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa woman, the punishment consists in a fine of one thousand, and also тАШshaving with urine,тАЩтАФi.e., the urine of the ass being used in place of water.

Others explain the verse as follows:тАФSince no other caste is mentioned, the punishment is meant for the case where the Vai┼Ыya has intercourse with a woman of the same caste,тАФthe additional punishment being due to his keeping her for a year. The sense is that if he keeps her for a year then his punishment shall be as here laid down.

As a matter of fact however, the former explanation appears to be more reasonable. It cannot be argued against it thatтАФтАЬthe same punishment cannot rightly apply to cases of intercourse with equal, superior and inferior castes;тАЭ because it has been declared that тАШthe wives of all castes are to be guarded with the greatest care.тАЩтАФ(375)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 396), which adds the following explanatory notes:тАФFor having recourse to a guarded Br─Бhmaс╣Зa woman, the Vai┼Ыya is to be imprisoned for one year and his entire property is to be confiscated,тАФthe Kс╣гatriya is to be fined 1000, and shall have his head wetted with urine and then shaved;тАФand in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 1009).

рдЕрдЧреБрдкреНрддрд╛ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рддрд╛, рднреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╢реАрд▓рд╛ рдЕрдирд╛рдерд╛ рдЪ ред рддрджреНрдЧрдордиреЗ рд╡реИрд╢реНрдпрдВ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрд╕рддрдВ рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдХрд░реЛрддрд┐рдГ рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрд╛рджреН рджрдгреНрдбрдиреЗ рд╡рд░реНрддрддреЗ ред рджрдгреНрдбрдпреЗрджреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рдкрдЮреНрдЪ рд╢рддрд╛рдиреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕реНрдпреЗрддрд┐ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрд╢рддрдГ, рдмрд╣реБрд╡реНрд░реАрд╣рд┐рд░реН рдорддреНрд╡рд░реНрдереАрдпрдГ ред рддрдерд╛ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдВ рдпрдерд╛ рдкрдЮреНрдЪ рд╢рддрд╛рдиреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕реНрдп рднрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ ред

рдПрд╡рдВ рд╕рд╣рд╕реНрд░рд┐рдгрдВ рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд╕рд╣рд╕реНрд░рдореН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рджрдгреНрдбрдГ, рди рдЧреГрд╣реЗ рдзрдирдореН ред “рдЕрдЩреНрдЧрд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрд╡реА” (рдореНрдзреН рео.рейренрек)рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпреЗрдпрдореН- рддрдерд╛ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдВ рдпрдерд╛рдЩреНрдЧрдВ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрд╡рдВ рдЪ рддрд╕реНрдп рджрдгреНрдбреЛ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдзрд┐рдХреЛ рджрдгреНрдбреЛ рд░рдХреНрд╖рд╛рдзрд┐рдХреГрддреЛ рд░рдХреНрд╖рддрд┐ рддрддреН рдкреБрдирдГ рд╕ рдПрд╡рд╛рдкрд░рд╛рдзреНрдпрддрд┐ рее рео.рейренрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШUnprotectedтАЩтАФhas been explained as one who has lost her chastity and has no one to look after her.

For having intercourse with such a woman, he shall тАШcommitтАЩ the Vai┼Ыya тАШwith fine hundred.тАЩ The verb to commit is to be taken in the sense of fining, from the context; the meaning is that тАШhe shall be fined live hundred.тАЩ

The term тАШpa├▒ca┼ЫutamтАЩ is to be expounded as тАШhe who has live hundred,тАЩтАФthe Bahuvr─лhi compound denoting possession.

The meaning is that the king should so commit him that he gets five hundred.

тАЬDoes this mean that if the man has more than five hundred, the excess shall he confiscated?тАЭ

Not so, we reply; for in that case if the man has only five hundred, then for him there would be no punishment prescribed.

тАЬWhat I hen is the meaning?тАЭ

The expression тАШhe shall he committed with five hundredтАЩ means that he is to be punished with a fine consisting of five hundred. That such is the meaning is indicated by the context.

Similarly, тАШthe Kс╣гatriya is to be committed with one thousandтАЩ;тАФi.e., his punishment shall consist of one thousand; and not that his property at home shall he one thousand.

The expression тАШaс╣Еgasarvasv─лтАЩ (in verse 371) is to be explained similarly to mean that (he king shall so act that the manтАЩs punishment consist of his limb and bis whole property.

The penalty for the Kс╣гatriya is severer, because it is his duty to guard people; so that if he offends, his guilt is the greater.тАФ(376)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This v├йrse is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 106);тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.286); where B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л adds that in тАШpa├▒ca┼ЫatamтАЩ we have Bahuvr─лhi compound; and notes that the penalty for a Kс╣гatriya is double that for a Vai┼Ыya, because it is the function of the former to protect and guard people from all kinds of harm; and that the fine of 500 prescribed for the Vai┼Ыya is meant for that case where he does it under the impression that the woman is a ┼Ъ┼лdra, or for that where the woman concerned is merely Br─Бhmaс╣Зa by birth and is entirely devoid of all Br─Бhmaс╣Зical virtues.

It is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 156a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШBoth these,тАЩ i.e., the Vai┼Ыya and the Kс╣гatriyaтАФтАШoffending againstтАЩтАФi.e., having sexual intercourse withтАФa protected Br─Бhmaс╣Зa womanтАФтАШshould he punished like the ┼Ъ┼лdra,тАЩтАФi.e. тАШdeprived of everything, if the woman is protectedтАЩ (as declared in 374).

тАШOr he should be burnt in a fire of dry grassтАЩтАФthe term тАШorтАЩ is meant to indicate option in the method of killing, and not in regard to the killing itself. Because in the case of the protected Br─Бhmaс╣Зa woman, there is no other penalty for the ┼Ъ┼лdra except deathтАФ(377)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra p. 318);тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 106);тАФand in Mit─Бk с╣гar─Б (2.286), where B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л adds the following notes:тАФIf a Kс╣гatriya or a Vai┼Ыya have intercourse with a guarded Br─Бhmaс╣Зa woman, he should be punished like a ┼Ъ┼лdra, i. e., deprived of his whole body and his entire property (according to 374); i.e., his entire property should be confiscated and he should be put to death;тАФanother alternative penalty prescribed is that he should be put to death, without any confiscation of property; and it is by means of the тАШKaс╣н─БgniтАЩ that he is to be put to death.

It is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 155b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Even though one has lost her chastity, if the woman continues to be protected by her father, brother or relatives,тАФand a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa has intercourse with her by force, he should be made to pay one thousand.

If however the woman is protected and still chaste, then the man is to be banished and branded, in addition to the fine.

Even if the word тАШprotectedтАЩ be taken to mean chaste, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa would be absolved by paying a thousand тАШbanishmentтАЩ and тАШbrandingтАЩ being the general punishment laid down for all cases of immoral intercourse with other women.тАФ(378)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 317), which remarks that this refers to cases where the woman is not the wife of oneтАЩs teacher or friend;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 393);тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 105), as laying down the penalty for forcible intercourse with a chaste Br─Бhmaс╣Зa woman;тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (p. 256) where B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л notes that inasmuch as the latter half contains the epithet тАШicchanty─Б,тАЩ тАШwilling,тАЩтАФwhich is in contradistinction to тАШbal─Бt,тАЩ тАШby force,тАЩ of the former half,тАФit follows that in case the first half refers to the guarded woman, the second half must refer to the unguarded one; the meaning being that if a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa has connection only once with a willing woman of the same caste, he should be fined 500;тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 330);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 144b and 155b), which explains тАШguptamтАЩ as тАШproperly guardedтАЩ; and adds that this refers to cases of adultery other than those with the wife of the guru or the friend, for which latter other penalties have been prescribed.

рдЗрддрд░реЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрд┐рдХ рдПрд╡ рд╢реНрд░реБрддрдВ рдорд╛рд░рдгрд╛рджрд┐рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдореН рдПрд╡ ред рддрджрдирдиреНрддрд░рдореН рдЗрджрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЙрдЪреНрдпрдорд╛рдирдВ рдореМрдгреНрдбреНрдпрдВ рддрдЪреНрдЫреЗрд╖рддрдпрд╛ рд╕рд╣рд╕реНрд░рдВ рджрдгреНрдбреЛ рд╡рд┐рдзреАрдпрдд рдЗрддрд┐ рдордиреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрджрдгреНрдбрд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рдирд╛рддреН рдХрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╕рдЩреНрдЧреЛ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдп рдпреЗрдиреИрд╡рдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рдореМрдгреНрдбреНрдпрдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрд┐рдХ рдЗрддрд┐ ред “рдкреБрдорд╛рдВрд╕рдВ рджрд╛рд╣рдпреЗрддреН” (рдореНрдзреН рео.рейренреи) рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдпрд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рдирдкреНрд░рд╕рдХреНрддрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рдЪреЗрддреН, рддрддреНрд░реИрд╡ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдВ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН рддрдерд╛ рд╣рд┐ рд╕реНрдлреБрдЯрдВ рддрджреНрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрддреНрд╡рдВ рдкреНрд░рддреАрдпреЗрдд288 рее рео.рейренреп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In cases where тАШdeathтАЩ has been laid down for the Kс╣гatriya and other castes, it is to be тАШtonsureтАЩ for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa. For instance, for adultery, the non-Br─Бhmaс╣Зa deserves the death-penalty,тАФthe general rule being that тАШthe male shall be flayed.тАЩ

The term тАШpr─Бс╣З─БntakaтАЩ is to be explained as pr─Бс╣З─Бn─Бm antam gacchati or тАШpr─Бс╣З─Бn─Бmant?m karoti,тАЩтАФthat which brings about the end of life; the form being formed with the тАШс╣ЗvulтАЩ affix.

Others read тАШpr─Бс╣З─БntikaтАЩ;тАФin which case the affix is тАШс╣нha├▒,тАЩтАФthe meaning being тАШrelating to death.тАЩ

тАШFor the other castesтАЩтАФthe Kс╣гatriya and others, except the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa,тАФтАШit is to be actual death.тАЩ

Putting to death having already been prescribed before, the present text has been taken as serving the purpose of putting forward the injunction of tonsure and the fine of one thousand, as supplementary to the former injunction. Otherwise, in as much as the death penalty has not been prescribed for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, what would be the occasion for declaring that тАШTonsure is the death-penalty for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa?тАЩ

It might be argued that the possibility of death-penalty for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa is indicated by the general law that тАШthe man should be flayed.тАЩтАЭ

But in that case the substitute should have been put forward in that same connection; so that the connection of the two could be clearly perceived.тАФ(379).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 393), which adds the explanation that тАШfor an offence in connection with which death penalty has been prescribed, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa shall only have his head shavedтАЩ;тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (─Аc─Бra, p. 399);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 159);тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 681), which adds that banishment from the city and such other penalties are equal to the death-penalty, so far as the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa is concerned;тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 115);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 58b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 8.379-381)
**

Gautama (8.13).тАФтАШThe Br─Бhmaс╣Зa who is well-versed in his dharma must not be subjected to corporal punishment; he must not be imprisoned; he must not be fined; he must not be exiled; he must not be reviled; he must not be excluded.тАЩ

Baudh─Бyana (1.18.17).тАФтАШA Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, forsooth, shall not suffer corporal punishment for any offence.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (5.2-3).тАФтАШIn the case of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, no corporal punishment must be inflicted; a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa must be banished from the country, his body having been branded.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Theft, 41, 42).тАФтАШOn no account shall the King kill a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, though convicted of all possible crimes. He may be banished. The King shall confiscate his entire wealth or leave him a fourth part for himself.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (27.11, 12).тАФтАШA Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, though a mortal sinner, shall not suffer capital punishment; the King shall banish him and cause him to be branded and shaved; the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa who deserves capital punishment shall be compelled to pay one hundred Suvarс╣Зas; one deserving to have a limb cut off, half as much; and one deserving to have the thumb and index finger cut off, half of that.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 634).тАФтАШEven if he has committed heinous crimes, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa may be banished, branded, or made to undergo expiations; for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa should not be made to suffer bodily pain.тАЩ

H─Бr─лta (Do., p. 631).тАФтАШFor the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, there is no cutting off of limbs; the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa is always purified by penances and austerities.тАЩ

Yama (Do., p. 636).тАФтАШFor crimes committed by the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, the following punishments have been ordained: shaving of the head, banishment from the city, proclamation of his sin, parading on an ass, branding on the forehead.тАЩ

  • span style=“text-decoration-underline;">рдХреЗрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЖрд╣реБрдГ ред рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╕рдиреЗ рддреНрд╡реН рдЖрдзреАрдпрдорд╛рдирдВ рд╕рдзрдирдВ рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╕реНрдп рдзрдирджрдгреНрдбрдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрддрд┐ ред

рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреБ рд╕рдордЧреНрд░рдзрдирдВ289 рд╣реГрддрд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрд╡рдВ рдХреГрддреНрд╡рд╛ рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╕реНрдпрдд рдЗрддрд┐ рдордиреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ рее рео.рейреореж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШIn all crimes.тАЩтАФWhat is said here should not, on the strength of context, be taken as applying to тАШadulteryтАЩ only; it pertains to other crimes also.

тАШEvenтАЩтАФThis term means that even though the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa may have committed all the crimes simultaneously, he should never be made to suffer the death-penalty.

тАЬWhat then should be done to the criminal?тАЭ

The king shall тАШbanish himтАЩтАФsend him awayтАФтАШfrom the kingdomтАЩтАФout of his realm;тАФтАШwith all his propertyтАЩтАФalong with all his belongings;тАФтАШunhurtтАЩтАФin body.

тАЬIf the property even is not to be confiscated, what would be the punishment to the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa?тАЭ

Some people say that when the text distinctly says that the man is to be banished тАШwith his property,тАЩ it is clear that it forbids the imposition of fine. Others however explain the words тАШbanished with his propertyтАЩ to mean that he shall be banished after all his property has been confiscated.тАФ(380)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 681), to the effect that even though actual death has been prohibited as a penalty for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, yet there are other penalties which are equal to, and substitutes for, that penalty;тАФagain on p. 842, where it notes that the banishment here laid down is meant for cases other than the тАШmortal offences.тАЩ

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 682);тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.81), which remarks that corporeal punishment is never to be inflicted on the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa; this is the general law laid down here; and again on 3.267;тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 115);тАФand in Pr─Бya┼Ыcittaviveka. (p. 183), to the effect that for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa there is no death-penalty.

It has been said above (in 376) that in the case of approaching an unprotected Br─Бhmaс╣Зa woman, the Vai┼Ыya тАШshould be committed with five hundred and the Kс╣гatriya with one thousand.тАЩ So in the present case also the fine for the Vaisс╕еya would be five hundred.

The heavier punishment for the Kс╣гatriya is justified on the ground that being entrusted with the task of protecting the people, if he takes to offending against them, he incurs a great sin.тАФ(382)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.286);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 319), to the effect that between the Kс╣гatriya and the Vai┼Ыya, if one has recourse to the woman of the other caste, the penalty is a fine of 1,000 and 500 paс╣Зas respectively;тАФand in V─лramitrodya (Vyavah─Бra 156a).

тАШS─БhasraтАЩ is the same as тАШSahasra,тАЩ the affix тАШaс╣ЗтАЩ having the reflexive-force. Or тАШS─БhasraтАЩ may be explained as that which consists of a sahasra or thousand; the тАШaс╣ЗтАЩ affix having the force of the possessive.тАФ(383)

рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдп рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рджреНрдпрдЧреБрдкреНрддрд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдЧрдорди рдЙрднрдпреЛрд░реН рджрдгреНрдбрдГ ред рдЕрдиреНрддреНрдпрдЬрд╢реН рдЪрдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓рд╢реНрд╡рдкрдЪрд╛рджрд┐рдГ ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╕рд╣рд╕реНрд░рдореН ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдпрдВ рд╕рд╣рд╕реНрд░рдкреНрд░рдгрджрдгреНрдбрд╕рдВрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ ред рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдп рдЪрддреБрд░реНрд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╡рд░реНрдгреЗрд╖реБ рдЧреБрдкреНрддрд╛рдЧрдордиреЗ рд╕рд╣рд╕реНрд░рдореН ред рд╢реНрд░реЛрддреНрд░рд┐рдпрджрд╛рд░реЗрд╖реБ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд╛рд╕рдирд╛рдЩреНрдХрдиреЗ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд░ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд╛рд╕рд╛рдирдореН рдПрд╡ ред рд╢реНрд░реЛрддреНрд░рд┐рдпрдбрд╛рд░реЗрд╖реБ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдорд╣рддреНрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдПрд╡ рдХрд▓реНрдкреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЕрдЧреБрдкреНрддрд╛рдЧрдордиреЗ298 рдкрдЮреНрдЪрд╢рддрд╛рдирд┐ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд╛рд╕рдирд╛рдЩреНрдХрдиреЗ ред рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрдЧреБрдкреНрддрд╛рдкрд░рджрд╛рд░рд╛рд╡реНрдпрдкрджреЗрд╢реНрдпрд╛299 рднрд╡рддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рд╕рдВрд╕реНрдХрд╛рд░реЗ рд╕рддрд┐, рддрдерд╛рдкрд┐ рд╕реНрд╡реИрд░рд┐рдгреА рднрд░реНрддреГрд╕реНрд╡рддрд╛рдореН рдЕрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрд╛, рдЕрдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдиреНрддреЛ рдЧреБрдкреНрддрд╛рдЧрдордиреЗ рджрдгреНрдбреЛ рдмрд▓рд╛рддреН ред рд╕рдХрд╛рдорд╛рдЧрдордиреЗ рд╕рд╛рд╣рд╕реНрд░реЛ рджрдгреНрдбрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд╛рд╕рдирд╛рдЩреНрдХрдиреЗ рдЪ ред рдЧреБрдкреНрддрд╛рдЧрдордиреЗ “рд╡реИрд╢реНрдпрдВ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрд╢рддрдВ рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рддреН рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрдВ рд╕рд╣рд╕реНрд░рд┐рдгрд╛рдореН” (рдореНрдзреН рео.рейренрем) рдЗрддрд┐ рее рео.рейреорел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This is the punishment for the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa having intercourse with a Vai┼Ыya or a Kс╣гatriya woman.

тАШOf the lowest orderтАЩтАФi.e., the Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, the ┼Ъvapaca and so forth. In their case the fine shall be one thousand.

The law relating to the fine of thousand тАШpaс╣ЗasтАЩ is briefly as follows:тАФFor the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa approaching a protected woman of any of the four castes, the fine shall be one thousand; and in addition to this for having intercourse with the wife of a Vedic scholar there shall be both banishment and branding, while in other oases there shall be banishment only. We presume this to be the case with the wife of a Vedio Scholar on the ground that the expiatory rite prescribed in connection with such intercourse is of a serious character.

For intercourse with an unprotected woman, there shall be a fine of five hundred in addition to banishment and branding.

Though the unprotected woman may he spoken of as тАШanother manтАЩs wife,тАЩ on account of her having undergone the marriage-rites, yet, in reality, when she becomes loose in her character, she practically ceases to belong to her husband.

For the non-Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, there is death-penalty if he approaches by force a protected woman: for approaching a willing woman, he shall be fined one thousand, and also banishment and branding;тАФas laid down under 376 above.тАФ(385)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШAntyajastriyamтАЩтАФтАШCh─Бс╣Зс╕Н─Бla womanтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, Govindar─Бja, Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШwoman belonging to such castes as washermen, cobblers, actors, basket-makers, fishermen, M─Бdas and BhillasтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 394), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШKс╣гatriyavai┼ЫyeтАЩ is the dual form in the Accusative;тАФтАШantyajastr─лтАЩ, washerwoman and the like;тАФin view of what is said here the death-penalty laid down elsewhere for having recourse to the тАШantyajaтАЩ woman should be understood as meant for men other than Br─Бhmaс╣Зas;тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 1008);тАФand in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 108), which explains тАШantyajaтАЩ as тАШthe washerwoman, the cobbler, and so forth.тАЩ

That king in whose town there is no thief, no adulterer, no defamer, no criminal, no assaulter,тАФattains the regions of Indra.тАФ(386)

рдпрд╕реНрдп рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрдГ рдкреБрд░реЗ рджреЗрд╢реЗ рд░рд╛рд╖реНрдЯреНрд░реЗ рд╕реНрддреЗрдирд╢реН рдЪреМрд░реЛ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рд╕ рд╢рдХреНрд░рд╕реНрдпреЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд╕реНрдп рд▓реЛрдХрдВ рд╕реНрдерд╛рдирдВ рднрдЬрддреЗ рд╕реНрд╡рд░реНрдЧрдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрдиреЛрддрд┐ ред рдирд╛рдиреНрдпрд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдЧреЛ, рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдп рдпрд╛ рд╕реНрддреНрд░реА рднрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рд╡рд░реБрджреНрдзрд╛ рдкреБрдирд░реНрднреВрд░реН рд╡рд╛, рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдореН рдЕрднрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдпрд╛ рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд┐рдиреНрдпрд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред рджреБрд╖реНрдЯреНрд╡рд╛рдХреН рддреНрд░рд┐рд╡рд┐рдзрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдХреНрд░реЛрд╢рд╕реНрдп рдХрд░реНрддрд╛ ред рд╕рд╛рд╣рд╕рд┐рдХ рдЙрдХреНрддрдГ ред рджрдгреНрдбреЗрди рд╣рдиреНрддрд┐ рджрдгреНрдбрдкрд╛рд░реБрд╖реНрдпрдХреГрддреН ред рд╢рдХреНрд░рд▓реЛрдХрднрд╛рдЧреН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рддреНрд░рд╛рдиреБрд╖рдЩреНрдЧрдГ ред рд╕реНрддреЗрдирд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрд╕рдВрдЧреНрд░рд╣рд╢реЗрд╖реЛ300 рд╜рдпрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрдГ рее рео.рейреорем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

That king in whoso тАШtownтАЩтАФkingdomтАФthere is no thief, reaches the тАШregions of IndraтАЩтАФheaven.

тАШNo adultererтАЩтАФwho has no intercourse with a married woman, or to one married a second time. The mention of the тАШwomanтАЩ indicates that the prohibition applies to the case of all such women as are not oneтАЩs own wife, and are not related to him.

тАШDefamerтАЩтАФthe man who commits the three kinds of defamation.

тАШCriminalтАЩтАФalready described above.

тАШAssaulterтАЩтАФwho commits physical violence.

тАШAttains the regions of IndraтАЩтАФis to be construed with each of the phrases.

This verse constitutes a hortatory supplement to the injunctions regarding the punishing of thieves and others.тАФ(386)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, (p. 408), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШDuс╣гс╣нav─Бk,тАЩ defamer of people,тАФтАШdaс╣Зс╕Нaghna,тАЩ one who strikes people with a stick, i.e., an assaulter;тАФand in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 264).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 8.386-387)
**

Viс╣гс╣Зu (5.196).тАФтАШThe King in whose dominion there exists neither thief, nor adulterer, nor calumniator, nor robber, nor murderer, attains the world of Indra.тАЩ

Cf. The Upaniс╣гad text, where a king is represented as sayingтАФтАШIn my realm there is no thief, no miser, no drunkard, none who is not tending the Fires, nor any illiterate person, no female libertine,тАФwhence then can there be any male libertine.тАЩ

Yama (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 408).тАФтАШWicked persons, criminals, rogues, gamblers, oppressors,тАФthat King in whose realm these persons are not found becomes entitled to the realm of India.тАЩ

N─Бrada (18.7-8).тАФтАШWhenever wicked acts, opposed to the dictates of the sacred law, have been committed, the King, after having reflected upon the matter, shall himself inflict punishment upon those who deserve it. What is opposed to revealed and traditional law, or injurious to living beings, must not be practised by the King; wherever it is practised, he must check it.тАЩ

рд╕рд╛рдореНрд░рд╛рдЬреНрдпрдВ рдкрд░рдкреНрд░рд╛рдгрдпрд┐рддрд╛, рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рддрдиреНрддреНрд░реНрдпрдореН ред рд╕рдЬрд╛рддреНрдпреЗрд╖реБ ред рд╕рдорд╛рдирд╕реНрдкрд░реНрджреНрдзрд┐рдиреЛ301 рд░рд╛рдЬрд╛рдирдГ рд╕рдЬрд╛рддреНрдпрд╛ рдЕрднрд┐рдкреНрд░реЗрддрд╛рдГ ред рддреЗрд╖реБ рдореВрд░реНрджреНрдзрдиреНрдпреН рдЕрдзрд┐рддрд┐рд╖реНрдарддрд┐, рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдХрд░рд╛рдГ рд╕рдВрдмрд╡рдиреНрддреАрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердГ ред рд▓реЛрдХреЗ рдЪ рдпрд╢рд╕реНрдХрд░ рдХреАрд░реНрддрд┐рдореН рдЙрддреНрдкрд╛рджрдпрдиреНрддрд┐302 ред рдЙрднрдпрддреНрд░рд╛рдкрд┐ рдирд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣ рдПрд╡ рдХрд░реНрддрд╛ рд╣реЗрддреБрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН ред рдЬрдирдорд╛рд░рдХреЛ рд╜рдпрдВ рдХреНрд░реЛрдзрди рдЗрддрд┐336 рд╡рджрдиреНрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рддреБ рд╕реНрддреБрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ рее рео.рейреорен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШParamount sovereignty,тАЩтАФlordship over others, independence.

тАШAmong his peers.тАЩтАФ the term тАШpeersтАЩ stands for such kings as are his rivals. The king in question rises to lordship over all those; i.e., they become subservient to him and obey bis wishes.

тАШFame in the worldтАЩтАФalso is brought about.

In both cases it is the тАШsuppressionтАЩ that brings about the said result.

The meaning is that people continue to eulogise the king, even though they say that тАШhe is a very cruel chastiser of the people.тАЩтАФ(387)

  • рдпрд╛рдЬрдирдХрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдПрд╖ рдПрд╡ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдГ ред рддреИрд░реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рддреЗ рдпреЛрдЬрдиреАрдпрд╛рдГ ред рдЛрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрдВ рдХреГрддрд╛рд░реНрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдпрдВ рддрддреНрдХреБрд▓реАрдирдВ рд╡рд╛рдиреНрдпрдВ рдпреЛ рди рд╡реГрдгреАрдд рдпрд┐рдпрдХреНрд╖реБрдГ, рдЕрдкрд┐ рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреНрдпрдВ рдпрд╛рдЬрдХрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдердпреЗрддреН ред рд╢рдХреНрддрдВ рдХрд░реНрдордгрд┐ рдпрдЬреНрдЮреЗ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЧрдЬреНрдЮрдореН рдЕрджреБрд╖реНрдЯрдореН рдЕрднрд┐рд╢рдВрд╕рдирд╛рдЩреНрдЧрд╡реИрдХрд▓реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рд░реН рджреЛрд╖реИрд░реН рдЕрдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН ред рдПрд╡рдореН рдИрджреГрд╢ рдПрд╡рд░реНрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЧреН рдЕрд░реНрдереНрдпрдорд╛рдиреЛ рдпрджрд┐ рдирд╛рдЩреНрдЧреАрдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рджреН рдпрд╛рдЬрдХрддреНрд╡рдореН рдЕрджреБрд╖реНрдЯрдореН рдПрднрд┐рд░реН рдПрд╡ рджреЛрд╖реИрд░реН рдЕрдирд╛рдХреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрдВ рдпрд╛рдЬреНрдпрдВ рд╢рдХреНрддрдВ рд╡рд┐рджреНрд╡рддреНрддрдпрд╛ рдЪ ред рддрд╛рджреГрд╢реЗ рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧреЗ рддрдпреЛрдГ рд╢рддрдВ рджрдгреНрдбрдГ ред рдЛрддреНрд╡рд┐рдХреН рд╢рддрдВ рджрд╛рдкреНрдпреЛ рдпрд╛рдЬреНрдпрдВ рддреНрдпрдЬрдиреН, рдпрд╛рдЬреНрдп рдЛрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрдореН ред

рди рдХреЗрд╡рд▓рдореН рдЕрдпрдореН рдЛрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЧреНрдпрд╛рдЬрдХрдзрд░реНрдордГ, рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдЪрд╛рд░реНрдпрдпреЛрд░реН рдЕрдкрд┐ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪ рдЧреМрддрдордГ- “рдЕрдерд╛рдпрд╛рдЬрдХрд╛рд╡реН306 рдЛрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЧрд╛рдЪрд╛рд░реНрдпреМ рдкрддрдиреАрдпрд╕реЗрд╡рд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдЪ рд╣реЗрдпреМ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд░ рд╣рд╛рдирд╛рддреН рдкрддрддрд┐” (рдЧреНрдзреН реирез.резреитАУрезрей) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рджрд╛рддреГрд╕рдВрдкреНрд░рджрд╛рдирдпреЛрд░реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣реЗ рдХреЗрдЪрд┐рджреН рдзрд░реНрдордореН рдЗрдордореН рдЗрдЪреНрдЫрдиреНрддрд┐ рее рео.рейреорео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШOfficiating priestтАЩтАФa person who performs the several acts in connection with тАШsacrificial performancesтАЩ; e.g., the с╣Ъtvik, the Hotс╣Ы, the Udg─Бtс╣Ы and so forth.

Though the name тАШofficiating priestтАЩ becomes applicable to the man only after his appointment, and continues so till the completion of the rites, yet the law that is laid down here pertains to the forsaking done before the actual appointment, and not to that during the performance of the rites that have commenced. And the titles are applied on the ground of past events; that is to say, it is only one who has had previous experience; as a priest who has the chance of being chosen again. In fact the title is applied, not only on the basis of previous experience, but also upon hereditary qualifications; as says N─БradaтАФтАШthe man employed previously is self-chosenтАЩ; and further, this applies not only to the experience of a single generation, but to the family-traditions of several generations; as has been described in detail in the Mah─Бbh─Бrata in the sections dealing with Saс╣Гvarta and Marutta.

The upshot thus is that those persons should be chosen as officiating priests who belong to the same family members whereof have been chosen in the past by the forefathers of the selector.

This same is applicable to the case of the тАШsacrificesтАЩ also; the priests also should hare recourse to the same sacrifices with whose forefathers their forefathers may hare had dealings in the past.

тАШOfficiating priestтАЩтАФthe man who has performed the priestly duties, or one who belongs to the family of such a person.

If a man going to perform a sacrifice does not appoint such a priest, but ask some one else.

тАШCapable of doing the workтАЩтАФof sacrificing; i.e., conversant with the entire procedure.

тАШFree from disqualificationsтАЩтАФi.e., not haring any such defect as a defective limb, or being accused of a serious crime and so forth.

If such a qualified priest, on being requested to officiate, refuses to do so, and does not accept the priesthood offered;тАФwhen the sacrificer is free from the said disqualifications and is fully learned.

In the case of both these forsakings, there shall be a fine of one hundred. If the priest forsakes the sacrificer he should be made to pay a hundred, and so also the sacrifices if he forsakes the priest.

This rule is applicable, not only to the case of the sacrificer and the officiating priest, but also to that of the Preceptor and the Pupil. As says Gautama (21.12-13)тАФтАШThe Priest and the Preceptor are to be forsaken only if they are deficient in learning, or happen to serve an outcast; by forsaking them otherwise one becomes an outcast.тАЩ

Some people hold that this law is applicable also to the case of the giver and the recipient.тАФ(388)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 122), which adds that whether the fine is to be 200 or 100 is to be determined by the offence being intentional or unintentional, and also by the richness or poverty of the offender.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 837), which adds that this rule applies to such priests as are hereditary, or have been appointed by the man himself;тАФin Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (91a);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 120a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Neither the mother, nor the father, nor the wife, nor the son deserve to be forsaken; he who forsakes these, unless they are outcasts, should be fined six hundred by the king.тАФ(389)

рдорд╛рддрд╛ рди рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧрдореН рдЕрд░реНрд╣рддрд┐ ред рди рддреНрдпрд╛рдЬреНрдпрд╛ ред рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рдЧреГрд╣рд╛рдиреН рдирд┐рд╖реНрдХрд╛рд╕рдирд╛рдВ рдорд╛рддреГрд╡реГрддреНрддреЗрдГ рд╕реНрдЦрд▓рд┐рддрд╛рдпрд╛рдГ,307 рдЙрдкрдХрд╛рд░рд╕реНрдпреЛрдкрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдпрд╛рдореН рдЙрджрд┐рддрд╛рдпрд╛рдореН рдЕрдХрд╛рд░рдгреЗ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпреЗрдпрдореН ред рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд╕рд╛рд╣рдЪрд░реНрдпрд╛рддреН308 рд╕реНрддреНрд░реА рднрд╛рд░реНрдпреИрд╡рд╛рднрд┐рдкреНрд░реЗрддрд╛ ред рдЕрдкрддрд┐рддрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдПрд╖рд╛рдВ рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧреЛ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ ред рдорд╛рддреБрд╕реН рддреБ “рди рдорд╛рддрд╛ рдкреБрддреНрд░рдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐ рдкрддрддреАрддреНрдпреН рдПрдХреЗ” рдЗрддрд┐ рд╢рд╛рддрд╛рддрдкрдГ ред рднрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдпрд╛рд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдкрд┐ рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧрдГ рдЕрд╕рдВрднреЛрдЧреЛ309 рдЧреГрд╣рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдирд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред рднрдХреНрддрд╡рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рджрд┐рджрд╛рдирдВ рддреБ рди рдирд┐рд╖рд┐рдзреНрдпрддреЗ ред “рдпреЛрд╖рд┐рддреНрд╕реБ рдкрддрд┐рддрд╛рд╕реНрд╡реН рдЕрдкрд┐ ред рд╡рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрдирдкрд╛рдирдВ310 рджреЗрдпрдВ рдЪ рд╡рд╕реЗрдпреБрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рдЧреГрд╣рд╛рдиреНрддрд┐рдХреЗ” (рдореНрдзреН резрез.резреорен) рдЗрддрд┐ рдкрдареНрдпрддреЗ рее рео.рейреореп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The mother does not deserve to be forsaken,тАФshould net be cast off. тАШForsakingтАЩ consists in turning her out of the house, if she has failed in her maternal duties; i.e., if she fails to do what she ought to do in return for what she receives at the bands of her son.

The same explanation applies to the case of the father and the rest also.

The term тАШstr─лтАЩ (woman) stands for the wife, as is clear from the fact that the text mentions only relatives.

These should not be forsaken, unless they are outcasts. As regards the mother, ┼Ъ─Бt─Бtapa has declared that тАШto the son the mother never becomes an outcast.тАЩ

The тАШforsakingтАЩ of the outcast, wife consists in giving up all intercourse with her and in forbidding her to do household work; but the giving of food and clothing is not forbidden; as it is declared thatтАФтАШfood and clothing should be given to even outcast wives, and these should live near the house.тАЩтАФ(389)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 357), which notes that тАШty─Бga,тАЩ тАШabandonment,тАЩ here means тАШnot according such treatment to them as has been prescribed in the scripturesтАЩ;тАФand that тАШstr─лтАЩ here stands for the wife.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 823), which remarks that this rule refers to the abandoning of all the four collectively;тАФand in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (p. 154).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (5.163).тАФтАШA husband forsaking a blameless wife shall be punished as a thief.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.237).тАФтАШBetween father and son, brother and sister, husband and wife, teacher and disciple,тАФif one forsakes the other, unless he or she has become an outcast, he shall be fined one hundred.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita (Apar─Бrka, p. 823).тАФтАШThe father and the mother should never be forsaken; indeed no Sapiс╣Зс╕Нas possessing good qualities should be forsaken; if one forsakes these arbitrarily, unless they have become outcasts, he should he fined 200. Nor should one misbehave towards the father, mother, or teacher; one who misbehaves towards them shall have his limb cut off.тАЩ

For twice-born men disputing among themselves regarding any point relating to the orders, the king, desirous of his own welfare, shall not determine the law.тАФ(390)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

311рд╡рд╛рдирдкреНрд░рд╕реНрдерд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдореН рдЕрд░рдгреНрдпрд╛рд╢реНрд░рдорд╡рд╛рд╕рд┐рдирд╛рдореН рдЖрд╢реНрд░рдореЗрд╖реБ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдВ рдзрд░реНрдордВ рд╕рдВрдХрдЯрд░реВрдкрдореН тАФ “рдЕрдпрдВ рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рд░реНрдердГ”, “рдирд╛рдпрдореН” тАФ рдЗрддрд┐ рдЗрддрд░реЗрддрд░рдВ рд╡рд┐рд╡рджрдорд╛рдирд╛рдирд╛рдВ312 рди рдзрд░реНрдорд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛рдВ рд╕рд╣рд╕рд╛ рд╡рд┐рдмреНрд░реВрдпрд╛рддреН рдкреНрд░рднреБрддрдпрд╛ рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЗрд╡ рди рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдХрдердВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐ ред рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдорд╛рдгреЗрди рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд░реЗрдг ред рдПрд╡рдореН рдЖрддреНрдордиреЗ рд╣рд┐рддрдВ рдХреГрддрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрдпрд╛рдЧреЛ рди рднрд╡рддреАрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рдЧреГрд╣рд╕реНрдерд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЪрд╛рд╢реНрд░рдорд┐рддреНрд╡реЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдпрдереЛрдХреНрдд рдПрд╡ рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд░рдГ ред рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдВ рдзрдорд╕рдВрд╢рдпрд╛рддреНрдордХрд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рджрдкрджрдореН ред рдЖрд╢реНрд░рдордЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╛рдЪреН рдЪ рд╡рд┐рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдпрддрд╛ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рдпрддреЗ рее рео.рейрепреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In regard to the тАШdutiesтАЩ of the various orders of the Hermit dwelling in the forests, several disputes arise as to this and not that being the sense of the scriptures.

When these men happen to dispute among themselves, the king shall not, in a hurry, lay down the law; i.e., he should not, in the exercise of his sovereign power, determine what the law on the point is. What he should do and how is going to be explained later on.

By acting in this manner, the king accomplishes his own welfare; i.e., he does not relinquish the injunctions of the scriptures.

In the case of householders, even though they also belong to an тАШorder,тАЩтАФyet, the method of laying down the law should be the same as laid down before (and not as declared in the present text, which pertains to the Hermit and the Recluse only).

тАШPointsтАЩтАФi.e., doubtful questions regarding the duties; that this refers to this particular matter of duties is indicated by the mention of the тАШorders.тАЩтАФ(390)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШ─А┼Ыrameс╣гuтАЩтАФтАШThe hermitages of V─Бnaprasthas and other hermits living in the forestтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШthe HouseholderтАЩs and other life-stagesтАЩ (Kull┼лka).

This verse is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 4);тАФin V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 10a), which explains тАШ─Б┼Ыrameс╣гu k─БryeтАЩ as тАШbusiness arising out of the life-stagesтАЩ;тАФand in Kс╣Ыtyakalpataru (10a), which explains тАШ─Б┼Ыrameс╣гuтАЩ as тАШin the matter of the life-stagesтАЩ,тАФand тАШna vibr┼лy─Бt,тАЩ as тАШshould not apportion victory and defeat.тАЩ

313рдпрдерд╛ рддрддреН рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдВ рддрдереЗрджрд╛рдиреАрдореН рдЖрд╣ ред рдпреЛ рдпрд╛рджреГрд╢реА рдкреВрдЬрд╛рдореН рдЕрд░реНрд╣рддрд┐ рдЧреБрдирд╛рдиреБрд░реВрдкреЗрдг рддрдВ рддрдереИрд╡реНрдЖрднреНрдпрд░реНрдЪреНрдп рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгреИрд░реН рдордиреНрддреНрд░рд┐рдкреБрд░реЛрд╣рд┐рддрд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рдГ ред рдЕрд░реНрдЪрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рд╕рд╛рд╣рд┐рддреНрдпрдВ314 рдзрд░реНрдордкреНрд░рд╡рдЪрдиреЗ рд╡рд╛ ред рддрджрд╛ рдЪ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рдГ рд╕рддреНрдпрд╛ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрд╛рдГ ред рддреИрдГ рд╕рд╣ рд╕реНрд╡рдзрд░реНрдордВ315** **рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпреНрдпрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдердВ рдмреЛрдзрдпреЗрддреН ред рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзреЗ рдорд╣рддреНрддреНрд╡реЗ рд╕рднреНрдпреЗрднреНрдп рдЙрдкрджреЗрд╢рдГ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдзрд╛рдиреНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдердГ ред рддрд╛рдиреН рдкреБрд░рд╕реНрдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рддрдерд╛ рд╣рд┐ ред рди рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрдГ рдХреНрд░реБрдзреНрдпрдиреНрддрд┐ рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░реЗрдг ред рдкреНрд░реАрддрд┐рд╕реНрддреБрддрд┐рд╡рдЪрдиреИрдГ рдкреНрд░рдердордВ рдкреНрд░рд╢рдордпреНрдп рд╡реНрдпрдкрдиреАрддрдХреНрд░реЛрдзрд╛рдиреН316 рдХреГрддреНрд╡рд╛ рддрддреЛ рдмреНрд░реВрдпрд╛рддреН рее рео.рейрепрез рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

What the king should do under the circumstances is now explained.

Having received each of the men with such honour as he deserves, by reason of his qualifications,тАФhe should, тАШwith the assiatance of Br─Бhmaс╣ЗasтАЩтАФhis ministers and priests,тАФthis тАШassistanceтАЩ being rendered in the reception, or in the explaining of duties. It is only in the latter that the true character of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa becomes revealed.

With the assistance of these Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, he shall explain to them their duty.

The assistance of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зas having been insisted upon, the declaration that the king shall explain the duties is meant to indicate the predominance of the king, who is to associate the Br─Бhmaс╣Зas with himself. And this predominance is due to the fact that kings never lose their temper.

The king should explain the duties to them after having at first тАШpacified themтАЩтАФi.e., having soothed their temperтАФтАШwith soothing wordsтАЩтАФaffectionate and complimentary words.тАФ(391)

тАШVe┼ЫaтАЩ is that where people live, a dwelling-house; the house that is in the front of oneтАЩs house is тАШprative┼ЫaтАЩ; and he who lives in that is the тАШprative┼Ыya,тАЩ тАШfrontal neighbourтАЩ If we read тАШpr─Бtive┼Ыya,тАЩ we would add the reflexive affix тАШaс╣З.тАЩ Similarly тАШanuve┼Ыya тАШis one dwelling at the back of oneтАЩs house.тАЩ

Persons occupying houses on the two sides also are called тАШneighboursтАЩ; hence the two terras тАШprative┼ЫyaтАЩ and тАШanuve┼ЫyaтАЩ may be taken as standing for persons occupying houses next, and on both sides, to oneтАЩs own house.

If the man does not entertain these two, after having invited them to the тАШfestivalтАЩ in his house, in the shape of marriage and the like,тАФтАШat which twenty other twice-born persons are invited,тАЩтАФthen he should be made to pay a fine of one тАШm─Бс╣гa.тАЩ That this тАШm─Бс╣гaтАЩ is to be of gold is indicated by its being distinctly specified in another place.

тАШWorthyтАЩ;тАФif the frontal and back neighbours are both worthy,тАФi.e., neither inimical, nor absolutely unqualified.тАФ(392)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШPrative┼Ыya-anuve┼ЫyaтАЩтАФтАШNeighbour living in frontтАФneighbour living at the backтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШthe next neighbour and the neighbour next to himтАЩ (Kull┼лka, N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and R─Бghv─Бnanda).

тАШM─Бс╣гakamтАЩтАФтАШOf goldтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШof silverтАЩ (Kull┼лka).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 358), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШKaly─Бс╣Зe viс╣Г┼Ыatidvije,тАЩ тАШat which twenty Br─Бhmaс╣Зas are entertainedтАЩ;тАФat such a festival if one does not feed his front neighbour and back neighbour,тАФboth of whom are perfectly fit persons for being entertained,тАФhe should be fined one тАШM─Бс╣гaтАЩ which should be understood to be of silver, in view of the fact that Manu in the next verse prescribes the golden тАШm─Бс╣гaтАЩ as the fine for the offence of not feeding the neighbours at a rich entertainment.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This text refers to persons who are not neighbours. The rule here laid down pertains to fellow-students.

The Vedic scholar who does not entertain a duly qualified Vedic scholar at such тАШauspicious ritesтАЩтАФrites performed by virtue of the possession of wealth; such for instance as the feeding of many men and so forth; or тАШrichтАЩ may be taken as an epithet of the тАШritesтАЩ; the meaning in which case would be the rites, such as marriages and the like, which are performed on a lavish scale; where more than twenty men are fed;тАФif at such times, the Vedic scholar does not feed a fellow-scholar, ho should be made to offer twice the quantity of the food that would be offered at the rich rites; and one тАШm─БsaтАЩ of gold shall be paid to the king as fine.тАФ(393)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШ┼ЪrotriyamтАЩтАФтАШWho is not a neighbourтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШa neighbourтАЩ (Govindar─Бja, and Kull┼лka);тАФтАШa resident of the same villageтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 359), which adds the explanation that the quantity of food that he might have eaten should be made to be given to the uninvited man.

тАШAn old man of seventyтАЩ;тАФthe instrumental ending in тАШsaptaty─БтАЩ is on the analogy of such expressions as тАШprakс╣Ыty─Б vir┼лpuс╕е.тАЩ The man who has passed seventy years of age is so called.

One who тАШattends uponтАЩтАФserves, either with personal attendance, or as a craftsman.

These men should not be made to pay any taxes,тАФsnoh as working for the king for one day in the month, as laid down for craftsman under 7. 138;тАФby a king, even when his treasury has become depleted. This is what is meant by the phrase тАШby any oneтАЩтАФ (394)

рд╕рдВрдкреВрдЬрдирдореН рдЕрдиреБрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ, рдЕрдиреЗрдХрд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдзрд╛рддреВрдирд╛рдореН ред рди рд╣рд┐ рдмрд╛рд▓рд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╛ рдкреВрдЬреЛрдкрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╢реНрд░реЛрддреНрд░рд┐рдпреЛ рд╜рддреНрд░ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордг рдПрд╡реЗрддрд┐ рд╕реНрдорд░рдиреНрддрд┐ ред рдЖрд░реНрддрдГ рдкреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╡рд┐рдпреЛрдЧрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ ред рдЕрдХрд┐рдВрдЪрдиреЛ рджреБрд░реНрдЧрддрдГ ред рдорд╣рд╛рдХреБрд▓реАрдирдГ ред рдЦреНрдпрд╛рддрд┐рдзрдирд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рд╢реМрд░реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдЧреБрдгреЗ рдХреБрд▓реЗ рдЬрд╛рддреЛ рдорд╣рд╛рдХреБрд▓реАрдирдГ ред рдЖрд░реНрдп рдЛрдЬреБрдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрд┐рд░реН рдЕрд╡рдХреНрд░рдГ ред рдПрддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рджрд╛рдирдорд╛рдирд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рд░реН рдЕрдиреБрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред

рдХреЗрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрдХрд┐рдВрдЪрдирдВ рдорд╣рд╛рдХреБрд▓реАрдирд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгрдВ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЪрдХреНрд╖рддреЗ рее рео.рейрепрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШRespectingтАЩ here stands for kindly treatment; verbal roots having several meanings. No other kind of тАШrespectтАЩ would be possible in the case of the infant and several others. The тАШVedic scholarтАЩ has been held here to mean the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa scholar only.

тАШDistressed,тАЩтАФby separation from his loved ones or such other causes.

тАШIndigentтАЩтАФ in reduced circumstances.

тАШThe man of high familyтАЩтАФone who is born in a family endowed with fame, wealth, learning, bravery and such other qualities.

тАШGentlemanтАЩтАФone who is honest and upright of nature.

All these should be received with kind treatment, in the shape of gifts and honours.

Some people explain the term тАШindigentтАЩ as qualifying тАШthe man of high familyтАЩтАФ (395)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (R─Бjan─лti, p. 252), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШSamp┼лjayet,тАЩ honour them with presents; this implies that he should not take anything from them.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

N─Бrada (18.34-35).тАФтАШLet a king be constantly intent on showing honour to the Br─Бhmaс╣Зas; a field furnished with Br─Бhmaс╣Зas is the source of prosperity of the world. A Br─Бhmaс╣Зa may command respect and a distinguished seat at the KingтАЩs court. In the morning, the King shall show his face to, and salute, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa first of all.тАЩ

The washerman shall wash (clothes) gently on a smooth board of cotton-tree wood; he shall not carry clothes in other clothes; nor shall he allow them to be worn.тАФ(396)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╢рд╛рд▓реНрдорд▓реА рдирд╛рдо рд╡реГрдХреНрд╖рд╕реН рддрджреНрд╡рд┐рдХрд╛рд░реЗ рдлрд▓рдХреЗ ред рд╕ рд╣рд┐ рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддреНрдпреИрд╡ рд╢рд▓реНрдХреНрд╖реНрдгреЛ328 рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рди рдЪ рд╡рд╛рд╕рд╕реЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдкрд╛рддреИрд░реН рдЕрд╡рдпрд╡рд╛ рдЕрд╕реНрдп рдЪреНрдпрд╡рдиреНрддреЗ ред рддреЗ рд╣рд┐ рдЪреНрдпреБрддрд╛ рд╡рд╛рд╕рдГ рдкрд╛рдЯрдпреЗрдпреБрдГ ред рди рдЪрд╛рдпрдВ рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рдирд┐рдпрдореЛ рд╜рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдп329 ред рддреЗрдирд╛рдиреНрдпрджреН577 рдЕрдкрд┐ рдпрддреН рдХрд╛рд╖реНрдардореН рдПрд╡рдВрд╕реНрд╡рднрд╛рд╡рдВ рддрддреНрдлрд▓рдХреЗ рди рджреЛрд╖рдГ ред рд╢реНрд▓рдХреНрд╖реНрдгреЗ рд╜рдкрд░реБрд╖реЗ рдЪ ред рд╡рд╛рд╕рд╛рдВрд╕реНрдпреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрджреАрдпрд╛рдиреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрджреАрдпреИрд░реН рд╡рд╛рд╕реЛрднрд┐рд░реН рди рдирд┐рд░реНрд╣рд░реЗрддреН ред рдмрджреНрдзреНрд╡реЛрдкрд░рд┐рд╡реЗрд╖реНрдЯреНрдп рддреАрд░реНрдереЗ рдкреНрд░рдХреНрд╖рд╛рд▓рдпрд┐рддреБрдВ рди рдирдпреЗрддреН ред рдмрдиреНрдзрдирд╛рджреН рд╡рд╛рд╕рд╕рд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рдирд╛рд╢реЛ рдорд╛ рднреВрддреН ред рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрдВ рд╣рд┐ рддрд╛рдирд┐ рдкреАрдбрд┐рддрд╛рдирд┐ рднрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ ред рди рдЪ рд╡рд╛рд╕рдпреЗрддреН ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрджреАрдпрд╛рдирд┐ рд╡рд╛рд╕рд╛рдВрд╕реНрдпреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдореИ рди рдкреНрд░рдпрдЪреНрдЫреЗрддреН,338 рдореВрд▓реНрдпреЗрди339 рд╡рд╕рдирд╛рд░реНрдердВ рди рджрджреНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдПрддрджреН рдзрд┐ рд╡рд╛рд╕рдирдореН- рд╡рд╕реНрддреЗ рд╜рдкрд░рдГ, рддрдВ рд░рдЬрдХреЛ рд╡рд╛рд╕рдпрддрд┐ ред рдЕрд╢реНрд░реБрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рджрдгреНрдбрд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрдорд╛рд╖рдХрдпреЛрдЬрдирд╛ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛ рее рео.рейрепрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

the тАШcotton treeтАЩ is a kind of tree; the board should be made out of this tree; because its wood is naturally soft and тАШsmooth,тАЩ so th.it when the clothes are beaten upon it, their component parts do not become torn.

тАШGentlyтАЩтАФso that the clothes being beaten do not become torn.

The injunction regarding the particular wood is not with a view to any transcendental result; hence there would be nothing wrong in using any other wood, if it satisfied the said conditions.

тАШSmoothтАЩтАФnot rough.

тАШClothesтАЩтАФbelonging to one man,тАФhe shall not тАШcarryтАЩтАФ tie up and carry to the washing placeтАФтАШin other clothesтАЩтАФbelonging to another person; so that the clothes may not be torn by the tying, in which they undergo a great strain.

тАШNor shall he allow them to be wornтАЩ;тАФhe shall not give over, for a consideration, to one man the clothes belonging to another, for wearing. This is what is meant by тАШallowing to wearтАЩ; the other man does the wearing, and it is the washerman that allows him to do it.

Since no penalty has been laid down in this connoction, we have to take it as consisting of the тАШm─Бс╣гa of goldтАЩ which has been laid down before.тАФ(396)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 823), which adds the following notes:тАФThe washerman shall not carry clothes tying them in cloth;тАФтАШnav─Бsayet,тАЩ nor should he keep them in his house, or he should not allow them to be used by others on receiving cash-hire from them.

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.238), which adds the following explanation:тАФThe washerman shall wash clothes by rinsing them on a plank of cotton-wood, and not on stone; he shall not mix them up, i.e., shall not exchange them among the diverse owners, says B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л,тАФnor shall he keep them in his house;тАФif he does any of these things, he should be punished.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 313), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШ┼Ъ─Бlmale,тАЩ made of cotton-wood,тАФтАШ┼Ыlakс╣гс╣Зe,тАЩ soft,тАФтАШnirс╣Зijy─Бt,тАЩ should wash,тАФтАШnejakaс╕е,тАЩ washerman,тАФтАШnacha v─Бs─Бс╣Гsi v─Бsobhirnirharet,тАЩ he should not carry clothes tied up in other clothes, to the washing-place,тАФтАШna ca v─Бsayet,тАЩ he should not let the clothes of one person be worn by another. The meaning is that if he does not act up to these rules, he becomes liable to punishment.

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 311), as laying down rules for washermen.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.238).тАФтАШIf the washerman wears the clothes belonging to others, he should he made to pay 3 Paс╣Зas; and 10 Paс╣Зas, if he sells or lets or pledges or lends them.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ
